as deputy. Hold up your right hand;
so, we'll call you sworn. Casey, you're
witness. Remember: If you get him the
California side of the line you've no
Moses and Mrs. Aintree
jurisdiction. In that case plug him and do

him this side, plug him, and there won't be
no argument. Have you got a good gun?
Take mine."
"This one's an old friend."
"Now remember. He may go slow now,

guess he saw our lights as we went over.
I hate to lose that good car. Listen: Five
miles up the road on the right-hand side

Norcross. If his phone's working, call up
every police station within a radius of
thirty miles, and get a crowd started on the

Maybe old Norcross '11 lend you a rig; but
he's moody; you'll be taking a chance if you

"I'll take another chance or two," I said.
"Good boy. Now there's this: Bhopal
Gosh may have his plans all laid for crossing
Lake Tahoe by boat."
"How big's the lake?" I asked.
"Thirty miles by sixteen, and more than
a mile deep where they've found bottom---

and never gives up its dead. If he's got a

and get around the lake to head him off.
You'll be able to see his boat all the way
across in this moonlight. Stop wherever
there's a phone and keep the gangs wised
up. Whatever you do don't follow him
alone across the water. He'll spill you and
you won't stand a chance. Besides, a bit

"How'll I find his house?"
"Can't mistake it. Follow this road
about nine miles as straight as she'll take
you. The side-tracks to the right all go to

lead the simple life in Summertime. You
keep straight on. His house is on the left,
facing the lake. There's a garage in line
with it big enough to hold four cars, and
the house is a brown shingle affair with a
-of a big roof pitched steep like a hill-
side. It stands by a clump of sugar-
pines, and whether he's got servants, or
any one to help him put up a fight I can't

watch the place and wait for help to reach

"Ye owld amachoor daytective! I'll
bet ye the drinks ye'll never get him!"
murmured Casey by way of farewell.

really did have tire trouble and a

Either his engine was badly overheated, or

In ordinary circumstances I would have
reveled in that walk, instead of cursing
every bend in the road that only showed
another bend as soon as you rounded it--•
and that again another bend beyond.
Some six or seven thousand feet above
sea-level, the air was perfect and the
scenery as wild as any man could wish. I
even saw a bear lolloping across the road
in front of me, and hove a rock at him out of
sheer envy, because he might enjoy the
solitude, whereas I must hurry on.
I made what I took to be Norcross' shack
well within the hour, but there was nobody
home. I made noise enough to wake any-
one a mile away, and tried to break the
door to get to the phone, but failed. How-

shed, and a spider-wheel rig that would
just about hold together as long as the

and drove away at a slow trot--the best
that nag could offer. He had only three
gaits anyhow; the second was a walk, and
the third was to sit down on his rump be-
tween the shafts and think a while. So I
let him trot, five miles an hour, or maybe

And try how I would I could find no
telephone. ■ All the places except one that
I tried were unoccupied. In that place
there was a Chinaman, who grinned and

Adventure
So I drove, and it began to feel lonely
under those huge trees, with nothing to
disturb the silence except an occasional
wind-moan and the clop-clop-clop of that
disreputable horse.
As far as my experience goes it's untrue
that a fellow reviews his whole career in a
- moment of time when death looks him
straight in the face. But this I have found
true--that when you're going forward to
what you expect will be a crisis, all the
circumstances that led up to it review
themselves whether you will or not, until
you are sick at heart from recognizing
half-a-million mistakes you made and two
or three opportunities you overlooked.
After I left the Norcross shack I daresay I
thought of thirty better ways to bring
Bhopal Gosh to account.
Nevertheless, strangely enough, and un-
expectedly enough, I didn't experience the
slightest fear, until the old horse trotted
around one last turn between sepulchral
pines and cedars, and on my left hand, in a
clearing, loomed the house that must be
that of Bhopal Gosh, if the sheriff's de-
scription of it was correct.
Then fear struck me like a cold breath.
There were no lights visible. There seemed
to be nobody about. But I could hear an
engine purring in the darkness by the front-
door, and the horse threw up his head and
neighed.
CHAPTER XIII
"Lake Tahoe don't give up her dead."
T T OCCURRED to me to go at once and
put that car out of commission. I might
possibly need it for pursuit, but setting off
one possible contingency against another it
seemed wisest to dish the car. So I tied my
borrowed Rosinante to a tree, walked up
the drive, and tore out the wires leading
through the dashboard to the switch. That
was decidedly enough to delay Mr. Bhopal
Gosh if he had not gone already.
However, as it turned out I made a mis-
take. I could have caught him handily by
leaving that car purring away peacefully
with its lights full on. But the minute I
tore out that handful of wires the circular
glow of white light cast by the lamps on the
front of the house vanished simultaneously.
It didn't occur to me until then that Bhopal
Gosh would not have left the house in dark-
ness, with all that illumination on the outer
wall, unless there was something to be
gained by it.
It's not easy to puzzle out the other fel-
low's motives at a time when the least false
move is likely to lose you the game. A
crook thinks crookedly. If you've spent
your waking moments for thirty or forty
years endeavoring to think straight you're
out of harmony with a villain's reasoning.
All that I accomplished by extinguishing
the light was to give Bhopal Gosh notice
that someone was close on his trail. That
glare on the house wall had been visible
from the lake shore, a quarter of a mile
away, and I now saw somebody come carry-
ing a lantern from the lake toward the
house. He was coming in a hurry--didn't
notice that the lights had gone out until he
nearly reached the road, still well out of
pistol range, perhaps two hundred yards
from where I waited. Then he saw my gray
horse, for the moon had dispersed the
shadow in which I left him standing.
I tried to figure out what I would do if the
positions were reversed, but gave it up.
I didn't know why he was returning to the
house. I remembered one of Terence
Casey's sayings that "crooks, me boy,
always overlook something, for that's the
natur' of a crook. Ye catch 'em because
they blow their noses on a dead man's
handkerchief, or some such idiotic stunt as
that."
That didn't help much. Bhopal Gosh
wasn't blowing his nose. In fact, I couldn't
see him, I could only see the lantern.
I watched the lantern steadily for several
minutes, until it dawned on me that it was
hanging from a twig and its owner had gone
elsewhere.
The odds were now that he was hunting
me. As he knew the ground and I didn't
those odds were a hundred to one in his
favor. I elected to stay where I was for
the moment, between the car and the front
door, listening for a footfall that would give
me a hint of his whereabouts. I heard two
sounds--first, the pop from the exhaust of
a motor-boat engine down by the lake
shore. But he hadn't had time to reach the
boat. I decided that the boat was moored,
with its engine running, ready to get under
way the moment its owner should come.
The next sound came from the direction
of my rig. I heard the shafts fall to the
ground--a smart slap as somebody hit the
horse--and then the click of hooves as the
Moses and Mrs. Aintree
beast started off homeward at an easy trot.
It was like a game of Freeze-out--funny, if
I'd been in a mood to laugh. I had put out
of action a car that he possibly didn't want,
and had demobilized myself as far as possi-
ble pursuit went; he had discovered that
not more than two men were on his trail; for
that rig would have broken down under the
weight of more than two. And he had cut
off my retreat.
What puzzled me most was, why he didn't
make straight for the motor-boat. I heard
his heavy footstpes over to my right be-
hind a row of trees, and he was walking as if
he weighed a ton, breaking twigs and crash-
ing through the undergrowth like an ele-
phant at feeding-time. I elected not to
walk into that trap. Time was all in my
favor.
IF I had been sure that he hadn't
another car waiting at the rear of
the house I would have headed for
the boat at once and put that out of com-
mission; but it was possible he was calcu-
lating on my doing just that, and did have
a car in reserve; so I waited, not so much
reasoning really as acting from intuition and
habit developed in hunting days. - It was
that refusal to come out in the open and be
seen that forced his hand. He had to try to
unmask my batteries somehow, and took
a rather silly way of doing it.
He began to scream like a beast in agony,
pausing to wait for a reply and then scream-
ing louder. As that had no result he yelled
in English that he was caught by the leg
in a bear-trap. If it was true I was glad
to hear it; he might stay in the trap. I was
certainly not going to be such a fool as to go
and investigate; and what was more, he had
done me the favor of demonstrating that he
was all alone, for obviously any one within
hail would have gone to his assistance; but
nobody did go. He left off yelling after a
few minutes, as a man at all prone to yelling
would hardly do with his leg caught in the
iron jaws of a bear-trap. Those things hurt.
Continuing to puzzle away at the prob-
lem I decided that he had gone down to the
motor-boat to get the engine started, and
had then come back to the house for his
treasure. Perhaps there had been some
doubt in his mind whether he could start
the engine, and he had preferred to make
sure before committing himself to that
means of escape. If those heavy gold plates
were in the house yet it was hardly likely
that both he and they would escape me
before morning.
But he had grown suspiciously quiet
again, and I listened intently, wishing that
contact with cities and railroads hadn't
dulled my hunting ear. I could hear the
motor-boat popping away steadily, but not
one sound from Bhopal Gosh. The lantern,
swaying gently on its twig, still burned
brightly where he had left it.
His next move took me utterly by sur-
prise. The porch light was switched on sud-
denly from inside the house, and I stood
exposed between the door and the car at
pointblank pistol range. I ducked around
behind the car, astonished that I wasn't
fired at; and, from that. position, peering
under the top, I caught sight of his face
looking through a window to the right of the
front door. I pulled the wrong pistol from
my pocket--his that I had picked up in the
road beside the abandoned tire--took a
snap shot at him, and missed. But he didn't
shoot back. It dawned on me that I had his
only firearm! True to Terence Casey's dic-
tum, the arch-crook had overlooked one
simple, necessary point!
That settled it. I smashed in the win-
dow with the pistol-butt, and scrambled in,
cutting my hand, but as luck would have it
not badly enough to make it useless. The
door at the end of that room slammed in my
face, and I heard the key turn on the out-
side, but I took a heavy chair and swung it
ax-fashion, breaking the door down in less
than a minute. That let me through into
the hall. He had switched the light off, and
was doing something in a devil of a hurry,
for I could hear his heavy breathing not far
off. Then I caught the metallic hum of a
safe opening, and the rattle of the handle of
the inner, sheet-iron door as he fumbled
with it in the dark. By the sound I judged
he was at the end of the hall, so I fired the
same pistol I had used before to try and
catch sight of him by the flash--or hit him
if I happened to be lucky.
What I did see was the wall-button that
controlled the electric current. I heard
another door slam, and by the time I had
switched the light on Bhopal Gosh was
gone; but he had not removed the plunder,
although he did get away with the key to
the inner door of the safe.
The safe stood under the main stairway,
and was an inexpensive affair with a
6o
Adventure
combination lock on the outer door, which
he had left unfastened in his hurry. I dare
say I could have forced that inner door with-
out much trouble if given time, but it
seemed wiser in the circumstances to leave
the treasure in there and return when I had
reckoned with the man. He wasn't likely
to be doing nothing while I fooled with the
safe.
So I went back for another chair and
smashed the door on the right-hand side 01
the safe that he had disappeared through.
It was a good, heavy office chair with an
iron revolving screw in it and iron-braced
legs, so the door went down in short order;
but at that I wasn't in time. There was a
cellar below-stairs piled high with old, dry
cord-wood, and ms the door crashed out-
ward a stinging cloud of white smoke met
me with the crackling of blazing bark and
splinters.
I charged through, with the idea of catch-
ing him before he could' take advantage of
the smoke to give me the slip altogether.
I was holding his pistol in my right hand,
having shoved it in my hip pocket while I
used the chair for a battering-ram, making
two pistols in one pocket, and as I rushed
through I grabbed the first one that my
fingers closed on. Bhopal Gosh was waiting
for me just inside the door, and seized me
by both arms from behind.
IT NEEDED no expert in intuition
Vtg- to guess what his game was then.
------ He meant to hurl me down into the
blaze below, and return for the contents of
the safe. And it was a new experience to
discover myself almost helpless in the arms
of a stronger man. All up and down the
world I have only met three amateurs who
could beat me with their fists or on the mat,
and they had to work for their laurels. But
this fellow twisted the revolver out of my
right hand with the ease of a gorilla, and
flung it down the cellar stairs into the gal-
loping holocaust below us.
"Yah-ah-ah!" he laughed.
But it was an expensive little joke, for
as he let go my right hand to hurl the
weapon away I swung sharp round to face
him and crashed my fist into his mouth,
cutting it a second time on his magnificent
teeth, but giving him far the worst of the
exchange. However, he had me by the wrist
again before I could reach for my own re-
volver, and luckily--so swift he was1--before
he even guessed that that was my intention.
The heat was already terrific. Once or
twice when a draft caught them the
flames licked over the top of the cellar
stairs, and he started to force me backward
toward that hell, grinning in my face ma-
levolently as he stepped forward like a great
fat dancing-master--only it was muscle that
made him bulk so big. It was the first time
I ever felt really helpless in the grasp of a
stronger man,\tnd after the first strain that
warned me of his enormous power I wasted
no more energy on trying that issue with
him.
I relaxed my muscles suddenly. By the
light that roared behind me I could see the
triumphant malice in his face; but he was in
no hurry; he was enjoying the foretaste of
victory--grinning like a great ape. You
could see how he had been so easily mistaken
for Italian by men who were not suspicious
of an alias, yet his face grew more Mon-
golian as you examined it. And he took
care that I should examine it, thrusting it
close to mine in order to peer into my eyes.
"You feel the fire behind?" he sneered.
The brute wasn't even out of breath.
"You are going down into it backwards!
But we will wait just a minute or two and let
the flames take hold, because there is a door
leading from that cellar to the garden, and
you seem to have a gift for breaking doors!"
He thrust his great, dark face still closer
to mine, so that his enormous shoulders
rose higher than his neck. I guessed him at
fifty inches around the chest, with every
other detail in proportion, but he may have
been bigger than that.
"I am curious about you!" he went on.
"You are not of the police. Are you^one of
those poor fools who discovered a treasure
that they could not keep? You are too un-
wise for Providence--I suppose you would
call it Providence?--to leave it in your
hands! You would not know how to use it.
I do. I shall use it! I shall leave you
roasting here, and take it away with me!
You're not talkative! It's your last chance
to talk, you know, until you come into the
world reincarnated as a beetle or a rat!
You don't like the prospect of being burned
to death? It terrifies you? Too bad! You
would prefer the butt of Malmsey wine
selected by the Duke of Clarence?"
Even the least astute of us become one-
horse philosophers as we grow older. When
any man starts boasting in my face I take
Moses and Mrs. Aintree
courage. Boasting is the inevitable prelude
of disaster., I'm convinced of that, and an
ounce of conviction is worth a ton of any-
body's argument. I knew that minute that
he might hurl me down into the fire, but if
so he was coming with me, and I guessed I
could face those flames as well as he
could.
Maybe he read the determination in my
face. He started there and then to force
me backward, and I tried to throw him
with a trick of the heel. He saved him-
self from that, but lost his balance and I got
my left fist free, gaining a good two yards
away from the flames and sending my left
home three times, once into his wind, and
twice into the region of his jaw. He had to
let go my right wrist to protect himself, and
I got my right home into his left eye before
he closed.
Then, gripping like a bear, he began to
force me backward once more, lifting me
as my ribs cracked under his pressure. He
had me under the arms, which left both
fists free, and I rained blows on his mouth
and eyes that would have taken some of the
fight out of a Spanish bull. I guess I blinded
him for the moment. I could feel the sicken-
ing scorch of the flames behind me as the
floor-beams and door-posts caught; but
I caught him by the neck and swung clear,
and if I hadn't been in too much of a hurry
he would have gone down into the cellar
instead of me, for I drove for the region of
his ear with my right fist, and the blow
went wild.
Then I thought of my own revolver in my
right hip-pocket, and he thought of all out-
doors. The smoke and flame were blinding;
the back of my jacket was smoldering, and
I think his coat was too. At any rate, with
his eyes half-shut, and with the floor-beams
beginning to crack under our combined
weight, he lowered his head and charged me
like a bull. Instead of meeting him with my
knee, as I should have done, I stepped aside,
took a shot at him, and missed! Missed
him at fifteen inches! So much for smoke
in the face.
SWE 1 BOTH went out of the house
like rabbits running from a grass-
fire, he straight by way of that nod-
ding lantern for the motor-boat, and I after
him, with the flames behind us lighting up
all the windows now as they caught the
draft from the open front door. It was only
a matter of seconds before the whole house
was a raging furnace.
I was out of breath, for he had crushed my
ribs in badly, and on top of that I had swal-
lowed a lungful of acrid smoke. What was
worse, I am built rather for heavy work than
running races; and for a man of his prodig-
ious weight and strength he was fleet-
footed. But he ran with his hands to his
eyes. I had done him harm enough to
equalize the odds.
Moreover, he wasted energy. His short-
est course to the motor-boat was not by
way of the lantern. In order to take the
lantern en route he had to cover two sides
of a broad-based triangle, giving him at
least an extra hundred yards to run. Yet
he did that, and I took the shorter route to
cut him off, wondering what strange frenzy
possessed him and supposing that his eyes
might be so badly hurt that he was running
half-blindly for whatever he could see.
Yet he didn't pick up the lantern. He
paused there for half-a-second, tugging at
something else that shook the lantern to the
ground as it came loose from the tree, and
carried whatever it was away with him. He
was still in the lead by a dozen yards, and I
tried a shot as I ran, with no result except
apparently to increase his speed; and of
course I had to slow down for a second in
order to take aim, which gave him a few
more yards of advantage.
I had now four shots left, and no spare
cartridges. On the other hand, in spite of
the pace, I was beginning to feel better as
the smoke got pumped out of my lungs.
Moreover, the fire by now was enough to
alarm the countryside; they would turn out
to save the forest trees if nothing else, and it
was likely I would have help any minute.
Yet he was gaining on me--careering like a
hippopotamus for his own element, cover-
ing an ell to my yard as he crashed through
and over everything. I never saw any man
take such enormous strides as he did, and
all the way with his hands before his face, as
if I had done his eyes real damage.
He was easily fifty yards ahead when he
reached the water's edge and hesitated be-
fore jumping to the beach below. ' In that
uncertain moonlight, and with my hand no
doubt trembling from the run, it seemed
like a fool's chance to take another shot;
yet I took it--stopped dead, aimed care-
fully, and fired. I hit him. He dropped
something that was hanging from his arm,
Adventure
clapped his hand to his side, and toppled
sidewise over the bank.
I did that last fifty yards in record time--
my record at all events. I figured on jump-
ing on him from the top of the bank and
finishing the business. But when I reached
the bank he was clambering off a short
plank pier into the boat and snatching
feverishly at the lines to cast loose. He had
made the boat fast in two places, which was
in my favor, but he got both lines free and
the instant he had thrown the clutch into
gear and opened up the gas he crouched
below the boat's side.
I remembered then that there is such a
thing under heaven as horse sense. I could
have easily wasted my three remaining
shots in an effort to plug him, but the boat
was a considerably larger target. I fired all
three deliberately, plunk into the boat, and
one of them damaged the engine.
It doesn't take much to stop one of those
single-cylinder affairs. I hadn't done much
harm to the engine, for he got it going again
in less than a minute; but during that min-
ute the water must have made headway
through two bullet-holes, and by the time he
began to pay attention to it the water was
swishing all' over the bottom. What with
the state of his eyes and the darkness he
couldn't find the trouble. For a minute or
two after that he seemed to be lifting off the
seat-covers and looking for a pump, but
there was none, for he began bailing with
a small tin can. Then the engine gave a
final cough and quit for good.
I lit a cigar. I'm willing to take oath
that if there had been a boat within reach I
would have put off and tried to save him
for the hangman. But there wasn't any
boat. I daresay he had taken care there
shouldn't be. And as for swimming--he
might swim in that nearly ice-cold water if
so minded; I tested it with my hand and
knew that I for one couldn't stay afloat in
it for two minutes.
One of my bullets must have done much
more than bore a hole in the hull, for he
could have bailed against two. or even
against three bullet-holes. But though he
worked like fury the water gained on him,
and I could see the hull submerging inch by
inch.
He lost his courage in the end completely.
The chill of that rising water around his
legs gave him too definite a foretaste of
what was coming. He began to scream for
help and to call on some Deity I never heard
of. I tore two planks off the pier and hurled
them as far as I could out into the lake, but
he was a quarter of a mile away, and I doubt
even if he saw me throw them. He could
never have reached them anyhow.
He went down screaming, and the cold
calm water closed over him with a ring of
ripples that danced in the moonlight until
the last, ever-widening circle nearly reached
the shore. Then I turned to examine what-
ever it was that he had dropped when my
bullet touched him, and clambering up the
bank discovered nothing less than Allison's
leather satchel.
YOU'LL be right if you- suppose
that I unbuckled the flap with
trembling fingers. Maybe I shouted
---I don't know--when I discovered the gold
plate safe inside. But it was badly dam-
aged. My bullet had struck it near one
corner, ploughed through the soft gold for
several inches, itself expanding as it went,
and finally had gone clear through to expand
its last momentum on the ribs of Bhopal
Gosh. The plate had been further damaged
when he dropped it, for it was bent out of
shape, and I think he must have stepped
on it, because a good deal of the scripture
was obliterated. Nevertheless, it was the
plate, and I had at least something to re-
turn to poor old Allison.
There was no more chance of recovering
the other plates than of gleaning snow on
the plains in midsummer. We had left the
outer safe-door open, and the whole house
was a roaring furnace. It might be possible,
when the ashes should cool off, to recover a
shapeless mass of nearly pure gold; but it
was far more likely that the safe had tilted
forward as the beams gave way underneath
it and the stuff as it melted had run out and
got lost so thoroughly that its recovery
would cost more than the game was worth.
I tried to get some of the fellows who
came racing to the fire to help find a boat
and look for Bhopal Gosh, but when I told
them sufficient of the circumstances they
laughed at the idea.
"Never dragged a corpse out o' that lake
yet, unless in the shallows inshore. The
cold sets them solid. The body don't form
no gas, and they stay down there a mile
deep. No; Lake Tahoe don't give up her
dead, and never will till Judgment Day."
So I borrowed a big car instead, and got
Moses and Mrs. Aintree
two of them to come back along the road
and help me with the sheriff, Terence Casey
and the deputy. Less than an hour later,
as we drove dead-slow around a bend, I
heard the sheriff's voice--
"I notice you got your man!" he called
out.
Now I don't know how he knew that, nor
would he tell me how he knew; but he swore
that he knew it from the moment that our
headlights came in sight around the corner.
I asked the deputy about it, who was not
much the worse for his experience by that
time, and he laughed.
"Shore he knew!" he answered. "He
weren't guessing. He told us two that you'd
got your man 'fore ever he spoke to you at
all. Didn't he, Casev?"
"He did that," said Casey. "It all comes
o' running over that black cat. Any man
in his senses knew that somebody was going
to get the gate tonight. Well, Lord be
praised it wasn't me! I'm due for me pen-
sion. Hey, steady! Lift me easy--easy,
you! I'm not the inimy, Ramsden! Ye're
after pulling me to bits!"
fcSKS SO IF you should have the good
.tlfej luck to visit London one of these
days, and should have the sound
horse sense and taste to pass a portion
of your time in the British Museum, turn
first into the Egyptian Gallery. And if you
see there in a glass case by itself a battered
gold plate with a great trough plowed
across it so as to obliterate the head and
shoulders of what was once the portrait of
a man, you'll understand how it came there.
They have marked it, "Very ancient; prob-
ably period of Israelitish occupation; mostly
illegible; purpose unknown." For they are
cautious men who conduct that institu-
tion.
But there's a middle-aged Scotsman at-
tached with no ver)/ definite duties to that
department. They say he is rather a mental
wreck, and has been more or less pensioned
in that way. He'll tell you the whole story
of that gold plate, and better by far than I
have done. But better not mention my
name to him, for he vows, and will vow to
his dying day, that I know quite well where
the rest of the plates are, and that I mean to
unbury them some day and offer them for
sale when I suppose the game is safe.
"But just ye watch!" he'll tell you, in
case you should mention me. "I'll balk
him! I'll expose the chiel! I'll bring him to
his downfall yet!"
Brice, on the other hand, is still digging
for antiquities in Egypt, and he and I are
great friends.
And if you should happen to meet Terence
Casey--he'll be guarding a President, 01-
tracking down a forger, or some such child's
play---you might remember me to him; and
if he says to you, as he surely will the minute
that you mention me--•
"My friend Ramsden is a well-meanin'
man, I'll have ye know, and a good man of
his inches. He knows a •-of a lot about
ilyphints, and if he had his rights he'd be
with a circus, or curatin' at the Bronx
Park Zoo. But he's gone into the amachoor
daytective business, and that's not a fit
subjec' for conversation--not with prohi-
bition running wild!"
If he says that to you, as he will, you
might remind him that he owes me a round
of drinks--a point that he unaccountably
forgot when he came out of hospital. And
you might add, that as good drinks are hard
to come by these days, I'd be grateful if he'd
come across.
And as for what became of Mrs. Aintree,
and of the foreign entanglements of the
P. O. P., most of which we had to straighten
out before our job was done, let me remind
you all once more of those Indian story-
tellers, who invariably pause and pass the
hat when it would seem that their audience
has had its money's worth.
"Kull khadami tilzam. Allah yihfazak;"
and may all your ways be peace!
Author of "The Odyssey of Chander Roy"
ONROY should have been con-
tent to derive his information
from books and explain his
mission in life to well-chosen
friends in his club's smoking-room. Then
he would have acquired a reputation, and
his monographs on the advancement of civil-
ization among native races would have
been accepted without reservation.
As matters stand now, however, Conroy
snarls when the word "native" is mentioned
in his presence and in his more impassioned
moments he recommends the use of poison
or other foul means to rid the earth of his
erstwhile "dark skinned brethren."
It all happened because some ten years
ago when he was inspecting cattle stations
on the fringe of the great Australian desert
he was invited to witness the Aruntas' totem
dance. Thereafter he ceased to be merely
one of "new South Wales' farseeing finan-
ciers," as the Sydney papers called him, and
acquired a mission in life. On the strength
of his one close contact with aborigines he
decided that they were unfortunate people,
downtrodden by the brutal white races, and
he brought a good deal of influence to bear
to have their conditions improved.
Such was his enthusiasm that he read
Spencer and Gillen's "Australian Abor-
igines" and looked at the wood cuts in
Codrington's "Melanesians." People took
him seriously because he had much money
and controlled far more live-stock than any

man should really be allowed to handle.
He even wrote a couple of articles for a daily
paper urging the abolishment of marriage
by capture among the Cape York tribes and
the establishment of compulsory education.
Because he nearly succeeded his mission in
life became an obsession.
He talked folk-lore at directors' meetings
until somebody suggested that he visit
some of the Pacific Islands and make a com-
parative study of existing conditions. As he
had just cleaned up half a million pounds by
selling out some Western sheep-ranches just
before the big drought, he decided to act on
the suggestion.
"I'll make things hot for the colonists out
there if I find any slavery or oppression," he
told one of his acquaintances just before
sailing. "I'll raise the roof. People know
me. I'll expose 'em!"
"Going to New Caledonia?" asked the
acquaintance.
"Yes, worse luck. Got to go to Noumea
and transfer there to a schooner for Tanna
in the New Hebrides."
"Why not stop off for a few weeks and
look over the island?" queried the acquaint-
ance. "We have a cattle-station out there
at a place called Nakitalo. McLaird, our
manager, tells us the interior is full of tribes
who have never seen a white man. He
could put you up. I'll give you a letter of
introduction."
'Splendid!" boomed Conroy.
The Naked Truth
He was a large man with a heavy red face
barred by a fierce, upcurling moustache,
and he affected a broad smile which never
quite reached his round, prominent eyes.
"Splendid!" he repeated.
"And if you think the place looks promis-
ing, and I assure you it is," added his friend,
"we could talk things over when you come
back."
"I'll think about it. Thanks for the
introduction," answered Conroy who never
allowed his mission to run away with his
business sense.
So he went to New Caledonia and jour-
neyed up to Nakitalo in a disgustingly dirty
little boat which lurched and staggered in
the slightest swell. For three days he was
too miserable to admire the scenery, and the
smell of food appalled him. The ever-
changing panorama of jagged yellow hills,
sharply outlined against the blue sky and
the narrow green valleys where the graceful
coconut trees stood guard at the water's
edge, failed to excite his interest.
Once ashore at Nakitalo, however, with
a fellow-Australian to talk to he became as
self-assertive as ever. McLaird impressed
him not at all, for he was a little, bald man,
with very blue eyes set in a clean-shaven,
weather-beaten face; and his voice was low
and gentle. In fact, Conroy tended to
assume command of the homestead and
hinted at a change of ownership.
"Well, that'll be nice for you," murmured
McLaird when he heard the news for the
first time.
"Nice--it's a drop in the bucket, my good
fellow," retorted Conroy, "a mere drop.
You've probably worked on some of my
ranches around Kalgoorie."
He named an imposing list of stations
extending over an area of some thousands
of miles.
"Your memory is still good," sighed his
host without so much as a ghost of a smile in
his blue eyes.
Those eyes at tirftes really annoyed Con-
roy for they were unwavering and not in the
least abashed. '
Otherwise everything went admirably
well. McLaird provided him with a half-
caste boy from Mare to act as interpreter
and turned him loose among the coastal
tribes who knew the value of money and
were quick to sense what the fat, red man
wanted to know. They told him beautiful
tales of oppression and cringed when they
mentioned the gendarme who administered
the district or McLaird, who gave them em-
ployment. They were sophisticated people
with a craving for contraband rum and
they retained few of their original customs,
living in miserable hovels patterned after
the gendarme's fort-like house at the end of
the valley. But Conroy thought that it was
all magnificently primitive.
He filled several large note-books with
comments on native life and customs and
devoted a lot of space to the tribes' economic
life. As he paid the villagers five francs
an hour to talk to him of their grievances
they never failed to cluster about him when
he walked down the village street and took
his seat in the shade of a great banyan tree.
News spreads fast in the islands, and be-
fore long, in twos and threes, men began to
drift down from the more remote villages
in the foot-hills to acquire some of the
fabulous wealth which was being poured
out by this red-faced man. The newcomers
attracted Conroy's attention for they were
not dressed in the conventional blue loin-
cloth and open mesh singlet of the coastal
natives, but wore strips of bark cloth
wound about their waists and carried queer
weapons.
The local people seemed to resent these
intrusions, but always gave way in fright-
ened dismay when the hill-men appeared.
At last they went to the hated gendarme
and begged for protection.
'Master," they wailed, "the men of
Vohlu are out again, and we walk in terror
Adventure
lest evil befall us. Our war-clubs are goneS
and you are our father and mother."
And the gendarme, who knew the treacher-
ous ways of the Vohlus, rudely broke up one
of Conroy's friendly meetings and marched
the visitors out of the village with orders to
leave their weapons at home next when they
visited Nakitalo.
Then the gendarme sought cut McLaird,
who was busy breaking in a new saddle,
horse for the next season's round-up, and
explained in explosive French that Conroy
must not, under any circumstances, stir up
trouble between the villages. It appeared
that he had given the people of Nakitalo
less money than he had offered to the hill-
folk and things were not as quiet as they
might well be. There was more drunken-
ness than was absolutely necessary, and the
Vohlu Avere restless.
The gendarme wanted peace and quiet
in his district, so did McLaird for the sake of
his bullocks, but neither of them had taken
Conroy's mission into consideration. He
was beside himself with indignation and bel-
lowed at the gendarme until the latter
bellowed back and the air rang with the
oaths of Marseilles and the curses of unre-
generate Kalgoorie. McLaird sat on the
paddock fence and smoked cigarets until
the noise gradually subsided.
'Say," he called to Conroy in the same
dispassionate voice he used for all occasions.
"Say, Mr. Conroy, you don't own this place
yet. I got to keep on friendly terms with
the gendarme, so just cool off a little. He's
quite right, too. I can't get any labor at all
since you started throwing money at the
natives. Talk to 'em all you like, but don't
be so darned generous. I need labor."
"All right," he added in halting French
for the benefit of the enraged gendarme,
"I will guard him tranquil. Comprenez?
No more de le noise. Tres bien, mon ami,
oui?"
The officer grinned good-naturedly as he
turned to go and waved his hands to express
hopeless disgust.
But Conroy felt that his great mission
was being trampled upon. He was being
forbidden free access to the natives by a
glorified policeman and a herder of cattle
who called Sydney the "Big Smoke" and
couldn't lay claim to a bank-account.
These ignorant men were afraid of him, his
power, his reputation.
"No," he shouted at McLaird, "I will not
be quiet. I am going to finish my investi-
gation and I refuse, ab-so-lu-te-Iy refuse to
be deterred or coerced by you."
McLaird lighted another cigaret and
smiled. His sunburned face creased and
wrinkled into a thousand little lines, his
small teeth gleamed and his blue eyes
danced with merriment. No man, ever
before, had dared to grin at Conroy in a
temper.
"Laugh at me!" he spluttered. "Laugh
at me--how dare you? I'll tell you what I
am going to do!"
He was still explaining as the shadows
grew long and the sun slipped down the side
of a purple hill into the sea.
He was appalled at McLaird's callous-
ness, he declared. He had seen enough to
convince him that everything had been
done or left undone to wreck the natives'
standards and reduce them to slavery. On
the morrow, he would go up to the Vohlu
territory and see for himself exactly how
these hill-people fared. No doubt but con-
ditions were quite as bad up there.
He went to great lengths, repeating him-
self several times, to assure McLaird that
he might as well begin looking around for
a new job.
"As a drover perhaps you'll be a success,"
he snarled, "but you're incapable, absolute-
ly incapable of holding such a responsible
position as this where the future of a race
lies in your hands."
McLaird finally broke his long silence.
"Come in to dinner. Food must be
getting cold," he suggested as he jumped off
the fence and walked away with an indiffer-
ence which quite upset Conroy's calcula-
tions.
He followed dumbly, choked by the
thousand things he still had to say.
After coffee had been served he launched
another -attack. He leaned back in his chair
and eyed his host malevolently through
half-closed lids.
"Your silence leads me to believe--" he
began.
"That's enough," snapped McLaird. A
change had come over him, his blue eyes
were cold and merciless and his mouth was
set in a thin, hard line. " I've put up with
you for a week. As I said once before you
don't own this place yet. Remember that.
"I've nursed you because you're out of
your depth as soon as you step off an as-
phalt pavement. I won't bother to tell you
The Naked Truth
how wrong you are because it's waste of
time. But get this straight--you are not
going up-country tomorrow. You'd have
to have a permit from the gendarme. He
won't give one to a maniac like you. You're
dangerous. You'd either get killed or start
a rebellion. That's not needed. And I
won't let you have that interpreter or lend
you horses. The sooner you pack up and
get out the better. Hospitality is wasted on
you. Go back to Sydney and get control of
this place -before you come back. There's
a launch going down tomorrow to Mbopari.
You'll be able to shift for yourself there."
Conroy was amazed. This little man
trying to bully him! He smiled tolerantly
and blew a ring of cigar smoke toward the
ceiling. No interpreter, no horses--that
could easily be fixed. The gendarme's
permit? What did he care for that? Had
he not talked to some official at Noumea
who had assured him that he could go any-
where he liked about the island?
Without a word he left the table and
went out to the stockmen's quarters where
he found the Mare boy squatting at ease by
the door.
They whispered together for some min-
utes and a wad of notes changed hands,
silencing the boy's objections. Then he
went back to his room and slept soundly.
He dreamed a little of his coming journey
through the hills and thought of the space
he would devote to it in his book.
At dawn, carrying a heavy kit-bag, he
tip-toed out of the house, down through the
mist to the ford where he found the boy
awaiting him with two horses. They lost
several precious minutes strapping the bag
in place, and Conroy cuffed his guide in his
hurry to be away. He didn't want to be
stopped now at the very outset of his real
work. At last when all was ready he swung
heavily into the saddle and cried out good-
naturedly--
"Lead on, Apatwa, my boy, now we shall f
find our way to the truth!"
He raised his riding-crop and pointed
ahead with a commanding gesture.
" Yassah," dubiously answered the boy.
"When we get back-"
Conroy got no further for McLaird, at a
run, loomed out of the mist. In his hand he
carried a murderous looking Colt which he
leveled at the speaker.
"Come on, Conroy," he ordered. "Get
off that horse!"
Conroy hesitated and he came closer.
"Come on," he repeated. "Get down."
But for once in his life he was caught off
his guard. Conroy, bending forward as if to
dismount, suddenly brought down the butt
end of his heavy crop like a flail. It glanced
off McLaird's head and crashed on to his
shoulder. He fell to the ground and rolled
over.
"That," muttered Conroy, "will keep you
quiet for a while." And he urged his horse
forward across the crumpled body.
KASSUI, chief of all the Tiukas,
owner of twelve wives, squatted on
the sacred stone seat before the
men's sleeping-house and listened with wick-
ed eyes to the reports of his spies.
"O Chief," said Ngoroto, a lean warrior
with hair bleached yellow after the fashion
of the Lifou people--a proof that he had
traveled greatly, "I come from Vohlu.
They have grown fat and lazy once again.
Their men are weak and their women many.
Their pigs would gorge our ovens. The
way lies open before us to the very heart of
their huts. We ^ieed heads for the
shrine-"
"Go ari, I know," snapped Kassui tugging
at his gray beard. "My son's new house
will need its attendant spirit, and my father's
soul calls for another slave."
For among the Tiuka a dead man should
go in state to his heaven with an escort of
prisoners' souls to wait on him, and no house
is complete unless the skull of an enemy be
stuck upon the ridge-pole to ward off evil.
"Is that all you saw?" asked Kassui after
a pause. " The Vohlu are close to the valley,
and the white men lend them their magic,
I am told."
Ngroto laughed and spat scornfully.
"Wah! I watched for a week in the
shadow of their skull shrine on the hill. They
no longer honor their dead, and their magic
is harmless. Do I not know? See-"
From his loin-cloth he produced a handful
of human teeth which he threw on the
ground before the chief.
The assembly swayed and shuddered.
Who knew what might not befall? All were
not as strong as Ngoroto to withstand evil.
But an old man laughed shrilly and slapped
his shriveled thigh in derision.
"O Chief," he cackled, "Ngoroto is
strong. Already he has slain as many men
as I have toes on my feet. He has much
Adventure
honor among us--but he has no cunning!"
The crowd shrank back as Ngoroto arose
grasping his war-club, but the old man still
squatted on the ground and nodded at
Kassui. He was Ngoroto's great-great-
uncle by marriage and no stripling may
strike such an one without losing his soul.
"What is your tale, old man?" grunted
Kassui.
"This--" he answered. "While Ngoroto
lurked by the deserted shrine, I went down
into the village as one who comes in peace.
Have I not a woman of the Vohlu in my
hut?"
" Wahl" yelled the assembly, and the men
stamped their feet in approval. Here, in-
deed, was temerity worthy of a man of
Tiuka.
"And when I found my kin," went on the
old man, " I saw a very fat white man sitting
by their cooking-house. I made inquiries.
He is neither a bearer of magic nor a spy
but a fool who pays in the money of the
French to be told lies. They sit about him
all day and receive notes for their talk.
It is said these notes will buy many things
such as tobacco and cloth and rum--but
who knows the truth when a Vohlu speaks?
"How did he come among them?" asked
Kassui.
"He is said to love the Vohlu. He sought
them out alone, for his guide fled when they
reached the first little hills. _ He says he is
the Vohlu's brother, but they will surely kill
him when they need a sacrifice."
"His head," suddenly exclaimed Kassui,
"shall go on my son's house, and we shall
feast as we did of old."
He stepped from the sacred seat and hur-
ried out of the village up into the bush on
the steep hillside.
"He has gone to talk to our fathers,"
whispered Ngoroto.
"War!" shrilly cackled the old man, and
the assembly clapped and chanted while the
young men, three deep around the throbbing
drums, danced the Eragi war-dance, which
is dedicated to the ghosts of the ancestors
who have died in battle.
The call was heard from afar. It was an-
swered from remote hillsides and from lost
villages. There came warriors with their
clubs and spears, elders with the hideous
masks of the secret lodges, keepers of sacred
places, naked and daubed with red ocher.
All through the night and- all the following
day they drifted in, gathering family by
family, group by group until the tale was
complete and not a man missing.
There followed a great feast while the
elders took ghostly council at the shrine
beneath the banyan-tree and the drums
boomed incessantly. Then the elders re-
turned to the round-house and the tribes-
men, in a hushed silence, waited expectant-
ly. Just before dawn, when the tree-tops
began to take shape, Kassui appeared in the
doorway. In his hand he held aloft a
bundle--a wild taro to which had been
bound a tuft of the red wooly hair of the
flying fox and the broken shaft of a spear--
the sign of war. Shout upon shout filled
the air, and the drums spoke with a new
voice as the young men stamped and swayed
to the measure which called all men to the
killing.
But war, even among the hill-tribes of
New Caledonia, is a matter of preparation.
Spies must make sure that the path lies
clear, ancestors must be propitiated and
omens be observed. The spears, the clubs
and the throwing stones must all be placed
for a second upon a certain carved rock
that the spirit of the original founder of
the tribe may enter into the weapons and
guide them swiftly on their way.
All went well with the Tiuka. The yam
harvest on the terraced hillsides was abun-
dant, the warriors grew sleek and smooth-
skinned and the comer posts of Kassui's
son's house were put in the ground the day
after his marriage; for no woman needs a
home until her first child is born.
"The young men grow restless,'" an elder
at last told Kassui. "All things are ready.
We wait for a sign-■"
"Aie," answered the chief, "it has come!"
And he sprinkled water over the fire in
the men's house. The steam dissolved and
vanished before it reached the thatch, proof
that the ancestors had accepted the liba-
tion and the old men began to chant until
the drums drowned their clamor.
That night the men of Tiuka swarmed out
of their valley and dropped swiftly down
the rocky slope beyond. Dark bodies
gleamed here and there in the moonlight,
occasionally a dislodged stone rattled from
ledge to ledge or a spear rasped against a
tree-trunk.
Before the cool dawn wind rustled
through the palm leaves they reached the
outskirts of the Vohlu village. There fol-
lowed a rush and a yell and a scream.
The Naked Truth
Flames suddenly licked up the walls of a
hut, a shower of sparks flew wide and
roof after roof caught fire. By the red
glare the warriors swept through the
village, and the Vohlu died, squealing for
mercy.
Long before the morning mists left the
valley the village was reduced to ashes,
where here and there a headless body
sprawled in the open, and Mr. Albert Con-
roy, the farseeing financier, was being prod-
ded none too gently up and up and up the
mountain side, through thorny bushes and
over sharp rocks. In a hysterical voice he
cursed his captors, for he was clad in red
morocco slippers and pink pa jamas, which
were rapidly shredding and disappearing
as he clambered up the slope, and he was
suffering acutely. To make matters worse
he was herded with a score of Vohlu pris-
oners and as many of their lamenting
women folk.
He fainted when the blazing sun beat
down on his unprotected neck and two other
captives were given the task of bearing him
throughout the day. When he recovered he
lay face down in the dust before the sacred
stone where sat Kassui. Some one had
thrown water over him and his hair hung
damply in his eyes.
"Wah!" grumbled the chief. "Never
have I seen such fat on any man."
Conroy sat up slowly gathering together
odd strips of pink cloth which had clung to
him to his journey's end. In a wide circle
about him stood or squatted a crowd of
men blood-stained, wild-eyed, with great
head-dresses of cowrie shells and feathers.
On the fringe of the crowd women hovered,
watching him. Beyond the cluster of huts
he saw the towering forest-covered hills
penning him in.
A Vohlu ma,n with his arms bound tightly
behind him was thrust forward into the circle
and cringed before Kassui.
" What is this fat man's magic?" demanded
the chief.
"Great One, I speak the truth, seeking
mercy," came the stammered answer. "His
magic is great. He rules men of his own
kind by virtue of tokens which he gives to
those who serve him. White men pay him
homage and one who lives near the coast at
Nakitalo, a powerful man indeed, is said to
be his slave."
"Where are these tokens?" queried Kassui
anxiously.
In his haste to seek favor the Vohlu man
fell into the trap.
"The tokens were burnt when his hut
was set on fire," he answered.
"Can he create more?"
"Who knows? He had many with him
when he reached us."
"Then tell him that unless he produce two
fists full of such tokens he shall die, and his
soul go to keep my son's house."
"And shall I live?"
"Tell him!" thundered Kassui, and the
circle of warriors narrowed in.
So the-prisoner made shift to explain the
order to Conroy, who understood not at all.
' Notes--or we die. Money, French
money--or we die," the captive repeated
again and again.
Light dawned at last in Conroys' mind
and a great weight lifted from his heart.
These people were not as dangerous as he
had been led to believe. They dared not
kill him. They were holding him for ran-
som.
"Money? Why, my good fellow, where
am I to get it? If they will send a messen-
ger to Nakitalo they will be given a thou-
sand francs. Also explain that unless I am
released forthwith I shall see that these
people are punished, severely punished.
I cannot imagine how-"
"What does he say?" sharply queried
Kassui. "Is it a spell?"
"No spell, Great One, but he cannot pro-
duce the tokens," answered the Vohlu man.
"If you send to Nakitalo, he says you will
be given tokens in handfuls for his release,
for he is needed by his people. More I
cannot understand."
"Make clear that unless the tokens appear
now he shall die when my son's house is
ready," retorted Kassui.
Gradually Conroy began to understand.
He must produce money or die. Fear, icy-
fingered, clutched at his throat and he tried
to bluster and bully while Kassui gnawed
at his beard and watched him with blood-
shot eyes.
"He has no magic," miserably repeated
the Vohlu man. "May I be spared, O
Great One?"
For answer the chief raised his'left hand,
and a half-dozen spears struck down the
shrieking captive as the warriors closed in
to the kill.
Now Conroy, for all his vast experience,
had never seen death, violent death at such
Adventure
close quarters. Street accidents he knew
and understood, for he had seen an old man
knocked down and killed by an automobile
in the busiest district of Sydney; but he
could not face this ghastly horror. With dis-
tended eyes and drooping jaw he watched
a warrior chop off the fallen man's head with
one blow of a bamboo knife, saw them pick
up the body and bear it away, heard the
clamor of the other captives and then
fainted dead away for the second time that
day.
Thus he mercifully missed the great feast
which took place that night when the Tiuka
ceremonially ate their victims to acquire
their soul substance and afterward danced
to the sound of the drums, stopping fre-
quently that each man might recount his
deeds of bravery.
^THE ensuing days, however, be-
came one long nightmare. Another
prisoner had been spared for a fu-
ture sacrifice and through him Conroy dis-
covered how and when he was to die. The
surviving captive had a gift for graphic
description, and Conroy was tortured by
visions of his own bleaching skull adorning
the new hut. He vividly pictured the last
rite when he would be led out to his death
surrounded by frenzied tribesmen.
To his surprize he was not harshly
treated. True, he was kept under guard but
the Tiukas, even Kassui, provided him with
food and conversed with him through the
Vohlu man. When he spoke of his great
power in his distant home they grinned and
chuckled.
The man of Vohlu, at once resigned and
contented, worked in the fields with his cap-
tors and took up a definite place in their
social system. He was given a wife and a
hut of his own and lived apparently, on the
best of terms with his neighbors.
His days were long before him, he told
Conroy, for his soul would only be needed
when the taro season came around. Mean-
while he was happy. He had food and shel-
ter and a woman. Death came to all men,
to each his appointed hour.
Conroy merely shuddered and glanced
fearfully at the hut which his soul was to
guard. The whole tribe worked spasmodic-
ally at its construction. For days it stood
untouched, then a score of men would work
at it, singing lustily while they lashed and
pounded and chopped. Conroy grew de-
pressed and frightened. The remnants of
his pajamas and his slippers had long since
vanished and he went about clad in a strip
of bark cloth, which a native woman,
laughingly, had thrown to him.
Gone was his mission and his love for
primitive people, gone his desire to help and
improve them. In his mind he evolved
drastic disciplinary systems to curb and
check their barbarous ways. The sword
and the bullet were mild when compared
to the methods he would advocate. Above
all things his soul revolted at their lack of
cleanliness and decency. Once he wit-
nessed an initiation ceremony which left
him gasping in horror.
When the crossbeams were put in place
on the fateful house he tried to escape, only
to be caught as he stumbled heavily in the
darkness between the huts. He incurred no
punishment for this offence except that
Kassui spat at him and the women laughed
him to scorn. At last, however, when the
singing Workers began to thatch the hut and
the women were collecting fruit and food
for the coming feast, Conroy roused himself
from his dejected torpor. He would not be
killed like a scared rabbit, he told himself,
he would make one last dash for freedom.
"I can't die like this," he repeated again
and again as he lay in the dark and listened
to the heavy breathing of his jailer.
Late at night he became hysterical and
sobbed in great gulps. The native stirred
restlessly in his sleep, and Conroy trembling,
edged toward the dimly outlined doorway.
His groping hand found the Tiuka's club
and his fingers closed around the smooth
handle.
Crouching on his knees he raised the
weapon above his head. But he had no
control over his muscles now. His arms
refused to act. He was shaking with terror.
"I can't do it," he whimpered. "I can't
do it. Oh, God, the last of my manhood has
gone. The very last of my manhood."
Tears streamed down his dirty cheeks as
he looked at the dark body barring his way.
Still murmuring, "The last of my man-
hood," he suddenly stiffened and brought
the club down on the sleeper's head.
Somehow he crept out of the village and
up through the bush. As the dawn broke
he reached the crest and paused for breath.
He was torn and bleeding and still sobbed as
he lashed the low bushes about him with
the blood-stained club.
The Naked Truth
7i
Away below him he heard faint cries
which reached him softened and mellowed
through the still morning air. The man-
hunt had begun. The clamor increased in
volume. He caught sight of a dark body
leaping from rock to rock. They were after
him already.
And ahead lay the sea, placid and blue
and still. He stumbled forward and began
to toil down the hillside, falling and rolling
among the rocks, crying aloud for help.
McLAIRD sat with his feet cocked
up on the window-sill reading a
month-old copy of the Sydney
Bulletin. The cigaret between his lips
glowed at regular intervals and unhurried
puffs of blue smoke emerged from his
nostrils, curling slowly up into the hot, still
air.
Behind him at the table sat two heated
gentlemen in faultless white clothes who
glared at the back of his bald head and
fidgeted uncomfortably.
"This is ridiculous!" one of them declared.
"Mr. Shelburn and I demand your atten-
tion. Be kind enough to listen to me."
"Mr. Thorpe is quite right," assented his
companion. "You cannot refuse to answer
our questions."
' Well," drawled McLaird, "it's this
way. You two have been here for a week
telling me about Conroy and how much
money you lose if he dies. I've been think-
ing about him, too, and what an almighty
beating up he'll get if I ever meet him."
"Now, now," admonished Mr. Shelburn,
"No threats, please. The whole affair looks
bad enough as it is."
"So you've said a good many times,"
pointed out McLaird. " Conroy disappears.
I'm found with a dislocated collar-bone and
a bruised head, so I must have murdered
him. That's the idea, isn't it?"
"I'm no lawyer," answered Mr. Shelburn,
"but on the face of it-"
"Rot," snapped McLaird. "You're as
crazy as that nut Conroy. Just hang about
here for a few hours until the gendarme
turns up and he will give you all the latest
news. This business pleases him an awful
lot, I should imagine; having to run around
after a wild Australian when he could be
writing nice reports or nursing his goats.
D'you know, he lets a whole bunch of 'em
stray into my fattening paddocks! Graft,
that's what it is. But he's not a bad lad."
Mr. Thorpe helped himself to warm
brandy and set the bottle down on the table
with a crash.
"I am not concerned with your absurd
troubles," he exclaimed angrily. "Mr. Con-
roy is urgently needed to complete the
plans for the Australasian Livestock Cor-
poration. He must be found if he's alive.
We are losing hundreds of thousands
through this delay."
' I've heard that before," McLaird gently
reminded him. "My people in Melbourne
told me to give you every assistance. I've
tried to. I've been doing nothing else ever
since I got out of bed. And I want friend
Conroy just as much as you do. Now leave
me alone until the gendarme gets here.
"But--" began Mr. Shelburn.
McLaird turned and leveled his discon-
certing blue eyes at the speaker.
"Keep quiet," he ordered, and Mr. Shel-
burn sat back limply with a dismayed look
on his face.
The gendarme arrived in the middle of
the afternoon, tired and disgusted, but he
had some information.
He had been up to the most remote Vohlu
village, which he had found burnt to the
ground. He had not been told about it
earlier because the tribesmen wanted to hit
back at their enemies. The attackers were
little-known people living beyond the pre-
cipitous slopes of Mount Ndoki. They had
captured Conroy and taken him away alive,
so a survivor had told him.
"This man should be put in prison if he
still lives," grumbled the officer. "No per-
mit did he have from me! No permission to
visit these people. He should do twelve
months in Noumea."
"Oui, oki," assented McLaird. Then he
translated the conversation for the benefit
of his guests.
"An expedition--" suggested Mr. Shel-
burn.
"And I shall have to ask for a squad of
soldiers," went on the gendarme. "It will
ruin my district's reputation. If I catch
this imbecile it will go hard with him."
Here McLaird took command of the
situation.
" I'm going up-country tomorrow hunting
for strayed cows. I'll have a look around
for Conroy while I'm about it," he told the
official, and that worthy nodded his head
vigorously.
If his friend, Monsieur McLaird, was fit
Adventure
enough to undertake such a journey, well
then, he would accompany him. Perhaps
they could lbcate this crapule without out-
side help.
"He's probably dead," sighed McLaird.
"but we'll, find out something definite.
I'd have gone before, but I couldn't move,
my shoulder was too bad."
The gendarme was delighted; here was a
chance of maintaining his district's good
standing. On the morrow then, at five
o'clock, he would call for McLaird. To-
gether they would scour the country. He
saluted and withdrew before either of Con-
roy's friends understood quite what was
happening. When matters were explained
to them, however, they grew frantic, de-
manding punitive expeditions, reprisals and
detectives.
"I protest against such methods!" cried
Shelburn. "I want to register a most em-
phatic protest. The proper authorities, the
competent authorities, should deal at once
with this matter."
"It will take another three weeks before
any outside help can reach Nakitalo," an-
swered McLaird. "Conroy was probably
killed the very day they caught him. It's
a certainty he won't be alive in another
month. This is about our last chance, and
it's a mighty poor one.'"
"Then I insist that we accompany you on
this expedition," said Thorpe. "I want to
get to the bottom of this affair."
"You want to come along?" grinned Mc-
Laird. "That's fine. It will do you good.
I'll order a couple of horses for you at
once.''
NEITHER Thorpe nor Shelburn
would have undertaken the next
day's journey had they realized the
dangers they were called upon to face. At
first they were rather pleased with the nov-
elty of the ride. Ahead in single file along
the shaded track all bordered with palms
and pines and silver-barked niaouli trees,
went four native stockmen bareback on lean
Australian cattle ponies, then came Shel-
burn on a high-stepping dun-colored mare
and Thorpe fumbling at the bit of a rangy
seventeen-hand horse with a wicked under- .
lip. Behind rode McLaird and the gen-
darme wrangling as usual about the latter's
pasture rights.
"This," quoth Shelburn as they wound
along following the river bed, "is entrancing-
ly tropical. The color of those hills--splen-
did!"
He waved a well-kept hand at the tum-
bled mountains turned to gold by the rising
sun.
"Quite," answered Thorpe looking at his
horse's ears which had a nasty habit of lying
flat back against his head as no good horse's
should.
After lunch they reached the foot-hills
and left the narrowing valley for a
path which carried them up, straight up,
until Shelburn, looking downward, called
back--
"I say, Thorpe, this is trick riding!"
Thorpe's answer was brief and incisive,
but he kept his eyes straight ahead of him
and held his reins bunched in his left hand,
for his horse exhibited a growing fondness
for grisly pas-seuls neatly performed on
crumbling ledges overhanging dangerous
heights.
The next day when they attacked the real
mountains the track grew worse.
"Like riding over waves in a high sea,"
thought Thorpe, sawing at his horse's now
bleeding mouth.
At last they reached the charred and de-
serted ruins of the Vohlu village and camped
among the wind-blown ashes.
"Tomorrow," said McLaird when they
had dined off corned beef and stale
bread, "we'll push along across that
crest."
He pointed to the frowning height just
ahead of them.
"The gendarme thinks the raiders came
down that way. There's said to be a big
tribe in the next valley, but nobody knows
much about them."
"Are we in sufficient numbers?" asked
Thorpe. "We might meet with opposi-
tion."
"If we do, just keep out of the way," an-
swered McLaird. "We don't want any
more deaths in the family."
When they went forward the following
morning there was no track to follow. On
foot, leading their horses, they clambered
up through dense undergrowth and around
boulders. Shelburn's white riding-breeches
ripped open at the knee, and he left a per-
fectly good leather legging hanging in some
particularly thorny bushes. Thorpe who
had come to fear his horse jerked savagely
at the bit when he found himself being left
behind. His steed, flattening back his ears,
The Naked Truth
began to practise an intricate jig on what
seemed to be the world's overhanging cor-
nice.
The others at last reached a rocky pla-
teau, half-way up the mountain-side and
rode slowly forward beneath the pitiless
sun, and Thorpe cursed with a fluency and
directness which would have astonished his
more fortunate colleagues of the Australian
Livestock Corporation. Sweating, panting
and infuriated he reached level ground and
swung into the saddle after his horse had
danced and circled around for several min-
utes. In his exasperation he did a very rash
thing--he used both his long, nickel-plated,
heavily roweled spurs, and his horse bolted
headlong at right angles to the party, taking
boulders and bushes in his sudden mad
rush.
By some miraculous intervention which
had nothing to do with good horsemanship
Thorpe kept his seat and his wild cries
reached McLaird just before he was carried
out of sight behind a high clump of
bushes. The party wheeled and followed
as best they could while Shelburn, closing
the cavalcade at a dignified trot, kept
crying:
"Stop him! Oh, stop him!"
THE Tiukas recaptured Conroy
without trouble. They found him
sprawling and exhausted at the foot
of a giant pine. In fact, at the moment, he
was past caring what his fate might be. He
wanted to lie flat on the ground and sleep
and rest. So they bound and trussed him
hand and foot, offered a prayer to the spirits
of the giant pine for having arrested the
captive's flight, and Squatted down in the
shade for a while before bearing such a
weight back across the hills.
"Why not finish him here?" suggested a
young warrior who had only killed his first
man in the raid on the Vohlus and had but
scant respect for traditions.
"Kah! Be still," grunted one of his com-
panions. "He must be alive and whole for
the sacrifice; strong and healthy, otherwise
his soul would be weak and useless."
"And I say it is better to kill while the
blood is hot," retorted the young man.
"That is indeed a sacrifice, but if Kassui
wants this fat man-"
He arose and stood looking out toward the
distant sea, thinking of the wives he would
have now that he had reached man's estate.
Suddenly there came a thunder of hoofs
and cries.
"Look," he yelled, "they come to his
rescue!"
And all at once they saw, heading straight
at them, a group of charging horsemen, led
by a demon who yelled with a wide open
mouth.
The young warrior paused to hurl a spear,
a bullet caught him neatly in the chest as he
lunged forward, and he went in state to the
land of his fathers, dying with honor in the
heat of battle. But his companions who
knew the ways of white men fled, fled and
were engulfed beneath the thick under-
growth on the hillside.
The hurtling spear struck Thorpe's horse
full in the neck. It halted, reared and
crashed to the ground throwing its rider
into a tangle of low shrubs. McLaird, with
a smoking revolver in his hand, helped him
to his feet. /
"What a horse," spluttered Thorpe. "A
devil!"
"Well, you've got a long walk ahead of
you," answered McLaird. "But what about
this black boy?"
"Gendarme," he added as the latter
rode up, " what do you make of those
people?"
"Tiukas," replied the officer very much
out of breath. "Many of them. It is
strange. Let us go and see."
They found Conroy shortly afterwards,
quite naked, very pink of body and very
red of face, lying on his back on a bed of
pine-needles.
Somebody gasped with astonishment,
somebody chuckled, somebody else mur-
mured--
"My lord, what a beau-tiful baby!" and
they broke down and roared and laughed
until tears streamed from their eyes. When
a pause came Shelburn cackled:
"He's so pink! The dear boy!" and they
laughed again until they grew weak and
sore.
Then they cut his thongs and listened to
his opinions of mankind while they gulped
and wiped their eyes.
There is little more to tell. Along George
Street, Sydney, where the financiers hold
court, Conroy is called "the pink baby,"
but not to his face, and he is apt to resent
any references to his tour of inspection of
the Pacific islands, which began and ended
in New Caledonia. He takes no interest

in people of ruder culture and has given Nakitalo Station, where McLaird still lives
away his two books on native customs. and raises fat bullocks what time he argues
