The gunner, having made three passes,
lighted one of his winnings and allowed
that it was a great war.
"I will bet you," said he, "my second
mess-kit of slum, that there are no Jerries
on the other side of the Marne, nor any-
where else in this sector. Here have we
sat and worn out our uniforms at the seat
for some seven or eight days, and there is
a pile of tin cans back of the kitchen that
you can see in Berlin, and not a-shot
have we heard, and not so much as seen a
balloon. No wonder this war has gone on
for four years."
Now there was one within hearing who
was shining the eye-pieces of his gas-mask
and cleaning a pistol and burning the end
of a piece of cork, and he looked up at this.
"Look you, now, Sheehan, for the Con-
nemara bog-trotter that you are. I will
bet you a bottle of vin rooge, which I gave
a Frog my slicker for this very morning,
against your syrup ration for the week,
that there are Huns across that river, and
that I will bring one back for you to send
home to your girl, more by token that the
old man has detailed me to go patrol this
very night with a wild crazy looey from the
doughboys, a curse on him and all his, and
I must go and prowl about in the wheat
with no hat on. Moreover and beyond, I
must blacken my face with this cork, so
that when I am dead no man will
know me, and I shall fill an unknown
grave to the glory of some mail-order
officer."
With that he applied himself to the cork
once more.
"You observers," said Sheehan, "lead a
hard life, what with your meals brought to
you and every two nights in bed all night
and no rocket-guard to stand, and I will
bet you my allowance of Karo for the week,
and if we have none then I will get a bottle
The Patrol
of white mule for my extra pair of shoes and
bet that. But I am not very like to lose."
NOW when it began to grow dark
the observer gathered his pistol and
a short and husky knife to him and
walked out through the wheat field and
along a path to the road. There was a sign
here that said Gas Alert, and the observer
knew that it was just four hundred yards
from that sign to the machine-guns that
guarded the batteries' flank, which was the
reason for the sign's being. So then he went
on up the road and passed a cross-roads
where the signs said Brownsville and Dragon
Fly and Home Run, they being the names
of regimental or battalion headquarters
that were in that direction.
The observer looked off at the German
lines that were across the river and won-
dered whether any one was watching him
and thought that the sunset was gorgeous
and that the valley of the Marne was quite
the most beautiful place that he had ever
seen. He went on down a road bordered
by elms, ancient and immemorial, down into
a little town where every house had blanket-
ed windows, and after following a line of
arrows went down into a cellar and reported
to the officer that he found there.
This one turned him over to a sergeant,
who led him by a nice trench back of some
houses and through some gardens to a place
just under the railroad track, where he
found some seven men, hatless, and each
with his face blackened and a look of dis-
quiet upon it, like a child seeing the castor-
oil appear, or a man on horseback who is
not quite sure of his seat.
"I suppose," said the observer, seeing no
sign of any shoulder-bars, "that the officer
is still eating his supper. Perhaps the steak
was done a trifle too much, or the potatoes
cold. So shall we sit here and wait, and the
American Army suspend operations until
Sears Roebuck lias smoked his cigar."
"We are waiting until it is dark," said a
voice that seemed to come across miles of
snowy fields and glittering ice, and the
observer looked and saw that he who spoke
had on a heavy gold ring of peculiar design,
and then he knew that there was the officer,
and that he was a real one, and that it was
like to be a wild night.
"Now that the artillery is here, give ear
to our plan," said the icy voice. "We are
directed to cross this river and to bring back
a prisoner if we have to go to Germany to
get him. Now we will cross in a boat which
has been provided and go straightway up
the bank in single file. I will be in the lead,
and each man shall hold the ankle of the
man in front of him. As we crawl along,
should I kick twice, the signal will be passed
along the line, and we will all execute right
into line, each man with his bombs in his
hand, and when I say, 'Now!' then let each
rush forward. For the rest, let every man
do as the man in front of him does. Any
questions?"
"I have no bombs," said the observer.
"It will be your duty," said the officer,
"to locate machine-gun nests, strong points
and trenches, by the system of Cartesian
coordinates, and not to be throwing high
explosives around with an unpractised
hand. This is once when the artillery will
not shoot up its own troops."
When it was dark the patrol crept over
the railroad track and down through the
wheat to the river's edge. It was damp and
cold, and the observer was stricken with
chills, and his teeth chattered, and his body
shook like a leaf. When they were getting
into the boat, he nearly capsized it, and had
he done so, they were all dead, for the other
bank was German and was but ten feet
away.
They lay under the shelter of the bank for
some time, and then up and across a narrow
path into the wheat, the artillery man
clinging for his life to a thick ankle. Now
this ankle belonged to a large, rough man,
by name "Gopher," a Tar Heel, and he was
a good man to cling to.
So they went on, and ever and anon
stopped to listen, and loud was the pounding
of their hearts. The wind whistled through
the wheat, and the observer wondered how
they would ever get back across the river,
and the tears ran down the bridge of his
nose and tickled it so that he was hard put
to keep from sneezing.
Now some one with few brains and much
curiosity found a rocket on the American
side and touched it off, to see what would
happen. At once every man with a Very
pistol discharged it so that the bank on
both sides of the river was as bright as day.
The patrol lay without breathing but
cursing inwardly, for they knew that they
must have worked either east or west and
were in front of troops that had not been
warned that there was a patrol out, and by
Adventure
the fact that the lights were almost over
them they knew they were not far from the
bank for all their crawling.
Moreover, the Americans were having a
merry time with their machine-guns, and
although the bullets were all going high,
still it was not pleasant to hear the pounding
and see the wheat falling and dropping
around one's ears.
It came like a thunderbolt. Gopher
kicked the observer suddenly in the face,
and he rushed forward without further
parley, falling headlong into a shell-hole.
There was a startled grunt, and he saw
some one running off trailing a blanket.
Out pistol and a bullet away to the moon,
the lieutenant kicking him vigorously and
cursing him to a fare-you-well, and a free
fight going on under his nose. The light
went out, and darkness came that you could
taste. Much straining and cursing, then a
thud, and silence. Two husky whispers
proclaimed--
' I've got one of the illegitimates."
Startled mutterings, and--
"Why, I thought you was one of them,"
from two throats at once.
"Hot dog!" said a voice. "You got teeth
on you like a shark."
"Oh, blessed day," said the lieutenant,
"that ever I joined the Army! What an
aggregation of wooden heads and tipsy
soldiers! You naughty, naughty boys, not
to know enough to be able to tell one another
apart from the enemy, for the double-
cross, compound, triple-expansion, nameless,
brainless descendants of horrible ancestry
that you are. Blight me and strike me all
colors of the rimrocked rainbow if I ever
saw anything like it before. And 'Wild
West Artillery' here, shooting off his pistol
right in front of the whole German Army.
By this and by that, you ought to write the
Kaiser a letter that you are going to call.
Now look at that--" as a rocket curved up
behind them, green and blue-- "Fritz will
reap and sow and harrow this field with
artillery and machine-gun until the prince of
all evil himself wouldn't have it. And after
all this commotion, which was as much as
would be made by a division with trains,
Y. M. C. A. and all, we have got no prisoner
and are like to be made some ourselves."
"Not so," said Gopher, "for we have one,
on whose head I now sit, and I know that
he is a German, for I can smell him."
Now this prisoner was for the moment
quite still, as Gopher had felt him wiggle
and had wound the barrel of his pistol about
the German's head just over the ears. In
his limp state, then, he was confided to the
care of Gopher and another man, called the
"Squarehead," because no one knew his
real name, the patrol coming from all over
the regiment.
"If I find, upon returning home, that you
have lost my prisoner, then shall you come
softly back and get another one, and no
mistake. Now, let us begone from this
shell-hole."
SO THEN they started the return,
crawling single file as before, with
Gopher and the Squarehead in the
middle with the prisoner and the rest with
their hearts in their throats. There was no
artillery fire and few lights, which meant
that the enemy had out patrols looking for
them, and their hearts sank in consequence.
It was growing colder as the night ad-
vanced, and the way back to the river
seemed overlong. They had'been crawling
since the world began, thought the artillery-
man, and then he tried to think how long
it had taken them to come from the river,
and it seemed to him that they were, some-
what overlong on the homeward way.
The wheat stopped. They were on the
edge of a road. Two cautious kicks, and
the patrol rushed to the front. At once they
were all among flower pots and crashing
glass, lights going up everywhere, machine-
guns pounding, men rising up under foot,
a dark shape jabbing at the artilleryman
with a bayonet, a house with windows that
leered in the ghastly light from the flares,
the lightning thought that the patrol was
lost and that it had crawled into Chartreves
or Jaulgonne.
The observer fled headlong into the wheat.
For the infantry the task of fighting hand
to hand with angry Huns. Two jumps,
and he swan-dived in gorgeous style into
a shell-hole, among a number of soft things.
"You-!" said a soft whisper, and the
artilleryman's wind was at once shut off
with a hand of steel, the while something
hard was slammed against his ribs.
"Let him up," quoth another voice, "it
is one of our guys."
The three men dismounted from the
fourth one's head, leaving him to gasp and
choke as best he might.
"Now," said one, resuming a conversation
The Patrol
that had been interrupted, "get gone,
and see that you lose not my prisoner.
Give me a gun and a couple of eggs, and I
will see if I can not hold Jerry in play a
while."
Now all this time there was great thrash-
ing-about in the wheat and much muttering
in an unknown tongue, so that it appeared
that the patrol would have scant chance to
get back to the river. Howbeit, they eased
out by inches, the observer, the Squarehead
and Gopher going first with the precious
prisoner, who was still in the land of Nod,
and the lieutenant bringing up the rear.
A long hiss, and a faint plop. The patrol
hugged the ground until the light would die
out. Six inches from the observer's face
was a German, looking at him with slack
jaw and goggling eyes. Both recoiled with
speed, a cry, a tearing grunt.
"Run like -!" and the artilleryman
sped toward the river, toward the American
lines, and toward Spain and the African
coast.
Had his wind lasted, he would have been
on the edge of the Sahara by daybreak.
The flare still burned. The officer was
standing up and was taking them as they
came, until both guns were empty. So died
a very gallant gentleman.
So long as one has his face toward the
enemy, terror keeps at a distance. Let him
once turn, let him feel that safety lies before
and that a bloodthirsty foe presses on his
heels, that all is lost save his own neck,
and a man's own fright will drive him on
when all danger of the enemy has long since
ceased.
The artilleryman ran at the top of his
speed. He fell into shell-holes and scram-
bled out of them. His breath came in sobs.
He threw away his pistol, belt and gas-
mask. He wept. He cared not the slightest
whether he was seen or not. He took no
heed to the fact that all this banging and
yelling would arouse the whole sector, and
that the Americans would gaily shoot up
that wheat field until a mouse was not safe
in it. So the Providence that watches over
fools brought him safely to the river again.
There was a little path along the river,
where aforetime youths and maidens were
wont to walk of an evening. The observer
lay on his stomach on the far side of the
path, trying to regain some of his wind and
to quiet the roaring in his ears. The pound-
ing of his heart shook him like a leaf. If
he tried to cross the path and swim the river,
most likely the Americans would lay down
a rain of steel and throw bombs and have
a most delightful time killing him.
If he called out that he was a friend, Jerry
would make a colander out of him from the
near side of the bank. While he debated
with himself he heard a stealthy creeping
along the path, and when he was like to die
from fear and horror he heard words and at
once knew that the creepers were Americans,
for they were both cursing a third to their
heart's content. There is no more heart-
breaking thing than to have to swear at
some one in whispers.
Gopher it was, and the Squarehead, and
the prisoner, who still slept.
"He began to take on and squeak a while
back," said Gopher, "but I hung one on his
chin, and he has held his peace the while
we dragged him around in the weeds by the
slack of his neck."
It seemed that Gopher knew where there
was a machine-gun whose crew knew him,
and it was his mind to crawl along until
they were opposite and then hurl his gas-
mask, which had his name on it, across the
river, leaving the little book on which one
was supposed to write each time he used the
mask, hanging outside. On the book he
would write--
"Throw us a rope, and shoot like --
when you want us to come over."
This then was done. The note was written
as best it could be in the dark and the three
started down-river, dragging the Jerry with
them. They stayed in the wheat, but not
so far in as to get themselves lost, and well
it was that they did, for they passed several
dark, humpy things that they knew were
machine-guns, with their crews lying along-
side in a hole.
Anon they paused, and Gopher crept
down to the edge of the bank and gave a
mighty heave to his gas-mask. They heard
it land.
Shortly thereafter a length of rope
whistled through the air.
A flare went up at this, and much banging
ensued. It died down, only to have the
whole American line leap into a long, con-
tinuous pounding.
"Let's go!" and they were in the water
and scrambling through the reeds on the
other side.
Eager hands dragged them under a little
foot bridge. Others pulled right lustily
Adventure
on the rope which Gopher had tied around
the prisoner and brought him over, a little
damp but not spoiled. A group of officers
arrived, bringing a doctor. Excitement,
hurried whispering, cigarets, hand-shaking,
clapping on the back, feeling of great pride
by the patrol, visions of the D. S. C.
"When," said the doctor, who was kneel-
ing over the prisoner, "was this man shot?"
"He was not shot," said Gopher. "I
smote him as to the jaw."
"Not so," said the medico, and he
pointed to the blouse which he had
taken off, all soaked with blood, and
then to a small hole just over the prisoner's
collar-bone.
"It is in my mind that this Hun was shot
earlier in the evening and laid aside to cool,
for his wound has been dressed by unskilful
hands. Now whether that long ridge-run-
ning Tar Heel really heard him squeak or
thought he did is not material, for it is very
certain that he has been plugged through
the lungs, and has been dead some time, for
he is quite cold."
Whereat the survivors of the patrol, being
but children of a larger growth after all,
wept bitterly.
THE MEN WHO WOULDN'T BE LED
by Wm. L. Mallabar
CHARLIE got his in a barroom scrap
Somewhere north of the Line;
Tom was doped on the Barbary Coast;
Jack was crushed in a mine.
There isn't one of the old gang left
But me--and I'm nearly dead;
The last of the crew--the crowd I knew,
The men who wouldn't be led.
We're not so bad when you figure us out;
We played the game pretty square.
We always shared the good--and the bad,
And treated the worst of them fair.
It was just a kink in our brains, I guess,
That made us hate home and a bed;
We had to get out and travel about,
The men who wouldn't be led.
We have left our bones on the desert plains
And up on the Yukon Trail.
We have faced big odds, laughed at men and gods,
But you never saw one of us quail.
To us a flag is only a rag,
But we fought for the hand that fed;
For the Game--won or lost; no count of the cost,
The men who wouldn't be led.
Up on a trestle or down in a mine,
On the veld--in the hills--through the snow,
We have followed our choosings, a will-o'-wisp fire;
All we knew was--it forced us to go.
And now I am going--that last shot was straight;
No name--"Unidentified Dead;"
Oh, the tales that we'll tell when we gather in hell--
The men who wouldn't be led.

HAR d' y'u come frum?"
An un com pi im en tary empha-
sis distinguished the use of the
personal pronoun. Ed Elsware,
the speaker, was a huge deep-chested man
of the pioneer type whose muscles bulged
conspicuously beneath his dirty khaki
clothes. The queries he addressed to the
newcomers were short and pointed. He was
looking over their physical qualifications
prior to assigning them to their jobs.
"New York," replied Bob Kingdon whose
apparel, though now soiled and travel-
stained, bespoke the man of culture.
"N' Yawk, hey?" commented Elsware
with an unenthusiastic grunt. "I hed
some N' Yawk fellers on th' job oncet or
twicet, but they didn't stay long. I never
yit seed one of 'em thet was willin' t' shake
han's wi' hard work."
"I'll do the best I can," was the reassuring
reply of Kingdon, who nevertheless had a
guilty consciousness that his acquaintance-
ship with hard work was likewise likely to
prove both short and uncongenial.
"Put this feller down fur th' rock cut,"
directed Elsware sourly to the camp clerk.
"We'll try 'im out thar."
Kingdon and hard work soon became
acquainted. High above him the jaws of a
deep rock-cut opened wide toward the
scorching sky. Below and about him
stretched piles of blasted rock newly torn by
an explosion from the face of a granite hill

through which the men were cutting.
Around him two-score sweating bodies
strained at their toil. They broke up the
huge pieces of blasted rock with heavy
sledges and loaded the fragments upon
dump cars preparatory to being drawn
away and dumped into the "fill."
At intervals upon hearing the sharp
warning, "Fire! Fire!" the workers would
leap for shelter behind jutting ledges of rock
while the dynamiter "bulldozed" a big
boulder. This, having been split into sec-
tions by the charge, would be pounced upon
by the returning workmen and smashed
by the sledges into pieces small enough to
handle. The hot air was filled with eter-
nally-circling black flies, the steady clink of
hand-drills biting their way slowly through
hard granite and the ring of steel on steel as
the husky drillmen drove home their heavy
blows. Sweat was running into Kingdon's
eyes; black flies were persistently lodging
in his eyes and nose and ears; his soft hands
were cut and blistered from handling jagged
pieces of rock; his back was aching. Alto-
gether he felt in no mood for manual toil.
"I wonder how Dante came to overlook
this?" he muttered. "This must be the
latest style in hells."
The New Yorker's musings were swept"
suddenly and rudely out of his mind, how-
ever, by the burly foreman of the rock cut
who thrust a ten-pound hammer into his
reluctant hands.
8o
Adventure
"Hi, young feller!" he bawled threaten-
ingly. "Take this sledge an' git busy!"
Kingdon shamelessly spat upon his
blistered palms and began trying to wield
the heavy tool. Each time the hammer
struck its hard target a fresh shock was
registered on his tortured spine. Whenever
he would pause in his efforts and seek to
straighten the kinks out of his aching back,
he seemed to see the foreman's keen glance
fastened ominously on him. When the
gang knocked off work Kingdon walked
dejectedly to the bunk-house trying to de-
cide whether he was a hero, martyr or
plain fool. •
Night and repose brought a stiffening
of the muscles. Morning found him
scarcely more competent than a cripple.
Nevertheless he went unfalteringly to the
cut, picked up the heavy hammer and began
a second day's torture between the grim
rock walls. The minutes crawled like
snails across the long day. The inexorable
sun from a cloudless stronghold threw
vertical mid-Summer shafts upon the toiling
forms beneath, superheating the still air
that was filled with black flies and rock-dust
and the fumes of frequent blasts. Kingdon
strove manfully to perform the unaccus-
tomed labor; but he could not help realizing
that toward him continually the suspicious
gaze of the foreman was being cast. At
nightfall after he had eaten his"supper he
was suddenly confronted by the huge bulk of
the walking boss.
"N' Yawk," demanded the latter dis-
gustedly. "Y'u hain't never worked on a
railroad--hev y'u?"
"No, to tell you the truth, I haven't,"
was the New Yorker's ready and candid
response.
"Wal," continued Elsware sarcastically,
"Th' foreman tells me y'u ain't got no guts
fer th' rock--termorrer y'u're a-goin' in
th' sand-cut."
Morning found Kingdon shoveling sand
with the sand-gang. The job, which con-
sisted of digging through a hill and loading
the sand upon dump-cars, proved to be
somewhat easier than the slavery of the
rock-cut. Unfortunately, however, no
blasting went on in the sand cut. Conse-
quently there were no pauses in the labor.
The shoveling was continuous. Ten hours
a day the routine was stoop and shovel,
swat black flies, stoop and shovel. The
monotony was intolerable.
"Us blokes 'as got a - good boss,
Yank," confided a fellow shoveler to
Kingdon. " 'E don't s'y nothink hat all."
That this was very true the New Yorker
soon discovered; but, while the foreman of
the sand cut didn't "say anything," never-
theless his eyes proved to be even busier
than those of the rock foreman had been.
All day long he maintained an attitude of
silent surveillance, literally looking down
the men's collars and never even consider-
ately walking away for a minute to give
them a chance to straighten their backs.
All day Kingdon stooped and shoveled,
swatted black flies, stooped and shoveled.
He feared that he was beginning to contract
curvature of the spine. All day long the
foreman's eyes seemed to be drilling holes
in his shirt collar; so he kept on stooping
and swatting and shoveling. Gradually
also there grew upon him an unaccountable
tendency to scratch. He had heard some of
the men complaining of sand-fleas in their
blankets and therefore concluded that a
few of these pests had wormed their way
beneath his clothes. Nevertheless--to sat-
isfy himself upon this point, which op-
pressed him with an increasing uneasiness--
after working hours he went to a secluded
spot in the forest and examined his under-
clothing.
"Fleas!" he muttered in amazement.
"If these be fleas, where are their wings?"
Suddenly the full horror of his plight
burst upon him. With a shudder he ran
to the office and had his account charged
with new underclothes. These he took,
together with soap and towel, to a tiny
lake that lay within gunshot of the camp.
"Good ----!" he groaned. "Yale alum-
nus, member of the exclusive Yorkville
Club and--getting lousy on a railroad job!"

"Drive a dump car, you mean?"
"Roight, O, mytey."
"Well, to tell you the truth, cockney, I've
never driven a horse in my life. I'm game
to try it, though. Can't be much about it
to learn. I've often seen cabbies and coach-
men do it."
"Bli' me, Yank, if you haren't a funny un!
Cawn't you do nothink hat all?"
"Lord, no, cockney," grinned Kingdon.
"I've just come out of a blasted college."
The Londoner stared, scratching his
head, almost incredulous.
"-Ow did you 'appen to come hup to
this blinkin' place, Yank?" •
"Got broke in Montreal. I wired the
dad for money to get back, but he turned
me down. Served me right. Now I've
got to earn money to get back."
On the following morning Kingdon went
early to the stable and stepped gingerly
between the rows of breakfasting and
stamping beasts until he located the
stableman.
"Elsware told me to take out a horse," he
announced briefly.
"Wal, y'u'll hev t' take ol' "Dinnymite"
thar--he's th' only hoss thet ain't a-workin'.
"Dynamite!" echoed the New Yorker
curiously. "What a name!"
"Thet name jist suits 'im, young feller.
He's lybel t' go off any time. Y'u got t'
handle 'im wi' care."
"I'll be kind to him," promised Kingdon
hastily.
The stableman, choking a queer sound
back into his throat, well-nigh swallowed his
cud ' of tobacco. After Dynamite had
broken his fast the harness was thrown upon
his back and he was led forth. The animal
proved to be coal-black excepting his eyes,
which glowed with a strange red fire.
"Giddap!" commanded Kingdon firmly
after the manner of the city hack drivers,
at the same time gently slapping the horse's
flanks with the reins. Dynamite giddaped,
at the same time pulling his driver after
him at headlong speed. He giddapped
all the way to the rock-cut. Kingdon,
with the reins wound firmly about his hands,
served merely as a sort of rudder to steer
the speedy beast whose broad flanks, for-
tunately for the man behind them, broke
down or swept aside the impeding forest
undergrowths.
"Well, he's obedient, anyway," gasped
Kingdon, trying to regain his breath and
picking the thorns and brambles out of his
clothes. The fiery steed had paused at the
mouth of the cut--head held proudly high
and ruby eyes flashing--awaiting further
orders.
"Hook y'ur hoss on t' this here kyar,
young feller," directed the foreman sharply.
"Then go git y'ur load."
Kingdon began maneuvering with Dyna-
mite's steering-gear in an effort to haul
his stern tackle to within hooking distance
of the dump car. Dynamite's hoofs stac-
catoed nervously on the tow-path.
"Be keerful o' thet hoss, now," warned
the foreman harshly. "He's been a-standin'
in th' stable too long."
"Giddap, Dynamite," said Kingdon cau-
tiously.
A hundred yards down the track was a
crossover. This evidently did not enter
into the calculations of Dynamite, whose
private ideas on railroading seemed to
counsel him to proceed via the most direct
routes and ahead of schedule time.
"Hang on t' thet hoss!" yelled the fore-
man frantically.
That was precisely' what Kingdon was
doing; but his one hundred and seventy
pounds' weight made little difference to
Dynamite, who utterly ignored the New
Yorker's frantic signals to starboard his
Adventure
helm and continued his fleet course un-
swervingly along the tow-path. The car
left the rails at the crossover and landed
across the ties, bringing the plunging horse
suddenly back upon his haunches.
"Y'u blasted ijit! Didn't I tell y'u t'
hang on t' th' hoss?" shouted the foreman
wrathfully. "Now my men's got t' lose
time a-gittin' y'ur kyar back on th' rails
Kingdon's eyes flashed. A slow rage
was fermenting in his bosom, but he held
his peace. Half a dozen workmen straggled
leisurely over to the crossover and hoisted
the dump-car back upon the rails.
"Now give this feller a load," directed
the foreman angrily. "Give 'im a-big
load, too--a load thet'll take some o' th'
hell'ry outen thet black devil, Dinnymite!"
Dynamite's sable hide, however, har-
bored much more "hell'ry" than the fore-
man was aware of. The stout collar
strained against his broad chest as he
bowed his neck and tugged obediently at
the burden. The heavy load of rock began
to move along the rails with gradually in-
creasing speed. The rails led directly out
to the crest of the advancing wall of crushed
rock that was being thrown across the
neighboring valley. This crest was called
the "dump." The terminating rails pro-
jected a few inches beyond the edge of the
dump and across their ends was bolted a
piece of heavy timber called the "bumper."
The modus opercmdi was as follows.
A dump-car was driven at a moderate
rate of speed to within a few yards of this
bumper. The horse would then be pulled
sharply about, automatically unhooking the
whiffletree chain from the car. The car
would then proceed at its own momentum
until it struck the bumper, the force of
such impact operating the mechanism
that dumped the load. The horse would
then be rehooked to the dumped car and
the process repeated.
Dynamite was quite familiar with the
details of this operation--much more so,
in fact, than was his driver. Whether the
powerful black had it in mind to show off
his capabilities before his new attendant or
whether his act was inspired by a pure love
of deviltry, was a matter of individual
opinion. At any rate, notwithstanding
Kingdon's desperate attempts at control,
the horse assumed complete charge of the
proceedings. He pulled the heavily loaded
car toward the dump at full speed. The
dismayed New Yorker could hear the fore-
man's voice filling the air with shouts and
curses behind him, but all the power of his
arms could not swerve Dynamite from his
self-willed course. Ten yards from the
dump the horse turned sharply about and
unhooked himself with practised ease.
The speeding car struck hard against the
bumper and instantly dumped its contents.
Then, with its momentum still urging it on,
it turned completely over the obstacle and
crashed down the side of the hill of rock in a
series of somersaults until it landed bottom
up in the valley a hundred feet below.
Kingdon stood holding the reins with pal-
sied hands until Dynamite, scenting his
driver's confusion and helplessness, took
advantage of the situation by galloping
away to freedom. The whiffletree, still
attached to the traces, caught against a
stump and snapped in twain as the powerful
beast crashed his way through the forest.
Kingdon's ruin was complete. The gang
from the rock cut came running excitedly
out to the dump. Curses and epithets
popped from the foreman's mouth like
sparks from an anvil. The New Yorker's
face paled and his hands clenched as he
faced the foreman's opprobrious attack.
"Even a worm will do it," he muttered.
"-y'u! W'at y'u drivin' at?" howled
the foreman, failing to understand the
danger signal.
"You!"
The New Yorker struck. A moment
later his persecutor was lying on his back on
the tow-path. Blood was flowing from his
nose. The grimy crowd of workmen stood
silent, gaping at the strange man from the
big city who had actually had the audacity
to strike a railroad gang foreman!
Kingdon quickly left the amazed knot
of laborers clustering about their fallen
slave-driver. He made his way angrily
back to the bunk-house. It was there, an
hour later, that Elsware found him.
"Git outen th' camp, y'u-!" bellowed
the walking boss. "Thar hain't no money
a-comin't' y'u! Git back t' N' Yawk, whar
th' likes o' y'u belongs! Ef we counted 011
fellers like y'u t' build this here railroad,
we'd never git it done in a million years!"
Elsware's surly visage contracted into a
glare of mingled ferocity and contempt.
He towered above the New Yorker, moun-
tainous and threatening. Kingdon knew
N' Yawk and Elsware
that even one clumsy hug from this big
hulk of a man would have been almost as
deadly as- that of a grizzly bear, but some-
how the New Yorker was not afraid.
"You great big ignoramus!" he roared
desperately. "You don't know one thing
in this world but rough stuff! You might
be king out in these jungles, and know it
all--but if I only had you in New
York--"
Half an hour afterward Kingdon was
striding swiftly along the trail toward the
south. Between him and the end of the
steel lay sixty miles of forest and granite
hills and muskeg. From the end of the
steel it was still seven hundred miles to
New York. He hadn't so much as a cent
in his pocket.
"Sent adrift into the wilderness," he
muttered grimly, "because I don't know
how to build a blasted railroad!" 1

THE drowsy aftermath of carouse
was written unmistakably over this
man's gigantic person. He was
standing in the center of a throng--standing
stock still, as if anchored to the pavement.
The massive head had sagged down into the
shirt collar. The great shoulders were
canted sidewise like a listed ship. It seemed
almost as if the giant were trying to person-
ate the leaning tower of Pisa. The awe-
struck spectators had ringed themselves
in a wide circle about the unusual spectacle
•--wide, because they evidently feared that
at any moment the tower-like legs might
give way.
"Teched."
The monosyllable rumbled suddenly and
sleepily out of the big man's mouth like a
distant growl from a sleeping volcano. A
set of massive, calloused fingers began list-
lessly and apparently half-consciously stray-
ing in and out of his various pockets.
"He's been robbed," came in hoarsely
whispered accents of understanding from
several of the bystanders.
A vigilant policeman hove in sight,
drawing the legal bludgeon from it^ leathern
scabbard. An imperative flourish of this
weapon opened a lane through the fast-
collecting crowd. Expectantly the on-
lookers looked from the center of attraction
to the officer. He, however, scratched his
head in pardonable perplexity. The job of
salvaging such a huge derelict bade fair to
be an unenviable one. Moreover, he was
not exactly disturbing the peace. In fact
he seemed, on the other hand, to be the
injured party in some shady transaction.
This officer, who liked an occasional tot
himself, was loath to add to the big man's
misfortunes by making him a target of
legal discipline. However, he was un-
deniably obstructing traffic. Some sort of
action therefore became immediately neces-
sary.
"What's your name? Where do you
live?" came out of the policeman in a
friendly growl.
"Teched," grunted the stricken giant
dismally.
The policeman repeated the query, which
elicited merely a dolorous repetition of the
barbarous word. A strong liquory aura
invested the victim's person.
"Huh! Charged up to the neck. Don't
even know your own name, eh?" sum-
marized the Law disgustedly. "Don't any-
body know who this human elephant is?"
He looked appealingly about the circle
of grinning countenances--sailors, lumber-
jacks, trappers, railroad laborers--because
Craig Street at that time was a.sort of little
Bowery where the rough-and-ready tribes
were accustomed to disport themselves
while in Montreal. It was shortly after
eleven o'clock at night. Montreal's curfew
for the bibulous rings at that hour. Pre-
cisely then the saloons' doors are slammed
and locked, the faucets are turned off and
the disciples of Bacchus, with such cargo
aboard as they have been able to acquire,
find themselves in the cold and unin-
spiring street. This was undoubtedly the
reason for the tipsy big man's appearance on
Craig Street. Some saloon lounger had
got his money--he had subsequently been
thrust into the street. Too bad. The
Law sighed. He would have the job of
his life to haul such a monster to the nearest
call box.
Just at that moment, when the officer
was about to take a grip on his hesitation
and act in accordance with the letter of the
law--a young man pushed his way smil-
ingly forward.
"Sh!" he whispered. "It's Elsware, the
big railroader. I know him. He's con-
siderably under the weather, eh?"
Human nature is often a sheepy thing.
The officer had never heard of Elsware, but
the well-bred-looking young man's cautious
implication generated the idea that here was
Adventure
a "big" man of affairs whose foibles must
occasionally be winked at. The policeman
smiled knowingly.
"I'll take him home," volunteered the
stranger. "Wait till I call a cab."
"Cab?" grinned the officer skeptically.
"Why not a truck?"
Eventually, however, they stowed Els-
ware's ponderous frame away in a hack--
the task being accomplished through the
combined efforts of the Law, the affable
young stranger and the hack driver. The
curious crowd began disappointedly dwind-
ling into the night. The officer, heaving a
sigh of relief, sheathed his bludgeon and
continued his interrupted saunter through
Montreal's Tenderloin. The young stranger
climbed to the box and sat beside the
driver; after which the hack proceeded east
through Craig Street. Elsware sat behind
in solitary and maudlin majesty, his chin
drooping indolently upon his breast.
"Teched," he rumbled faintly.
IN AND about the labyrinth of the
great Grand Central Terminal; from
lower level to upper level; from upper
level back to lower level; into the subway's
mouth that growled constant subten-anean
thunders; back through the interminable
network of corridors and into the vast
waiting-room--slowly, dazedly, dejectedly,
a conspicuous figure of a man was making
his way. He was a colossal specimen of
manhood, standing easily six feet four
inches in his heavy shoes. His eyes, how-
ever, held such a look of dismay as accorded
ill with his formidable mold. At intervals
his hands fumbled nervously in his pockets
as if loath to abandon a search for some-
thing no longer there. His demeanor was
so completely indicative of bewilderment
that at last he was accosted by a lynx-
eyed little man who had been observing
him for some time.
"Pardon me, have you lost something,
sir?"
The giant turned sad and anxious eyes
upon the questioner.
"Reckon I hev, young feller--reckon I'm
all lost--me an' ev'rythin' I got."
"How's that? Don't you even know
where you are?"
"I dunno nuthin 'bout m' self. Whar am
I at?"
"You're in the Grand Central Station,"
replied the plain-clothes man, beginning to
suspect that he had located a case of am-
nesia.
"I knowed I wuz in a station, all right,
cuz some fellers put me offen a train this
mornin'," was the naive reply. "But
w'at d' y'u call this here place?"
"The name of the city, you mean?
Why, New York, of course."
"N' Yawk!"
The words shot out of the big fellow's
mouth like the bang of a siege gun. A new
terror leaped into his haggard eyes.
"How fur's it t' Muntreeyawl?" he
gasped.
"Between four and five hundred miles."
Something like the last sigh of the dying
Cyclops came out of the lost man's mouth.
"Who are you, and where do you come
from?" persisted the detective.
"I'm frum th' North--name's Ed Els-
war'--I come t' Muntreeyawl fer a couple o'
days' good time. Yistiddy--leastaways I
think it wuz yistiddy--I hed two hundred
dollars wi' me. As fur's I kin mind w'at
happened, some fellers teched me while I
wuz a-tryin' t' git hum. I don't mind
nuthin' arter thet till I got put offen th'
train this mornin'. An' now here I be---in
N' Yawk!"
The plain clothes man smiled under-
standingly. He had already lost interest
in the case, which had turned out to be
nothing more exciting than the common or
Barleycorn variety of amnesia.
"I guess you'd better get the air," he
said meaningly.
"Jist w'at I'm a-tryin' t' do, mister,"
groaned Elsware, "but durn me ef I kin git
outen this tarnation place nohow!"
The sleuth laughingly piloted the big
man to the main entrance and at last saw
him swallowed up in the swirl of traffic on
Forty-second Street.
"Some hick!" he muttered.
Elsware breasted the human billows as
far as Fifth Avenue, pausing in consterna-
tion at the moving wall of vehicles that
barred his further progress. The traffic
policeman suddenly lifted his hand and,
presto! A lane was miraculously provided
through which the ponderous railroader
nervously thrust his way. At Times Square
he stopped in astonishment, gaping at
great buildings that thrust themselves
fearlessly skyward; looking in awe at the
tens of thousands of people who streamed
Heedlessly along in six directions; trembling
N' Yawk and Elsware
at the frequent underground roarings that
poured upward through the subway grat-
ings beneath his feet. As he wandered
aimlessly about the city he saw railroads
in every direction. There were railroads
through the thoroughfares, railroads in the
air over his head and railroads under his
feet.
Elsware walked along the gayest prome-
nade in the world without receiving a sign
of recognition or a glance of friendliness
from a single one of all the thousands that
passed him by. Curious looks there were
aplenty, drawn naturally in his direction
by his unusual size. But alas! He en-
countered never a welcoming grin or a
cheery "Bon jour!" or a "Howdy!"
When night at last overtook him--the
weird, metropolitan night with its hundreds
of thousands of lights stabbing the darkness
--Elsware was sitting in Herald Square
listening dejectedly to the thunder of the
subways, watching with awed eyes the
racing "L" express trains and marveling
at the never-ceasing clang and hum of the
trolleys.
"Dang me," he sighed, "ef they hain't
more railroads in this here N' Yawk than
they is in th' hull dang Province of Quee-
bec!"
The rugged railroad pioneer felt like an
ant with a sudden conception of the uni-
verse. Out in his own wilderness he was
king, but here, in this bedlam of sound and
scene and motion, where they built up to
the sky and down, for all he knew, to the
infernal places; where all his northern im-
portance and cocksureness seemed somehow
to have been cast by the board--why, he
was nothing more than a drifting hulk of a
man headed irresistably for the rocks.
Where would he sleep? His huge organ-
ism was already clamoring for food. How
could he eat? His brain was still hazy
from debauch and practical ideas for his
relief offered themselves very slowly. How
could he get back to the job? He hadn't
even the price of a telegram to his em-
ployers so that he migh ask for a loan of
money. How did men go about these
things when they had neither money nor
friends and were adrift in the great wilder-
ness of New York?
Elsware groaned. At that moment a
well-dressed young man, nonchalantly puf-
fing a cigaret after the manner of his kind,
seated himself upon the bench beside the
despondent derelict.
"Elsware," he said evenly, "about four
months ago you chased me out of your
camp--without a nickel--because I didn't
know anything about building a railroad.
How I ever got back to the steel is a night-
mare--1" don't remember half what I suf-
fered on the way. At last, when I was
nearly all in, I landed a job in the chief
constructing engineer's office at the end of
the steel. Saved six hundred dollars in four
months. So you see, Elsware, I know some-
thing about building a railroad after all.
"I was on my way to New York when I
saw you last night on Craig Street. I'll say
you needed a friend. I took you away
from a cop, finally got you to the station,
hired a porter and the cabby to help me
hoist you into the smoker, shoved a ticket
into your hat-band and let you snooze.
I've been tagging you around all day, en-
joying myself."
"N' Yawk!" exclaimed the unfortunate
railroader, with a glance of piteous appeal
from his haggard eyes. "Y'u be n't a-goin(
t' git even wi' me now, fer w'at I done t'
y'u--be y'u, N' Yawk? Hain't I got 'nough
trouble now. N' Yawk?"
Kingdon laughed, throwing away his
cigaret and slapping Elsware jovially upon
the shoulder.
"Why, you great big grampus. I've got
nothing against you! The experience did
me good. I learned lots that I never could
have learned in college. But here's the
idea--I want you to get the other fellow's
point of view. I learned some things in
your country, where men know how to buiid
railroads and things with their hands; but
now I'm going to show you around a town--
and we'll put some paint on it, too--where
they teach people to build railroads and
things with their heads"

desk calendar. The first of the month was
eleven days off. Much could happen in
eleven days, including the possibility that
she would be able to induce the Great Dane
to change his mind again.
"All right. Thanks. I'm sorry we've
bothered you and--and I'll try not to ask
any more questions."
"That will help," Parker said with all
Adventure
the agreeable effect of a straight right be-
tween the eyes. "Please ask Malkett to
come in--no, don't bother, I'll-"
"It's all right," Catherine interposed
sweetly. "I'm only too glad to help, even
if it's simply as an office girl."
Catherine halted with her fingers on the
knob of the screen door.
"Thank you," she said gratefully. "That
assures me that you think I'm almost grown
up." Then softly, "Good night, Commis-
sioner."
Catherine went out leaving Parker to dis-
color the atmosphere in the library as
savagely as he pleased, and with a doubtful
smile of triumph hugging the corners of
her mouth, she searched for Malkett.
Captain Walton and he had joined
Hogmanay and Margaret, but Fran was
standing beside the rail looking up-river.
Catherine did not see her at first, but, hav-
ing delivered the Great Dane's message to
Malkett, she looked about, then moved
across the deck.
Fran's arm now lay along the rail and her
forehead rested upon it. Apparently she
did not hear Catherine's step until she came
very .near to her, then she lifted her head
sharply and spun about in startled inquiry.
There was also a haunting guilt in her eyes
that Catherine did not see clearly enough to
enable her to detect it.
"What's up?" Fran demanded impa-
tiently.
"Nothing," quietly. "Got a headache?"
"One of the buzzing kind," Fran returned
and suddenly decided to be pleasant about
it. "Bees and bees and bees. It'll be gone
in the morning. What did Parker have to
say. to you? Ponderous words of eternal
devotion, I suppose, in the guise of official
business?"
"No," sourly. "We're to get out by the
first."
"And he's been making sneaky goo-goo
eyes at you all day!"
"Has he? I hadn't noticed. Don't you
think you'd better toddle to bed?"
And Catherine took a gentle but firm hold
of Fran's wrist.
"Rot!" Fran snatched her wrist out
of Catherine's grasp with a sharp jerk.
"You're not going to make an interesting
pathological study out of me. Go over there
and take MacGregor's temperature. If he
had a clinical thermometer under his tongue
this minute, the picture would be complete."
Catherine looked and smiled warmly.
Fran laughed, and the sound struck a new
note in her life, a note even Catherine did
not suspect or understand. Also, Fran did
not have a headache, nor, just then, was
she giving a great deal of thought to her eyes.
"Are you really going to leave on the
first?" she asked and seemed a little anxious.
"Not if I can help it."
"Then there's nothing to worry about,"
Fran declared confidently, and drew a long,
silent breath of relief.
NEXT morning, Catherine received
another cable from her mother,
and cable-like, it did not squander
words. Therefore Catherine's anxiety for
the sort of action that was wholly visible
and understandable increased feverishly
with every hour.
She met the Great Dane's morning-after
tendency to be pleasant with a saccharine
humility that was somewhat thin and
ragged in spots; and when Parker or Mal-
kett were not looking, she became suddenly
attentive to Arthur Garriman Bark.
Obviously Bark did not like the questions
she asked. He appeared to be afraid of
them, and in the evening, when Catherine
told him blandly that she expected Char-
teris to visit the yacht "in an hour or so,"
Arthur's confusion became most manifest.
Shortly after nine o'clock he disappeared.
In the interval, Catherine held a long and
persuasive conversation with Andy Gra-
ham, the chief engineer. Andy said "No"
and shook his head most of the time, but
finally he nodded in a slow cautious way
that did not commit him too much.
The Gray Charteris
And shortly before ten o'clock Catherine
announced that she was going over to
Hogmanay's to talk over and have him
send the reply to her mother's cable.
Oddly enough, she did not ask Fran to
accompany her, and Andy Graham was in
charge of the Bonny's launch when she
reached the foot of the companion ladder.
The launch started off in the direction
of Marsden& Co.'s wharf; then, about half-
way, swerved sharply in the pitch black
dark and shot up-river.
CHAPTER XVII
ABDUCTION
IN THE flickering light of a small kerosene
lamp, Charteris squatted upon his little
pile of blankets in his corner of Grandison's
erstwhile office, and smoked and talked
sonorously to Abado, who paced up and
down in impatient restlessness, hurling an
occasional staccato curse at Agwala's an-
cestry.
Abado's state of mind was chaotic. Not
because, for the time being, he was not
perfectly safe; simply that Charteris put
an awkward and galling restraint upon his
impulse to do rather than to wait.
In the bush round about were many eyes
that watched every moment of the day and
night. They belonged to Abado's sons or
his hirelings and at the first hint of danger,
the Sobo slithered to cover by the simple
process of vanishing into the bush.
When the danger departed, he returned
to the shelter of the gray man's protection,
which was as complete as it was beneficent.
Neither the government nor Agwala seemed
at all eager to interfere with him.
Nevertheless, Abado was not happy,
despite the promises Charteris was at that
moment making; and when Ogulo suddenly
projected himself into the room with the
rather tiresome announcement -- "Gov'-
ment come"---Abado whined like a child
whose patience with authority is on the
verge of exhaustion.
"Go to back beach bush!" Charteris
ordered sharply. "We go Dowadda when
gov'ment go 'way."
Abado muttered under his breath, but
obediently vanished like a wraith, and Ogulo
followed him down the galley stairs.
Charteris did not leave his corner.
Quickly dropping his mosquito curtain, and
composing himself as comfortably as possi-
ble behind it, he gave every appearance of
having gone off to sleep.
His position furnished him the advantage
of seeing without being seen and when foot-
steps sounded on the stairs, he knew that
Malkett or Parker, or whoever it was, had
not come alone.
And then Charteris smiled a wisp-like
smile that almost became a laugh.
"Anybuddy at home?" Andy Graham
queried doubtfully from the doorway.
Catherine was directly behind him look-
ing inquiringly over his shoulder, and her
expression was that of one who is trying to
be just politely interested in waiting for the
performance to begin. She was thankful,
however, that she wore skirts. Otherwise,
her tell-tale knees might have told a more
nervous story.
Charteris yawned audibly.
"What's that? Who's there?"
And then before any one could answer, he
thrust back the mosquito curtains and
looked out.
"Oh, that you Graham? And Miss
Morrison!"
He scrambled to his feet, rubbing his eyes.
"I must have dozed off. This is splendid
of you. A most unexpected pleasure. If
I had known it was coming off, I should cer-
tainly have become possessed of a chair.
May I, however, invite you to squat?
Those blankets--but perhaps you would
rather stand?"
Catherine laughed at the queer look of
horror on Andy Graham's face.
"No, I'll squat," she decided, and
promptly became enthroned in Charteris'
corner. "But what are you going to do if I
use up all of the blankets?"
"Squat lower and look worshipful.
What's wrong, Graham? Where are you
going?"
"I'll go and sit on the stairs," Andy ad-
vised, moving toward the door. "Ye'll find
me there if ye want me."
Charteris looked pointedly at Catherine
as Andy went out, then seated himself on
the floor.
"He didn't think of that all by himself,
did he?" he asked mildly.
"No--not altogether."
"Then this isn't a social call?"
"Ladies do not pay social calls after ten
o'clock at night. Not even on the Benin
River."
Adventure
"Quite true. They don't. Er--if I may
smoke, there's a tin of cigarets almost at
your elbow. Will you be so good as to cb uck
them over to me, please? Also the matches.
But be careful you don't cut yourself on
that knife."
The Hausa dagger Etaji had unwillingly
left behind him, was some distance from the
cigarets. Catherine probably would not
have noticed it if Charteris had not made
known its existence.
Whether he knew this or not, or whether
he was simply taking a roundabout method
to put a weapon into bter hand if she
thought, even vaguely, that she needed the
comforting assurance of a ready defense,
Catherine did not know. Her color height-
ened just a little, however, as she "chucked"
the cigarets and matches at her host. Then
she picked up the knife.
"It's an ugly thing," she commented.
"Horribly business like."
"It .wasn't made for sharpening pencils,"
Charteris admitted, contentedly exhaling
cigaret smoke. "You may have it as a me-
mento of this frankly improper call. I'm
sure its former owner would be glad to
think it was in your possession."
"Thanks. I think I'd like to have it.
Who did you take it from? Some one who
tried to use it properly?"
Charteris glanced toward the door and
beyond it into the fire-fly-dotted blackness
toward the river. He did not seem to think
that Catherine's question required an
answer.
"What did you come to see me about?"
he asked suddenly, but Catherine was in no
wise flustered by it.
"Because I've become conviced that you
know a great deal more about my father's
death than you pretend to," she said with
unfaltering directness.
"Bark is afraid of you," Catherine went
on steadily, "and when Agwala came to the
yacht the other day he told Mr. Parker, in
my presence, that you were interfering, or
likely to interfere with justice."
"Great Scott!"
Catherine studied his astonishment, try-
ing to find a flaw in it. Then, quietly,
deliberately, measuring each word, she
added--
"He said, in short, that you were--shel-
tering Abado."
Charteris threw his head back and
laughed. Even his eyes joined in. Appar-
ently the accusation was too funny for
words. Then, when he found himself able
to be serious again, he asked.
"Sure you are not mixing me up with
some one else?"
Catherine had a sinking feeling. Even
though she heard Andy Graham cough
every now and then, she felt terribly alone--
futile--circling about an impenetrable wall
with a hair-pin for a battering-ram.
"You are the 'gray man' aren't you?" she
'asked, as if there might be some doubt
about it.
"I'm gray enough if that constitutes
identification."
"Then Agwala meant you. Also, when
Bark came Up here the other evening and
reported you absent, I'm sure he knew you
were not here or else he would not have
come up."
Charteris smiled unbelievingly.
"What on earth makes you think that?"
"It isn't my thought exactly. Fran--
Miss Goddard, you know--put it into my
head. Said she had had an ocular demon-
stration of Bark's fear of you. So to-day
I watched him, quizzed him, frankly both-
ered him about you and became convinced
that Fran was right. The man actually
jumped when I told him that I expected you
to call this evening, and he at once left the
Bonny for an unknown destination."
Again Charteris laughed.
"That wasn't quite fair. What, might I
ask, did Parker say when Agwala accused
me of throwing a monkey wrench into the
law's machinery."
"Oh, he just told him he was talking
rubbish, or something to that effect. But
I don't altogether believe it. So I'm
here."
"I see," quietly and flipping his cigaret
through the open door. "Frankly, I did not
expect to see you occupying that corner.
I appreciate the honor keenly. Graham
a trusted confidant of yours?"
Catherine's heightened color was per-
ceptible this time. She glanced quickly
down at the knife in her lap, gingerly fin-
gered the edge of it, then put it aside with
an involuntary shudder.
"I've known Andy for years. And I've
never known him to betray a confidence.
Dad trusted him implicitly, and Dad knew
men."
Charteris nodded.
The Gray Charteris
"No one other than Graham knows you
are here tonight?"
Catherine looked just a little startled.
"Why do you ask that?" she questioned
cautiously, and felt, for the first time, that
she was farther away from the yacht than
she had any right to be.
Charteris picked up the cigaret tin and
the matches and rose. His movements
were leisurely but deliberate.
"Then you'd better get back before any
one finds it out," he said simply. "Be-
cause, of course, there is really nothing I can
do for you."
Catherine stared. Her cheeks flamed.
She felt like a very little girl who was being
sent home because her conduct had not been
good. Her eyes lighted up angrily.
"I'm not a child!" she began, not at all
aware of the impulsiveness of her speech.
"And I didn't go to all the bother of induc-
ing Andy Graham to bring me up here sim-
ply to go away again without coming to
some sort of understanding about your po-
sition in this terrible affair. Malkett, of
the police, agrees with Mr. Parker that
Agwala was talking nonsense. But I
don't."
"No?"
"No, I don't. The government officials--
and Sandy MacGregor, too, for that
matter--know too much about this country
to believe that a white man would shield
a black one in a case of this sort. I don't
know anything about it, so I am not allow-
ing prejudice to interfere with my ideas
about things."
"There is something in that," Charteris
admitted pleasantly. "And I'm afraid I
shall have to talk to Agwala in plain
language for trying to ruin my spotless
reputation. But, before you further im-
peril yours, I shall have to send you home.
You're altogether too desirable to be wan-
defing around in the dark like this."
Catherine's expression declared that she
did not know whether to be angry or sur-
prized or suspicious or all three at once.
So she compromised by laughing softly and
rising lightly to her feet.
"That's just make believe," she decided.
"You want to get rid of me and are trying
to scare me off. I didn't come here alone."
"No. But there is a back door as well as
a front door to this establishment."
Catherine paused. The stillness that
gripped the place had a smothering effect.
There was a queer hint of stifled laughter
in the air. She loitered a few steps nearer
to the door.
"I wish you would be frank with me,"
she said simply, as though his veiled threats
were not worthy of any consideration. "I
have been brutally frank with you because
I think you can help me to--to discover the
man who did it. And I won't leave the
country till I do. I had another cable from
mother this morning, too."
"What does Miss Goddard think about
it?"
"Fran? Oh, she--" Catherine stopped.
"Why is that important? You know per-
fectly well you irritate her simply because
she can't hurt you."
Charteris glanced along the veranda to
where the shadowy outline of Andy Graham
was wrapped in a furious cloud of pipe
smoke. Then he moved out of the doorway
into the room again, giving Catherine an
opportunity to run if she wanted to.
"You forgot the knife. Shall I get it for
you, or would you prefer to get it your-
self?"
Nothing could have been plainer to Cath-
erine than that. The way to the door was
clear, and he gave her permission to possess
herself of the ugly Hausa dagger to make
sure that the way remained clear. Her
color drifted and her mouth became a severe
line. There was something of Hugh Morri-
son in her face then.
She walked suddenly toward Charteris
and there was not the slightest sign of fear
in her eyes. When she halted he could have
touched her with his outstretched hand.
"I've come up here because I believed--
and still believe--that you really know more
about the inner workings of native intrigue
than Malkett and MacGregor and Parker
and all the rest of them put together."
"Thank you."
"And I thought you would be man enough
to help a white woman when she needed
help very badly. You see, I don't believe in
playing with words or facts, nor have I any
intention of getting down on my knees."
"No. Don't do that."
"And I'm not going to be frightened or
driven out of the river one minute sooner
than I want to go."
"I hope not. I like to see the Bonny
lying out in midstream when the sun comes
up. Reminds me of lots of things--includ-
ing cream puffs and white icing cakes."
Adventure
His hands reached out quickly and caught
Catherine's wrists. She gasped, drew back
a step, stopped because she had to--but did
not scream. Charteris knew she was trem-
bling, but her eyes did not show it.
The sound of Andy Graham coughing had
no effect upon the situation except to relieve
the outer darkness a trifle. A moment later
it was blacker and more silent than ever.
Catherine asked with just the suggestion of
a sneer--
"This is my cue to yell, I suppose?"
"Not unless you want to. Frankly, I
don't believe you do want to."
His hands slipped up her arms to her
elbows and Catherine pulled her head back
sharply.
"Don't! This is just cheap dramatics.
Or more trifling. Please let me go."
Charteris' shoulders ceased to lean
against the wall. He drew her a little nearer.
"You know, there's a whole lot to be said
in favor of taking advantage of one's oppor-
tunities. And if you refuse to use the voice
the Lord gave you, what's a mere man to
think? You aren't even restless!"
Catherine tried to draw away from him.
"Rubbish!" she exclaimed disparagingly,
but her voice sounded weak and uncon-
vincing. "This is all bosh! Please let me
go. Don't!"
Charteris' hands had reached-her shoul-
ders in a twinkling and she found, in another
moment, that she was being held very
firmly in his arms, his face a scant few
inches above her own. Yet she did not
scream. She was, in -point of fact, afraid
and ashamed to admit to Andy Graham
that her secret adventure had been a mis-
take.
"You're hurting me," she said quietly,
trying with all her might not to look
frightened while she shrank from the queer,
cold laughing blue of his eyes.
"I'm sorry," softly. "But I understand
that even the nicest ladies like to be knocked
about a bit. In fact, I think they prefer to
be carted off bodily."
His left hand curled about her neck and
slipped over her mouth without a second's
warning, stifling her involuntary cry of fear
so that it was nothing more than a choking
gurgle in her throat.
Before she fully realized that it was possi-
ble that such a thing could happen to her,
Charteris was half way down the rickety
galley stairs and she was being "carted off
bodily" as if she were no more trouble than
an infant.
The arms that held her captive were sure
and strong and without mercy. The hand
that was clapped across her mouth was by
no means gentle. She could not use even
her teeth to bite her voice's way to free-
dom.
So that the experience hurt as well as
outraged, and, going down the galley stairs,
Catherine had a moment 01 two in which to
realize her predicament, because it was
dangerous to struggle then.
At the foot, however, she leaped in Char-
teris' arms like a wild thing; leaped and
kicked and tried to tear her head out of the
clamping grip of his left hand. The result
was simply a tightening of that grip--a
crushing sense of helplessness--a groping
in the dark of unbelief as she gathered her-
self together for another strenuous bid for
freedom.
She could not see very well where they
were going, but presently she heard Char-
teris say softly:
"This is really exciting. Wonder what
poor old Graham will say when he finds it
out. Hope he doesn't take it too much to
he&rt and shoot himself or something like
that."
Again and more furiously this time, Cath-
erine twisted and lunged and tried to tear
his hand from her mouth. The.n, she struck
at him, but her blows fell short and broke
their strength upon his shoulder, hurting
her knuckles more than they did his shoul-
der-blade.
Presently, out of the storm, came Char-
teris' voice smoothly:
"A perfect conclusion to a wonderful
evening. What a pity it isn't real!"
And then he suddenly stood her upon her
feet, saw that she preserved her equilibrium,
and stood off a pace blandly watching her
amazement.
She was standing on the gig-wharf.
CHAPTER XVIII
THE BULGE IN THE SCREEN
"T TOLD you there was a back door,"
Charteris said pleasantly. Then after
a short and heavy pause. "Shall I call
Graham, or would you prefer to make your
own explanations?"
Catherine leaned against the wharf rail
The Gray Charteris
in absolute silence. Her mouth hurt, her
breath came hardly and she was trembling
in the grip of a reaction that was almost as
terrifying as the imprisonment of Charteris's
arms.
Speech was beyond her, but she felt so
inconsequent and so utterly foolish that
nothing at all mattered very much. Had
Charteris laughed at her, perhaps she would
have liked it better. But he was so irritat-
ingly pleasant and sympathetic that even
the incessant hum of mosquitoes about her
ears did not disturb her.
She looked down into the Bonny's launch
that was tied up to the wharf, smothered
a somewhat hysterical sob of anger that
was mixed with an odd kind of disappoint-
ment, then, with a tremendous effort, her
aching body straightened and she said in
a voice that, though it hesitated a little for
want of breath, was almost normal--
"I suppose that was your way of proving
to me that it isn't wise to be too sure of any-
thing or any one?"
"Perhaps. But I'll admit you were a
violent burden. Elsie--that's your sister's
name, isn't it?--would be lighter and more
tractable than you, I imagine?"
Catherine swallowed once or twice and
then decided to ignore his reference to Elsie.
"It was also your way of saying definitely
that you won't take sides with me? That
you would rather I'd go away and not
bother you?"
"Good Lord, no! I'm glad you came and
I hope you'll come back some evening and
stay longer."
And though Catherine gave vent to an
exclamation of impatient unbelief, he actu-
ally meant that. Then, in quiet warning, he
added:
"Better not lean too heavily on that rail.
It may collapse."
Catherine left the rail without a sound,
looked down into the launch again and
stepped on board, denying herself the prof-
fer of any assistance.
"Please ask Andy to come down," she
said in a low, toneless voice.
"Certainly. What shall I say to him?"
"Nothing. I'll tell my own lies."
Charteris excused himself politely, then
walked up the path leaving her to her own
somber reflections.
Her mouth and her throat were dry and,
in a moment or two, whether she would or
not, angry tears sprang into her eyes. She
jabbed at them with a handkerchief,
clenched her hands and bit upon her already
aching Ups with astonishing intensity for
a woman of her accustomed poise and
calm.
It was not often that Catherine Morrison
had occasion to feel cheap and, in these few
minutes, she did not bless the impulse that
had encouraged her to trifle so carelessly
with edged tools. Her anger, however, was
not directed against Charteris. Repeatedly
and without stint, shrinking from the shad-
ows of canoes that whispered and crooned
as they passed her by, she called herself
a fool.
The night that had wrapped her in
a cloak on the way up, was now pitted with
eyes that peered and laughed. Not because
she had come there and had been ridiculed
for her pains, but because she was going
away again so unimportantly and so pain-
fully little desired.
Therefore Catherine writhed and con-
tinued to denounce herself as an impression-
able idiot, who was so mentally unbalanced
as to become maudlinly sentimental over
a man who was little better than a tramp.
Presently Charteris appeared again, chat-
ting most unconcernedly with Andy Gra-
ham who was obviously suspicious of the
Hausa dagger Charteris carried so openly
in his hand.
"You forgot this," Charteris said to
Catherine, bending over to put the weapon
carefully into her grasp.
"Oh--thanks," she acknowledged weakly
when she realized what it was. "I--I'm
sure Elsie will be glad to add it to her col-
lection."
Later, when the silent Andy Graham had
steered the Bonny's launch away from the
little wharf and was heading thankfully
down-stream, Catherine could almost have
enjoyed cutting her tongue out for that
final remark. It sounded so small and weak
afterward.
Charteris, however, did not stop to think
about it. He hurried to the bush at the
back of the beach. Passing the galley
stairs, he whispered to Ogulo the dwarf to
go up and blow out the lamp, then went on
to join Abado who was fuming impatiently
at the entrance to the narrow bush path
that led to the village of Dowadda.
"Wha's matter?" the Sobo complained in
a disgruntled voice. "I wait long time.
What gov'ment man do?"
Adventure
"Shut up," Charteris ordered in an impo-
lite whisper, and then added in belittling
pidgin: "Abado talk all same mosquito.
Mm -- Mm -- Mm -- Mm -- Mm -- all
time. Soon Agwala shut him hands--so--"
Charteris brought the palms of his hands
sharply together to illustrate--"and Abado
shut up plenty too quick. Sof'ly, sof'ly.
Wan!"
Without any further talk he dived into
the bush path and thereafter brushed his
way through the eery, bat- and moth-
haunted darkness with no more concern
than he would have shown in the Strand.
He had evidently traveled the path often
enough to be able to dispense with a lan-
tern.
Abado followed in silence; the sulky
quiet of a disciplined child. He did not
understand the queer gray man's queerer
methods and did not pretend to. And now
that his rage against Agwala had roused him
completely from his suicidal lethargy, he
was beginning to think for himself and to
hunger for action of his own devising.
As in the case of the murder of Morrison,
that action would be subtle only in the
soundlessness of its execution; simply a
question of striking swiftly in the dark be-
fore his enemy had any opportunity to do
likewise to him.
And, in truth, Abado was frankly out for
blood. Every nerve and sinew of him cried
out for the kind of vengeance that his hands
could feel and his eyes could gloat over.
There was nothing fine about his vision.
His mercy would be the mercy of a wounded
bush cat, and if it were possible that he
could see Agwala's fat body die slowly, inch
by inch, or pound by pound, he would con-
sider that all of life had been well worth the
trouble just for the reward of that single
evening.
The village of Dowadda did not promise
anything to him. It's chief was a small oil-
trader named Roku, who, from Abado's
viewpoint, would sell himself to the highest
bidder.
Why Charteris put faith in men whose
canoes and wives were few, Abado could not
understand. It would not have startled the
Sobo if, in the interval since the sun had
gone down, the village of Dowadda had
become a death trap, bought and paid for
by Agwala.
Suddenly Abado heard the light scuff of
Cgulo's feet behind him, but, save for a
half-turn of the head, he ignored the dwarf
altogether. Keeping his eyes fixed upon
the middle of the gray man's back, he
plodded on in an unenthusiastic jog-trot
that expressed his mental attitude more
eloquently than speech.
The night voices of the bush rustled and
whimpered and coughed and shrilled. And
though it was not at all impossible that
among the unseen, friendly shadows of
near-naked men who saw them go past,
there might be others who would risk their
lives to serve Agwala, Charteris did not
change his gait or hesitate even for a mo-
ment.
Roku, the chief of Dowadda, met them
just as they emerged from the path and
headed for the village. Evidently Char-
teris' visit had been prearranged.
Roku was a stout, but well-conditioned
Jakri 'who had migrated from the Warri
district some years before; which was one
reason why Abado did not trust him. Jakri
men from Warri were, in Abado's opinion,
as smooth and treacherous as their women
were expensive.
"Gov'ment come," Roku informed Char-
teris in a mumbling voice. "Mas' Malkett.

Then, taking belated notice of Abado, he

As he turned toward the village, Char-
teris laid the tips of his fingers retainingly

"Wait. Agwala live Benin River all

Savez?"
He kept his fingers on Roku's arm, but v

"All right. We go," he said at last, and

The Gray Charteris
mud-built village, which, being the home of
a Jakri of Warri, was cleaner, less evil
smelling and less of a hodge-podge enter-
prise than the majority of the villages in the
Benin country.
Just then it was in complete darkness,
and save for the spasmodic wailing of a
wakeful infant or two, it was also sound
asleep. \
Roku was wholly unattended, and the

It was, of course, a larger hut than any

ble circle, the compound being in the center.
They went no farther than the first room

cause of the curse that was upon him, did

himself in the dust outside the door while
Roku seated his guests upon trading-beach

constructed of unplaned deal boards. Roku
liked to give the impression that he lived
like a gentleman, white man fashion.
In the dark and silent rooms that lay
beyond a screen of fiber mats, the mysteries
of Roku's household, in spite of trading-
beach furnishings, were as rampant as ever.
A white man might go through the rooms
from the "hall of the gods" to the burial
chamber and look those mysteries full in the
face and be entirely unaware of their mean-
ing and even of their presence.
Some of them would remain unsolved
even at Roku's death, because if his gods
were good and no ill of the flesh or spirit

that house.
' For such was the honor due to a chief such
as he had every intention of being--with the

And to prove that he was worthy, he
lighted a small kerosene lamp, dropped the

from a hole in the mud wall that was con-
cealed behind another colorful mat, he pro-
duced a bottle of perfectly good Scotch and

Glasses followed, and for the honor of
Roku's house, Charteris drank two fingers
of Scotch. Abado with a surly grunt took

sion of it, became a blood brother to the

Charteris smiled, glanced from one to the

"Maybe so, I want eight-paddle canoe?"
Roku nodded. That was easy enough.
"I think I go Agwalla-town--now--one
time."
The whites of Roku's eyes showed sharply
for a second, then vanished.
"Cha/"
The exclamation was Abado's and he
leaped to his feet, glaring wildly about him.
Roku, having composed his features again,
merely nodded gravely and did not appar-
ently observe the big Sobo's excitement.
Charteris gave no heed to either of them,
He was casually studying a nervous-
appearing bulge in the fiber mat screen
which separated the room from the others.
This screen was divided into two equal
parts, the one overlapping the other, and

"Squat!" he ordered Abado quietly, and

Then, before he had an opportunity to feel

"You go back to Materri, sof'ly, sof'ly."
Again Abado stood upright expressing
more amazement than before.
Materri was his own village and he knew

Roku smiled and shrugged his glistening
shoulders and the bulge in the fiber mat
screen shifted. Charteris leaned across the
