"You fit to give him canoe?" he asked
Roku, as if Abado's protests were of no con-
sequence.
Roku admitted that he could provide
Abado also with a canoe.
"All right. Two canoe, one time. We
talk Doridi palaver, tomorrow time."
Roku nodded. He knew Doridi was the
confidant of Agwala who had generously
told Noni and Abado so much about the
Morrison-Agwala interview at Forcados.
No one had seen or heard much about him
since that time.
When the chief of Dowadda departed to
do the gray man's bidding, Abado's protests
Adventure
broke out anew in a jabbering crescendo.
He came and stood beside Charteris' chair
in an effort to impress him with the sin-
cerity and wisdom of his contentions.
If he went back to Materri, he argued, it
would be equal to walking into the govern-
ment barracks at Warri or Sapeli. The
village of Materri was surely being watched
night and day, both by the government and
by Agwala, and Abado thought it would be
more simple to cut his own throat then and
there than to do anything so foolhardy as to
paddle his way into Agwala's hands like that.
Charteris did not attempt to suppress
him. Instead he allowed him to go on talk-
ing, and, rising from his chair, argued
convincingly with him, too, all the while
twining his fingers about the neck of the
bottle of Scotch.
The bulge in the mat screen leaped for-
ward suddenly.
Abado's back was toward it. One mo-
ment he felt the grip of Charteris' powerful
left hand upon his arm; the next he was
spinning across the room to the startling
accompaniment of the crash of breaking
glass, a sudden darkness that swirled and
smothered and the sound of a revolver shot
that made his ear-drums ring.
Then, out of the dark there came the
unmistakable threshing of struggling bodies,
a sharp squeal of pain that died in an un-
canny grunt, and finally a low, feeble moan
that chilled.
Abado, who was not unused to fights in
the dark, crouched against the farthest wall
and shuddered.
CHAPTER XIX
A PARTIAL EXPLANATION
OGUL0 was many yards from the door
by that time. Roku's household was
awake, rubbing its eyes. The lifeless figures
who slept outside their huts were no longer
lifeless, and Roku himself, down at the edge
of Dowadda Creek, making ready the canoes
at the gray man's bidding, turned his head
sharply at the sound of the shot and prompt-
ly became the color of dirty ashes.
Muttering whispers that grew louder and
louder passed up and down the village from
end to end and back again. The jabbering
of the women and the staccato grunting of
the men, the frightened cries of many chil-
dren and the bleating and stampeding of
equally frightened goats and sheep, the
scurrying of excited naked feet and the
querulous inquiries of the very old--these
demonstrations rose and fell in waves and
died down again like the sucking rumble of
receding waters.
Roku did not stir. Neither did he inquire.
He was afraid he knew; so afraid that he
cursed the white man's government and,
still more fluently cursed Agwala. His
dream of greatness burst like a bubble in
a moment; and, if that were so, there was
nothing to be gained by flight.
Abado still cowered against the wall in
Roku's hut. Once, he heard a sound like
the rattle of a belt buckle, but it meant
nothing to him. When he finally did move,
it was because he felt the approach of Char-
teris rather than saw or heard him. Why
he knew it was the gray man, he could not
have told, because, while there was a tu-
mult outside, within that room there was
a silence that made breathing as difficult as
it seemed thunderous.
Then Charteris was at his elbow whisper-
ing in his ear.
Abado was frightened. There was no
doubt about that. But that which Char-
teris whispered made a slow, evil grin ex-
pand from ear to ear. He obeyed the touch
of the gray man's hand without so much as
an instant's hesitation, drew his overcloth
up over his head to conceal his face, and
followed Charteris out into the welcome
open, still grinning.
A gasp of astonishment and fear went up
when they made their appearance. It died
into a whispering awe as they proceeded to
the waterfront where Roku waited. There
was something unreal in the manner in
which every mouth was stopped and ev-
ery arm hung in listless inaction as they
passed by.
Charteris ignored Roku and gave all of
his attention to Abado. He saw to it that
the Sobo entered the small canoe provided
for him, and when Abado again whimper-
ingly protested his return to Materri, Char-
teris cursed him roundly in his own jargon
and told him impatiently to be off.
Like a child venturing into the dark
alone, Abado paddled slowly and reluc-
tantly up stream. So reluctantly at first,
that Charteris picked up a handy piece of
mangrove stick and hurled it after him with
such good aim that Abado uttered a fright-
ened cry and paddled furiously out of range.
The Gray Charteris
His grin, however, was broader and more
evil than ever.
Then Charteris turned to Roku and said
simply:
"Come. We go."
And he led the way back to Roku's hut.
The Jakri followed quaking. He had not
failed to observe that there was a revolver
sticking in the gray man's belt--a revolver
that had not been there before.
And he knew to whom the weapon be-
longed.
Fight, under the circumstances was even
more useless than flight. Roku never even^
thought of it. His skin was still whole and
he passionately wished it to remain so as
long as possible.
"Bring lamp," Charteris ordered when
they reached the door of the hut again.
"Tell all man go sleep. No make talk.
Sof'ly, sof'ly."
Roku gulped. Quaveringly he issued an
order to his excited villagers to cease their
chattering and resume their disturbed slum-
bers, then scurried nervously in search of
another lamp.
His dignity, for the moment at least, was
gone. He might recover it again if the gray
man did not put an everlasting blight upon
him. But until he was sure about this, he
would feel like a paddle boy whose back
was raw after a flogging.
Charteris entered the hut and went direct-
ly in the direction of the right hand corner
of the first room.
Some one was wriggling like an eel in that
corner and giving vent to an occasional
moan of pain or fear. When Charteris told
the wriggler to save his energies, quiet fell
instantly.
Presently Roku returned with a lamp,
placed it on the table and then looked fur-
tively at the trussed figure of Arthur
Garriman Bark. Roku seemed afraid to
assimilate too much of the truth all at
once.
And, unquestionably, Arthur was a pa-
thetic spectacle. His arms were strapped
behind him with his service belt, and his
ankles were bound with the belt that ordi-
narily supported his trousers. He was dirty
and disheveled and his head ached from the
effect of the quieting crack Charteris had
given him with the butt of the revolver.
His morale, therefore, was at a very low
ebb. Charteris had the revolver, Abado
had escaped and Malkett did not know he
was there. Many things could happen to
him long before Malkett found it out.
"Sorry I missed you when you called at
Grandison's the other evening," Charteris
said blandly. "Would have saved all this
trouble if I hadn't. Was Malkett foolish
enough to post you in there?"
Arthur did not answer. He was afraid
to lie and more afraid to tell the truth, and
he was not at all sure that Roku was well
enough paid to go on lying indefinitely.
So he kept his peace.
"Why were you so confoundedly anxious
to put a bullet into Abado that you couldn't
wait until I was out of the way?"
Arthur did not answer that either, but his
expression at once betrayed the fact that
Charteris's surmise was unfailingly correct.
"Remember what I told you on the Bonny
the other day?"
Arthur remembered, and looked as if
he would like to forget.
"And yet you took a cold-blooded pot
shot like that at him." A thoughtful pause.
"I suppose that was why you visited
Grandison's in my absence. Thought you
might spot him and do the trick without
having to take so desperate a chance as this?
You used to be such a nice voung man, too.
What is it? Agwala or wonfen or both?"
Bark writhed. He hoped Roku did not
understand much of what Charteris was
saying.
"As I see it," Charteris informed him
gratuitously, "you were going to take your
man, as dead as you could make him, and
turn him over to Malkett as a good servant
of the Crown should. In other words--
Come here!"
The command was addressed to Roku,
who was edging toward the bottle of gin.
All he wanted, however, was a drink to
steady his trembling legs, but Charteris
ordered him to stand against jthe opposite;
wall and await his pleasure. Then he turned
to Bark again.
"In other words," he went on as if no
interruption had occurred, "you were will-
ing to take that chance with me in the room,
and if a careless shot had gone wild-"
"No!" The negative was as hoarse as it
was desperate. "My chief gave me orders
to secure Abado, dead or alive-"
"And Agwala prefers him dead."
"I know nothing of Chief Agwala's
desires."
"You were so nervous about it, too, you
Adventure
could not keep your shoulder out of the
picture."
Arthur looked down his nose because
there was nowhere else to look with any
comfort and he was visibly relieved when
Charteris switched*Tiis attention to Roku,
whose knees sagged the moment the gray
man turned in his direction.
Outside, quiet had fallen again. Prob-
ably there were whispering speculations
being indulged in within the darkened walls
of every hut in Dowadda. But they were
only whisperings and did not reach Roku's
ears. Even Ogulo the dwarf had returned
and resumed his place jn the dust outside
the door.
Charteris spoke in a low voice in Roku's
own tongue:
"Speak truth, small snake. Whose oil
paid for--this?"
He touched Bark contemptuously with
the toe of his boot.
Roku looked all about him in a shivering
terror, and his fear of the gray man was not
merely physical. Several times he began to

throat.
Finally, being between the devil and the
deep sea--almost as fearful of Agwala's
far-reaching vengeance as he was of the
powers of darkness attributed to the gray
man--he flung himself in the stereotyped
native fashion at Charteris' feet, mumbling
the equally hackneyed admission that he
was a poor Jakri man whose village was
small, whose wives and goats and puncheons
were few and----
Charteris put his right foot down hard on
the groveling neck and his left dug sharply
into Roku's ribs.
"Get up!" _ /
A squeak of pain answered him and the
Jakri threw himself bodily out of reach of
further punishment. He huddled on the
floor about a yard away from Bark and
quakingly awaited the gray man's next
move.
"All right," Charteris said as if he were
perfectly satisfied. "We go Agwala-town.
Wahl"
Instantly Roku began to whine in real
earnest, while Bark, staring up at Charteris
in petrified unbelief, made queer sounds in
his throat as if he were choking for breath.
Neither of them seemed to be at all
anxious to visit Agwala-town under these
conditions.
"I won't go!" Arthur sputtered at last.
"It's preposterous! I Stm a servant of His
Majesty^ __ I wear his uniform. This sort
of thing may be all perfectly well for com-
mon natives, but I am an officer of the con-
stabulary, and though I am at present--
pro tem, that is--at a physical disadvantage,
it is simply pro tem, and the sooner-"
Charteris went quietly to the door of the
hut, saw Ogulo squatting there, and called
him in.
Ogulo backed away.
"I no fit," he whimpered, knowing that
because he was accursed, he would defile
Roku's house if he entered it, and thereby
unnecessarily incur the displeasure of the
chief.
Apparently Charteris understood Ogulo's
hesitation.
"The house of Roku is the house of a
very small lizard," he said simply. "Smaller
even than you. Come."
Ogulo obeyed this time,, but gingerly.
And when Roku saw Ogmo-of-the-long-
arms put his foot across the threshold, he
immediately set up a wail that threatened
to rouse the house and the village again.
He covered his head with his cloth and
rocked back and forth, calling the shades
of his fathers to witness that the blight that
had fallen upon his house was not of his
devising.
Charteris ordered him to be silent and
with a gesture to the amazed Ogulo, told,
the dwarf to release Bark's ankles. Then
sliding over to Roku, he seized him by the
scruff of the neck and yanked him most
ungently to his feet. He held him there
voiceless and unmoving until Bark stood
reluctantly upright, his arms still strapped
behind him, his trousers' belt returned to its
proper sphere of influence.
All the while Arthur,had been protesting
in more or less grandiloquent English
against the indignity he was suffering; and
finally, since Charteris gave no heed to his
eloquence, asked thickly and hopelessly--
"You are going to take me to Agwala-
town like this?"
"Exactly. Why not?"
Arthur made several attempts before he
was able to say:
"Bu--bu--but you have the revolver!
Isn't that security enough?"
Charteris laughed tonelessly.
"It's the moral effect I'm driving at," he
explained. "You're a yellow dog, you know,
The Gray" Charteris
and I want to be sure you feel the part."
Bark's chin had the decency to sink
lower and lower until it rested on the first
button of his tunic. He had nothing more
to say.
Whereupon Charteris gave Roku most
explicit instructions as to his conduct on
the way down to the creek side, and indi-
cated, with a prod of Bark's revolver muz-
zle, what was likely to transpire, first and
foremost, if there was any trouble of his
making.
Then, telling Ogulo to see to it that Bark
behaved properly, they filed out of the hut
and started off in 'the direction of the
waterfront.
There were eyes that saw them go past,
vague whispering voices that questioned
their going, but there was no demonstration
of hostility. Charteris said to Roku in a
low voice as they neared the creek:
"Five puncheons. You laugh inside your
head. 'Member?" Charteris chuckled
while the Jakri squirmed. "What's matter

Roku's step lagged purposely.
"Agwala no savez this palaver," he
mumbled. "Agwala no pay. Be Bark pay.
I no savez Bark go make shoot palaver."
"I see. Bark's own idea entirely, eh?"
Then dropping into pidgin again. " 'Mem-
ber them time you laugh when I say
Agwala live on Benin River all time?"
Roku remembered that, too, as his sheep-
ish expression indicated.
"You laughed plenty too much," Char-
teris informed him for his future guidance.
"When Jakri man on Benin River laugh at

He lie in his belly and in his head. Savez?"
Roku felt as if he were shrinking. His
feet became like heavy weights to be
dragged along the ground.
"Agwala no pay," he repeated thickly and
desperately. "Be Bark pay. I no savez
he go make shoot palaver."
Charteris did not dispute the point. He
prodded Roku into a faster gait. .Presently
they arrived at the Creek side, where an

Ogulo the dwarf sharply:
"Go for my canoe. Bring it Agwala-
town creek. Make plenty quick!"
Ogulo had no relish for the assignment.
The farther he kept away from Agwala-
town creek, the better pleased he would be.
But he hesitated only a moment or two, then

A few minutes later, in spite of Bark's
eloquent indignation and Roku's sniveling
appeals to be left behind, Charteris and his
"guests" were squatting under the grass
awning that sheltered the small matted
deck of the eight-paddle canoe.
As the sleepy paddle boys shoved off and
turned the canoe's nose down stream, Char-
teris said to Arthur Garriman Bark pleas-
antly:
"I had a 'notion, earlier in the evening,
that I might be compelled to visit your fat
friend. But I didn't anticipate quite so
much company."
CHAPTER XX
THE POPULARITY OE AGWALA
Hogmanay sandy MacGregor
had not stuck a revolver in his belt
since Chief Motu of Segwanga had made his
justly famous "last stand." This had been
several years before.
Consequently, the circumstance that he
was oiling no less than two regulation army
revolvers--his beach clerk's and his own--
when he heard Catherine Morrison's step
on the stairs late that evening, was more
remarkable than Catherine might have
thought had she been permitted to see the
weapons.
They were out of sight in a drawer of
MacGregor's desk when she entered his
office, and Hogmanay called to her from his
bedroom while he washed his hands.
"Sit right down, Catherine. I'll be with
you in a minute."
"All right. Don't hurry."
MacGregor had not expected Catherine
so soon and she, for her part, was calling
upon him only because she had said she
would before she left the yacht. She did
not anticipate that Hogmanay would have
anything to say to her she did not already
know, and took it for granted that he had
seen her come up the beach from the launch,
and that he was probably struggling into
a collar and tie, most of which his beard
would conceal in any case.
It was apparent--or would have been to
Fran Goddard, for instance--thdl Catherine
was torn loose from the solid foundations
IOO
Adventure
she had been so careful to build under her
feet.
She did not sit down while she waited
Hogmanay's appearance. Pacing the floor
»f his office, she was still acutely conscious
of the pressure of Charteris' arm, and she
knew it would be impossible to forget the
awful, stifling feel of his hand across her
mouth.
The experience had been far from playful.
While it lasted, she had been entirely at
Charteris' mercy, and, as is common wi^h
adventures of the sort, their real significance
becomes more apparent afterward.
Catherine was just beginning to realize
what had happened to her, and how simply
it had happened. Later, when her perspec-
tive improved, she would understand it
even better. While she was trying to bring
some semblance of order out of the chaos
of her uprooted emotions, Hogmanay
came in.
"Ye're worried about something?" he
asked at once quietly. "Who brought ye
over?"
"Andy," Catherine answered shaking
hands. "He's waiting in the launch. I just
came over because-- Oh, Malkett doesn't
seem to be getting anywhere, and I had
another cable from mother this morn-
ing."
"Aye. So ye would. She'll be anxious
about ye. Will ye not sit down?"
Catherine accepted the chair MacGregor
offered, looked out toward the lights of the
Bonny and the farther dim lights of the
hulk, then asked--
"Do you think Abado really did it?"
Hogmanay thought that over. In truth,

teresting to induce him to borrow a revolver

"I've not decided yet," he returned

room galleyward. "What makes ye think

"I didn't say I thought that."
"No, but ye're doubtin' an apparently

"Oh, don't quibble!" Catherine rose so

"I'm in no mood to bother with-fine defini-
tions. What I want is action!"
MacGregor nodded placidly.
"Aye. I don't doubt it a bit. I feel that
way myseP sometimes when I'm waitin'
for other folks to do a bit o' work for me.
Tell me about it."
"Tell you about what?" Catherine ex-
ploded.
"About what's makin' ye snap at me

"No. Don't say you're sorry. Didn't

Catherine laughed a little off key and

Then because Catherine continued to

Catherine breathed deeply. She saw a

"How do you know I went to Grandison's

"Oh--I just guessed it. There's not
The Gray Charteris
much else up that way, and--he's a fasci-
natin' man."
Catherine's mouth, still tender, tightened

"Yes. Quite. But niggardly with infor-
mation." Her fine eyes suddenly met Hog-
manay's without a flicker. "He refused to

Hogmanay grinned.
"You're Hugh Morrison's bairn," he
conceded, and, in his opinion, that was the
highest compliment he could pay her. "And

"Tricks!"
"Just that. His trade is wanderin' about
--here, there and everywhere--and we're
not gettin' the half of it. Even Jardine, over

Catherine regarded Hogmanay's unusual
indignation with a slight smile.
"You don't mind that very much, do
you?"
"Mind! And why not?" Then observ-
ing Catherine's scepticism more closely.
"Oh, ye mean Margaret?" He shook his

ject, can I ask you a favor?"

"Will ye try to kidnap her or something
and take her wi' ye when you go home?"
Catherine laughed.
"Fran suggested that this morning," she

"That's fine."
Hogmanay paused a moment or two, then

that jarred. Apparently he was in no mood
to let sentiment interfere with his responsi-
bility to the firm.
"Agwala is not livin' up to the promises
he made your father at Forcados," he rum-
bled. "When I sent for him to come up
here tonight, he put me off wi' an excuse.
So, I'm goin' to him."
"And where do I come in?" Catherine
asked expectantly.
"Well, ye see, you're a Morrison," Mac-
Gregor ansveered with solemn conviction.
"And Agwala knows the difference between
a member o' the family and a servant. I'm
just a servant. You will be something he

"Of course! I wouldn't miss it for worlds.
And I'm just crazy to do something to
help."
"Aye. I thought ye would be. It'll be
a sort o' business meetin', with you as chair-
man o' the board. I'll do the talkin' and
you'll nod like a judge and make him as un-
happy as ye can by sayin' as little as possi-
ble. The Charteris man didn't happen to
mention trade, did he?"
Catherine's smile faded with a sharpness
that was startling.
"Nothing. I told him what Agwala said
about the shielding of Abado, and he
laughed at me."
"Um--well, ye shouldn't have told him
that," MacGregor said cannily, as the
back beach watch boy solemnly struck six
bells on the old ship's bell that hung
inside the oil yard fence. "But it's no
matter. He probably knew it already.
That watch boy's a bit slow. It's nearer
twelve than eleven. Just a minute till I
call Garland."
"Is he coming, too?"
"Aye. I'm thinkin' he'd better. He's
a handy man to have about ye in a native
village."
"Gracious! That sounds exciting!"
"No---just a bit o' caution in the matter of
where to put yodr feet," Hogmanay said,
halting a moment in the doorway. "Native
villages are not overparticular under foot,
and ye wouldn't be fit to live with if you
were laid up with a sprained ankle now."
Catherine laughed. She was tingling all
over in the hope that the visit to Agwala-
town was not going to be as mild as Hog-
manav promised. MacGregor went along
Adventure
to Garland's room praying that he was not
making a mistake in taking her there.
Garland was waiting for him.
"All right," the shop clerk announced.
"I'm full of artillery. Can you see any
of it?"
Hogmanay looked him over critically.
"Just a suspicious looking lump under
your left arm. Pull it for'ard a bit and it'll
be all right."
Garland's hand disappeared under his
shirt and pulled the "lump" forward a little.
"Fine," Hogmanay approved. "But
I'm hopin' we don't have to murder any-
body. Come along and take Miss Morrison
down to the launch while I get ready."
In another minute Hogmanay was ex-
plaining to Catherine that he had one or
two little things to attend to and that if she
would go to the launch and advise Andy
Graham where they were going, he would
join her in a jiffy.
Catherine accepted Garland's escort with
a smile that put him immediately at his
ease. The moment they were gone, Hog-
manay promptly retrieved the revolvers
from his desk.
He loaded them carefully, and, like Gar-
land, slung one under each armpit inside his
shirt. It was a trick he had learned from
a poetic gentleman, known from Sierra
Leone to Duke Town, Calabar, by the vio-
lent pseudonym of "Knife-Edge" Harring-
ton; the gentleman, by the way, who was
responsible for the aforementioned last
stand of Chief Motu of Segwanga.
Hogmanay recalled the affair and the
man with a reminiscent grin, then, making
sure that there was nothing but the measure
of his own speed to hinder the "draw", he
solemnly gave instructions to a sleepy
steward not to blow out the lamp, and went
slowly and meditatively down stairs.
There was not the smallest danger to
Catherine in the little midnight adventure.
Agwala-town, under MacGregor's guidance,
would be safer than West Kensington. Not
because Hogmanay's mighty right arm was
a source of terror; simply that he was a
trader.
A uniform has frequently been a man's
death warrant in the Delta; while a gray
flannel shirt and a pair of oil-smeared white
drills have gone blandly through many a
seething caldron of rebellion.
And MacGregor believed that this was
still the case in spite of the murder of Hugh
Morrison. Morrison had died because,
blinded by the strong sunlight on the
heights, he had thought himself immune
from the penalty of taking sides in a black
man's quarrel.
So that Hogmanay, with two revolvers
under his shirt, was not worrying to any
extent about what would happen to Cath-
erine. He was troubled, however, because
of the demonstration he would probably
have to make to induce Agwala to keep his
promises.
And he knew that the ponderous chief of
Agwala-town was desperately afraid of
guns.

CHAPTER XXI
GUNS
CATHERINE had but a misty realiza-
tion of the journey between Marsden
& Co.'s beach and Agwala-town.
When the launch had turned from the
main stream into Agwala-town Creek,
there came a blacker dark that made the
walls of mangrove still more forbidding.
Canoes slipped past like ghosts, giving
forth no sound save the swish of the pad-
dles which was not unlike the rustle of a
shroud. Others that dawdled close in to
the bush whispered a little more excitedly
than usual as the launch passed by. But it
was all vague and indefinite to Catherine,
who had a desire to turn a searchlight upon
it to discover what it was all about.
"Won't Agwala be annoyed at us for"
waking him up?" she asked Garland while
Hogmanay was occupied showing Andy
where to go.
"He'll be annoyed whether we have to
wake him up or not," Garland declared with
a grin. "But I'd be willing to wager he
hasn't gone to bed yet. He's a grand old
night owl, is Agwala. His own people say
he never sleeps."
"From what I saw of him, I should have
said he was asleep most of the time. Are
we nearly there?"
"In a few minutes. Just around the next
bend."
"He doesn't expect us, does he?"
"No. But we won't surprize him very
much. He has too many watch boys."
Catherine was visibly disappointed. The
little adventure had a dark, midnight
flavor, it was true, but it lacked the spice of
uncertainty. Keeping the mosquitoes away
seemed to form the most active part of it.
The next bend was accomplished without
difficulty and in another minute the launch
had scraped alongside Agwala's little wharf
and Hogmanay was saying to the shadow-
like figure of the watch boy thereon:
"Tell Agwala I bring Missy Cap'n
Morrison. Make quick."
The watch boy, startled by the announce-
ment, shot up the path to the town with
hardly a second's delay. And he had barely
disappeared when another, also carrying
a bobbing hurricane lantern, came forward
suddenly from a by-path to the right and
took his place.
Evidently the second watch boy, when
he saw Hogmanay, Garland and Catherine
climb on to the wharf, did not consider him-
self and his solitary lantern sufficient for so
large a visitation of white people.
So he made a thick, unintelligible noise
in his throat and two more watch boys ap-
peared out of the bush with a suddenness
that made Catherine jump. She realized
that Garland had spoken the truth when he
had stated that Agwala had too many watch
boys.
Garland took a firm grip upon her arm
with his left hand. His right, under caver
of a broad, flowing four-in-hand tie, rested
idly on his chest.
MacGregor's beard made a better screen
than Garland's tie, and as he grunted an
order to the watch boys to go ahead, his
expression indicated that Agwala was going
Adventure
to keep the promises he had made at For-
cados or else have reason to regret he had
ever made them.
Andy remained in the launch and smoked
the mosquitoes from about his ears. With-
out expressing any opinion on the matter, he
condemned the whole business utterly.
Passing along a broad, well-worn busk-
path and around a single turn, then past
a straggling group of mud-and-wattle huts
that became less scattered and developed
into a large and fairly compact circle,
Catherine was aware of only a blurred con-
fusion of shadows and unclean smells, and
of indeterminate things that lay around like
animals asleep.
Then something huge rose up out of the
dark; something with a light in it; and she
stood before the house Agwala had built.
It was a white man's house, and Chief
Agwala was secretly annoyed by the cir-
cumstance that he was not the first native
chief who had built one. But it was bigger
than that of any competitor, and when
Catherine saw it, she wondered if she were
not actually standing before one of Marsden
& Co.'s house-and-shop constructions.
As a matter of fact, she was. Agwala had
built his house after the pattern of Mars-
den's at Warri. Even the lower of the two
floors, in imitation of the customary "shop,"
was used as a store-room and, like the
general warehouse of the trading-factory,
contained all things necessary to man.
Agwala lived "on top." In one corner of
the house there were lamps burning, and
as Catherine climbed the stairs, she realized
that she had been climbing just such stairs
on factory after factory all the way up from
Old Calabar.
From the top of the stairs, however, she
could see that Agwala-town itself was much
as it had ever been. It spread out, all
around Agwala's house, fawning in slavish
squalor at the feet of opulence. Sordid,
dank and sinister, and but vaguely in-
definite of population and purpose, it was
still but a meager shelter of a groveling
people, huddling together in the heart of a
sun-scorched mangrove swamp.
So that Agwala's house was all the more
incongruous. It had no place in Catherine's
picture. Particularly at that time of night.
His "reception room"--the equivalent to
a trading-agent's office--was furnished in
wicker from Madeira, and lavishly strewn
with native mats more colorful than Jo-
seph's coat. Here and there were enlight-
ening evidences of Upper Niger handcraft
and needlework.
But the extravagant number of lusty
colored cushions that occupied the wicker
divan and the chairs and overflowed, as it
were, on to the floor, suggested at once to
the initiated that Agwala had become pos-
sessed by a fad and had indulged in it to
his heart's content.
He met MacGregor in the doorway lead-
ing on to the veranda, and even in his suave
and oily moments--and this was one of
them--he was simply a little less neutral
than usual.
"Doh," he greeted MacGregor, Jakri
fashion. "I glad Missy Cap'n Morrison
come look me." He made a heavily
stilted courtesy to Catherine. "You sit
down? I hab boy bring drink one time."
Hogmanay waved the offer of drinks aside
in a manner that sent Agwala back to his
cushioned divan with an inquiring look in
his eyes.
"No drink," Hogmanay said shortly,
and evidently intended to waste no time
with the finer points of diplomacy. "Missy
Cap'n Morrison came talk trade palaver.
Savez?"
Agwala nodded. Apparently he thought
the prospect both new and interesting. He
made no audible comment, however; simply
settled himself among his cushions and
waited for the discussion to begin.
"You 'member you talk with Missy
Cap'n Morrison's father at Forcados?"
MacGregor asked, as Garland casually took
up a position behind Catherine's chair.
"'I 'member. I sorry he done die. Sorry
too much."
"You 'member you talk trade palaver?"
MacGregor continued.
"I 'member."
"Then what's matter you no do them
thing you promise to Missy Cap'n Morrison
father?"
Agwala thought that over. He looked at
Hogmanay with his head a little on one side
and then slowly shifted his glance to Cath-
erine.
"I no savez," he said simply--which is
the Delta native's invariable answer to
anything he does not care to understand.
Thick guttural whisperings from the vil-
lage lifted themselves into the short silence
that followed; a restless sound like that of •
some large animal moving uneasily and

grunting in its sleep. Hogmanay permit-
ted ttfe silence to hold for fully a minute,

"Huh!" It was not often that Mac-
Gregor sneered. His contempt for Agwala

"You no savez, eh? You're a small-boy,

Savez? You lie like bushman. You trade

"You say I lie? Be all righ'. You be big

Hogmanay sat down again and tried

"You trade in Siluko?"
"Li'l bit," Agwala admitted with oily

Another expressive shrug of the shoulders

vinced that he was a liar, there was not

Hogmanay's right hand slipped under his

Catherine simply sat and watched Ag-
wala's fat, shiny and imperturbable coun-
tenance with the fascination of one who was

"When white man make promise," Hog-
manay said slowly, "white man do what he
say. When he no do what he say, big pala-
ver live. Savez?"
Agwala understood that and admitted it;
so Hogmanay asked--
"You make promise to Missy Cap'n
Morrison's father at Forcados?"
"I make li'l bit promise. Missy Cap'n
Morrison's father make promise to me.
But he done die. He no fit now_to do um
promise. Palaver set."
Hogmanay did not agree with Agwala's
sophism. His hand came slowly from be-
neath his beard and descended, without
any fuss or demonstration of hostility to his
knee. Garland's hand also appeared from
under his tie and came to rest leisurely on
the back of Catherine's chair.

It was then, just as she felt Garland's
free hand grasp her shoulder warningly, that
Catherine saw Agwala's expression change.
As if the craven fear that lurked behind its
smug and self-satisfied shelter of fat were
suddenly uncertain of its security, a massive
sort of restlessness shook him from head to
foot. He sat bolt upright and the whites of
his eyes showed for the first time.
Catherine stole a sidelong glance at Mac-
Gregor and discovered a large blue-barreled
revolver resting quietly--but only too sig-
nificantly--on his knee. And, following
Agwala's fear-filled look behind her, she
caught the glint of another revolver barrel
that rested almost indifferently on the back
of her chair.
Garland's grip on her shoulder tightened
a little and she exhaled a deep breath sound-
lessly. Then smiled. This, she admitted,
with another glimpse at Agwala's graying
countenance, was most interesting.
The shrill whistling of the crickets in the
bush seemed to grow louder and louder and
the low drone of voices somewhere not far
distant made the possibilities of the situa-
tion assume an explosive quality that was
exciting.
"Now, we go talk," MacGregor said
quietly. "And we go talk true talk.
Savez?"
"E-yaw! Cha!"
"All right. Keep your seat. This gun,
he nice, quiet gun when man talk true.
But when man talk lie--"
Hogmanay left the rest of it to Agwala's

whatever protection he might be able to

"I---I no savez what's the matter," he
whined, and looking toward Catherine,
tried to be friendly and indignant at the
io6
Adventure
same time. "I no do nothing. I be your
friend, all same I be your father friend.
Long time I savez your father. He be

Catherine listened attentively enough.
Then, appreciating what was expected of
her, and being conscious of an acute desire

MacGregor with an assumption of imperi-
ousness that disturbed Agwala in no small

"Tell him he must keep the promises he

Hogmanay nodded respectfully, and Gar-
land had considerable difficulty in conceal-
ing a grin. Then Hogmanay interpreted

marks on his own account.
The effect upon Agwala was most marked.
He looked from Hogmanay to Catherine in
a bewildered fashion, and it was evident
that he did not know what to make of Missy
Cap'n Morrison. There was a quality in the
steadiness of her gray eyes that bothered
him considerably. And, of course, there
were the guns that made his fat quiver and
upset his powers of thought completely.
Suddenly Catherine had an idea of her
own. Perhaps it was a dangerous idea, but
the moment ' it came to her, she was
compelled to give voice * to it. She
spoke so sharply that even Hogmanay was
startled.
"Tell him, on second thought, I may
change my mind about the promises that
were made at Forcados. If he has forgotten
his responsibilities in the matter, we can
forget ours, too. Tell him, also, that if he
is looking for a fight, with guns or without
them, Marsden & Co. will give him one
that will make him the sorriest Jakri in
Benin River."
Garland wanted to cheer, but Hogmanay,
canny as usual and having some difficulty
in concealing his surprize at Catherine's
sudden vehemence, hesitated.
"Go on. Tell him. Who the dickens is
he that we should have to come here at this
time of night to argue fine distinctions
with him?"
Agwala saw the fire in Catherine's eyes
quite plainly. And, as Hogmanay had
said, he knew the difference between a mem-
ber of the family and a servant. MacGreg-
or's attitude increased the difference, and
Garland, standing behind Catherine's chair in
so protecting a position, heightened the effect.
"What--what's matter?" Agwala asked
Catherine respectfully. "You no savez I
be your friend?"
Catherine dismissed the plea with a ges-
ture that left no doubt, in Agwala's mind at
least, of her position in the matter. She
turned quickly to Hogmanay and said
just a little impatiently:
"Oh, go on! Tell him what I said. You
could also tell him, just for effect, that
Abado isn't dead yet. I'm sure he wouldn't
like to be reminded of that."
MacGregor's eyes brightened for a sec-
ond. He nodded slowly and thoughtfully
and finally began where Catherine left off.
He asked Agwala to remember that
Abado was still very much alive. Also, until
the Sobo was proved guilty of Morrison's
murder, he was innocent in the sight of the
white man's law, and his trade, in its sub-
stance at least, was just as purchasable as
that of any other trader.
Therefore, since Agwala had not kept his
promises, Marsden & Co. did not feel under
any obligation to keep theirs. They could
not trust Agwala again and did not care to
make a new agreement. If they wished to
trade with Abado's boys, they would do so.
Such, MacGregor concluded for the sake
of emphasis, was the decision of Missy
Cap'n Morrison.
Agwala gasped. His fat hands orna-
mented with diamonds that splashed rather
than sparkled, pawed the air then in an
effort to make himself understood. Cather-
ine was plainly, as Hogmanay had pre-
dicted, an element he had not considered for
a moment. And the guns-
"But--but Abado! He kill your father!"
he stammered at last, while a cold trickle

trade-"
"We go trade with all man," Hogmanay
answered and rose to indicate that the dis-
cussion was ended, and Catherine immedi-
ately followed suit. "If Abado's boys bring

The Gray Charteris
Agwala sank among his cushions, as un-
moving as he had been, but a minute before,

He was not looking at Hogmanay or

The scuff of a naked foot sounded on the

Then Charteris, with Bark's revolver

AGWALA seems to be popular this eve-

Charteris regarded the little tableau as
though it earned his unqualified approval.
Apparently it did not surprize him in the
least. Whether he had managed to escape

boys altogether, or had simply, by virtue

at Roku and Bark--particularly Bark--

Agwala's face sagged and he sank deeper
among his cushions. His dull little eyes
narrowed and he waited, more in fear than
in caution, for some one else to speak first.
Catherine drew a little nearer to Hog-
manay and Garland kept his position at her
elbow. When he touched her arm to assure

that she was trembling, and she drew away
from him as though she did not want to be

"I don't seem to be very welcome?"
Charteris said, breaking the pause.
"Oh, ye're welcome enough," Hogmanay
declared, studying the unique-situation as
cannily as possible. "But what have ye
got him tied up like that for?"
"It's an outrage!" Arthur broke out
vehemently, lilting his head with dramatic
emphasis, as if the sound of MacGregor's
voice had suddenly awakened him from a
brow-beaten lethargy. "He has brought me

He went toward Agwala suddenly and

SOME time later, when all of his
unwelcome visitors had gone, Ag-
wala squatted among his beloved
silken cushions, holding a broken coral
necklace and a cloth-wrapped amulet in his
plump hands.
He was quite alone. The village below
was almost still again; a quaking quiet that
had an uneasy dread of the dawn.
Agwala's unctuous bulk was shaking
with alternate rage and fear, and it would
have been difficult to determine which
emotion controlled him most.
His hatred was of the sort that strips the
flesh from an enemy's bones, strip by strip,
while the victim's eyes-
But, to his old and ever growing fear of
Abado, was added a still deeper terror of a
force he did not understand.
Abado was just a man; trade was largely
a matter of price; but the gray man who
never hurried, the old, old man with the
face of a boy--there was no explaining the
why or the wherefore of him!
Agwala had witnessed the amazing sub-
jection of Bark. He had seen the still more
astounding downfall of MacGregor; and he
had no difficulty in remembering how Char-
teris had struck him--him, Agwala!--just
as if he were nothing more than the least of
his inofficial slaves.
Also, he remembered distinctly what
Charteris had said about the "son and the
father of dogs."
He could neither read nor write. The
Jakri tongue knew nothing of letters or hiero-
glyphics. But the writing on the wall can
always be read by the man who sees it there.
Agwala nursed his broken coral necklace
and the sacred and all powerful cloth-
wrapped amulet in his trembling hands and
spelled out the letters one by one.

So that the Bonny continued to rock
gently in midstream, while the raw, but
soundless intrigue of the bush crawled
creeper-like and with lightning speed
throughout the length and breadth of the
Benin country; silently reached out and up
into the land of the Ibo even into the
"street of N'ri," and dipped down into the
villages of the chiefs of Brass.
In the few succeeding days--days of
broiling heat and the weariness of a cramped
environment---a sullen heaviness seemed to
descend upon the face of the rumpled
waters.'
And the natives who plied up and down
the river assumed an expression that
suggested they^ were . listening--always lis-
tening.
There was nothing imaginary about this.
The sinister, whispering voice of vengeance
that haunted the gloomy network of creeks
or ran breathlessly along the narrow bush
paths in the blackness of the night, was
growing louder and louder.
In these few days, where the creeks were
darkest, men died suddenly and without
warning, and their bodies slid gently into
Mother Niger's lap where the gurgling
rattle of complaint in their throats was
swiftly soothed into silence. 1
Whereupon, their women donned their
oldest raiment and their brothers or sons
became avengers of their blood.
So that it was necessary for every man to
look behind him at frequent intervals, and
canoes that had formerly traveled close
in to the bush, sought the greater safety of
midstream.
By these signs was it known that, at last,
Agwala had moved; and like the great,
black toad Catherine had compared him
with, he had wallowed from his cushions
of silk and the words he whispered into the
ears of men were immediately translated
into machete blades,.muzzle-loaders, and,
here and there, an occasional rifle purloined
from the white man.
None of this was visible on the yacht,
however. Even Hogmanay and the Great
Dane had no proof of its actual existence.
They knew simply of an unrest; a^-faintly
perceptible rustle and stir that would ul-
timately express itself, in certain quarters,
in a red trickle of blood.
Merely as a precaution, the watch on the
yacht was quietly doubled. On the hulk
ancj Marsden's beach the Kroo headmen
were given monotoned orders to assign four
boys to night duty instead of the customary
one or two. But aside from this indication
of possible strife, the river was, to all ap-
pearances, quieter and more sober than at
any time since the Bonny had arrived there.
In these few days, too, the cluster of
canoes about the hulk diminished almost
hourly.
As Bart Jardine's stock of goods sank
lower and lower; as he scurried frantically
about the hold in search of a possible bale or
case that might have been forgotten, the
nondescript native traders who had poured
the wealth of the oil palm into his long, lean
The Gray Charteris
hands, drifted away from him to crowd
Hogmanay's breakwater or to proceed to
the business of emptying the warehouses
and shops of the Siluko and Koratown
independents.
Up at Grandison's beach, Ogulo-of-the-
long-armS slept by day and prowled more
cautiously than ever by night. He was in
sole possession of the place, and, from a
governmental standpoint, was not sup-

Therefore, on an evening, four days after
the disappearance of Charteris, when a pale
moon lurked intermittently behind scat-
tered banks of clouds and three indetermi-
nate shadows slipped in upon Ogulo from
behind, there was no one to whom the un-
gainly dwarf might have called for assis-
tance; nothing between him and death save
the quickness of his ear, the swiftness of his
foot and the ape-like length of his arms.
From right, from left and from behind,

with scarcely the sound of an indrawn
breath for warning.
With a low guttural of surprize, Ogulo
heard and sprang forward. Two of the
machete blades missed his head by a hair.
The third gashed his shoulder but did not
halt him long enough for a second blow to
be struck. He had no means of knowing
whether his assailants were three or thirty,
and, scurrying out of reach of those nearest
to him, with astonishing rapidity, he bolted
straight for the waterfront and plunged into
the swift running river.
His pursuers followed, but only for a
little while. Swimming as, in the Jakri
country, only Ogulo-of-the-long-arms could
swim, the dwarf speedily left the satellites
of Agwala far behind and headed directly
for Hogmanay's breakwater.
Arrived there, he cautiously became pos-
sessed of a canoe that belonged to Marsden
& Co., and, without any compunction or
apologies, he paddled out into mid-stream
and then headed straight up river.

looked out toward the Bonny and the
Jardine hulk.
"I go trade for hulk," he said sullenly.
"All right. Plenty canoe trade for
hulk."
Agwala winced and drew away from the
rail. MacGregor's sarcasm did not miss its
mark. Just at that moment the number of
canoes about the hulk was something less
than half a dozen. Consequently, there
was no balm in that direction. Agwala
might sell, for high prices, on credit if he
cared to. But he knew there was no cloth
or gin or salt or rice to be found anywhere---
except in the shops and warehouses of
Marsden & Co., and the trading-companies
affiliated with it.
For a minute, perhaps, he stood flat-
footed, facing Hogmanay, his great bulk
rocking slowly with a rage that was but
faintly expressed in the flatness of his eyes.
Then suddenly MacGregor rose, and
Tommy made a quick grab for his arm.
"Mac!"
"Get off my beach!"
"Careful, Mac! You'll kill him if you
hit him now!"
MacGregor paused and stiffened, and
Agwala backed slowly away, muttering to
himself. Tommy's hold on Hogmanay's
right arm tightened.
"Och! Why should I haud my hands?"
It was almost a lament. There was a
look in Hogmanay's normally twinkling
eyes that Tommy had never seen before.
Agwala took his departure as hastily as
possible, and waddled down to the gig-
wharf again. MacGregor stood between
two of the veranda uprights, a large hand
wrapped about each of them, and watched
every scuffling step the fat chief took.
He continued to watch as Agwala's
canoe drew away from the gig-wharf and
headed, as Hogmanay thought, for the
yacht. But Agwala's destination proved
to be the hulk, and when MacGregor was
sure of that, he let his hands fall to his
sides and observed,if or the first time in several
minutes, that Tommy was still at his elbow:
"Dod! I hope he'll no' tempt me like
that again!"

N A certain day in the long ago,
five gunmen descended from
surrounding hillsides and closed
in on Henry Madrigal, cowman,
who had assumed squatter's rights in the
San Andres Mountains before Government
surveyors had parceled out the country for
purposes of homesteading and purchase.
Madrigal fought a valorous but losing
battle, drilling two of his assailants into
eternal silence before the combat reached
the hand-to-hand stage. Then he clubbed
his long-barreled six-shooter and rendered
two more temporarily helpless before a bul-
let nicked his valiant Old heart.
Madrigal lived long enough to demand
that some one look after his "children"--
a little boy and girl, presumably waifs, who
were known to be living with him. They
had disappeared, and the supposition was
that the killers had included them in their
slaughter, but disposed of the bodies,
ashamed of their inhumanity.
Madrigal also, during the last hours of
his life, told Sam Barnhill, owner of the
Fying Y, in lurid and specific detail what
he thought of him.
Then he died, a martyr to the cause of
range freedom. In traditions of the South-
west he still lives as a criterion of courage.
Two of the gunmen, of course, required
nothing but burial for their services. The
other pair apparently received what they
thought they were worth and left for parts
unknown.
Zeigline, the one killer who remained
on his feet when Madrigal fell, squatted on
the location until Uncle Sam's engineers
platted, plotted and surveyed the San
Andres. Shortly thereafter title to the
Madrigal place passed to Barnhill--as
Madrigal in his last moments had prophe-
sied it would. Zeigline received his "pieces
of silver" in live stock bearing a Box X
brand--which, analyzed, was nothing more
or less than the Madrigal "M" amplified
and doctored by the branding-iron.
Even at that time Barnhill was con-
trolling range factor. His five thousand
head of cattle dotted the Flats that spread
like a canopy at the eastern base of the San
Andres. Madrigal had nested, several
miles back in the mountains with a small
bunch of live stock. This had made
Madrigal's western range boundary identi-
cal with the eastern limits of Flying Y,
which was intolerable to Barnhill, who saw
in it a design to usurp his empire and steal
his cattle.
He had dealt with it accordingly, vigor-
ously and expensively.
"The old Madrigal place" thus became
one of the numerous Flying Y camps.
Later it was known as "Madrigal place."
Today it is referred to as "Madrigal."
After this experience Barnhill looked to
his defenses, determined never again to be
afflicted by nesters. Like many great
generals, however, he overlooked one strate-
gic position. The Hackberry Hills bit a
right-angled chasm into the southwestern
extremity of the Flats and constituted a

Bern's appearance was not hailed as a

unknown and returned equally so. He took
nothing for granted, but looked up land
office records and discovered that Hack-
berry Hills were "open territory."
He entered into a partnership with the
youthful, ebullient and wholly efficient
Thad Wyman and developed a ranch con-
sisting of two-room bunk-house, corral,
wagon-shed, well and several hundred
head of cattle which fattened in the Grama-
grassed hills and valleys.
Among other things Bern brought back
with him forty years of ripe experience,
the muscularity of youth and a keen desire
to plant his wandering foot where it would
take root.
The tradition that a rolling stone gathers
no moss held true with Bern. Likewise the
axiom that an itinerant pebble acquires a
polish more desirable than any lichenic
growth. The physical burnishing was man-
ifested in the smooth bronze of his always
clean-shaved face where character lines
were etched lightly, due to the firm flesh
underneath preventing deeper inroads. The
mental refinement was reflected in his
speech, due probably to a painstaking study
of pure Castilian--a sure guide to perfect
English--and an ability to quote Shakespere
with ease and accuracy.
Bern had drunk of the Rio Grande years
before and had responded to another tra-
dition that "when you drink of the Rio
Grande, you must return before you die."
Bern was far from dead, but he answered to
the lure of the muddy waters nevertheless.
He returned, not to die, but to live. To
be sure, the Rio Grande flowed ten miles
west of the Hackberry Hills--but tradition
is allowed that much latitude.
A bond of affection, admiration and re-
spect linked Bern and his youthful partner,
quite aside from their business relationship.
Friends characterized them as "Tiger" and
"Cub." Each was all to the other, and they
reveled in their plans, work and play.
"Only one place in the world I'd rather
own than this," Bern was wont to comment
luxuriously after a hard day in the saddle
when he and Thad were enjoying their
after-supper smokes, "and that's Madrigal
Place. There's the last word in cow
ranches--big mountains, living springs,
pine-trees and range almost unlimited.
A real place for a home. And Barnhill
doesn't appreciate it. To him it's just
one of the camps."
And Thad, as regularly, unfolded his
secret:
"Barnhill only thinks he owns Madrigal.
The forty acres he holds patent to are lo-
cated nearly a quarter-mile from the
springs, accordin' to the way Land Office
records tally out with a secret survey I had
made. Why don't we grab it?
"Either the boss chainman miscounted
his chain lengths while runnin' his line
from the township comer-stake--which is
plum' easy t' do--or else the transitman
trusted to his memory 'stead o' his note-
book. Mebbe some land office clerk thought
he knowed better how t' describe the land
than Barnhill did--an' put it down 'south-
west quarter' 'stead o' 'southeast quarter,'
range, section, township so-an-so. Half the
patents in this country are held on faulty de-
scriptions--you know that, Louis--only
neighbors don't gen'rally bother each other
because they're friendly an' trust each
other. Barnhill, he don't trust any one--
an' I'd sure admire t' hang his hide on the
barn-door. I don't care whose barn it
is so long's the hide's ol' Sam's."
"What has Barnhill done to you?"
Bern would counter.
"Nothin'. But you know how he come
into possession of it--hirin' gunmen to kill
off old Henry Madrigal an' then buyin' a
relinquishment from Zeigline with Hank's
own cattle. We've got as much right to it
as he has."
"If I could be certain that Barnhill was
behind the murder of Madrigal-"
Bern never finished his soliloquy because
Thad was at him immediately with proof,
evidence, legend and hearsay,

"Interesting and undoubtedly true,"
Bern mused, studying the tracks carefully--
he knew the hoof imprint of every horse in
Goren';* string of mounts. '
The trail led through a pass in the red
rimrocks and then angled south where it
was joined by another.
"Thad's," Bern chuckled. "He must
have seen Goren coming. They both
stopped their horses and evidently had a
chat. Wonder what it was about?"
Wonderment increased to anxiety when
Bern noticed that Thad had reined along-
side Goren and accompanied him on the
southerly course.
He looked full at the sinking sun medita-
tively.
"It's time that boy was back at the
ranch," he decided, "but judging from the
freshness of the tracks and the direction
they take, he won't get there for some time."
The ranch lay to the northwest. "Goren
must have gotten him interested in some-
thing to lead him down here at this time
of day."
Another half-mile south, the tracks of the
two horses led into a rocky canon so desti-
tute of grass that cattle rarely strayed
into it.
"Strange place to go," Bern muttered.
"Never was here but once before, myself.
And I don't think Thad ever rode this
canon."
He spurred his mount, a magnificent
blood-bay, to a fast trot. Daylight would
soon fade, and he felt the necessity of follow-
ing the trail to its logical conclusion. This
was the most isolated part of B. W. range,
and Bern was reasonably curious to know
the reason for the pilgrimage.
He rounded a sharp jut in the canon and
solved the problem all in the same instant.
Gruya, Thad's mount, stood riderless,
nickering into a yawning prospect-hole
which had been abandoned many years
before by the discouraged miner who dug it.
Bern's mental eye beheld the scene of
tragedy as it must have been enacted; he
reconstructed the-events leading up to it:
Goren had lured Thad into the desolate
canon on some plausible pretext and then,
catching his victim off guard, the cattle de-
tective had either pushed or knocked him
into the pit. Boot tracks of both men
offered eloquent testimony, and Bern over-
looked nothing.
Bern hurled himself from the saddle,
his copper-hued face faded to a subdued
pink, and bellied his way to the crumbling
brink of the shaft.
"Thad!" he shouted into the darkness--
and the name rose up from the depths in
echo to mock him.
"Thad!" again he called--and the re-
bound of his voice ascended with a force
that seemed to smother him.
Bern had to summon all his reserve
courage to make his third attempt to rouse
Thad--
"If you are alive, Thad, in the name of
God, answer me!"
From the confused jumble of noise re-
bounding from the bottom and sides of the
abyss came the last three words, clear as if
shot from a sounding board--
"God, answer me!"
Bern snapped to a sitting position and
clapped hands to ears. The ghastly reper-
cussion unnerved him.
Action served as a sedative.
Knotting the rope which he took from
Gruya's saddle, he tied it to his own.. A
heavy rock, secured to the sixty foot length,
dangled in midair.
Tense despair gripped Bern.
" 'God, answer me!' " he quoted the re-
sounding words that had leered at him
from the open grave. "What shall I do?
Thad is gone! Dead! And I can't even
get his body."
For a moment Bern stood motionless,

his active brain grappling with the situa-

A flying leap carried him to Redman's

SWEAT blackened Redman's neck
as he held the terrific pace, re-
sponding to Bern's commands of
voice and steel. Bern knew that he must
sight Goren before dark, otherwise the
chase would be indefinitely prolonged;
Goren might even escape.
The trail led down into the next caiion
and showed that Goren was traveling easily,
apparently without fear of pursuit. The
isolated position of Granite canon--where
the crime was committed--with the meager
possibility that any one would invade it
for months, gave Goren a sense of security.
The chase led diagonally through Hack-
berry Hills toward the Flats, and Redman
quickly closed the intervening distance.
When dusk faded Bern decided that Goren
could not be more than a mile ahead and
guided his horse up a little pinnacle that
commanded a view of the next canon.
The sight of a lazily moving horseman in
the hazy depths below inspired Bern to a
gutteral exclamation of joy--choked back
barely in time to save him from discovery.
As it was, Goren turned in his saddle-
listening for a sound that he thought he
heard. Bern thought for an instant that
Goren saw him, but continued to "freeze"
in his place of semiconcealment behind the
scraggly limbs of a scrub cedar until the
man disappeared around a turn in the
canon. ,
Bern played a one-sided game of hide and
seek for the next half-hour. He rode the
ridges with utmost caution, stopping every
few minutes to listen. As darkness shrouded
the hills he followed Goren by sound. Al-
ways he rode a little faster than the man he
was following, and gradually he widened
the circle until finally he was in the lead.
Then he left Redman and, taking his
saddle-rope with him, crept silently down
the hillside, where he stationed himself in
protecting shadow of a giant clump of
mesquite. ___
Goren's first knowledge that he was not
alone came when a swish of rope warned
him--too late. A noose settled and tight-
ened about his neck. He loosed the bridle
reins to grapple with the strangling hemp
and was jerked unceremoniously from the
saddle. He hit the ground heavily and,
before he could recover, Bern was upon
him with the ferocity of a jungle beast and
the science of a wrestler.
Face down in the shale, rock and sand,
the cattle detective fought viciously against
a paralyzing leg-hold. Bern shifted to a
sitting position in the middle of Goren's
back, always drawing the tortured leg to-
ward him until the struggles ceased and
agonized profanity began; then he used
one hand to snatch Goren's gun from its
holster.
"Pardon my seeming roughness," Bern
panted, throwing a double half-hitch around
Goren's ankles with the loose end of the
rope, "but I'm in a hurry and can't stop
to argue."
He hastily "dallied" the lariat's remain-
ing slack around his own leg and increased
the tension to maintain the leverage on
Goren's limbs, drawing a hogging-string
from his belt with which he-trussed Goren's
wrists.
Bern made short work of freeing himself
from the rope, retrieving Goren's mount--
which had stopped to graze outside the
danger zone--and cutting from the saddle
the leather thongs that, under happier
circumstances, were used for packing pur-
poses. From these he fashioned another
tie-rope and used it to replace that portion
of the lariat binding Goren's ankles. He
also removed the noose from the detective's
neck and delivered a few succinct remarks
while coiling up the rope:
"This may seem a trifle unnecessary to
you, but just now I'm in need of an extra
length of rope for the purpose of getting my
partner's body from that prospect hole.
Also I want to be sure you'll be here when I
get back. See you in about an hour and a
half and then--I'll settle with you!"
Bern started to leave, then hesitated.
He came back and observed Goren's
tumble-bug efforts to free himself.

He unsaddled the horse, carried Goren to

THE Autumn chill inspired Goren
to efforts at escape. He knew that
the double-half hitches knotted be-
hind him at ankles and wrists, held him se-
cure; the saddle held him immovably in
place, but wriggling and squirming kept his
blood more actively in circulation. Then,
the sudden thought that Bern in retrieving
the body of his partner would learn defi-
nitely how he came to his death twisted
Goren's swarthy, mustachioed face into a
grimace of fear, and he set to work in earnest
to free himself from bondage.
He leaned back on the fleece-lined inner
surface of the saddle and pressed down. It
slipped a trifle as the circingles stretched.
He repeated the operation again and again,
sweating copiously with the labor. An hour
passed and the saddle was midway past
his hips.
Goren paused for rest and reflection.
If he could free himself of the saddle it
wouldn't be much of a trick to hop to a
sharp-edged rock and saw his wrist mana-
cles apart. Time was all he needed. He
calculated how long Bern would be gone:
It would take him at least twenty minutes to
ride the five mountainous miles to Granite
Canon.
Then--how long would it take for two
horses, pulling at a ninety-foot length of
saddle rope, to drag Bern and his inanimate
burden from the shaft? Goren pondered.
It couldn't be done! The dead weight of a
yearling on the end of a thirty-foot rope
was all the average cow-pony could move.
More than double that weight on even a
sixty-foot rope would either stall two horses
or break the rope.
Ninety feet of it would be impossible.
Bern would discover this only after experi-
ment that might be disastrous. At least
it would delay him while he figured out
some other plan. Then he would have to
dispose of the body. Would he take it to
the B. W. ranch? Probably. The county
coroner would be called in to determine,
officially, the cause of death, and he would
find-
Goren had enjoyed meditation on the
time element, but a forecast of the coroner's
findings, with Bern to assist, spurred him to
further activity. He had to escape or Bern
would kill him. If Bern didn't, the law
would.
The saddle slipped gratifyingly after
another fifteen minutes of writhing and
pushing; it fell to the ground, and the leather
skirts pinioned his spurs. He kicked them
free, bent over to find a fairly soft place on
the hillside where he could rest his head--
and then somersaulted from his saddle
prison.
A jagged rock freed his hands after
several minutes of awkward sawing, and his
pocket-knife cut the ankle-thongs. All he
had to do now was to catch his horse, saddle
him and leave promptly in a southerly di-

when he heard the clattering hoof-beats of a
galloping horse on the ridge to the north.
He knew then that Bern had upset the
time calculation in some manner and had
returned a full five minutes too soon.
Goren abandoned the saddle and rushed
toward his horse--which shied at his hasty
approach. Goren cursed and made a futile
grab at the trailing bridle-reins as Redman
came slithering down the slant with Bern
swaying easily in the saddle, uttering
ironical comment and advice:
"Speed up, Goren! You're slow as a drag
cow's tail. Do I note by the dim starlight
that you were about to leave bare-back?"
Bern hurled himself from Redman's
back, six-shooter in hand. Goren dashed
behind a boulder.
"Come out of there," Bern snapped.
"You can't hole up like a ground-hog.
Come out this way and I won't shoot.
Start in any other direction and I'll fill you
full of lead."
Goren appeared, hands elevated.
"Now," Bern told him. "Put your hands
down. I know, you're not heeled. You
need killing, but I can use you alive to bet-
ter advantage. You're going with me to
my ranch and there, with all the comforts of
home at your disposal, write a confession
about how you killed Thad Wyman--and
why."

A remonstrance surged as high as Goren's
larynx--and died there to the click of
Bern's gun. He thought about his knife,
buried snug and useless in the trousers'
pocket under his chaps.
"Roughly," Bern rambled on, "it will run
something like this: You met Wyman at the
B. W. range-border and roused his curiosity
about the shaft, which he'd never seen be-
cause none of our cattle ever go into
Granite Canon and consequently he hadn't
been there. The two of you dismounted,
and Wyman was looking into the hole when
you hit him on the back of the head with a
rock. He fell in and the rock went with
him. I found it beside him. Any re-
marks to make?"
"You're so wise," Goren sneered, edging
closer. "Maybe you know that Flyin' Y
cows sometimes stray there."
"You ought to know. You rode B. W.
range for months before I ordered you off.
Perhaps a dozen a year stray into Granite
Canon. I saw one there tonight."
This was interesting information to
-- Goren. He hadn't seen any. He wanted
to know about it, but other things were
more vital.
"An' what makes you think I clouted
Wyman with the dornic you found by his
body? Wasn't there any others near him?"
"Yes, but none others with hair and
blood."
Goren had maneuvered within striking
distance and sprang. His nose collided
violently with Bern's left fist.
"I hoped you'd do something like that,"
Bern told him, tossing the pistol into a bed
of gravel. "My hands itch for the feel of
you. Your gun's in one of Redman's
saddle-pockets; mine is where you see it--
behind me. Get them if you think you can
wade through me."
This was a chance Goren hadn't antici-
pated. Bare fists against a man twenty
pounds lighter than himself, who insanely
threw away his advantage. Catch-as-catch
can--grapple--kick. Goren knew the
rough-and-tumble game. Let him once
get his arms around Bern-
He rushed. Bern drove an accurate
"one-two" into the detective's midriff and
followed with a hurricane of staggering
blows to the face. Goren shook blood from
his eyes and waded in for more, crowding
Bern back toward the faint glint of the
blued Colt. His arms flailed the air with a
windmill motion and he felt he was making
progress in spite of the fearful punishment
he was taking.
Bern retreated before the onslaught of
superior weight until his boot-heel rested
on the butt of the six-shooter. Then he
planted himself and shot his fist with the
full power of shoulder and body behind it
to a point slightly below Goren's left ear.
The detective's feet cleared the ground, and
he lay unconscious where he fell while
Bern picked up the gun.
He was still prostrate after Bern had
caught and saddled the Flying Y pony. It
required the cold steel of a gun-barrel at the
back of his neck to revive him.
"Any further remarks before you write
the confession?" Bern inquired.
"Not none."
Goren mounted. Tears of agony crept
from his battered eyes and scalded his
abraised cheeks. His nose had been
wrecked and faultily repaired at some for-
mer date; its condition was now hopeless.
" 'Cept I'd like to know how you got
Wyman out o' that shaft so quick. Saddle
ponies never drug you out."
"Of course not," Bern laughed as he rode
beside his unfettered prisoner, with a pecu-
liar exultation that puzzled Goren. "I
didn't even try to use the horses. Didn't
it occur to you that I might anchor one
end of the rope to a boulder and climb out
hand-over-hand with Wyman lashed to
my back?"
"Nuh-uh," was Goren's ambiguous reply.
He looked at Bern in the faulty light with
a new appreciation. He tested his jaw
by moving it clockwise on its hinges and
shook his head to determine whether his
brains were still in place. He understood
now why Bern's hitting powers had the
qualities of a mule's kick. Prodigious
brawn was required to pull a weight of over
three hundred pounds, seventy-five feet
straight up, with nothing but an occasional
toe-hold to assist.
