same as ol' Henry Madrigal use' to do before
he got his. That's why I hired you--an'
you'd 'a' caught both of 'em cold if you'd
been onto your job."
Silence from Goren. He answered only
after his employer inquired testily--
"How did you work it to get Wyman,
then?"
"I led him down a canon in the Hack-
berries an' hit him on the head with a dornic
while he was peerin' down a seventy-five
foot prospect-hole."
The detective spoke without pride, almost,
it seemed, with reluctance.
"Serves him right, the - thief,"
Barnhill commended. "Wish his pardner
was there, too. But suppose some one
finds the body?"
"No one hardly ever goes into that
canon," Goren replied peevishly. "An'
what if they do? It'll look like he fell in.
The fall's enough t' kill him even if I
hadn't cracked him with a rock. I left
his horse standin' there so's it'd look plum'
natural if any one should happen along.
In case they don't, the horse'll wander home
after a while an' the country's that rough
he couldn't be back-trailed."
"Sounds reasonable," Barnhill applauded
in guarded tones. Then, cautiously:
"How're you goin't' keep folks from talkin'
about you gettin' in so late? The hands'll
all know what time you slip into the bunk-
house."
"I'm leavin' the coimtry tonight," Goren
announced, "an' want my pay It's three
hundred an' twenty-five bucks."
"How come?" Barnhill inquired in the
manner of one who knows the answer to his
own question.
"I got twenty-five cornin' for the last two
weeks' ridin' an' three hundred which you
promised if I got either Bern or Wyman."
He spoke with some animation, glancing at
the north wall of the adobe. "Well--I got
Wyman."
Barnhill demurred:
"How do I know, except by your say-so,
that you've earnt the bonus? Besides,
what makes you think I've got that much
money on me?"
"You've got it 'less you lied," Goren
answered the last question. "You told me
this mornin'--or yest'day mornin'--before
I left here that the cash was in the safe in
your office. You said further that it'd
stay there ten days 'less I claimed it sooner
on account o' breakin' up th' B. W. com-
bination. If I didn't qualify for it in that
time I was to get th' gate. Three hundred
for either pardner'--seven-fifty for both--■
was the agreement.
"One's all I care t' collect on/ You go
get the money, an' I'll furnish proof that
Wyman's dead."
Barnhill climbed into the window and
Goren found time for a snatch of conversa-
tion with the man in hiding.
Faint signs of dawn streaked the east
when the cattleman emerged from the
room. His hands were full of greenbacks
and his eyes, naturally protuberant, were
filled with amazement as he stared at his
employe.
"How'd your face get that-a-way?" he
demanded. "It looks like the last act in a
barbecue."
Adventure
"I had a fall," Goren explained.
"Lookin' this way is one reason I'm in a
hurry to leave here."
"Horse fall with you?"
"No, I fell off him." Goren's temper was
wearing to a thin edge and his reply was
acid. "Say, do I have to wait here till
noon or do I get that money before it's
-good daylight?"
"Soon's I get proof that Wyman's been
accounted for." Barnhill reluctantly talked
business, though still fascinated by the
bruised and gory appearance of the detec-
tive's features. "Show me somethin' be-
longin' t' Wyman-"
Goren interrupted wearily and rudely: ,
" 'Somethin' belongin' to Wyman'? All
right. How'll Bern do? Step out!"
He called to the man around the corner.
Barnhill's startled vision followed the
direction of Goren's last two words and his
angular frame almost collapsed at sight of
Bern advancing from his place of conceal-
ment. \
Bern approached leisurely, his .45 caliber
six-shooter preceeding him with sinister
smoothness.
If the Avenging Angel with flaming sword
had made its appearance at that moment
the effect on the Flying Y owner might have
been slightly more enervating--though that
is doubtful. Enervation was sufficiently
complete to enable Goren to pluck the blood
money from his employer's nerveless hands
--convincing evidence that Mr. Barnhill
was not his normal, tight-fisted self. Or
perhaps he was satisfied with Goren's proof
of fidelity to orders.
Goren left without troubling to count the
currency.
Bern spoke first, the flash from his blue
eyes--now visible in the semi-light, adding a
certain meaning to his softly spoken words:
"Mr. Goren neglected to mention, I be-
lieve, that he was overtaken by the surviv-
ing member of the B. W. outfit. That will
explain, perhaps, the condition of his
none-too-Grecian features, but modesty
forbids me to give the painful details.
Perhaps I was a trifle testy, knowing, as I
did, that he'd sent my partner to the bottom
of a seventy-five-foot shaft."
Barnhill's comment indicated an entire
lack of sympathy for either partner--
"I've been double-crossed by that-"
"--cross between a barbed-wire fence and
a skunk," Bern supplied amiably.
"However, he didn't double-cross you
voluntarily. Surely he wouldn't abuse the
confidence of so splendid a gentleman as
yourself."
The silken irony caused Barnhill real
discomfort. He choked back an oath and
bit a perceptible chunk from his mustache.
Bern continued amiably:
"Passing lightly over unessentials, Mr.
Goren became sufficiently penitent to ac-
company me to B. W. ranch, where he
penned a complete confession. You*will be
interested to learn that this confession of a
not-too-penitent soul contained your name
no less than twenty-one times and would
seem to incidate that he had embarked on
his career of crime to save his job."
"Why did y'u let him get away?"
Barnhill snarled, regaining his natural
poise. "Don't devil me with his doin's."
"I'll be perfectly frank with you," Bern
pursued genially, modulating his voice as he
heard voices in the bunk-room. "I let
Goren escape because I promised to do so.
Your recent transaction with him shows the
sacredness with which you regard a prom-
ise, so I know you will understand why I
kept mine--when I explain.
"Goren bought his chance to escape by
writing the confession and by leading me to
this place where I could hear you express
yourself with such a charming lack of self-
restraint. I might add that Goren knew
that a gun was trained on him during all the
time he was making his report to you and
that it would never have been completed if
he had warned you that there was a witness.
If he had failed me I would have killed him
without more ado--and slightly less regret."
"Go ahead an' kill him," Barnhill sug-
gested helpfully. "He can still be over-
taken, an' you've give him his chance."
"You have followed my recital with dili-
gent care," Bern reproved him, "but you
never seem to get ahead of me. Wouldn't it
be an act of rare discretion on your part
to offer me hush money. Somewhat on the
order of your arrangement with Zeigline
after he and his companions killed Henry
Madrigal-"
Bern had expected an outburst at this
suggestion. Instead Barnhill snatched
eagerly at it--
"How'd five hundred dollars do?"
Bern controlled his emotions, but a new
quality crept into his voice--
"Come around to the north side of the
Uncle Henry Would Enjoy This
house where we won't be seen when the
boys come out of the bunk-room."
Barnhill obeyed uneasily, wondering what
counter-proposition he would have to deal
with, but relieved when Bern sheathed
his gun.
"When I came back to New Mexico I
heard--and only half-believed--the story
about Henry Madrigal's being killed at your
orders. The fact that -Zeigline apparently
got nothing but the Madrigal M cattle-
changed to a Box X--for his relinquish-
ment to the place gave it some semblance of
foundation. I know that you rode up to
the Madrigal place a very few minutes
after the old man was killed, too, and were
apparently on friendly terms with the
gunmen--but that didn't, prove anything.
My impression was that the dirty cowards
who hire assassins for their work lived only
in fiction. However, the business of this
night convinces me that at least one is alive.
If that wasn't enough, your remark of a few
minutes ago would be plenty.'"
Barnhill snarled again:
"We're dealin' with the present. The
past is dead an' buried."
"In one sense only is it dead and buried.
The present links itself with the past rather
importantly," Bern retorted. "You'll re-
member the two children, orphans, who
were living with Henry Madrigal at the
time your men killed him. Well--I'm one
of them. The other was my sister. Cudgel
your memory a bit and see if you can't
remember that the children's names were
-Louis and Louise."
It was evident from Barnhill's ghastly
pallor that he did.
"Sis and I were back in the hills gathering
wild raspberries when the shooting began.
She ran, I after her, and we got back in time
to see Uncle Henry--yes, he was my
mother's brother--lying apparently dead
and strangers in possession of the place.
We didn't know exactly what it all meant,
but we decided that men who would kill
lovable old Uncle Henry would do the
same to us. So we didn't give them the
chance. We tramped to Roswell--and it
was a hideous trip for us kids; Sis was nearly
dead when we arrived. I got a job as er-
rand boy in a grocery store; later, I worked
/as a horse-wrangler and sent Louise to New
England where we had some distant rela-
tives. Then I started out to see the world.
I've seen it now and came back here to
settle down because I love the country--it
contains the only memories of a home that
I can remember--Uncle Henry had moth-
ered Louise and me since we were babies."
"Henry Madrigal's nephew!" Barnhill
found his voice after exercising his Adam's
apple for several minutes.
"Yes," Bern answered levelly. "And
you've sent your killers against the two
men who have been the best friends I've
ever known. One substituted for my
mother--and did as good a job of it as any
man could do; the other my pal--you
probably don't know what the word means
in its glorified sense--the sort that I'd
liked to have had as a son if I'd ever mar-
ried. You even cost me the privilege of
growing up with my sister--she died ten
years ago--by destroying our home.
"In view of these things I'm going to sell
the B. W. ranch to you--at my price.
My reasons are, I suppose, obvious to you--■
I don't want it because of the associated
memories. I'll sell the whole layout, lock,
stock and barrel, reserving only the saddle-
horses, for twenty thousand dollars."
Barnhill stared glassily at the northern
horizon.
"Do I understand that Wyman's disap-
pearance will always remain one o' the mys-
teries of this country in case I buy at your
price?" he asked, biting another section
from the overhanging brush on his upper
lip. "That's a full five thousand more'n
the outfit's worth. It's a hold-up."
"It may be," Bern snapped in a tone
that roused Barnhill to the need for more
guarded utterance, "but it's not murder.
I need twenty thousand to carry out a plan
that Thad would approve. He's often
mentioned it, but there's always been an
obstacle in the way, and I'm willing, for the
sake of accomplishing this thing, to keep
quiet about Goren's confession.
"I'd suggest, therefore," he concluded
briskly, "that you make out your check for
the amount named and we will then proceed
to Marona--the county seat--in your high-
powered flivver, where the cashier will do
some certifying where it will do the most
good; also we can complete the transaction
while we're there and B. W. will belong to
you before the day is over."
"But how can you give title to the place
without certifyin' to Wyman's death?"
Barnhill inquired.
"Quitclaim. Thad's idea," Bern replied
Adventure
tersely. "When we found that you'd put
a detective on our trail, he insisted that
we each quitclaim to the other in case of
accidents. I thought it was useless--but I
see now that he knew your caliber."
"Where's y'ur horse?" demanded Barn-
hill with sudden animation.
"Behind the corral," Bern told him
promptly, sensing and 'sympathizing with
Barnhill's desire for secrecy.
"Get 'im quick. Lead 'im around here.
Unsaddle; throw your kak inside this door
an' ride bareback into the horse pasture
while I jockey my car out o' the wagonshed.
I'll pick you up in about five minutes.
Snappy, now, before any o' the hands
tumble out o' the bunk-house an' see you."
Bern was on his way. He knew that
Redman, sweat-stained and leg-weary,
would betray his nocturnal visit to the
horse-wrangler, who would be on the job
within fifteen minutes,--but that was some-
thing for Barnhill to worry about. Specu-
lation would be rampant among the Flying
Y cowboys immediately upon discovery of
Bern's horse in Flying Y pasture--and
Barnhill could think of his own explana-
tions.
BARNHILL'S sense of business
acumen was outraged by the price
he was called upon to pay for a "two
by twice" cattle outfit. The same inner
prompting, however, told him that while
the monetary consideration was far above
the market value, it bought a protection
worth infinitely more--if Bern would,keep
his promise to remain silent.
He decided that the next time he re-
quired the private and violent services of a
cattle detective he would hire someone who
knew the value of a. clean getaway.
A lurking suspicion that he was being
victimized found expression as he was
piloting his runabout along the sandy road
to Marona.
"Say," he jerked out, "we don't do any
business till I see that confession you say
Goren wrote."
Bern, who had been soliloquizing on the
softness of saddles as compared with the
once springy seat he now shared with
Barnhill, smiled easily.
"I'm surprized you didn't think of that
before. While you're busy with that steer-
ing wheel, I'll just spread it out for your
inspection. It would seem, though," he
rebuked his companion, "that you might
be willing to take the word of a trusted
employe who reported the work done, thus
showing great fidelity to your interests."
Barnhill's jaw muscles moved as if his
tongue had been inspired to voice a fitting
rejoinder--then relaxed. Bern reached into
his inside vest pocket--he wore no coat--
and produced the document which he held
where Barnhill could read it.
The contents evidently made unpleasant
reading matter.
"He lies," was the only comment.
"Your soft impeachment would sound a
trifle more chummy if I hadn't been an ear--
and eye-witness to your cheerful conver-
sation with Goren," Bern remarked return-
ing the paper to his pocket. "Perhaps, as
additional proof you'd like to inspect the
shaft in Granite Canon. I could let you
down with a rope."
Barnhill's rugged features registered irri-
tation at the first part of Bern's comment
and a violent distaste at the latter. He
was sufficiently in Bern's power now without
submitting to being tied to one end of a
rope over which Bern had complete control.
The gasoline sand-boat did most of the
talking for the remainder of the fifty-five
mile trip to Marona, and conversation in
that bustling county seat was confined
strictly to the business of purchase and sale
of B. W. ranch and cattle. m
Bern thanked Barnhill cordially for the
offer--which was not made--of a ride back
to Flying Y headquarters and requested
that his horse be kept in pasture until
called for.
"I'm headed south on the evening train,"
Bern confided, "and you probably won't
see me for some time." **
Mr. Barnhill's mobile features again
registered a sentiment which Bern inter-
preted to mean' that if the Flying Y owner
never saw him again, that would be soon
enough.
THE following week provided in-
IjjSgP! terest for all persons who knew
Thad Wyman, Louis Bern or Goren.
The purchase of B. W. by Barnhill would
have caused little comment had it not been
accompanied by the disappearance of both
partners and the Flying Y rider. Rumor
from Marona had it that Bern alone repre-
sented B. W.'s interests at the sale and
that he used a quitclaim to complete legal
Uncle Henry Would Enjoy This
formalities. It became known, too, that
Bern's mount remained at Flying Y while
"Gruya," Wyman's favorite pony, had been
at the home ranch when Barnhill's cowboys
tallied out the newly purchased live stock.
Barnhill, for reasons of personal policy,
kept his own counsel with regard to Bern
and Wyman and explained the departure
of Goren on the grounds of an urgent mes-
sage from home folks in Texas.
Another phase of Barnhill's personal
policy induced him to drive into Tedler--
shipping-point, post-office and merchan-
dising center of that territory, eleven miles
north of the ranch--to ask Hal Currie, the
deputy sheriff, whether anything had been
heard about Bern or Wyman. He was
anxious tp learn whether any foul play
was suspected or discussed.
Currie's mouth being too full for polite
utterance at the moment, he emptied it of
liquid content before replying. Then he
said he "reckoned Bern and Wyman knew
what they were doing and would show up
when they got good and ready."
The trip to town was not, however, with-
out thrills for Barnhill.
A letter postmarked El Paso sent him
flying to the hotel telephone. After being
connected with a Marona number, he gave
excited directions and waited perspiringly
for a return call. When it came, after a
half-hour interval, he swore venomously into
the transmitter and ordered that a sur-
veying crew be shipped to Tedler on the
afternoon train.
Emerging sweatily from the phone booth
he drew the letter from his pocket and re-
read it to assure himself that he hadn't
excited himself unduly.
He had not. The letter read:
El Paso. Sept. 30.
Dear Mr. Barnhill:
This will introduce the T. L. Cattle Company,
which respectfully requests the immediate removal
of all Flying Y cattle from the water known as
"Madrigal."
This land, we are informed, has long been con-
sidered Flying Y property, but a survey, made pre-
liminary to our purchase of same from the Govern-
ment proves otherwise. Your holdings, some forty
acres secured by patent, are located about four
hundred yards south of the ground you claim.
Our leases, in addition to what we have acquired
by purchase, fully protect our interest in the range.
While, of course, your cattle have a perfect right to
graze on the forty acres you own, the range will, I
think, prove too limited and dry for either comfort
to them or profit to you.
I will take this opportunity to make an appoint-
ment with you at the Tedler hotel for the morning of
October 2. I will arrive on Number Four, which is
due at 10:30. Better make it about the time of my
arrival as a trainload of T. L. cattle will land in
Tedler shortly after the passenger. The stock will
be driven to Madrigal immediately as the four-
hour ride from El Paso will not necessitate their
being held for rest in the stock pens.
Yours very truly
Louis Bern, Manager.
Citizens of Tedler contend that Barnhill
frothed at the mouth that last day of Sep-
tember and cursed lawyers, surveyors and
Louis Bern with equal and animated feroc-
ity. He talked mostly to himself, but Hal
Currie overtook him on the board sidewalk
in front of Elliott's store after hearing the
name of Bern mentioned hotly.
"Do I gather that you heard from
Louis Bern?" Currie inquired sociably,
lighting a long, crooked stogie.
"Blah!"--or words to that effect--an-
swered the harassed cattleman.
"Does he say where he's been or what
he's doin'?" the plump deputy pursued the
subject, apparently absorbed in the sput-
tering end of his smoke.
He looked up, expecting a reply; then, in
utter surprize, he craned his neck, owl-like,
and saw Barnhill stumping angrily in the
direction whence he had come.
J BARNHILL'S operations during the
next forty-eight hours subsequent to
the receipt of Bern's letter were
guided largely by three important con-
siderations: (first) The surveyors hired by
him verified Bern's statement that Madrigal
was not Flying Y property; (second) Bern
was possessed of information and proof that
would ruin him; and (third) Barnhill, though
an oppressor and a bully, felt a very personal
and physical fear of the bronzed cowman
who spoke with sardonic gentleness while
his eyes glittered with a menace of sudden
death.
The cattleman, seated on the Tedler hotel
gallery waiting for the arrival of Number
Four, reflected moodily on the scurvy trick
played by the Rio Grande in reaching out
to the ends of the world and bringing back
the man who as a child had drunk of its
turgid waters.
This circumstance was no less incredible--
and no less true--than the fate that had
caused him to cross the trail of Louis Bern,
the nephew of Henry Madrigal, twenty-nine
Adventure
years after the old pioneer had laid down
his life for the same underlying cause that
brought about the original conflict.
Most unbelievable of all was that Bern,
of the Madrigal blood, should come into
possession of the hills and valleys his uncle
lost--after fighting and dying for them.
Number Four steamed into the station
where most of Tedler's population--some
three hundred when they were all at home--
was gathered.
Amazement and joy held them speechless
as Louis Bern descended the day coach
steps. Then:
"Thought you'd left us for keeps!"
"How come?"
"Welcome to our fond embrace!" greeted
him.
Hand clasps and slaps on the back--also
a trampling of his toes, which were clad in
a pair of new, elegantly stitched riding-
boots--followed. Bern's weathered face
relaxed into smile-lines and crows' feet as
he shook sinewy paws, two at a time.
"I didn't think any one'd miss me," he
declared happily. "Only been gone a little
over a week."
Some one asked, "Where's Thad?" and
Bern pretended not to hear. He whisked
off his gray, undented, wide-brimmed hat--
also new--and cleared a path for himself.
"See you all later and talk till I'm out of
breath," he promised them, "but I can't
stop now; got an appointment to meet Mr.
Barnhill at the hotel."
A half-dozen cowboys and citizens were
still at his sides and heels when he ap-
proached Barnhill.
The rancher, without offering to shake
hands, suggested that they retire to his room
on the second floor.
"More privacy," he recommended, sig-
nificantly eying Bern's retinue of followers.
The lone chair in Barnhill's room induced
Bern to park himself on the bed.
"I judge you got my letter," Bern opened
fire smilingly.
A wry twist of the cattleman's mouth
answered. He was looking out of the
window.
"Is there anything further for us to mill
over?" Bern inquired.
"Yes, there is," Barnhill stormed, sud-
denly jumping to his feet. "I've got all
possible o' my cattle moved from Madrigal,
but there's still five thousand dollars' worth
of improvements there an' you needn't
think y'u can steal that, along with th'
range. I'll fight y'u to a finish 'less I get
paid for it."
"Tut, tut," Bern chided him. "I have
stolen nothing. I'm merely collecting in
part for thirty years' use of Madrigal place
--my rightful inheritance. And Uncle
Henry paid a thousand times over--with
his life--for any improvements you've
made. For all that, my partner and I are
willing to-"
"So," Barnhill sneered. "You cash in on
the death o' your friend Wyman an' then
gather yourself another pardner in less'n
two weeks. What kind of a man do y'u
call y'urself? That boy--" he waxed sen-
timental--"still layin' in a cold hole in the
ground an' you galiivantin' 'round on the
proceeds o' his death."
A blue blaze leaped into Bern's eyes.
"It will probably ease your tortured soul
to learn that I saw to the reclaiming of
Wyman's body the historic night when
Goren, at your orders'-"
"Where did y'u bury him?" Barnhill cut
in breathlessly. "Won't some one be ap'
to find the grave?"
"That's for you to worry about," Bern
shot at him. "All I promised to do was
keep quiet about the confession."
A cattle-train snorted past the station
and both men watched it back on to the
switch and move to the railroad stock pens.
Bern reached for his hat.
"Come along with me to the pens and I'll
tell you something for the good of your
soul," he said.
Barnhill concurred grumpily. He must
learn where Wyman's grave was located
and make certain that it wouldn't be dis-
covered.
"You remember I told you that I needed
twenty thousand dollars to carry out a plan
of Thad's?" Bern recalled as they clattered
down the hotel stairs. "Well--he wanted
to take Madrigal place away from you. He
knew about the defective title long before I
came into the country. And I couldn't
think of any more fitting way to avenge
him than by making good on his favorite
idea and using your money to do it. Poetic
justice, I'd call it, particularly as it brings
Madrigal place back into the family--
where it belongs."
Barnhill bristled like an angry dog.
He didn't enjoy being ridiculed--particu-
larly by a man who had stripped him of
Uncle Henry Would Enjoy This
thousands in money and the cream of his
range. The fact that he had laid himself
wide open to the attacks and deserved the
penalty didn't ease the agony.
Bern grinned.
"It will interest you to know that my
present partner was taking a gang of sur-
veyors out to Madrigal place the same day
I sold B. W. to you. I waited for him in
Marona till he got back with the description
of the land and we made our purchase before
the land office closed. His name didn't
appear on the papers so your attorney put
all the blame on me. As a matter of fact,
though, I've given him an undivided half-
interest in Madrigal."
Barnhill snorted--
"Dickerin' with an outsider while you
an' Wyman were still pardners--or else
you throwed in with this other party before
Thad was cold in death."
The caboose of the cattle-train was less
than ten yards up the track and three cow-
boys filed out of the door, clambering from
the steps as the brakeman signaled the
engineer. The train crunched to a jarring,
jangling stop. Cattle bellowed.
"Is one o' those waddies your pardner?"
Barnhill asked, looking at the strangers.
"No," Bern puzzled. "I thought he'd
be the first one out--oh, there he comes now.
Take a slant at the crippled waddie in the
doorway."
Barnhill took a slant--and continued
at it, stupefied and spineless.
"That's my partner--the 'T' part of the
T. L. brand," Bern informed him dryly.
"Smart boy; fell down a seventy-five-foot
prospect-hole after being hit on the head
with a rock, and had the sense to land on the
carcass of a Flying Y cow; only broke his
collar-bone and had a bad headache."
From the back platform Thad Wyman
kissed his fingers coquettishly at Barnhill
and paved the way for friendly gossip:
"Next time you write to Goren just
mention my name an' tell him that I ap-
prove his confession in all respects--even
though he did overrate himself as a thorough
workman. I was in the bunk-room rubbin'
horse liniment on my head while he an'
Bern were millin' things over in the kitchen
at B. W. Remember it took five gunmen,
workin' overtime, to clean up on Henry
Madrigal, an' while I know I ain't in his
class, still I think you insulted me by sehdin'
only one-"
"Meanin' just what?" demanded Hal
Currie, who headed the gathering crowd
that swarmed near the caboose steps to bid
Thad "welcome home."
The question stung Barnhill's somnolent
powers of locomotion into vigorous activity.
The defunct B. W. partner, now present
and too much alive, was bound by no pledge
of secrecy; and the deputy's query would, he
astutely surmised, bring disclosures in no
wise calculated to increase his popularity.
He pawed into the throng--there being no
other way to escape--with an eye to the two
hundred yards of clear space separating the
hotel from the stock pens.
"Meanin'," Thad grinned cheerfully as he

Oksook, the old medicine-man, peered

stretch, shook his matted head ominously

But the young bucks laughed. Who be-

The old man chewed his toothless gums

How things had changed! Oksook was not
an Indian. His was a parentage of a burly
Russian soldier and an Eskimo squaw. He
had spent his fatherless youth and early
manhood on the desolate salt marshes of the
Yukon delta. What a terrible struggle for

crouching through the long Winters in
stinking igloos. The hardships had forged
him into a powerful, sinewy hunter who
threw a harpoon with accuracy and force.
Then had come the gold-strike up the
Yukon at Dawson. Thousands of white
men came hurrying north to the Island of
St. Michael. Great river-boats were built
to carry the passengers and freight up-river.
It was on one of these boats that Oksook
got a job as pilot and came to leave the dis-
mal wastes by the Bering. There were no
eyes keener than Oksook's to detect snags
and sand-bars beneath the roily waters.
Time brought him far up the Yukon to
Oksook
the Tananas. Disease and whisky had not
yet contaminated this sturdy tribe, and
Oksook found the lithe, slender squaws
much to his liking. They were not like the
fat, greasy Eskimo women on the coast.
With his new manners and air of bravado
picked up from the boisterous boat crews he
soon ingratiated himself into the favor of
the tribe. Cunning and patience inherited
from his Slav father gained him fame and
prestige. He came to be known among the
various tribes on the Yukon and Tanana
rivers as Oksook, the Great Medicine-Man.
Month after month, year after year he sat
in his little cabin among his pots and bags
of herbs, brewing, muttering and sleeping,
while the hunters brought him the fattest

turn for these favors Oksook made charms
so that when the countless hordes of caribou
migrated north to their Winter feeding-
grounds in the Koyokuk they always crossed
the Yukon near the village of the Tananas.
Always it was his medicine that filled the
caches with fish. Therefore as he grew old
and fat Oksook smiled and was happy.
But there came a Summer when the
salmon changed the course of their run and
avoided the squeaking fish-wheels. of the
Tananas. Farther up the river the drying

Day after day he stewed and concocted

a new ridge north and 'crossed the river far
above the Tananas.
The Kantishnas laughed gleefully and
boasted of strong medicine as they traded
their fish and meat to the Tananas for fox
and beaver-skins. Now came also a noisy
little missionary, who told them that
Oksook's medicine was fraud and Oksook
was ruined.
Thus it was that the old native became
the joke of the village and an object at
which the boys threw sticks and the squaws
scolded when he begged for bits of meat and
cast-off moccasins. Each year as he,
starved and became more wretched the old
man grew more bitter and morose. He had
long since ceased making medicine, but
every morning left the village with its vici-
ous urchins and went down the trail to
Tanana where he loitered about the saloons
and stores. Often he met white men who
had known him when he had been famous,
and sometimes they gave him money and
whisky.
But this Winter promised to be long and
hard and the old medicine-man felt uneasy
when at night he heard the malemiuts
mourn with their pointed noses toward the
green sky.

"Wal the old boy used to pull some pretty

But Oksook was not drunk. He was
crouching over the battered stove in his
miserable cabin up at the village. A
twenty dollar gold-piece given him by
Scurvy still fested in his pocket. He was
absorbed in gloomy reflections.
Today an old Indian had come chattering
with fear to tell him of the dreadful noises
that had been heard on Bull Island. The
tale had puzzled Oksook, but with devilish
cunning he had painted to the superstitious
old buck an evil picture. No doubt it was
the great magoona which had come to the
water-hole to drink. The native knew the
magoona to be a terrible creature. Mas-
todons the white men called them.
Only a few miles down the river was a
high sandy bluff, known by the sour doughs
as the bone-yard, from which protruded
scores of gigantic bones. Often as the
natives hurried by this ill-omened spot in
their canoes they wondered what must
have been the awful ferocity of these pon-
derous brutes. A magoona was no animal
to trifle with.
From a mind inflamed with bitter re-
sentment and years of morbid reflection,
old Oksook portrayed to the shivering In-
dian a frightful vision of gruesome monsters
stalking down from the vast unknown bar-
rens to the north to visit disaster and death
upon villages, over which the protecting
influence of a medicine-man was not ex-
tended.
The old buck had slunk from- the cabin
to tell his fellows of this grisly thing hidden
in the dense thickets across the river. With
the coming of darkness the frightened vil-
lagers huddled together to spend a sleepless
night.
Left alone in the hut Oksook had found
it difficult to shake off the mood into which
he had worked himself. What could that
noise have been? He regretted that he had
not heard it. Perhaps it really was some
terrible creature wandered down from the
wastes above the arctic rim. No man knew
what the inhospitable stretches of this un-
explored region contained. If only the
blizzard would raise its concealing curtain
of snow and cease its confusing din.
He thought longingly of the reviving
whisky to be had down at Mickey's Place.
But on opening the door a whirling cloud
of powdery snow enveloped him and he
hastily shut it again. It was no weather for
an old man to be on the trail.
Not alone the Siwashes, however, were
destined to be frightened by the mysterious
noise this night.
Steadily the scream of the winds increased
as they filled the air with hissing snow.
Down on the unbroken stretch of the Yukon
an inferno of flying ice streamed and roared
between the high bluffs. Little life stirred
abroad. Even the woolly malemiut curled
his bushy tail over his nose and forgot to
howl.
But there was one man on the trail who
fled before the frosty hurricane and prayed
that he might soon reach shelter. He was
Pat Riley, the mail-driver from Fairbanks
to Tanana. He was late. The trail had
been soft with drifting snow and both he
and the dogs were fagged. It was with
gladness that he sensed the steep sloping of
the trail where it began its plunge down on
to the Yukon. Two miles more and he
would be at the little store which also served
as Tanana's post-office.
He paused to get his bearings before mak-
ing the dash across the howling confusion
below. When he had gone up to Fairbanks
just after freeze-up he had seen the open
stretch of water near the trail. Tonight he
would have to be careful because the ter-
rific wind would tend to crowd the dogs to-
ward the opening.
Ice had formed on his eyelashes and he
drew his hands from his warm mittens to
thaw it loose. Once on the river it would be
a grim struggle till the other bank was
reached.

It was Kitty who gave warning of the

Riley staggered forward to where the

He stooped and patted the dog.
"Good girl Kitty. Good girl."
A slight lull had come as if the storm foiled

moan of the storm in the spruce-trees

Then just before the wind-sirens renewed
their frenzied screaming, Riley heard a
noise that sent tiny electrical shocks

ghastly, surging sob through the quivering

The man threw up his forearm and shrank

Riley was Irish and had guts, but he also

A stinging lash ripped time and time

Kitty scurried frantically in a half-circle

It was near closing time in the saloon and

Only one or two noticed Riley's silent

"Thought Pat didn't hit the hooch any

As the man twisted his head to look, the

"Yeh," replied Riley shortly as he

The men sensed a change in his manner

Soon the mail-driver came over and stood

They had paused for a new deal when

The men glanced at one another queerly,

With an ever-watchful eye for oppor-

EARLY morning came, and with a
vast consumption of stimulants the
origin of the disturbing noise ever
increased in fantasy and' supernaturalism.
Nothing definite could be decided on. It
was finally resolved that when the blizzard
ceased, an expedition should go through the
thick brush on the island and endeavor to
learn the cause of this perplexing mystery.
Thus the matter stood when a last round of
drinks was consumed before the men shuf-
fled off to their cabins.
Strange to say one or two wood-choppers,
who lived across the river, decided to stay
overnight at the little hotel.
"She'll be too cold to cut wood in the
mornin'," they explained sheepishly.
But with daylight the storm grew worse.
Even old French Joe, who upon any occa-
sion could always remember a past situation
of double the intensity, sat silent and awed
by this terrific display of weather forces.
Excursions to outlying wood-piles assumed
the hardships of polar exploration. Never
had such a blizzard been seen on the Yukon.
However, in spite of the mountainous
heaps of shifting snow and blinding flurries
that whipped over exposed portions of the
trail, early forenoon saw Oksook wallowing
on his ancient snowshoes down to Tanana.
The burning possession of a twenty dollar
gold-piece and a morbid night of superstiti-
ous wakefulness had driven him out of his
gloomy cabin to seek companionship.
Upon his arrival at the little cluster of
half-buried buildings he lost no time in
spending part of his money for a generous
bottle of bootleg whisky. Neither Indians
nor half-breeds could buy liquor over the
bar in Tanana, but a detour to the back
door always resulted in a flaskful of a mur-
derous concoction prepared only for natives.
The news of the fearful noises coming
from Bull Island and their terrorizing effect
on the Indians in the village had spread
quickly among Tanana's few inhabitants.
Thus because of his once having been medi-
cine-man, Oksook found himself the object
of continual banter and some ridicule.
At first he took it good-naturedly, smiling
sagely to himself; but as the day wore on
and he drank more and more of his flask,
his good humor changed to irritation and
anger which did not decrease the sport but
served rather to aggravate it to mockery.
This continued more or less throughout the
day until evening came with its more boister-
ous gathering in the saloons. He retorted
to his tormentors with snarls of wounded
vanity until at last unable to withstand any
longer the continuous attack, he staggered
from a chair in the barroom where he had
been sitting and shouted frantically to his
revilers.
"Me show you. Me show you. Oksook
he make strong medicine. He stop beeg
noise on Bull Island."
With this he stumbled out into the night
followed by a great hubbub of drunken jeers
and laughter. Outside the door he swal-
lowed the remainder of his liquor and
crashed the bottle against the heavy logs
of the building.
Even in his passion-befuddled mind he
realized that he had made a fool of himself.
Now because of his insane boast he would
be jeered and laughed at also among the
white men. With the fumes of the poison-
ous whisky lashing him to a frenzy of des-
pair and anguish he bowed his head into
the storm and followed a heedless direction
which led him not up the trail to the village,
but down on to the wind-scourged surface
of the river.
No one but a drunken Eskimo could have
beaten his way up against that freezing
storm. He followed no straightway course,
but buffeted from side to side by the blasts,
slipped and floundered among the troughs of
powdery crystals between the clean-swept
ice-ridges. The worn webbing on his old
snow shoes soon parted leaving the useless
frames dangling unheeded about his knees.
He did not feel the bitter winds nor suffer
from the stinging particles; his mind para-
lyzed from the liquor served but one pur-
pose, to impel him forward and forward.
But the tremendous heart action induced
by the stimulant began to fail the old man.
Oksook
Gradually his limbs commenced to shake
and his pounding brain to cool. As his
deadened faculties came back to conscious-
ness he became aware of a sinister blackness
close to his right. It was the open water
by Bull Island. With the immunity of a
sleep-walker he had been staggering along
its jagged edge.
For a time he stood peering vacantly out
over the murky expanse. No recollection
of1 the terrifying mystery disturbed his
half-conscious study. The waters seemed
strangely soft and inviting. He felt an
overpowering desire to sink into their
soothing depths, out of the biting winds.
Therb was something hypnotic about the
white flakes that silently sought the dark
surface to sink gently out of view.
Lurching forward he stood swaying uncer-
tainly over the very rim. As he watched,
the river appeared suddenly to rise before
him. Out of the depths was emerging a
black, glistening body from which a pair of
luminous eyes stared malevolently.
Before he could draw back a gushing roar
"Shook the air, beating into his ears an old
familiar sound of his youth, a sound that
Oksook knew and loved.
His shout of joy was drowned in a, shower
of freezing water.
"Ot-si-kee!" he yelled in Eskimo. "She
blows! She blows!"
It was the old rallying cry of the whale-
hunt.
Then for a moment he stood silent, watch-
ing the black body as it skirted the rim,
disappearing at length in the darkness. In
spite of the intense cold a warm feeling of joy
diffused his benumbed frame. Once more
he would be Oksook, the Great Man, a man
to be respected, a man to be deferred to.
He must capture the great fish this very
night before the secret be discovered by
any one else.
How the whale happened to be so far
from its natural habitat did not perplex
him; his years as pilot on the lower river
told him that. So preoccupied was he with
his plans that on his way back across the
river he did not feel the biting wind nor
mind the rough going. In fact the storm
seemed to be diminishing in violence.
Once in his cabin he hastily sought an
old bundle brought with him when he first
came among the Tananas. From it he drew
a wicked looking harpoon head to which
was attached a long, heavy, native whale-
line. It was still in good condition. As he
fitted a shaft into the barbed steel he
hummed a weird old hunting-chant of his
youth, the days when he had been the best
harpooner of the tribe. Several times he
flourished the dangerous weapon at imagi-
nary objects and was surprized to find his
arm still retained its former skill. Then
arming himself with his rifle and ax he
started back to the opening.
The furious winds had dwindled to a few
spent whispers when Oksook again reached
the place where he had seen the whale.
Overhead above the scudding clouds, a flat
moon disk glanced palely through ragged
fringes. A dim light was diffused over the
water, but the whale was nowhere to be
seen.
Without waiting, however, for it to ap-
pear Oksook began to prepare for its cap-
ture. About midway between the ex-
tremities of the opening he selected near
the edge a large ice chunk which he hewed
down to the semblance of a stump. Around
this he wound his line, leaving enough free
that he might throw his harpoon a con-
siderable distance. This done he laid his
rifle and ax near and awaited his oppor-
tunity. Long years of hunting on the ice
floes in the Bering stood him in good stead.
With Eskimo patience he waited hour after
hour for the great creature to appear. Once
it rose with a high spout, but it was far over
near the island, and as it sank once more
Oksook wondered how long it would be
before morning would bring the Indians
and white men to share in the capture and
thus deprive him of the sole honor.
The malemiuts in the village had begun
their morning chorus when Oksook again
noted the swirl in the water that betrayed
the presence of his prey. It was rising near
the rim and on its way up-stream would
pass directly by. Closer and closer the
glistening back came, gliding swiftly and
easily. It would be an easy throw if his
arm did not fail him.
His first nervousness was passing off. He
drew back his arm tensely, leaned forward
and then hurled the harpoon into the black
form as it surged past. The instantaneous
whip of the heavy line almost upset him, but
he retained a hold on the snub end. A
terrific splashing and floundering turned the
whole morning into confusion. Great waves
of bloody spray came lashing up on to the
ice. He did not dare to let the line out

because he knew he could not pull the broad
hulk up against the swift current.
Had the'whale been in the prime of its
strength the line would never have held,
but weakened by the lack of food and the
effects of fresh water, the beast could not
exert its normal power and therefore soon
tired.
Watching his chance, Oksook secured the
line and held his rifle ready to shoot when
the spray should clear. Gradually the
mighty lashings grew feebler and feebler,
until the waves subsiding, he saw the black
hide awash. As the loud reports of the
heavy caliber rifle echoed and re-echoed
between the bluffs a fresh commotion shook
the water, but this time it was shorter.
Again the enormous body grew still and
drifted over against the rim of ice. To in-
sure his catch Oksook took his ax and sank
it deep into the back, severing the giant
vertebrae.
A distant shout from the village drew his
attention. Down on 'to the white surface
of the river was streaming in a black line
the entire Tanana tribe.
"Oksook! Oksook! What is it?" he heard
them cry.
The old man cackled grimly. He knew
none of them had ever seen a fish larger than
the king salmon which blundered into their
fish-wheels.
"Look!" he said calmly. "Can the Kan-
tishnas catch fish like Oksook?"
Murmurs of awe and astonishment rose
from squaws and bucks alike when they saw
the ferocious-looking creature that Oksook
had conquered. They eyed with shudders
the blood where the great tail had lashed the
gory water up on the ice. Truly Oksook
was a mighty man.
"Go," commanded Oksook authoritively,
"and get lines to pull the fish up on the ice.
I will prepare medicine for a great potlach,"
he added and turned his back upon the awe-
stricken natives.
Soon came also the white men to look
and wonder. Many were the speculations
as to how the whale should come to be a
thousand miles up the river; but it was
Oksook who told his old friend the Scurvy
Kid.
"Long time ago," he said, "me pilot beeg
boat on lower river. When tide he back up
into river, whale he come up to play and
sometimes he get in front of boat. Many
times we chase him long way, but when
boat stop for wood he turn back. Dis Fell
boats he start to burn oil, no stop for wood.
Whale he come all way up."

ed the mom blithely. Slim, who was six
feet four of loosely jointed skin and bones,

garding a merry monarch of the olden times.
The song, in a manner of speaking, was of
a vulgar nature, as Slim frequently admit-
ted. Other men, like little A1 Johnson,
greeted the flooding sunlight of a new Texas
day with eyes yet dull with slumber plus
the effects of a large night.
Hashaway Lewis, chocolate-colored cook
extraordinary, kept a wary eye on the
officers' quarters. Whenever one of the
flyers hove into sight around the corner
Hashaway took careful aim at a frying-pan
with two eggs, and fired without delay.
His assistant, the totally black and enter-
tainingly useless Taylor, hustled grape-

tive consumer thereof had entered the door.
Taylor's claim to fame rested on the habit
he had acquired of rolling a continuous row
of sevens in the crap games down at the
corral.
Nearly all the bachelor officers had pro-
gressed somewhat with their breakfasts
when Sleepy Spears staggered in, arrayed
hastily in a bath-robe that was a veteran
among negligees. His square, good-na-
tured face needed shaving, and his thick
brown hair was in a tall and uncombed con-
dition; but his eyes showed bright and
clear beneath the drooping lids.
"The sun is shining--it's a wonder you
even bothered to get up, Sleepy," remarked
Evans, attacking his bacon and eggs with
gusto.
Spears, whose perpetual lack of energy
during daylight hours was proverbial,
dropped into a chair, and the slow, wide
grin that was the Spears trademark spread

"Had a hard night last night," he said
gently.
"I'll say you did," corroborated A1
"Johnson, who didn't look as if his own had
been so peaceful.
Spears looked hard at his grapefruit.
"Taylor, you Ethiopian reptile, you've
le^t half the core in this thing," he stated

Taylor flashed a dumfounding double
row of ivory, and carried the grapefruit

He always chuckled at Spears.
"What were you doing--studying some
of those correspondence-school courscs?"
queried Jack Carruthers, who was head of
the motor department.
"No," replied Spears, leaning a wearied
head on his elbow.

In his fits of ambition, which overcame
him periodically, he had invested in many
pounds of books on subjects covering a very
wide range. At least two of the boxes had
never been opened.
"I was wooing the fair goddess," pursued
Spears, critically examining the improved
grapefruit that Taylor set before him.
"Which one? That blonde I saw-"
"No, the goddess of chance," grinned
Spears.
The table digested this for a moment.
"Over at Field Two?" asked Slim finally.
Spears nodded.
"Started out as a poker game in Bill
Black's quarters. The bunch got a little
drunk and pretty soon they were playing

and that stuff. Ask Al, he knows."
Johnson, who was so small that he seemed
like a manikin, grinned ruefully.
"Either of you do any good?" inquired
Dick Cartmell, who was charged with the

"Spe-e-a-ars! Telephone!" bawled Shot-
ten from the quarters, a hundred yards
away.
"Taylor, tell 'em I'm not at home,"

The grinning darky, who possibly recog-
nized in Spears the only man in the world

mouth.
"He say he ain't yeah!" he bawled, trail-
ing off into a chuckle.
"Ain't here-!" bellowed the disgusted

"It's long distance, loo-o-otinint," re-
ported Taylor. He pronounced the first
syllable with long-drawn-out unction, the

Spears arose languidly and strolled down
the board-walk to the quarters, his bath-
robe flapping loosely around his slippered

"He isn't exactly full of pep, is he?"

"Just barely gets around all day, but at

ruthers, a handsome, curly-haired chap

legiate sprint champion the year before he

"Seems to me that gambling must have

"Not for Sleepy," contradicted Evans,

They've got money--Spears has guts.
He'd gather every cent he had in the world

The little engineer officer shook his sleek

"The game got wild as --*--, and I

een hundred ahead about four this morn-
ing. He was the only winner. Finally

"Sleepy got the dice, and he sure woke

So help me, he rolled twenty-three times

" '.Oh, -,' says Sleepy. 'Played all

Taylor's "hee! hee! hee!" could be heard

"Man, oh man, dat's whut Ah calls
gamblin'l" he chortled.
Beale whistled.
"Oh, you'll get to know Sleepy if you
stay here long enough," grinned Peck, an-
other student officer who was just finishing

"He looked at the splinters and the hole

Once again the dusky Taylor was com-
pelled to cease all operations to give full

"He hasn't got enough life to even get a

"Funny bird--the queerest specimen and

"Sleepy's ideal of a job may be deliver-
ing mail to the Statue of Liberty, but I saw

"You mean that Kannville affair?"

A1 nodded.
"He wasn't the one that made that night

"The very man,", nodded Johnson.
Beale appeared to have received a body
blow.
"We heard about that down on the
border, but I never connected up the name.
Just what was it? He had a-of a fight,

"I'll say he did. He and I went down
there in two ships to give an exhibition at

some of the town bums, and that night they
kidnaped him and carried him off to a shack

of tarring and feathering him.
"We heard about it too late to overtake

with a parachute on his back. When we
got to the place Sleepy jumped, lit in a field
near the cabin, and sneaked up on the
bunch before the tar got good and sticky.
I was flying, and wasn't supposed to land,

"Oh, can it, Al," came Spears' voice from

appeared in front of the screen door.
"Oh, Beale wanted to know what a rough-
neck you really are," grinned Al, who was

Sleepy yawned and poured himself an-
other cup of coffee. Apparently he had lost

other flyers leaned back for an after-break-

"I wonder whether the major'd let me

inquired of the table in general.
"You're rather late--as usual--planning
a trip, Ambitious," Cartmell advised him.
"This is Saturday morning."
Sleepy, who habitually caught the bus to
San Antonio every evening in a half-clad

"I couldn't prophesy a telephone call,
could I?"
"Oh, that's it. Where to?"
"Gonsara. They're having one of those

Any of you know him?"
"Little red-headed runt?" asked Morris,
the adjutant of the school.
"Uh-huh."
"You never had life enough to follow him

"Oh, if somebody'll set the pace I can
follow," returned Spears, his already gen-
erous mouth widening slowly into an irre-
sistible grin.
His rather thick-set, broad-shouldered
body was a study in complete relaxation.
"Well, I'll do what I can to persuade the
major to O. K. it if you want to take that
ball-the-jack baby," Morris offered gen-
erously. "You must plan to give the na-
tives a thrill, don't you?"

"Oh, I thought they'd had enough Jennys
land down there, and besides it takes too
long to get there in a slow ship."
Slim Evans uncoiled his lathe-like form
and stuck his big Stetson on the back of his
head.
"They should have had the barbecue here
in the front yard and saved you the trip,"
he remarked as he strolled toward the door.
The others arose slowly and prepared to
sally forth into the sun, already hot and
blinding. The roar of motors warming on
the line came to their ears in a deep, far-
away drone that was like the humming of
some monstrous bee.
"NOW that we are left in peace,
Taylor, I'll pee wee for the dice with
you and then shoot you to see
whether you shine my boots before I
dress for nothing or double price," said
Sleepy.
"Yes, sah!" grinned Taylor.
He put down his coffee-cup and dropped a
haJf-eaten piece of toast, which nutriment
he had been absorbing in the kitchen, and
dived for his dice. He came up clicking
them like an angry rattler.
Spears, still resting an elbow on the
table, his head cradled in his hand, accepted
the dice and threw a five. Taylor, grinning
hugely, negotiated an eight.
"Mah dice, loo-o-o-tinint," he said, spit-
ting on his hands in preparation for the
roll.
Spears arose negligently and drew his
faded robe closer about him.
"You get double price for the shine,
Taylor," he announced plaintively, and
strolled slowly toward the door.
"Why I ain't rolled yit, sah!" said the
puzzled Taylor.
"You know as well as I do that you could
throw a pair of dice down a flight of steps
and show a seven. The boots are over in
my quarters. Hop to it."
The side-splitting hilarity of the dusky
Taylor followed him out of the door. He
stuck one hand in his bath-robe pocket as he
strolled toward the quarters, and felt some-
thing soft and folded. He pulled it out and
spread it. It was a ten-dollar bill. He had
no idea in the world how it had found its
way into his pocket; but it was there, and
he was not one to look a gift horse in the
mouth. He had a habit of finding money
in every pocket.
He made his way to the bath-house and
shaved leisurely. The drone of the air-
planes overhead reverberated inside the
building as the business of Donovan Field
proceeded without the aid of one Lieutenant
John Spears.
The feel of the lukewarm water on him
as he stepped under the shower impelled
him to sing, as it always did. In a totally
tuneless voice he burst forth into a verse of
one of the few songs that he knew:
"I used to loop and spin with all my m-i-g-h-t,
I thought I'd be a flying star and s-t-u-n-t;
Oh, once I yearned to knock 'em dead--my good
ship and m-e.
Though I was wild, thank God this child was
s-a-v-e-d!"
He ceased for a moment, to add a little
more cold water to the mixture. He al-
ways eased himself into a cold shower by
degrees. The insistent tinny drumming of
the phone reached his ears. He had an
idea it was probably for him, but as the
water grew colder he burst forth discordant-
ly, though with enthusiasm, into the chorus:
"Oh, g-l-o-r-y, my friends, I was s-a-v-e-d.
I never hit the ground too hard in my good s-h-i-p;
I'd rather have white whiskers than die y-o-u-n-g;
Give other guys the glory--I'm still a-l-i-v-e!"
He turned the warm water completely off
and began to dance briskly under a cold,
stinging flood. During the brisk rub-down
that followed, with a big, rough towel
marked with the name of a prominent San
Antonio hotel, he gave tongue to the song
of the border-patrol flyers, who daily cover
the wildest section of the country, from the
Gulf of Mexico to its sister gulf on the
western rim.
"Ten thousand dollars, going to the folks;
Ten thousand dollars-"
Again he became aware of the telephone
and stopped singing to devote attention
strictly to business. Once again clad in the
tattered bath-robe, he made a leisurely
progress toward the veranda and answered
the insistent ringing.
"Lieutenant Spears talking," he an-
nounced, leaning restfully against the wall.
"Sergeant Correll, lieutenant. The major
was just trying to get you on the phone,
and I told him you'd just stepped out."
"Thanks. I'll be up in a few minutes.
How'd you like to fly to Gonzara this after-
noon?"

"Suits me fine, lieutenant."
"We'll start at noon if we can get a ship.
Have Bitwel) write a request for the LePere,
will you, and say we'll be back Monday
morning? Purpose of the trip, practise

"Yes, sir."
Spears hung up and strolled into his
littered quarters. The temporary signs of
life he had shown under the shower had
disappeared. As he cast aside his bath-
robe the long, stringy muscles beneath the
white skin rippled in cat-like smoothness.
He lighted a cigaret, taking frequent puffs
between the various maneuvers connected
with arraying himself for the morning.
His room was a mass of conglomerate
junk, not yet ordered by the skilful hands of
Taylor and his high-yellow wife, who acted
as chambermaid, her husband supervising.
In one corner, covered by a brown blanket
to make the bulge in the room slightly more
esthetic, were two huge boxes, unopened,
which held complete correspondence courses
on banking and mechanical engineering
respectively. The shelf above the table
held two vividly red volumes authored by
Boccaccio and Rabelais, a couple of
technical works on airplanes, two represen-
tatives of Robert W. Chambers, the Medita-
tions of Marcus Aurelius and a whole set of
O. Henry.
On the table a pile of magazines had lost
equilibrium and flooded over all available
space, a Police Gazette having reached the
floor. The beaver-board walls were cov-
ered with pictures hung without particular
method. Between two of Frederic Rem-
ington's nestled a framed reproduction from
La Vie Parisienne; and some beautiful
cloud pictures, photographed from the air,
disputed an entire wall with a revealing row
of stage beauties.
Spears was finally ready to sally forth.
He ambled slowly up the road that ran
along the line of hangars, stretching for a
half-mile along the rim of Field One from
the bachelor quarters to the row of build-
ings on the northern edge, which included
headquarters and the enlisted men's
barracks.
A fifteen-dollar, made-to-order shirt that
he wore was slightly wrinkled as a result of
lying in a corner for several hours. His
twenty-dollar Stetson was tilted over his
eyes, dented individualistically according
to a plan that suited Sleepy, although com-
plying in no detail with the uniform regu-
lations made and provided. The black
cravat was loosely knotted, and there was a
considerable interval between it and the.
shirt collar.
Sleepy walked along as if every step would
be his last. The wide shoulders sloped as if
burdened with unutterable weariness, and
his arms swung loosely at his sides. It
took a very close observer to notice that
there was a certain effortless smoothness
about that seemingly tired walk--one move-
ment merged into the next with a panther-
like effect of sinewy, rippling strength.
To his left, westward, stretched the flat,
gray, two-mile square that was Donovan
Field. Field One, domicile of the school that
trained Air Service rookies to be trained
airplane riggers, motor mechancis, para-
chute experts, and what not, was a half-mile
long and half as wide, the eastern edge a
solid line of hangars.
Separated from it by a line of unused
barracks and the Rio road, Field Two lay
huge and level, merging into mesquite on
its western and southern sides. The north-
ern edge was a mile and a half of big white
hangars, paralleled by equally trim lines of
barracks, machine-shops, store-houses and
officers' quarters.
Above the field the darting little scouts of
the pursuit group dodged in and out among
the lazily floating billows of snowy mist
that were growing ever larger as the heat
increased. A thundering formation of
Liberty-motored De Havilands from the
bombardment group roared its majestic
way above the field, its unvarying regu-
larity testifying to the flying ability of the
pilots. Handling a ton-and-a-half ship and
keeping it twenty-five feet, no more and no
less, from the ship ahead and in precise
position in three dimensions is no task for an
amateur.
Spears slowly passed the flying-depart-
ment hangars. A dozen ships of different
types were lined up on the edge of the field,
ranging from the tiny Sopwith Camel up to
a big twin-motored bomber. The me-
chanics, dressed uniformly in coveralls,
were busily wiping down the ships in prep-
aration for the half-holiday. Dick Cart-
mell waved and jeered as Sleepy made his
leisurely way past the bench, and Beale,
who was in helmet and goggles for a flight,
grinned at him cheerfully.
The next group of hangars housed the
Adventure
airplane department, where riggers were
manufactured from raw youngsters who
sought to learn the technique of a still new
profession. Sleepy straightened his hat as
he entered the first big structure, and looked
around him keenly as he walked the length
of it. All around were groups of students,
each under an instructor, who were doing
everything from doping linen to putting the
final touches on a big De Haviland which
that particular class had assembled and
rigged.
Sleepy grinned in reminiscent compla-
cency at the memory of the hard days of
toil he had put in shaping the department
so that it was self-running. The task of
stealing hard-boiled old Sergeant Correll
from the engineering department to act as
personal representative, disciplinary non-
com, and general energizer had been ex-
hausting in itself.
The sergeant's huge, portly figure was
ensconced comfortably in its wonted chair
in the office as Spears entered.
"Here's that request for cross-country,
Lieutenant," he said, and shoved the type-
written missive over to Spears' uncluttered
desk.
Spears signed it without reading it.. Two
typewriters clicked busily under the flying
fingers of uniformed young men who were
ever mindful of the near presence of Correll.
"All the reports out?" queried Spears
without particular interest.
"Signed and gone. I put my initials
under your name inasmuch as you weren't
here," returned Correll.
"Good. Say, better take this request up
to headquarters yourself. Give it to Lieu-
tenant Morris, and when it's approved go
down to the flying department with it and
see that the Le Pere is ready to go at twelve,

The sergeant snapped his finger.
"Get my hat out there on the rack," he
commanded the orderly, "and stick by the
phone this morning while I'm gone. I may
need you."
Sleepy relaxed in his swivel chair, one foot
on the desk. His eyes followed the ser-
geant through the window as he strode up
the road toward headquarters. Ever since
that night when he had made a night para-
chute jump and with Al Johnson's help at
the end prevented a tar-and-feather party
at the sergeant's expense Correll had been
his right-hand man for any and all purposes.
The fight had been very bothersome and
had spoiled his evening in Kannville with a
certain creamy blonde, reflected Sleepy, but
on the whole it was well worth it.
He lit a cigaret and pushed his weirdly
dented hat back on his head. He leaned
forward and grasped the telephone, leaning
back again as far as the chair would go.
He must call up Major Stratton and tell
him he had just stepped back in again, and
then he'd catch up on a little slumber be-
fore the trip to Gonzara.

THE wicked-looking, low-hung Le
Pere was the only ship left on the
line at noon. With sturdy wheel-
blocks under the wheels, a mechanic on
each wing and another on the tail, Correll
was warming up the big twelve-cylinder
Liberty motor.
Sleepy waited until the soft hum of idling
grew into the drumming roar which an-
nounced that it was running wide open on
the final warm-up, and then left his quarters
,to walk the few hundred yards to the line.
Correll had already been down after his
suit-case, and he noted that the bag was
wired on the wing, close to the fuselage.
Everything was in readiness.
Correll slowly eased the throttle back
until the propeller was turning slowly be-
fore he climbed out of the front cockpit.
Sleepy adjusted his goggles--he wore no
helmet--and stuffed cotton in his ears. It
was not necessary to ask whether the motor
was O. K.--Correll's silent transfer of seats
told the story.
The pilot surveyed the crowded instru-
ment-board casually as he adjusted the
buckle of the wide canvas belt. Oil pres-
sure, thirty; air pressure, three; tempera-
ture, 70° Centigrade; and voltmeter charg-
ing--all was as it should be. He nodded to
the mechanics, and they jerked away the
wheel-blocks.
"All ready, sergeant?" he yelled.
Correll waved assent, and Sleepy taxied
up the field. The trip was a hundred and
forty miles. He figured they would get
there in an hour, which would be one o'clock,
and just the time that Gib Saunders would
be expecting them.
He turned around and slowly fed the
throttle. The Le Pere gathered speed
rapidly, and in a sdcond was speeding across
Riding Herd-
the ground like a bullet. Slow pressure on
the stick brought the tail up, and almost
before he knew it they were in the air. He
held the ship close to the ground for a
minute, and then lifted it upward in a beau-
tiful 300m that brought them to three
hundred feet. The air was very bumpy,
and even the heavy, solid Le Pere was
bounced around in the air currents as it
circled the field three times, getting altitude.
At two thousand feet Spears flew over
San Antonio, carefully picking out the
railroads leading eastward. He verified
the one leading to Gonzara by means of a
small stream which his map showed running
parallel to it. Five miles farther on a fork
in the tracks, the southern branch leading to
the Gulf of Mexico, was additional veri-
fication that he was right, so he settled back
comfortably in his seat.
Usually flying was merely mechanical
with him. There was no particular pleas-
ure in it--just sitting there until he got
where he wanted to go. Today, however
here was a certain satisfaction in it that
vas unusual. The swift rush of the air past
him was cool and comfortable in contrast
to the baking land below, and as the Le
Pere hurled itself through the misty lower
edges of cloud after cloud the feel of the cool
moisture was the acme of physical delight.
The Le Pere was the pride of the school--
one of the only two of the type on Donovan
Field. It was immeasurably faster than
any other ship on the field--it could fly
circles around a D. H., and left Fokkers,
S. E. 5s and even the powerful little 220
Spad hopelessly out of the running.
Like a majority of the American flyers,
it was a distinct event for Sleepy to get his
hands on a real ship. He had not flown
anything but frail, clumsy De Havilands or
rebuilt British and German scout planes for
so long that flying renewed its joy for him
as he surveyed the trim, strong wings,
without dihedral or overhang, and the solid
laminated fuselage, so different from what
he had been accustomed to since leaving
France.
Obeying a sudden impulse, born of his
whole-souled flyer's delight in flying an
honest-to-goodness ship for once, he throttled
the motor and nosed down. The strongly
built ship would stand it almost as well as a
Spad, so he allowed the air-speed meter to
go up to a hundred and eighty miles an
hour the while he carefully handled the

throttle until, despite their terrific speed,
the 450 horse-power Liberty was only turn-
ing fifteen hundred revolutions.
Like a meteor the big black-and-white
ship shot toward the sundrenched earth
two thousand feet below. It was a smiling
country of alternate flat cotton-fields and
small patches of mesquite, splotched with
shadow as the snowy cumulus clouds drifted
across the sun.
Correll, in the black cockpit, leaned over
anxiously and treated the instrument-
board, which he could see from his seat, to a
careful inspection. There was nothing
wrong there, and the motor was certainly
firing evenly and without missing, so the
portly mechanic leaned back again and
devoted all his attention to blowing out his
ears to keep the change in pressure from
deafening him. Every few seconds he
grasped his nose firmly, kept his mouth
closed, and blew hard, Spears following his
example as they sped ever nearer the
ground.
They were diving parallel with the rail-
road, and at two hundred feet Sleepy grad-
ually came out of the dive, easing the
throttle on slowly as he came level. At
fifty feet, directly over the railroad, the
ship was flying in normal position, the motor
turning 1550.
Spears leaned forward and opened the
shutters, which he had closed for the dive
to keep the motor from cooling too fast.
Then he settled down to fly the railroad--
every curve of it.
At a hundred and forty miles an hour, a
few feet above the wires, the Le Pere roared
its way down the railroad. The sensation
of speed, almost indiscernible a thousand
feet or more high, was now paramount.
The little town of Carston heard the ever
increasing roar of the motor, and stirred
from its midday lethargy to sweep the sky
with languid interest. It grew into as-
tonished wonder as a black-and-white
meteor shot across the housetops, the tiny
railroad station and on down the railroad so
swiftly, "Here she comes!" followed by,
"There she goes!" were about the only com-
ments a reasonably intelligent and quick-
witted person could encompass before the
Le Pere was gone.
Sleepy, his attitude still relaxed as he
guided the mighty machine beneath him,
was smiling slightly, and the lazy gray eyes
were glowing softly. It was the kind of
Adventure
flying that has killed many a pilot, for
chances of a crack-up in case of motor failure
were very promising. However, it was the
expression of a spirit without which there
would never have been a conquest of the
air; scientists may experiment, but some
one must take a chance.
Ten minutes of flashing progress along
the shining steel rails left the motor at 8o°
Centigrade--not too hot. A stretch of big,
level cotton-flelds on his right tempted
Sleepy to bank away from the railroad.
He dropped down to five, and skimmed the
tops of the cotton plants.
When he reached a fence a tiny zoom took
him over it. A cluster of houses loomed
ahead, and with a world of excess speed he
lifted the Le Pere in a smooth, curving zoom
that cleared the houses by a hundred feet.
He dropped down again for a wild rush
across a straight half-mile of waving corn.
A BIG, level stretch of closely
cropped grass showed ahead.
Thirty or more horses and mules
were grazing in it. Sleepy obeyed a sudden
impulse and dived along the eastern edge of
the field, close to the fence. A dozen of the
animals who were occupying that section
kicked up their heels and departed hastily.
Zooming up at the other end of the field,
Sleepy noted that one mule had not re-
treated far enough, so he shot down and
herded the recalcitrant beast into the main
bunch, along the western boundary.
This accomplished, he circled back of the
field a few hundred yards, slowly cut the
throttle, and stalled over the fence, landing
smoothly on three points. With a few
quick thrusts of gas he turned around,
taxied back to the fence, and pointed the
nose down the field in preparation for the
take-off.
"What's the trouble, lieutenant?" in-
quired Correll anxiously.
"Just wanted a smoke," returned his
chief, stretching mightily as he reached the
ground.
The sergeant took a full minute to digest
this information. He grinned as he looked
at Spears, now puffing contentedly as he
lay on the ground.
"Must be--er--feeling pretty good to-
day, lieutenant," he ventured.
"Oh, not so bad, not so good," replied
Spears airily. "Light up--we haven't got
much time."
The ship was idling softly. The airmen
lay restfully on the ground, undergoing the
severe inspection of the horses and mules,
who had retired to the farthermost limits
of the big field.
Spears moved a trifle to get in the breeze
generated by the propeller, and then moved
back again with a grunt of disgust as he
noted that he would lose his cigaret if he
remained there. He lay motionless, his
arm over his eyes to keep out the blinding
radiance of the noon-high sun.
When he had inhaled the last possible
supply of smoke from his diminutive cigaret-
stub he sat up, yawned, and put on his
goggles. Correll threw away his smoke
and climbed in the rear. In a moment
they were roaring across the field, taking the
air before its length was half-covered.
They flew straight down the railroad,
climbing gradually, until once again they
felt the cool air under the clouds against
their faces. Spears shook the stick, and
Correll leaned forward. Spears cut the
motor for a moment as he yelled--
"You fly it!"
Correll nodded with much satisfaction.
He could keep a ship level in the air all
right, and took great delight in an oppor-
tunity to demonstrate his ability. Spears
passed his map back to the mechanic, and
with his finger indicated their precise posi-
tion. Correll nodded his comprehension.
Spears settled deeply into his seat, so far
behind the wind-shield that he scarcely felt
any of the terrific air pressure compounded
of their speed and the propeller's blast.
The motor was running well within its pos-
sibilities at fifteen hundred revolutions.
His arms rested limply on the cowling, and
his eyes gazed calmly on the clouds drifting
just above them. The roar of the motor,
with its hypnotic monotony, lulled him into
drowsiness and in a moment, sleep.
For a wonder he awakened just before
they arrived alt Gonzara. Sergeant Correll
was just deciding that it was time to lean
over and shake the pilot when Spears stirred
and looked around. As they came over the
fairly large town he saw a railroad crossing
and recognized Gonzara. His wrist-watch
showed 1:10.
He was familiar with the landing-field,
and quickly picked it up. The wide-
spreading grove next to it--the location for
the barbecue--was swarming with tiny, ant-
like specks, and the smoke of the barbecue
Riding Herd--Modern Style
fires, rising almost straight in the air,
provided a good wind-vane. Evidently
there was practically no wind on the ground,
such as there was being from the south.
The field itself ran north and south, which
made it as convenient as could be wished
for landing.
Correll had climbed to five thousand feet
on the way. Spears took the stick and
pulled it back as far as it would go, applying
left rudder at the same time. The nose
came up until the ship was almost per-
pendicular in the air, and then fell off to the
left in a whirling dive. Spears cut the
motor half-way--he did not throttle fully
because that would foul the spark-plugs,
and it was very possible that he would need
a good motor before making his landing.
The heavy Le Pere, with a thousand-
pound motor in its nose running half-open,
screwed downward in a terrific vertical tail-
spin. Four hundred feet a turn, and the
turns came so fast it was almost impossible
to count them.
Sleepy watched the ground calmly, oc-
casionally blowing out his ears for com-
fort's sake. He kept an eye on the alti-
meter, which was wabbling crazily in an
effort to keep up with the rushing loss of
altitude.
Every wire was screaming with the speed,
and Correll, experienced passenger though
he was, was dizzy and sick as the big,
flashily painted ship corkscrewed through
the last thousand feet. Sleepy grinned
slowly as he caught kaleidoscopic views of
the crowd below, now motionless.
"Some of 'em are getting the roofs of
their mouths sunburnt,-' he reflected as he
jammed on right rudder and pushed the
stick forward.
A turn more, and the Le Pere straight-
ened out in a vertical dive. It took four
hundred feet before the nose started coming
up as Sleepy eased the stick back slowly.
It was not so easy to do against the force of
the wind on the elevators.
Three hundred feet above the ground the
ship was level, and the motor came full on
as Spears circled the long, narrow landing-
field, eying it closely for possible ditches or
crack-brained onlookers who might be in
the way. Satisfied that Gib Saunders, or
some one equally wise, was warning the
crowd to keep away, he made a wide circle
and approached the field in a slow dive from
the north.
"Slow" in a Le Pere means around ninety
miles an hour. The throttle crawled back
by degrees until it was idling as the ship
sped over the trees and dropped down until
it was two feet above the ground. Know-
ing the gliding propensities of his ship,
Sleepy kicked the rudder and sent the plane
into a skid that helped kill their speed.
They wrere less than fifty yards from the end
of the field when they stopped rolling.
As he taxied toward the western edge of
the field, which was packed with people
who had temporarily deserted the barbecue,
the pilot spied a dancing figure in the fore-
ground that he recognized readily. Even
at that distance there was no mistaking
the red hair and somewhat portly form of
ex-Lieutenant Gib Saunders.
Sleepy taxied toward Saunders, stopping
a few feet in front of the crowd that poured
out behind the one-time pilot.
"Burn out the motor; will you, Correll?"
requested Spears.
Correll climbed into the front seat and
turned off one of the gas pet-cocks as Sleepy
tumbled off the wing into the flailing arms
of Saunders.
"Not so vigorous, Gib, not so vigorous,"
Spears cautioned with his widest grin as his
freckle-faced, bright-eyed comrade of over-
seas days seemed bent on knocking the life
out of him with tremendous thumps on the
back. "These folks don't know whether
this is a fight or merely an exhibition, you
red-headed firebrand!"
"Nor is it any of their business," re-
turned Saunders. "I could see by the way
you got out o' that ship--which is a beauty,
by the way--that you haven't got any more
life in you than you used to have."
"Not in Texas anyhow. Of all the
stewing, fly-bitten, deserted-"
"Don't say another word. I hate to
beat up a guest," warned Gib, whose
monologs anent his beloved State were well
remembered by Spears.
Saunders led him through the curious,
ever-growing crowd that had already sur-
rounded the ship.
"Sure that big mechanic can 'tend to
everything?" queried the Irishman as they
threaded their way through.
"Anything he can't 'tend to would be far
beyond me," grinned Sleepy.
"In that case we'll hop into the car here
and get dad. He had to be at the bank this
morning. Mary's around here somewhere,
Adventure
but you can meet her later. What about
your suit-case?"
"Oh, we can bring that in later. I refuse
to wear a blouse until evening."
"Good. I've got a guard for your ship,
so your mechanic will be free. Hop in and
we'll jazz down-town and right back."
The big touring-car left a cloud Qf dust as
Saunders sped townward, his tongue going
♦ nearly as fast as his car while he tried to
cover two years in ten minutes.
