AT 12:15 P.M. Mr. Daniel Saun-
ders, genial cashier of the Gonzara
bank, let himself into his house to
prepare for a descent on the festivities of the
afternoon. The house was deserted, every
other member of the family having left for
the fair-grounds long before.
Mr. Saunders had barely applied himself
to the lunch left for him on the kitchen
table when the door bell rang.
"Come in!" roared the banker.
Gonzara was a small and easy-going
town, every inhabitant of which was per-
sonally known to him.
A tall, well-dressed stranger let .himself
in, and walked down the hall which led to
the kitchen. The open door of the kitchen
allowed Mr. Saunders to observe the prog-
ress of his guest, and he arose with an
apology.
"I thought it must be some of the neigh-
bors," he said with an unembarrassed smile.
The smile faded as he looked into the
business end of a Colt .45.
"Listen, and listen close," said the stran-
ger, whose face was minus the tan of the
native Texan. "You're going with me to
the bank. I'll have you covered every
minute from my pocket. When we get there
you'll open the vault. Get your coat on."
His words were staccato and strictly
business-like, and the impression he made
was undramatic. However, there was a
certain strength of purpose and cold re-
solve apparent that caused the amazed
cashier to put on his coat without a word.
Temporarily he was incapable of connected
thinking.
The tall stranger, who looked to be about
thirty-five, followed Saunders out of the
door. A big black touring-car, holding two
men besides the driver, was drawn vup in
front of the house. The men were all
smoking, and their attitudes were easy and
untroubled. The chauffeur started the
motor as they appeared at the door.
"If we meet anybody that speaks to you,
answer them naturally, do you under-
stand?" said the stranger in conversational
tones as they walked down to the car.
His right hand was in his coat pocket.
Mr. Saunders nodded mechanically. A
quick look up and down the quiet, shaded
street showed only three or four people,
all of them some distance away.
He and his captor took seats in the ton-
neau. The man who shared it with them
was stout and cold eyed, and was smoking
a big cigar. All of them were inconspicu-
ously dressed, and all had a young-old look,
their faces showing deep lines around the
mouth and hard eyes.
As the car drove toward the bank at
moderate speed Mr. Saunders was ever
conscious of the pressure of a gun at his side.
"Act natural, and keep your eyes open
for anybody you ought to speak to," ordered
the tall man once more as they approached
the town square.
"Any trouble srfaring him, Joe?" inquired
the man who shared the front seat with the
driver.
"Not a bit. Caught him with his mouth
full."
Mr. Saunders had had a wild hope that
perhaps on the <lrive through the square it
might be possible to arouse some one's sus-
picions, but the robbers took a roundabout
route that brought them up to the bank
without going through the main part of
town. The bank was located only a few
steps from the square, on a side street lead-
ing from it.
The car drew up in front of the small
brick structure, and the chauffeur calmly
stopped the motor. The thing was satan-
ically audacious, and yet well planned,
reflected the unhappy cashier despairingly.
Ninety per cent, of Gonzara's population
were out at the fair-grounds for the big
annual jubilee commemorating the found-
ing of the town, and there were so many
visitors from other towns that strangers
aroused no comment.
"Hop out, and don't waste a minute.
If w
friend of yours. This other fellow is a
friend of mine. And don't kid yourself
that we'll hesitate to pump you full of holes
if you squeal."

The stout man accompanied his accom-
plice and the cashier into the bank. Mr.
Saunders Unlocked the front door in a daze
and let them in.
"Pull up the window and door curtains,"
commanded the tall man, whom the others
addressed as Joe.
His stout comrade in crime took up his
station by the door, leaning easily against
the wall and peering through a crack in the
curtain. The men in the car smoked calm-
ly, although their hard eyes unobtrusively
watched the infrequent stragglers that
passed across the street a few steps ahead,
where it led into the square.
"Open that vault quick. We know the
lay of the land, so don't stall," said Joe
briskly, his gun out of his pocket once
more.
x The Gonzara bank was small, and it had
not reached the point yet where compli-
cated time-locks and other safety features
had been incorporated into its equipment.
With a heavy heart the cashier silently set
to work. He watched helplessly while
more than twenty thousand dollars went
into the traveling-bag that the stout man
carried.
It was doubly unfortunate that the bank
should have an unusual amount of cash on
hand. It was ginning-season, and the Gon-
zara cotton-growers had deposited a lot of
money during the last few days.
"Close everything up, and then let down
the curtains," said the tall man as the other
thief strolled nonchalantly down the steps
and into the car.
Mr. Calvin Burton, a gentleman of color
who was accustomed to do odd jobs for Mr.
Saunders, passed by the bank as the cashier
was letting down the shades to their accus-
tomed position when the bank was closed.
Passers-by had free view of the interior when
it was closed, but the big shades were
raised to keep out the sun when the bank
was open. Mr. Burton was on his way to
the barbecue, and yelled a cheerful, "After-
noon, sah!" as he passed.
"Answer!" came in a deadly whisper from
Joe, who was playing a light conversational
part for the benefit of passers-by.
One would have thought that he and the
cashier were close friends indulging in
cheerful small-talk.
Mr. Saunders forced a wave and a smile.
Apparently Calvin did not think it peculiar
that the cashier should be at the bank so
late, for he passed on, whistling cheerily,
vouchsafing the car and its occupants a
glance of only perfunctory interest.
"Now you're going to take a little ride
with us," stated Joe as his captive silently
locked the door.
He could scarcely grasp the situation
even then--it seemed like a dream some-
how that he should be forced to help rob
the bank. He simply could not compre-
hend it. At Joe's last words he came to
life with a snap.
"Where to?"
"Just out in the country a little ways
where you'll be safely out of the way till
Monday."
"I might just as well let you shoot me as
be suspected of conniving at this outrage!"
blazed Mr. Saunders.
They had stopped at the door of the car.
"Climb in, you - fool," snarled the
chauffeur, a thin-faced man wearing a linen
duster.
"We can club you over the head and make
you go," snapped Joe. "If it'll comfort
you any, you'll be tied up tight, with
plenty of food and water to last till you're
found."
Mr. Saunders took a last despairing look
up toward the square. The irony of it en-
tered his soul as he saw George Hardwick,
who owned a drug-store, drive his car past
the street on his way to the barbecue.
Even if the bluff Hardwick had turned
around, however, he could have done noth-
ing but wave, for Joe's gun could be felt
through the pocket as the tall, impressively
cool crook pressed close to him. He silently
climbed into the car, which turned around
in a leisurely way and rolled off down the
street well within the speed laws.

"THAT'S funny. The house is un-
locked, but where is dad?"
Saunders had shouted for his
father without result. Spears dropped into
a chair.
"Maybe he caught a ride out to the cele-
bration," he suggested.
"He wouldn't have left the house un-
locked," objected Gib. "Maybe he forgot
it, though. We'll wait around a while and
see whether he went over to some of the
neighbors for something. His lunch was
only half-eaten."

The two friends sat and smoked while
Gib tried to draw out Spears as to what had
happened to him during the last two years.
Sleepy had been assigned to the border
patrol for a while, around Calexico and
Yuma, working mainly out of San Diego.
Saunders' eyes glistened as he listened to
the very few things that Spears could be
prevailed on to tell about the doings of the
Air Service.
"I sure wish I was back sometimes," he
said wistfully, his good-humored face re-
gretful. "But it looked like too good a
chance to miss here at the mill. Of course
I'm making money, but-"
"Ambition is the curse of young men,"
stated Sleepy. "Why grub until you're
fifty for a hundred thousand that you've
forgotten how to enjoy?"
Gib grinned and glanced at his watch.
"Good Lord, it's two o'clock. I guess
dad must have gone to the barbecue with
somebody and forgotten to lock the door.
Let's go."
Out at the grove inquiries failed to locate
Mr. Saunders. The puzzled Gib finally
spotted Mr. Calvin Burton, arrayed like the
lilies of the field, and escorting a dusky
belle with much eclat.
"Oh, Cal, you haven't seen dad around
here, have you?"
"Nossah. I seed him down to the bank
'bout a hour ago."
"At the bank? For the love of-"
"Yessah. They was a man in there with
'im, and a car was sittin' out front, yessah."
"Jack, that's kind of funny," stated Saun-
ders. "Let's hunt up Mr. Sears. Maybe
he can tell us-- By gorry, when we asked
him whether he'd seen dad he didn't say
anything about his being at the bank late
for any special reason, did he?"
"No, he didn't," agreed Sleepy.
They rushed around through the milling
crowd until they espied the tall, thin,
weather-bitten old-timer who looked less
like a bank president than a cowboy. As
a matter of fact in his younger days he had

zara either.
"Mr. Sears, do you know why dad was

"Why, no, son, I don't," drawled the

"What did he appear to be doin'?"
"I don't know. Cal said there was a

A small, bright-eyed man whose "store-

"Who were the men, did Cal say?"
"He didn't know 'em," returned Gib, an

"Any bank-robberies being pulled around

The quiet question acted like an electric

Young Saunders departed rapidly on his

"Tom, you don't mean to tell me you

"Sears, you know what happened over to

The tanned, somewhat stooped banker

"I'm goin' to see right now," he declared,

"Let's wait a couple o' minutes for Cal.

In a moment Cal appeared in Saunders'

The sheriff and Mr. Sears set off in the
banker's car to investigate. The rumor

men approached Gib and Spears asking

a Considerable crowd of Gonzara citizens

ing for the return of the sheriff and Sears.
They did not have long to wait. In

THREE thousand feet high the big
Le Pere boomed along the San An-
tonio road. It was three-thirty,
and according to Cal's story the robbers
had almost three hours start. Probably
about ninety miles, reflected Spears, unless
something had happened. Saunders knew
every foot of the country, and had said that
there were no side roads that the thieves
would be likely to take.
They came to the fork in the road, and
Sleepy guided the plane squarely down the
middle line between the two. For fifteen
miles ahead the roads were not more than
ten miles apart, the gap between them grad-
ually widening.
They had sighted only two cars driving
along the way they were traveling, both
very small ones. They had played safe
and dropped earthward for a close look.
The country was not thickly settled, and
such traffic as there was, which was small,
was toward Gonzara and not away from it.
Saunders was watching the right-hand
road, and Spears the left. They had trav-
ersed about fifteen miles on a line between
the two when Gib reached over and shook
the pilot. He pointed down to a tiny speck
traveling along the road, toward San
Antonio.
Sleepy nodded and nosed down. He
did not believe it was their car. He figured
that to be several miles ahead. What he
did not figure on was the stop the desper-
adoes had made on a side road to chain Mr.
Saunders securely in a deserted shack,
where they had left him with sufficient food
and water to last three days.
They were a thousand feet high when they
caught the car, and as he circled over it
Sleepy noted that it was large and black
and* traveling fast. The country under-
neath was mostly mesquite, although iso-
lated cleared spots could be seen.
The Le Pere, under his handling, was
skimming the tops of the trees several hun-
dred yards back of the car. Sleepy flew
parallel to the road, as low as possible, and
throttled the motor slightly as they shot
past. There were several men in the car,
that was certain.
Gib, a long-barreled rifle in his hand,
leaned over the rear cockpit as far as he
could stretch, trying his utmost to identify
some one in the car. They flashed by so
fast, however, that they could come to no
conclusion.
Spears turned the throttle full on, and
circled back once more. He could scarcely
believe that was the car, and yet it might
be. Certainly the passengers had craned
their necks to the utmost to watch them;
but that would be only natural for anybody
to do in view of the low flying he was doing.
On the next trip past the car the thieves
gave themselves away. Probably it was
the sight of Gib's rifle, and the fact that the
circling of the plane denoted suspicion. As
the two flyers shot by, their heads turned
as they strained their eyes toward the car,
they saw two revolvers spit flame at them.
Gib's face was alight with exultation,
and his eyes flashed fire through the big
goggles. The shots did not bother them
particularly--a fast moving plane is about
as difficult a target as there is extant.
Sleepy pointed backward, and Gib nod-
ded. The map showed that the road
was without cross-cuts for twenty miles--
by the time the car covered that they could
be back again after signaling the posse
coming behind.
With motor turning eighteen hundred
and speedmeter showing a hundred and
forty miles an hour the Le Pere sped back
over the trail. It took less than fifteen
minutes to reach the three speeding auto-
mobiles that held the sheriff and his
deputies. The Le Pere turned around,
flew straight for a moment, and then banked
steeply to the right. It was the agreed-
upon signal to indicate which road the
bandits had taken.
The flyers wasted no time, but went swift-
ly back on their way. They found the car
speeding along the road, plainly making
every effort to get where they were going as
fast as might be practicable. The Le Pere
passed it five hundred feet high, and flew
on ahead. The next town was fifteen miles
up the road, and was only a hamlet.
They were perhaps five miles ahead of the
car when they struck a very large cleared
spot, extending at least three hundred
Riding Herd-
yards on each side of the road. It was
a corn-stubble field, mowed closely, and
what looked to be a partially broken-down
shack was in one corner.
Gib shook Sleepy energetically, and
pointed down. He motioned to it with his
rifle. Sleepy nodded, his eyes glowing
beneath the drooping lids and his face all
a-grin at what he conceived to be Gib's idea.
He dipped over the field, ascertaining that
the furrows were shallow and that the
stubble was very short, and then circled
back a few hundred yards for his landing.
There was plenty of room, but he stalled
down across the mesquite and landed, leav-
ing space enough for a take-off from where
the plane stopped. Gib had unfastened his
belt before the plane stopped, and was out
in a flash.
"I can get up there behind a tree or some-
thing, and pop their front tires," he said
quickly, his freckled face ablaze with ex-
citement.
"Can you shoot that well?" enquired
Sleepy doubtfully.
"Born and brought up in Texas, boy,"
stated Saunders. "You take off and keep
in touch with the posse. I could get every
one of them from behind my tree if they
started to rush me when I put their car out
of commission. If you stay here the plane
will warn them before they get near enough
for me. They could scatter in the mes-
quite then and make the deal a lot more
difficult."
Sleepy nodded his acquiescence, and
shoved on the throttle without delay.
There was plenty of room, and he cleared
the mesquite on the other side without
trouble. Below him he watched Gib's
somewhat stout form scurry across the
field and dive into the woods at the farther
end.
He kept the Le Pere circling above the
field at about five hundred feet, waiting to
see what would happen. He took time to
look over his instruments closely. The oil
pressure had dropped to twenty-two--the
oil had not been renewed since leaving
Donovan. However, that was all right,
for Sleepy knew the Liberty was good for
another two hours of flying on the oil sup-
ply. Air pressure was correct at three, and
the tachometer showed the motor turning
a good fifteen-fifty. Centigrade tempera-
ture was 87° --too hot, due to the low flying.
Sleepy throttled the motor to fourteen
■Modern Style 149
hundred--as low as would keep the Le Pere
level--and opened the motor shutters the
final notch.
In a moment he saw the car approaching,
going like mad. He tilted up his ship in a
shallow bank, his eyes on the ground below
him. The car was a quarter of the way
across the big clearing when he saw it lurch
suddenly. A hundred yards more and it
stopped on the edge of the ditch.
Sleepy grinned slowly. Apparently Gib
was strictly on the job. He saw flashes of
flame as the bandits returned the fire, but
there was no answering shot from the woods
as far as he could see. Undoubtedly Gib
was holding his fire for fear of hitting his
father.
Four men clustered behind the car.
Evidently Mr. Saunders was not there.
He wondered where the banker was. Pos-
sibly they had bound and gagged him in
some nook of his own house, he reflected.
Suddenly his eyes narrowed and the wide
mouth tightened. The four men were
making a break for the woods on the op-
posite side of the clearing from where
Saunders was hiding.
In a flash he saw the fatal mistake he and
Gib had made. By running on a course
that was a continuation of an imaginary
line made by Saunders and the car, they
could use the car as a partial screen all the
way. When they reached the woods they
could circle around, using the trees as pro-
tection, and shoot Gib from the rear. He
would be totally helpless against four men
spread out in the woods behind him. Their
only chance for escape, and that a slim one,
was to change their tires without being
under fire. In all probability they were
desperate enough to take any chance that
offered even the slimmest of opportunities
to escape.
ALMOST before these thoughts had
raced through Sleepy's head he had
nosed his ship down in a straight
dive, motor wide open. The bandits were
less than fifty yards from the car as he
came roaring across the field, not a foot
above the ground, and headed straight for
them.
The Le Pere was a thing of terrible power
as it hurled itself across the ground, and the
bandits turned and ran back toward the
car. The purpose of the pilot was very
evident to them.
Adventure
With a grin Sleepy thanked his stars that
they did not know how fatal it would be to
him if he really hit them. It would assuredly
break his propeller and pile him up against
the trees at the edge of the clearing.
No sooner had he gone past them than he
lifted his ship in a beautiful climbing turn
that was almost a wing-turn. The ship
was practically stalled at the peak of it, but
headed back the way it had just come. It
settled earthward, picking up speed as it
dropped until it was once more speeding
across the ground, nearer the car this time.
The bandits had stopped when it went past,
but as it returned they scurried the rest of
the way back to the car.
Once again Sleepy performed the same
maneuver. If there was any flyer at
Donovan Field who doubted Spears' flying-
ability, a grand-stand seat that day would
have settled his doubts. Wing-turning a
Le Pere from a foot off the ground is a ma-
neuver that leaves the pilot only a few feet
between himself and a bad crash. Stalling
the slightest bit too much at the top of his
climbing turn would mean a straight drop
to the ground, for there was not altitude
enough to gain flying speed after it was once
completely lost. At best it was necessary
almost to pick the ship off the ground as it
settled after the turn.
Twice more they tried to make a run for
it. The second time one man flopped face
down to the ground. Like a flash Sleepy
nosed down a bit more, trying to hit him
with the wheels. In all probability it would
not hurt him badly, but it would certainly
scare him effectually. His idea was simply
to bounce his wheels off the man's back.
He did not succeed, but with a grin he
reflected that he had not come far away, for
the man's body had disappeared beneath
the wing. The man started to get up as
Sleepy passed, to be knocked down by the
propeller blast. He dived for the car with-
out delay, and for ten minutes there was no
further attempt at making the woods. It
looked very peaceful down there--the field
stretching big and smooth in the sunlight,
four men clustered quietly around the car,
and the mesquite giving no sign of the dead-
ly rifleman within its cool-looking green
shelter.
One of the bandits showed himself in-
cautiously beside the car. As Sleepy
watchfully patrolled low over the mesquite
he saw the man grab his arm and leap back
behind the shelter of the auto. A thin wisp
of smoke arose from the mesquite. It was
lucky that the bandits apparently had only
revolvers as weapons, thought the pilot.
Suddenly he nosed down at full throttle.
All four men were making another attempt
to cross the clearing. For a moment he lost
sight of them as the top wing hid them in
the steepness of the dive. As he roared
across the ground they retreated near the
car, and flashes of fire from four revolvers
could be seen plainly. They shot continu-
ously.
As he passed them he felt a shattering .
impact in his shoulder. The plane wabbled
for a moment and veered perilously as the
pilot felt the searing pain of the bullet.
With an effort that left him faint he
straightened the ship as the wing-skid
dragged the ground, and held it level for a
moment. He lifted it over the trees and
banked around.
The lucky shot had left his right arm al-
most paralyzed. Every bump that hit the
ship caused him excruciating pain. He
had only one hand to handle both stick and
throttle. The blood was slowly staining
through his shirt, and he could feel it trick-
ling down his body.
Three times more, at intervals of a few
moments, the men below tried to outwit
him. Each time the roaring Le Pere, speed-
ing toward them as they started, sent them
back. Apparently they had no doubt of the
pilot's intention to hit them. With his face
white under the tan, and his body weaken-
ing rapidly as the slowly gushing blood
drained it of strength, Sleepy fought to re-
tain consciousness.
Of all the tragedies that happen in flying,
ninety per cent, start within ten feet of the
ground. An errot in leveling off--hitting
an obstruction in landing--slipping into the
ground trying to bank too close to it--those
are the things that kill pilots. Spears,
forcing himself to keep clear-headed and
conscious by main force of will, time and
time again wing-turned off the ground to
rush back across the field before his prey
could escape.
Never a time did that terrific dive last a
split-second too long and send the Le Pere
head-on into the earth, nor did it falter and
drop as it climbed and turned together, to
be ready for the next dive. Twice he de-
liberately tried to move his right arm, so
that the agony of it would help him fight
Riding Herd--Modern Style
off the faintness that threatened to master
him.
He had no conception of the passage of
time. The motor was running wide open--
he was too close to the ground to risk taking
his one good hand from the stick to cut it.
A seductively dangerous languor came
over him. It seemed useless to keep watch-
ing the men below--they had not made an
attempt to break for the woods in some
time. It was so silly and futile to go to all
this trouble.
He banked mechanically. For a moment
his hand dropped from the stick limply, and
the ship nosed up; hovered on the verge of
a spin. A terrific bump that sent agonies
of pain shooting through his right side
cleared his head, and he caught the ship
just in time. ^
The field danced crazily before his eyes.
He knew he must go down, or in a little
while he would cease to fight off the de-
licious drowsiness that seemed like paradise
as he thought of yielding to it. Just to let
himself go-
He kicked the ship around, and took his
hand from the stick. He jerked the throttle
back, and quickly grabbed the control again.
He felt a shock as the undercarriage swept
through the top of a tree. As if he were
watching some one else do it he uncon-
sciously leveled off, five feet off the ground.
The nose dropped, and the wheels hit and
bounced. For just a second the pain
cleared his head--he knew he was eight feet
off the ground, but he did not care.
He fainted as the ship bounced again, the
low undercarriage saving the ship from a
nose-on crash. Sleepy was crumpled in the
front cockpit as the Le Pere rolled almost
to the edge of the woods, and a red-headed
figure came bounding toward it, rifle in
hand.
VI
SPEARS opened his eyes and looked
up into a genial round face, belong-
ing to a bald-headed gentleman of
middle age. He was in bed, and evidently
in a private house. An electric fan buzzed
from the wall, and the setting sun sent a few
beams of light beneath the lowered cur-
tains. A gray-headed man was smoking a
cigaret as he sat on the edge of a table.
"That's the boy," grinned the bald-
headed man, ruffling the thin fringe of red
hair that he possessed.
"Where might I be?" inquired Spears
calmly.
He felt the bandages on his arm, and was
conscious of utter weakness that was not
unpleasant.
"My name is Saunders, and this is Dr.
White. You're in my house, son."
"Oh, yes."
A wide grin came into being slowly as he
looked into the bright eyes above him.
"How did they rescue you from the
boys?" he asked.
Gib came tiptoeing in, a tall girl with red-
gold hair behind him. As he met Sleepy's
gaze he • leaped for the bed and shook the
left hand of the pilot enthusiastically.
"Came to, did you?" he grinned. "Boy,
wasn't that a-"
"Meet my daughter, Mary," interrupted
Mr. Saunders, and Sleepy smiled up into
the face of the girl.
He noticed with approval the creamy
skin and gray eyes, fringed with sinfully
long, black lashes.
"You're not an applicant as nurse, are
you?" grinned Sleepy.
"Not an applicant--I've got the posi-
tion," she returned with a mischievous
light in the gray eyes.
"Good. How did things come out, Gib?"
"You rolled right up to me, almost, and I
taxied the ship close to the trees to have a
sort of two-way barricade. I popped one
of 'em when they broke for the woods, and I
previously had winged another one in the
arm. They stopped to carry the fellow I
nearly killed--he was a fat chap--and be-
fore they made the woods the posse got
there. When did they shoot you?"
"Second or third time I went across.
I'm some cowboy, eh?"
The people in the room looked at each
other meaningly as the realization smote
them that Sleepy had been flying for a half-
hour or more with that wound.
"It was a horribly lucky shot they made,"
Sleepy remarked.
"Mustn't let you talk too much," in-
terrupted the doctor, who had been listen-
ing quietly. "You've lost a bucket of
blood, and you've got a nasty shoulder."
"Tell me a couple of more things before
I shut up," begged Sleepy. "Where did
you come from, Mr. Saunders, and how is
the ship? Did I crack up-- No, I
couldn't have if you taxied it, Gib. Didn't
they shoot at you?"
Adventure
"Yes, but with revolvers. They told us
dad was chained in an old cabin out here.
He couldn't have gotten away, but they did
leave him enough to eat and drink. The
ship is all right--Correll is out there now
and we'll arrange a guard for it. We've
wired Donovan Field that you'll be here
three weeks."
"Nothing to do but lay around, eh?" in-
quired Sleepy.
He yawned as he spoke, and excused himself.
Delicious drowsiness was overcoming him.
"That's all--eat and sleep and let that
shoulder heal," said the doctor, replacing
things in his bag.
Sleepy's eyes roved to the luscious vision
of Miss Mary Saunders.
"Nothing to do but lay around and be an
invalid. I think I'm going to like it here,"
he murmured.
They all tiptoed out to avoid disturbing
him.

OMETHING was standing in the
trellised moonlight beneath the
pine trees. Something half re-
vealed, half shadow, half seen,
half guessed. And it had not been there
a few seconds before. Being in England, the
land of pheasant worship and the grouse
cult, the shadow ought to have been a dog
or a fox--but it was not. It looked like
neither of these, there was something differ-
ent about it, a suggestion of greater wild-
ness. It was a little larger than a fox, a little
smaller than a wolf; and when it turned its
eyes shone green. Then it stepped into the
full light, and became a coyote--a prairie
wolf.
The reason for so fierce a presence in so
tame a land came about as follows. Four
months before, this coyote had struck a trap
in America--on the south fork of the Stink-
ing Water River, to be exact. One month
before he was touring England as part of a
traveling menagerie. Upon this night of
nights he had been fed by his keeper--who
was beautifully and unashamedly drunk.
They found the man asleep in the cage
next morning; the key of the cage they
found on the floor, but the coyote they
never found. So much of this animal's
history is known, so much is public prop-
erty. The rest, that which follows, is here
revealed for the first time. It was told to
me by the wild folk, and it is not given to all
to understand the language of the wild folk.
A thin high scream cut aslant the cathe-
dral silence of the pinewood, a scream al-
most startlingly like that of a child, and the
coyote 'froze'. He sank upon the grass
and was still; eyes gleaming, ears pressed
close back, thin lean upper lip lifted a little
to display the cruel glistening fangs. Only
his flanks moved, still heaving to the
The Outcast
exertions of his ten mile removal from the
menagerie. Then quite suddenly, came the
scream again, and the coyote slid away on
his stomach.
He knew that cry, the last protest against
fate of a terrified rabbit. He came to a
hedge, and peered through. He saw a shad-
owy beast with a big bush-tail--something
like his own--dragging a kicking rabbit
toward the hedge. Red fox the coyote
noted to himself--and waited. By which it
may be seen that he knew all about foxes.
Reynard came on--knowing nothing in
his turn of coyotes--and slid into the hedge-
ditch with his struggling prey. He preferred
to kill it here than in the open, where its
pestilential squeal might attract any horror
--a keeper for instance.
"G-r-r-r", said the coyote, a yard above
him in the tangle of hedge-roots and the fox
stiffened from head to foot. He was fright-
ened, that fox, frightened no end, for he
had never heard a growl like that before in
all his marauding life. And a stoat, that
was enviously watching the fox, fell back-
ward down the bank of the ditch and fled;
while a dry, rustling flutter o'erhead told
that the roosting birds had heard that
growl also, and were afraid.
A head--almost wolf-like in its evil fierce-
ness, almost fox-like in its leering cunning--
was thrust suddenly from out the matted
tangle, and the fox visibly quailed. Then,
behind the head, came the coyote; not
slowly but like a brown streak. The fox
was aware of a burning pain in his near
shoulder, and he pivoted cringing back
among the damp dead leaves of the ditch--
forgetting the rabbit. The rabbit had not
forgotten him, however. It forgot nothing.
It went, or rather to be more exact, it was
gone, for noi|e had seen the going of it. In
the wild it is as well to grab your chance
while you can; you may not get another.
The rabbit must have known. But if that
rabbit thought--do rabbits think?--he had
check-mated his foes, he counted without
the coyote. Check it may have been, but
mate was not yet.
In a second the fox--badly bitten as he
was--had picked up himself and also the
rabbit's trail. Whereupon he went, with-
out comment, into the moonlit haze; and
soon, as he galloped, the rabbit danced
before him. He could see it a fleeing
shadow, a bunched up ball and a stretched
out streak alternately.
Bunny had no illusions. The drumming
of the four-footed death on the short grass
behind left no room for any. He wanted to
get back to the warren, which was not far
away, very badly indeed. He would have
got there,'if a strange thing had not hap-
pened--a thing neither hunter nor hunted
expected.
The fox was first of all aware of it, a long,
lean, silent, gray shadow which shot--it
almost seemed to fly so quick was it--past
close to him.- It had eyes aflame, that
thing, and he shied at sight of it, as a fright-
ened horse shies. In a flash it was ahead.
The rabbit may have heard it coming; but
it is doubtful if he knew what killed him.
Followed a glint of fangs as the apparition
shot up alongside the luckless bunny, a snap,
but no pause. At full gallop this ghostly
specter had killed and picked up the quarry,
swung round in a wide circle, and vanished
away, still going like the wind, into the
night. Then at last the fox must have
realised that this was his new enemy of the
ditch, the coyote, that strange, giant, foxy
apparition which had come out of nowhere
at him, and gone again as a whirlwind
might into nowhere, for aught he knew.
Having dined, the coyote set off across
country, at the long, tireless, wolf gallop
that will run down almost any four-footed
thing in the end. He had no idea how far
that menagerie might pursue him, and he
was taking no chances. A wild creature
never willingly takes chances.
Once--that was when he bee-lined over
a bare blunt-nosed hill--a line of hurdles
leaped up in front of him. He took them
in his stride and fell among ewes, many and
loud voiced ewes, who rose up as one sheep,
and ran about complaining in a full throated
chorus. Seeing that the poor outcast's one
notion at that time--possibly at all times--
was self-effacement, this action on the ewes'
part was unkind. For one thing it caused
him to fly the opposite line of hurdles like
a bird, and for another it awoke a long, low,
blue beast, from nowhere special, which fell
in dumbly at the coyote's heels. The shep-
herd called it a bob-tailed sheep-dog, but
it looked more like a silent devil in the light
of the "cynical moon." It took the coyote
half an hour to shake that speechless horror
off his track.
Once also--that was when he was gingerly
rounding the corner of a cattle-muddied
gateway--he fell on to and over a warm,
Adventure
feathery live thing, which got up and snored
away into the night on vast flapping wings,
more uncannily than any ghost. The next
five hundred yards he must have covered in
record time for he was scared almost into
rabies. The thing was an owl, a white owl,
and a big one at that, though what it was
doing in the mud of a gateway no one
knows. Perhaps some rat could have told.
Rats are generally intimately--too inti-
mately for their liking--connected with'the
doings of owls.
And once--that was the worst fright of
all--he barged head over heels into some-
thing that he could not see stretched across
a gap, and it clung. He fought madly for
a space, rolling about, snapping, and tear-
ing like a thing possessed, for this nightmare
held on all round him. Followed a curse
from the shadows, and after the curse a
man, and after the man a dog--a thin, lean
dog this time. The coyote did not like the
appearance of that dog, it looked under-
hand, and even a mole could see that it was
built for speed.
This may explain, perhaps, why he bit
the man on the hand--his teeth met, I am
told--and went away into the night with half
the unseen terror which clung, wildly flap-
ping from his hind quarters. The man
swore strange oaths and went away in a
hurry, which seemed strange. As a matter
of fact, however, the coyote had run into
a poacher's net stretched across a gap-way
for the entertainment of certain hares, and
the poacher was about as scared as the
prairie-wolf over the meeting.
An hour later came the dawn--cold, un-
pitying, matter-of-fact dawn---and it dis-
covered this coyote in the middle of a gorse-
and-bog-patched moor. He went into re-
tirement for the day in a fox's earth which
he sought and found in a great hurry. The
stench of the place--for there are few
fouler abodes among the wild folk than the
den of the little red rascal--made him very
literally, and shamelessly, ill. He knew,
however, that anything--even the most
appalling effluvium--is better than for one
of the night prowlers, the outlaws, to be
found abroad when the sun is up.
WHEN evening fell, and the shad-
ows hunted the raw, red sun home
to his lair, the coyote thrust out an
inquiring muzzle, and thrust it back again
in a hurry. A man was coming through the
gorse--a jet black shadow carved out, as it
were, against the crimson sky. Came he to
the fox's earth and dropped a rabbit by the
entrance. He gave no reason for so strange
an action, but the reason--seven of them--
had been found killed in his fowl-house
three nights before--and the rabbit was
poisoned. Evidently this tit-bit, this gift
gratis, was intended for the entertainment
of the rightful owner of that den, and he
happened to be away upon a blood raid,
in the opposite direction!
The coyote waited ten minutes after the
man had gone, then he wriggled out to the
rabbit. He gave one sniff, only one, then
he went away, also, straight as a die, and
very swiftly, with every hair along his back
sitting up all bristly. You see, he was ac-
quainted with poison. He had cause to be,
for he had once on a time watched his
mother die beside a poisoned carcass, and
the terror of the taint which had hung in the
air round that carcass lived with him ever
after. It had been a nightmare, and the
mere whiff of poison a hundred yards to
leeward, had the effect of terrifying him for
hours.
Like a hunted cat, this wolfish beast, that
was not a wolf, panicked across the face of
the sullen moor. Then he caught sight of
his own shadow cast by the dying sun--•
a blue figure against blood red grass--danc-
ing along at his side. He never waited to
think, but shot away ten yards in three
bounds--and stopped.
There was no question about the stop-
ping. One moment he was racing at I dare
not say what speed, the next he just--wasn't
moving. And the suddenness of it nearly
wrenched him to pieces. He had simply
bounded full into one of those quagmires,
one of those abominations which pock-mark
so many moors. But no flies settled on this
beast. He did not wait even so long as
one second. If he had he would have been
a very dead coyote; and he knew it.
How the miracle was accomplished, how,
without appearing to pause or think or hesi-
tate, he was able to rebound again exactly
as if he had landed upon a spring-board in-
stead of a quaking, shaking, sucking, death-
trap, is beyond mere human knowledge.
From this bound he reached a tuft of deer-
grass, at least one presumes he reached it for
he barely touched it, rebounding for the
second time and on to firm ground at last.
Being somewhat scared, he ran on for a few
The Outcast
yards along the edge of the bog before he
discovered that he was exhausted some-
what, and sat down.
It was the hour of brooding calm, when the
sun's last rays, lingering, charmed the pur-
ple heather into a deeper tone. In the pine-
wood behind him--such was the silence--
the coyote could hear the hollow purr of the
air in the upper branches, like the humming
in a shell, and the tiny tumult of an ant
city: the indescribable slithering undersound
which can only be detected in very still
places. Night was stalking westward swiftly
over the purple lakes of heather.
A jay screeched 'gratingly, somewhere
'way back in the wood; the last woodpecker
had fled laughing into the shadows; the last
family of titmice had trailed by, twittering
and "twee-jeeing" to each other, through this
hall of a thousand columns. Presently came
a long-drawn sigh echoing down the pillared
aisles, and after the. sigh a big brown bird,
flapping like some gigantic moth; that was
a long-horned owl, and it flew without sound
as an owl should.
Suddenly the coyote turned his head.
Something--some swift moving shadow--
was coming across the bog. How any beast
heavier than a mouse could cross that quak-
ing abomination was past understanding,
but the shadow proceeded leisurely and un-
flustered enough, and it did not sink. In-
stantly the coyote, the outcast, slid to a
heather patch on his belly, and lay there
crouched; his green glazed eyes fixed and
staring at the shadow.
The apparition came on, bounding lightly
from tussock to tussock of deer-grass, half
insolently, half playfully, it seemed toying
with the suffocating death that it only es-
caped by a hair's breadth at each fairy-like
bound.
The coyote's lips dripped, as he watched;
his eyes took on a crueler glow. The thing
was a deer, he knew the breed: the slender
legs, the arched hind-quarters, the graceful
step, as if the beast were walking on air.
As a matter of fact she--it was a she--was
a roe-deer but this he did not know. He
took her for a prong-horn antelope, perhaps,
or a white-tail deer--but, no matter; his
tactics would be the same.
She passed him--he had taken care to lie
well to leeward--quite close, so close that
as she vanished like some spirit of the wood
beneath the trees, he saw the transient
gleam of her white rump quite plainly. For
a minute he waited--time enough for her to
penetrate the wood well out of sight.
Then he dropped his head, and, with tail
slightly lifted, settled into the long easy
wolf-gallop on her trail. He must have
known by the scent how close he was--or
how far--for never once did he sight her or
blunder on to her heels in the pine gloom,
nor was she once startled, or aware of her
tracker. Thus nicely did he judge his pace.
As the trail broke from the wood and led,
straight now as a die over the open moor, the
pace increased. The lone night wind whis-
pered in his ears, and the night-hawks and
bats did their own small hunting above him.
But he never lifted his head. His eyes were
glued on the way ahead. Only his restless
ears took note of that which went on around.
Once a fox halted in the middle of trailing
a rabbit, to stare at this big wolfish beast
loping by with gleaming eyes; and once,
something, which was not a fox--though it
was as big--stood in his path chattering
obscenely, forcing him to go round. That
must have been a badger.
Finally--this after an exhibition of clever
windings, twists and turns--the trail led
to,a spruce firwood, black as a well, and
still as a well, or death. Here was needed
great caution, and the coyote slid belly flat.
The whorls of the trees came down and
brushed the needle-carpeted ground, diffi-
cult to avoid, hard even to creep through,
hard that is, when even the faint sound of
brushed back branches, would have ruined
all in that desert-like silence.
Suddenly, as if some cold hand had seized
him, the coyote sank where he stood, sank
and was still, like one that is stricken sud-
denly by death. In front was a clearing,
no more than a gap, shadowed as to its
center by one lone, big spruce fir. And
beneath that lonely shade stood the doe,
and she had business with something that
was there. She was anxious, that deer,
anxious and happy, making odd little noises
in her throat--and beside her were two
more shadows.
Then she stood out before the moon, and
there followed her, two fawns, their great
beautiful eyes shining like stars. Dainty
spirits of the shades--sleek, shining, satin-
eared, velvet-nosed, dappled and light as
thistle-down, upon legs "slender as hazel
wands."
How long the coyote lay and watched that
wonder is not known; some hours perhaps.
Adventure
He might have been a figure^carved out of
dark and light oak for all the signs of life
he gave. Only his eyes lived, those green
orbs, with the strange coldness of cruelty--
cruelty is assuredly a cold passion--ap-
parent in their depths.
At last a badger--clumsy, shuffling,
furtive, and morose--passed in the gloom.
He was in a hurry that beast, and when a
badger is taken that way dawn is not far off.
This the doe knew--or seemed to know.
She vanished with her double charge slowly,
under the pall-like shade of the giant and
isolated spruce, and when she came out
again she was alone.
As a smoke puff fades, so faded this elfin
like haunter of the woods. The flash as of
a faintly gleaming lamp caused by her light
rump as she whisked away, was all the indi-
cation a watcher would have had of her
departure.
The coyote followed, a slinking evil form
in the gloom. Followed her to the edge of
the wood, far enough to see the roe-deer
safely on her way--but no farther. He had
other work on hand.
In five minutes he was back again by the
miniature clearing, crouching motionless as
before, watching always the gloom beneath
the spruce that stood aloof. And the sky
paled to gray even as he crouched. So in-
tently were his cruel eyes fixed upon this
spot that he never saw a shadow--surely it
was no more than a shadow--which drifted
up from nowhere special behind him--
drifted and stopped.
The minutes dragged on painfully, almost
as if the dead silence, the stagnant air, was
waiting for something to happen.
A FOX passed, slinking and car-
mine tinted about the jaws. A
pine-marten "rippling in faultless
curves," the incarnation of living, moving
grace, went by in the dawn, and his jaws
also bore the blood stain, the badge of out-
lawry. A squirrel slid down perkily from
some tree near at hand, and slid up again
in a hurry, when it saw the couched coyote.
The fox was red, the pine-marten was red,
the squirrel was red, the watching, waiting
shadow behind was red, all of them red,
against a background of reddish tree-trunks
and pine-needles, lighted up all together
and suddenly by the fiery red of dawn, that
wonderful dawn which comes after the gray,
and is followed again by a day of gray rain.
Suddenly the coyote moved, sat up, and
the shadow--the shadow was gone. Only
a gleam as of twin stars, a flash as of a low
burning lamp, hastily extinguished, marked
its disappearance, and made one half suspi-
cious as to whether it had really been a
shadow after all, and half doubtful as to its
ever having been there at all. This also,
the coyote did not see.
Then the wolfish beast moved forward--
almost flat he proceeded---and his caution
was evident at every careful, creeping stride.
There was still darkness under the great
spruce, and for a moment he stood con-
fusedly. Then, in a soft place, just the
least noticeable spot, exactly where they
would be most difficult to get at, he saw the
fawns. They were lying down, but not
asleep; they were looking not at him but
past him, behind him at something that
was there--the shadow had come back
again.
A gleam of white fangs scintillated in the
growing light, but there was no sound as the
coyote half rose and dived forward headlong
upon the helpless fawns. They tumbled to
their feet. They could run fairly well, fast
enough to avoid a man, but not a coyote.
And they fled.
Then, without any kind of warning at all,
the shadow took unto itself life. It hurled
itself forward head down, preceded by short,
but rapier-sharp horns, at the speed of a
powerfully shot arrow; and its mark, its
goal, appeared to be the coyote. It was a
full-grown roe-buck, and of all the cloven-
hoofed ones the roe-buck is the least
troubled with fear and flurry.
The coyote was behind one of the fawns--
just about to deliver one of his quick, chop-
ping bites on the flank, in fact--when he
became aware of a small-sized whirlwind
hurtling down upon him from behind.
He realized his danger, and pivoted upon
himself, presenting a fanged and snarling
front in one and the same second, so it
seemed; being specially designed to do so.
But in the next second he was removed quite
twelve feet by the sharpest pair of horns, and
the most impetuous buck, he had ever run
up against. When he regained his feet--
which was practically the same moment as
he touched the ground--he was furious;
for this buck was only small--no larger than
a pronghorn antelope, and the wound in his
shoulder pained abominably. But he had
made one blunder; he had not reckoned
The Outcast
upon the peculiar character of the roe-buck
--there are deer and deer, and the roe-deer
is unique.
Next moment the whirlwind was upon
him again; the fury of the charge was ex-
traordinary, and amazed the half-recovered
coyote. He did not--being only an outcast
wolfling--stand up to it, but skipped to one
side, and delivered one of his chopping flank
bites. A whirl of pine-needles followed, for
the roe-buck can turn as can no other deer,
and the coyote fell backward, as the quick-
est way to avoid a hissing slash of those
terrible forked little horns.
Thereafter things happened, and hap-
pened quickly. The coyote was no amateur
in the matter of keeping a whole skin by
agility, and agility alone, but the deer he
knew were not like unto this little fury. He
leaped, and side-leaped and sprung back-
ward, pivoted on his tracks, spun like a top,
rolled from under the flying hoofs, raced like
a greyhound, and generally performed on an
average thirty acrobatic feats a minute.
His foe, however, plunged and stabbed,
jabbed and hacked, stamped and tore, and
raged, and fumed, and bucked, and backed,
and thrust, and cut, and slashed, and
foamed, like unto some four-footed fiend.
The coyote might have been a magnet, and
the buck a piece of steel, so close did they
follow one another.
Now a coyote, unharried and unpressed,
is many kinds of a coward, but a coyote
cornered and hanging on to his life by his
whiskers, is just any sort of a devil you like
to name. This may be why, at the end of
five minutes of this death dance, there were
triangular gaps on the roe-buck--chiefly
about the flanks--where the flesh had been
removed in chunks. On the other hand the
coyote was striped much as is a tiger; only
the stripes were red, not black.
Followed a collision. I don't know how it
happened. One of the combatants must
have made a mistake somewhere. Any-
way, they met. It was a bundle, that is all
you could say; a huddle, and it was not nice
to behold. The needles flew all whither,
and the earth followed suit. Which beast
was where, it was impossible to say. Save
for the horrible low and continuous snarling
of the coyote, there was no sound, but one
knew that death hovered round that jumble
of legs and bodies.
Then, with startling suddenness it
ceased--the fight was over. The roe-buck
was standing rocking in his tracks, as a tree
rocks in a gale. The coyote lay on his back
ten yards away; and both were unpleasant
to behold, were unclean to the sight.
Slowly the coyote heaved on to his feet,
and stood staring stupidly--himself rocking
to and fro--at his enemy. Then, like a
broken thing--reminding one in a singular
way of some half-killed insect--he dragged
himself away into the red eye of the rising
sun; a shocking nightmare of a beast, a blot
on the beauty of the dawn. And even as he
went the roe-buck toppled forward on his
nose, and lay still--for ever.
As for the coyote he blundered drunkenly,
half blinded, and half choked, straight
ahead to the open moor and its scattered
bogs, and into a bog, and under it for ever
and all time.
And that is why the dozens and dozens
of people, who scoured the country for that
lost and outcast coyote, never found him--
and never will.
Author of "A Shot at a Venture," "Evil Starbuck," etc.
R. TUDGAY, second mate of
the ship Yattaroi, stood at the
shore gangway gazing irritably
along the stretch of wharf at
Dunedin. His ship was a big handful for
the crew at his disposal, and getting ready
for sea was too big a job; five apprentices,
two of them first-trippers, constituted the
entire available gang. Of the ship's com-
pany sailing in the YaUaroi from Lon-
don, only these and the captain were left,
and Captain Kirk was even now scouring
Dunedin for a crew of any sort to carry his
ship to sea, for he feared he might yet lose
his boys, who knew little, and cared less, of
the legal tangle of words which demanded
a cash forfeit from the parent of each ap-
prentice defaulting his indentures. There
was a lure for healthy lads in New Zealand,
the land of Pink Terraces and tattoed Ma-
oris. As for the rest of the defaulting hands
--crew, cook, steward, and the first mate
himself--they had only followed countless
examples and struck off to seek fortune in
their own way.
"Blessed good mind to hop it myself,"
grumbled Mr. Tudgay.
He caught sight of the youngest ap-
prentice grinning as if he had overheard the
shameful confession, and was tempted to
turn loose his wrath in physical visitations
on the youngster's curly head. The sight
of a cart approaching the ship, laden with
boxes and bottles of the skipper's private
i
stores, swung his mind from an unhealthy
subject to a more wholesome one. He
aroused the boys with a resounding deep-
sea roar, and sent them scampering down
the gangway.
"Bear a hand and put those stores in the
captain's stateroom, and watch yourself if
either of ye broaches anything," he ordered,
and turned away, as a decent mate should,
to hide a grin; for the boys, almost before
the cart had stopped, had filled each a grimy
fist from a basket of peaches with the devil-
ish skill and uncanny instinct possessed by
all sailing-ship boys since the first wreck on
Ararat.
The chief thing was that the boys were
employed, and would be for half an hour,
which gave Mr. Tudgay a legitimate excuse
for standing idly gazing up the wharf in
case the captain arrived. The Uttered
decks were not so littered as they appeared,
for most of the rubbish was broken dunnage
and useless bits of discarded staging, which
were to be put into the cook's bunker or
hove overboard as soon as they were beyond
the harbor; and the hawsers were ready,
the topsails and courses, jibs and spanker
were bent--sufficient canvas to carry the
vessel to sea--and the staysails and t'gal-
lants'ls, royals and gaff-topsail could be
sent up and bent while under way, providing
the captain had managed to scare up a crew
with two arms and legs apiece.
The second mate's cogitations were broken
The Cook of the Yallaroi
off suddenly by the heaving into sight of
an imposing procession, led by Captain
Kirk in person, looking a bit out of place
with his dignified air and gait--the more so
by contrast with his following; and the
straggling fine was flanked by two hand
trucks containing a collection of nondescript
sea-going gear that would have disgraced
a rummage sale. A little way apart, but
still with the crowd, a big, darkly handsome
man strode along, carrying a bright new
portmanteau in his capable hand as if it
were a lady's handbag instead of a man-size
piece of luggage weighing sixty pounds or so.
"Shake a leg down below, boys," yelled
Mr. Tudgay through the saloon skylight.
"On deck wi' ye, and bear a hand. Oh,
corks! There's a full crew for us, lads, and
a bloomin' Don Juan packing his own dun-
nage that looks the spit of a liner mate!"
"Mr. Tudgay, this is the mate, Mr.--
"Galway," the new mate supplied, smil-
ing brilliantly and making the second mate
squirm with the grip he gave him. "Hope
we'll get along all right, Mr. Tudgay."
"Ye'd better," grunted Captain Kirk
darkly. "Get a move on wi' yer sea gear,
Mr. Galway, and we'll off to sea. The tug's
due now, an' we've lost plenty time."
"Crew signed on, sir?" asked Tudgay as
the new mate vanished to change into more
suitable attire for working the ship out.
"Yes!" snapped the skipper impatiently,
then saw the reason for the query.
The men were slouching about the gang-
way as if none of them had the least notion
what part of the ship they belonged to.
Of them all, only two showed intelligence.
The cook went directly to his galley, and
already the rattle of pots could be heard;
one seaman had gone direct to the fore-
castle, and now appeared dressed for work.
"Get for'ard, you!" the skipper roared to
the rest, "Are ye thinkin' to make it a
pleasure trip? Get changed and tur-rn to.
Can't ye put life into them, Mr. Tudgay?
Are ye second mate or am I? Here, you
parson-looking son of a waterspout! Aft wi'
ye and start yerwor-rk! Are ye a steward
or are ye not?"
A weedy, round-shouldered, pale-faced
biped, who looked as much like a washed-
out parson as anything else, shambled aft
and followed th: skipper into the cabin with
eyes upturned in shocked amazement at the
manner of his greeting. His lips muttered
soundlessly, and his fingers writhed as if he
were passing a benediction upon a crew of
cannibals the moment before he was in-
troduced to their cook-pot.
The new mate came to time smartly,
whatever his appearance might indicate,
and Tudgay fell into line easily after Mr.
Galway had been on the deck of his new
ship two minutes. He was certainly a full-
rigged chief mate, if he did look rather more
suitable for the high bridge of a shiny liner.
"The Old Man's picked us out a ripe
bunch, sir," grinned Tudgay as he fell to
work on his half of the gang and started
singling up the shorefasts.
"Overripe, Mr. Tudgay; very much over-
ripe. Did you take a slant at the cook?"
"Only man in the crowd who seems to
know which end of a ship goes first," grunt-
ed the second mate.
"Aye, but take a good quiz at his hand'
some dial, man!"
The mate plunged into his own duties,
and speedily made a working gang out of
the indifferent material at hand. The cook
was already peeling potatoes, seated on the
bitts abreast of his galley door. Tudgay
scrutinized him keenly. After the first
real look he could scarcely take his eyes
away. The man's face looked as if the two
ugliest human faces extant had been twisted
up together as two wet dishcloths might be,
then wrung out, flattened, and prodded
into shape roughly with the prongs of a tor-
mentor until something like a face was
evolved. The mouth was a slash, the eyes
were set in two slits--but the eyes them-
selves held the fire of the tiger's. One ear
was half-gone; upon the forehead was a livid
scar; the uncouth head was set, however,
upon a neck like a tree, which in turn rose
out of shoulders and a chest that would not
have shamed an eight-foot Hercules; and the
arms, hands, legs and hips were in harmony.
"What's your name, cook?" asked Tud-
gay, curiously regarding the man.
"Peters, sir; Joseph Peters."
"You're a regular he-man, ain't you?
You ought to be in the fo'csle instead o'
peeling little spuds. You'd make a top-
hole bosun."
"I don't like the forecastle, sir. The men
are so rough," replied the amazing cook in
a voice which would have reverberated over
the harbor if given range, but which sound-
ed muffled and dumb as if through sheer
apprehension.
i6o
Adventure
The second mate was to experience a big-
ger surprize yet. When the ship was bow-
ing to the great ocean swell just before let-
ting go her towline, he was at the monkey-
rail overseeing the placing of the booby-
hatch, and the new steward emerged from
the main-deck saloon door bearing a dish of
ingredients for the cabin dessert. Tripping
slightly over the high door-sill, the parson-
like steward gave vent to what sounded
suspiciously like a real, ripping, back-o'-
beyond curse and then abruptly resumed
his solemn aspect and gait and proceeded to
the galley. But the surprize came when the
cook, the big, Herculean cook, got up from
his own door-sill with amazing alacrity at
a sharply flung word from the steward, and
took the dish from him with the air of a
subdued underling.
At the moment the chief mate, having
seen the tug's line let-go, was passing to
superintend the making of more sail, when
the steward turned aft again and almost
collided with him. There was a very sub-
dued exchange of words; even the second
mate could detect that, since he was
watching keenly. Then the mate loudly
warned the steward to look where he was
going in future, and they separated, each to
his job. Then the cook's grotesque visage
was thrust out of the door, and for five
seconds he regarded the pair of receding
backs with a gaze of such bitter intensity
that Mr. Tudgay involuntarily turned away
with a shiver.
The incident might have suggested a
mystery to any one except a buoyant,
youthful second mate scarcely out of his
time, to whom the world was a round ball
made in such fashion that good square-
rigger sailors might be developed on out-
and-home voyages to the colonies, which
constituted a circumnavigation of the globe
every time. As it was, Tudgay was far
more concerned in thinking what the luck
of watch-picking would bring him out of the
frightful mob of incompetents struggling
with uncertain hands and feet at the
appalling task of putting sail on a full
clipper.
ONE of Captain Kirk's good habits
was the holding of deck church
every Sunday forenoon, and per-
haps it was all the better as a habit inas-
much as his ship always carried a number
of boys out of decent homes. With Sunday
arriving, and his ship stretching away on a
composite Great-Circle track for the Horn;
with his hulking, scowling, incapable crew
at least hammered into some sort of shape,
and ship's business going on with more or
less smoothness through sheer capacity of
himself and mates; Captain Kirk set the
boys to work laying out reading-desk and
books on the poop, and cast speculative
eyes upon the parson-like steward.
"Skeets, ye look as if some time ye had
taught Sunday-school," he said. "Can ye
conduct a sairvice for me?"
"I could have done a while ago, sir," re-
plied the steward in a voice simply soaked
with humility; "but I'm a backslider, sir,
a sinner and a renegade, sir; and J can not
make a mockery before those young, inno-
cent lads. Please excuse me, sir."
Mr. Tudgay turned away with a face
convulsed.
"Innocent boys!" he choked. "I wonder
how, much o' the cabin delicacies the inno-
cent boys ha' robbed him of already!"
He might also have wondered what such
a smug-looking steward, such a model of
humility, had said to that tough-looking
cook on the first day aboard to send him in-
side his galley so hurriedly. But since there
was no substitute, Captain Kirk would not
permit service to be delayed; the skipper
took up his place at the desk himself, at the
break of the poop where all hands could
hear, and bade the mate muster the men
aft.
The men came dubiously. Only half an
hour before they had all been turned out,
on a Sunday morning top, to brace up the
yards a trifle, and were sullen about it; for
there were enough among them who had
made at least one voyage who knew that
immemorial custom at sea gave Sunday to
the crew. And but for crass stupidity they
would have enjoyed the rest, too, except
for standing wheel in turn, for the
weather was fine even if the wind had not
yet settled down true. They came and
stood beside the mizzen hatch, sullen and
muttering, while the captain opened his
book and began to read service.
Midway to the end, the wind came ahead
again, and without stopping longer than to
give the order, the skipper sent both mates
with half the men--those whose regular
watch on deck it was--to trace the yards
sharp up. Even while Mr. Tudgay howled
hauling chanteys in the waist to encourage
The Cook of the Yallaroi
the men, the service droned along its inevit-
able course; and never once did Captain
Kirk seem to take his eyes from his prayer-
book. But he was the shipmaster even
while he played parson, and the end of the
service was more than a little broken in con-
tinuity.
"As it was in the beginning-- That'll do
th' foreyard!-- Is now and ever shall be--
'Vast hauling that!-- World without end--
Well th' mainyard, Mr. Tudgay!-- Amen.
--Turn to, ye useless lumps, and coil up the
gear!"
The skipper finished, flung his book down
and stamped the poop, cursing to high
Heaven the fate which had sent him such
a double-left-legged lot of sons of blind
tailors for crew, and audibly wondering
what sort of mates he had inherited that
they could not lick a crew into shape in
three days at sea. Perhaps the crux of the
matter was overheard by the second mate
at the pantry skylight after he had resumed
charge of the deck and captain and mate had
gone below to prepare for the noon observa-
tion. Under the little square of barred
glass the steward stood in his tiny pantry
handing out to the mate a cup of cold black
coffee left over from breakfast.
"Ever see anything like it, Skeets?" de-
manded Mr. Galway with a queer chuckle.
"Never! The old fool ought to be easy!"
returned the sometime meek and lowly
steward in tones not at all like those he
habitually used.
Mr. Tudgay walked away. He scarcely
noticed the change in the steward's tone;
but he did notice the lack of respect in the
steward's attitude, and wondered no longer
why his own watch were already far ahead
of the port watch in ability.
BOUNTY ISLANDS, and Antip-
odes Islands, both the merest
groups of specks in a waste of blank
chart, lay on either side of the YallaroVs
legitimate course; both groups are desola-te,
both have Government food and clothing
caches, there being in those old clipper days
ample need for such to succor not infrequent
sailing-ship castaway crews. On some
groups a boat is left in some secure crevice.
On the Auckland group two boats were al-
ways available; on the antipodes it was
harder to keep such valuable aids, and the
single boat? alloted to the group had been
stolen more than once by passing whalers,
though, to do those splendid seamen justice,
they nearly always left an addition to stores
to pay for the boat. Only the exigencies of '
whaling, and the stem necessities for sound
boats of the capable type used on' those
island stations, tempted an occasional
whaler to accept the gift of the gods and
sail away with a new boat.
Mr. Galway seemed well versed in all such
matters. He would talk for an hour to the
second mate about the time when he was in
one of the Government vessels depositing
those stores; he even went so far as to talk
for an hour with some of the unseamanlike
crew about the islands; once, so the ugly-
visaged cook asserted, he had shown a chart
of the ship's track to two of the seamen, and
chatted to them about it in a manner very
unlike that of a good chief mate.
The cook told the steward about it, and
the steward spoke to the skipper, bring-
ing the inevitable result; the Old Man sent
for the cook, and raved at him from the
head of the poop ladder. Mr. Tudgay and
two of the boys stood a little aft, and
could not avoid hearing the rave.
"The Old Man was peeved, wasn't he?"
Tudgay asked of the mate with a grin when
watches were changed later.
"He ought to be!" retorted Mr. Galway
with a fine air of indignation. "You want
to watch that plug-ugly cook, Mr. Tudgay;
if I'm any judge of men he's cooking trouble
as well as poor grub."
" I thought it was about chatting with the
men that the Old Man ragged-"
"Well, it wasn't. And I'll thank you to
mind your own business. The captain
called the cook down because he carried
yarns about me, the chief officer, and said
I was hobnobbing with fo'csle hands for'ard
o' the galley. You know, as well as any-
body, that I was trying, as always, to teach
'em a bit o' sailorizing."
Mr. Tudgay ought to have known better,
of course; he should certainly have known
better than to carry his indiscretions so far
as he did after supper, when he was alone
for a moment with the skipper on the poop.
He was rash enough to disclose to Captain
Kirk his suspicions that Mr. Galway--the
immaculate mate of such wonderful hand-
someness, as the steward had been heard to
call him--and some of the least seamanlike
of the crew, were too thick for the welfare
of any sailing-ship bound home Horn ward.
The skipper glared at him for a full thirty

seconds, puffing up like a woman on the

"Mis-ter Tudgay! I ha' seen traces o'

ha' ye to know that Mr. Galway is as fine

Ha' no more o' it, ma man!"
"All the same, sir, I'd watch that steward
if I had command," the second mate per-
sisted rashly.
He really ought to have known better.
He was not a first tripper.]
"Go to yer room!" roared the skipper,

four hours. And if I see no sign o' yer

-me! A-boy would ha' more sense!"
"You're right--than a blasted thick fool
of an Old Man!" muttered Tudgay, and
