termined to endure it in real comfort.
At a quarter of an hour before middle
watch that night one of the apprentices
tapped at Tudgay's porthole and found a
wide-awake listener to his report.
"The helmsman," he said, "was that.
quiet-looking chap that talks to the cook.
He's the only one as does, sir. He heard
all the Old Man said to you, and when I
went for'ard to rouse up Lamps for the
binnacle lights I saw 'em both very deedy
in chat. The cook caught me by the arm
and dragged me inside and told me to come
along for a dish o' collops--here it is, sir--"
passing a covered dish of savory, steamy
viands through the porthole--"and told me
if I blabbed a blessed word to anybody else
he'd scrag me and clap me into the copper.
What's up, sir? Isn't trouble, is there?"
"Trouble?" repeated Tudgay, sniffing
hard at his favorite dish and setting the
food carefully into a snug corner of his
locker-top. "Don't talk so - silly!
See what I get for mentioning trouble?"
"Yes, sir, I know. But that quiet A. B.
that was in the galley, he pinched my arm
till I nearly hollered, and told me in a voice
like a blessed snake's that he'd skin me and
eat me raw after the cook got finished with
me if I said a yap either about your grub or
about the Old Man's outbu'st. And he
ain't one to chatter without doing, either,
Mr. Tudgay."
"I never saw him do anything," grumbled
Tudgay, eager for his meat but more
.eager for news.
"•Well, nobody else did till tonight,"
chuckled the boy, full of his subject.
He was standing within the covering
shelter of the half-deck, speaking through
a port, hidden and inaudible to all except
an intending eavesdropper, and that he had
apparently guarded against.
"But," the apprentice continued, "I saw
him take on that big whale of a murderer-
lookin' cross-jack-eyed sailor in the port
watch and hammer seven bells out of him,
sir, and-"
"What?" burst forth Tudgay. "Lick that
tough? You're as mad as-"
"It's a fact," insisted the boy excitedly.
"Same tough as Mr. Galway and the
steward have been so thick with. Cookie
was referee, because all hands o' the watch
wanted to chip in on the side of the plug-
ugly. You betcher, sir, the cook said about
two words to 'em, and they stood back.
Hide the dish when it's empty, sir; here
comes somebody."
The boy vanished into the shadows of the
main-course like a bit of itself, and left Mr.
Tudgay to his reflections, which were none
of the clearest. Youthful as he was, yet his
sea time had been spent during a period
when it was nothing unusual for a sailing-
ship to change crews three or four times in
a round voyage; and in Australia, New Zea-
land or the West Coast there werS strange
characters always ready to take the places
of deserting crews, and that with the sole
idea of getting as far and as fast away from
their shipping port as possible.
Runaway convicts, weary of chain-gangs
and breakwater slavery; unfrocked priests,
beyond shame at their fall; deserting sol-
diers, defaulting, smug crooks from places
of trust, and sheer crooks--all these went
to make up crews of those glorious old clip-
pers that gave all the romance and spirit
to the glorious old sea. Mr. Tudgay had
seen every type, and though he had never
experienced any deeper trouble from such
crews than apprehension, he was still young
The Cook of the Yallaroi
enough to retain a sacred belief that one day
big trouble must burst right under his nose.
Now he was certain that the trouble-
laden voyage had come. He disliked many
of the crew; he distrusted the parsonlike
steward, and through him the too friendly
chief mate; he wasn't sure about the alarm-
ingly ugly cook, but had been inclined to
like the man, especially so since receiving
that steaming dish of Scotch collops, the
spoon of which he was even now licking.
But since devouring the savory mess he had
begun to think deeply, and now he recalled
the amazing subsidence of the powerful
cook at a single word from the sharply
different steward; he recalled with growing
astonishment the boy's report of that gor-
geous forecastle fight, in which the quiet,
slightly built seaman who was a friend of
the cook's had whipped the toughest-looking
bully in the gang.
The threat of the cook to scrag the boy
and make stew of him was lost in the newer
puzzle of the skipper. Captain Kirk had
never failed to show a subtle power in deal-
ing with refractory crews before; but here
was the one time when he apparently fell
down hard, for Tudgay could attribute his
own temporary disgrace to no other source
than the mental aberration of the Old Man.
He lighted a pipe, turned into his bunk and
prepared to thresh out the whole matter in
the peaceful solitude of his snug prison. He
found his tobacco unaccountably difficult to
keep alight; he lighted the pipe a half-dozen
times, then concluded that there was some-
thing amiss more than damp weed, for his
pipe was cold the last time he put match to
it, though he was convinced that the five
minutes' strenuous drawing at it following
the previous ignition must have made the
bowl hot-- Then the poop bell struck four
bells.
"Me sleeping like that?" he growled, and
slung his legs over the lee-board, rubbing his
eyes foolishly and trying to remember any-
thing queer in the taste of those collops.
Nothing that any man could have said to
him at that moment could have altered his
opinion that he had been drugged. That
sheer sleepiness could make him fall asleep
was absurd, to him. He was still puzzling
when a yell pealed up on deck that brought
him to the floor and at the cabin door in a
flash.
"Fire!" arose the yell. "Fire!"
Almost immediately the key was turned
im his lock, and the door opened wide. He
burst through into the warding arms of the
skipper, himself rubbing his eyes and mak-
ing for the companionway in his pajamas.
"On deck wi' ye, Mr. Tudgay, and see
what's amiss!" the Old Man cried. "I
canna let ye bur-run, though I believe ye've
been the cause o' this, wi' yer insubordina-
tion. Up wi' ye, man!"
Tudgay went, choking back the hot re-
tort that rose to his lips, and found the ship's
company milling in a strange sort of frenzy
about the poop ladders, while the mate, with
two sleepy boys beside him, bore himself
more like a liner captain at a fake fire-drill
on a swagger passenger steamer than the
mate of a prosaic old butter-and-mutton
wagon caught on fire in the wastes of the
extreme South Pacific.
Captain Kirk went past the chartroom on
his way to take charge, and glanced at the
ship's last position as pricked off. The run
since previous noon brought her within reach
of the Bounty group of islands and rocks.
He joined the mate at the poop rail.
"What ha'ye done? What are ye doing?"
he demanded. "Have ye ascertained the
source of the fire? Where is it, man?"
"Mr. Tudgay is seeking it now, sir," re-
turned the mate with exquisite calm. "He
has two A. B.'s and a boy. But I've seen
these fires before, sir, and if I might make
a suggestion I would say we had better run
for the islands in case of disaster."
"I ha' never yet pairmitted slack mates to
lose me a ship, Mr. Galway, and if the
Lor-rd's willing I shall not pairmit such
now," retorted Captain Kirk with a hard
glance at the debonair mate.
"Get ye down yon wi' Mr. Tudgay and
bring me yer repor-rt, shar-rp!" --
The smoke reek smelled like nothing
recognizable, though Captain Kirk sniffed
with all the sagacity of a forty-year sea-
mellowed nose. For a moment he lost sight
and sound of the crew, failed to catch the
ominous note in their deep mutterings, and
strove with all his faculties to put a name to
the amazing aroma carried by the swirling
smoke. Tinned mutton and tub butter
alone make a cargo hard to set fire to; the
butter might make a blazing inferno of the
fire when started, but neither it nor the
canned meat would be likely to catch fire
without strong inducement from outside;
besides, that puzzling reek was more remi-
niscent of very boyish days than of a grave
Adventure
marine disaster. He was still puzzled when
the mate rejoined him shrugging his shapely
shoulders.
"Afraid the ship's doomed, sir," Mr. Gal-
way reported. "The butter is melting, and
soon it'll catch. The ship will be like a pow-
der-mill then, sir. I would suggest we make
for the Bounty Islands while the ship floats;
then if we have to take to the boats safety
isn't very far away."
In the lantern light at the main-hatch the
crewT's faces were turned aft expectantly.
Expressions ranged from brutal indifference
to sullen ferocity; like a hideous mask the
ugly face of the cook appeared among them,
and as he faced the poop his features were
awork with some undecipherable hope, long-
ing or fear.
He caught the captain's eye just at the
moment when, together, the mate finished
speaking and that strange reek explained
itself. As glance met glance, the cook dis-
appeared through the hatch, and the mut-
tered growl of the crew rose fiercely.
"By Christmas, I have it!" roared the
skipper, thrusting past the mate and leap-
ing down the ladder. "Mr. Tudgay! Do
ye keep the poop and hold the course. I'll
see f'r maseP-"
"Better let me go, sir," the mate called
out, and started to follow.
The skipper flashed back:
" Stay where ye are! I sent ye to seek, and
ye smelled a trouble I believe is not here!"
He reached the hatch, and the mutter-
ing ceased through sheer wonder at his ex-
pression.
"Touchwood! Punk! Rags!" he mum-
bled as he flung his leg over the coaming.
In another instant his eyes were water-
ing, and his lungs labored in a thick blanket
of pungent smoke through which his smart-
ing eyes made out a red glow against which
an uncouth monster shape silently toiled
at some devilish task.
He recognized the cook, and in a fury of
blind resentment for the trouble on hand
hurled himself forward with hands groping
for the man's throat. He gasped sharply
when his own strong hands were seized in
a grip like a vice, yet as gently as might be,
and thrust aside. From the cook's crooked
lips came the soft warning:
"Easy sir, easy! Don't be hasty. I'm
helping you. I knew what was the matter,
but the crew would have murdered me if I
made any move to let you know. I took
a chance when I saw you coming, and I've
nearly got it out now. Here, sir; see the
trick?"
The man's eyes glittered and his entire
face writhed in horrible mirth. Captain
Kirk stared at him dubiously and bade him
stand aside. Then he flung himself upon
the smoldering pan of smoke-making ma-
terials and killed the last red spark before
ordering the cook to precede him on deck.
A grimace of still intenser subtlety con-
vulsed the cook's face, and he seemed to
hesitate; then with a shrug he obeyed, and
ran up the bulkhead ladder like a great cat,
leaping on deck with a crouch and with guard-
ing arms as if expecting a vicious assault.
Nothing happened; and the skipper came
up to find the entire crew following the
mate around the ship, pulling on a brace or
sheet here, turning up a coil there, growling
the while like a cageful of surly bears. The
cook halted as the skipper reached the deck,
waited as if to hear some comment on his
own case, then at a brief nod turned and
slipped into his galley and shut the door
silently.
Captain Kirk stared after the man with
open mouth, then shook his puzzled head
and joined the- second mate on the poop.
The helmsman was the same quiet seaman
who had whipped the forecastle tough, and
the faint light from the binnacle played on
his face as he raised his eyes to the star he
was holding course by. His lips moved as if
he too were muttering, and a spasm of rage
swept through the skipper from toes to
fingers.
"The fire's out, Mr. Tudgay," he snapped.
" It was a dir-rty trick played for some hid-
den pur-rpose which I shall seek and find
yet. Will ye keep close watch on yon ugly
devil of a cook? I ha' doubts o' his pair-rt
in this queer business."
"The cook's all right! He's about the
only one as is!" burst from the helmsman,
and the skipper regarded him blankly,
amazedly.
The man reddened and fixed his eyes on
his star again, shifting uneasily on his bare
feet, conscious that he had permitted his
tongue to carry him into the unforgivable
offense---forcing way into a conversation of
his officers without warrant. As if aware of
the gravity of his fault, and in desperation
determined to be hanged, if at all, for a
sheep rather than a lamb, he blurted out
again--
The Cook of the Yallaroi
"It's the mate you want to watch!"
Captain Kirk peered into the second
mate's face, suspicious that a sound he had
caught was too much like a chuckle for
respect. Tudgay's face was wooden, but he
could not hide the gleam in his eyes; and
the skipper's mouth was opened to demand
attention to duty, which would include
punishment of the presumptuous helms-
man, when the mate ascended the poop
ladder and briskly approached the skipper
with a smile that might have meant any-
thing from congratulation to amusement.
Captain Kirk stepped forward to tell him
what the helmsman had said, but Tudgay
reached out, touched his sleeve, and said
quietly but penetratingly:
"Don't tell him yet, sir. I can tell you
something that'll give reason for the man's
charge."
"Mystery on mystery!" growled the
skipper angrily; but he merely received the
mate's report with a nod, and so far ac-
ceded to Tudgay's request as to refrain
from telling Mr. Galway what the seaman
had exclaimed.
But he was reminded of Tudgay's recent
confinement to his cabin, and permitted
himself at least one safety valve.
"Ye'll be able to carry on now, Mr.
Galway," he snapped. 'Mr. Tudgay,
retur-rn to yer room. I'll ha' chat wi' ye in
the mor-rning."
Tudgay dipped through the companion-
way doors like a flash, too well pleased to
think of anything but unbroken slumber for
the rest of the night. He had no idea what
the theatrical fire meant, but placed small
importance upon it since it had been dis-
covered and smothered. The thing might
even have been a monkey trick of some of
the boys, perhaps to gain access to the but-
ter in the hold; for apprentices got no butter
in the Yallaroi. Anyhow it could be nothing
serious.
Hi£ decision was shocked back upon his
mind in the next instant. Entering the
saloon to go to his room, he came upon the
steward working feverishly to bundle food
and blankets anywhere out of sight. As he
stood watching the man in wonder, the
skipper entered, and uttered a gasp of aston-
ishment as genuine as Tudgay's.
"What in the wor-rld are ye doing,
steward?"
"I heard the cry of fire, sir, and consid-
ered it my duty to prepare stores and blank-
ets against a boat venture, sir," replied the
man with a greasy smile on his pallid face.
Tudgay passed on to his room, unwilling
again to risk the skipper's displeasure;
a glance at the dour Scotch face showed him
that anger and irritation were very near the
surface.
"And why are ye not retur-rnin' the
stores and blankets to their proper places
now that there's no need for them?"
"I have been laboring under stress, sir.
I believed it would not matter if I simply
put the things out of the way tonight and
asked for some of the boys to help me in the
morning."
'Well, maybe, maybe," grunted the skip-
per. 'Go t' yer bed, then. I doubt ye're
a poor body o' a man anyhow. Get awa'
wi' ye."
Growling deep in his honest breast,
Captain Kirk crossed over to his stateroom
and scowled fiercely as he passed the second
mate's cabin at finding the door a little open
and hearing Tudgay's voice accosting him.
"I told ye to tur-rn in, Mr. Tudgay!" he
snapped, and turned the key in the lock
again.
The irrepressible Tudgay popped his
head through the fanlight over the door.
"I tell you, sir, you must listen!" he said.
"I have to tell you something you'll be sorry
if you miss. It concerns the safety of the
ship and all hands--"
The skipper had passed the door, but the
words arrested him. He stood still for a
moment, fingering his stubborn chin. Then
he stepped back, unlocked the second mate's
door and entered, closing the door softly
behind him.
"Well? Be shar-rp wi' yer croaking.
I ha' small patience left for ye."
Tudgay went to the porthole which
looked out upon the recess of the half-deck
wing, and peered out. The port opened in-
wards and was hooked open to an iron de-
pending from a beam; a stout iron cover, for
bad weather, was fastened to the bulkhead
outside.
"Come on wi' yer yarn!" snapped the
skipper impatiently.
Tudgay turned to him with a queer look.
"I thought I caught sight of somebody
listening outside, sir," he said.
As he spoke, the skipper's head jerked
around toward the door; he leaped to it
with something like belief, and as his hand
touched the handle the key outside was

turned in the lock. At the same moment
the iron cover to the port fell with a heavy
clang, and the turning of the big screws
could be heard plainly.
"There, sir!" cried Tudgay excitedly.
"I told you-•"
"Silence, man!" retorted the skipper
furiously. "Why did ye not mak' me hear
ye, instead o' blatherin' by little bits about
mysterious troubles? Here, clap yer shoul-
der to the door!"
One assault they made, and a voice from
the saloon cried:
"Don't try it, cappen! Next time y' bang
on the door I'll put a brace o' lead slugs
through the panel!"
" What -d'ye mean?" roared Kirk.
"Keep civil, and maybe no harm will
come to you," returned the voice.
Then came the sound of conflict some-
where forward, the report of shots, the clash
of weapons, the curses of savage men.
The skipper and Tudgay stared at each
other in speechless awe, but gradually into
the junior's eyes there crept the inevitable
"I-told-you-so" gleam which even the des-
peration of the moment could not prevent
the skipper detecting. What he might have
said about it was halted by a violent im-
pact of bodies against the'half-deck bulk-
head, the shrill cry of a boy in pain, and the
roaring chorus of men in pursuit. Farther
away a seaman swore bitterly; a shot rang
out; then came the sound of running feet,
and the ghastly, suggestive crunch that an
ax makes when biting into flesh and bone.
"Oh, man!" groaned Captain Kirk in
horror. "Why did ye no' mak' me listen?
What's to be done? Poor Galway!
Poor-" _
"Poor swine!" retorted Tudgay savagely.
"I told you to watch him, sir. He's at the
root of this, I'll bet my life--if I save it."
He hurriedly related that little conversa-
tion at the pantry door, when the steward
confided to the mate that the Old Man
ought to be easy. Captain Kirk's keen eyes
glittered coldly, and his face grew hard and
stern as he listened.
Outside the cabin all seemed quiet; but
forward, far in the bows, sounds were not
wanting to indicate that at least some of the
crew were loyal to the ship and were putting
up a fight.
"And d'ye say yon parson-faced steward
that's so thick wi' the mate frightened the

'I know, sir. And I told you he was all
right; so did the sailor, Tom Peters. Now

with us?"
'We'll know soon, ma poor chappie,"
replied the skipper with unwonted quiet-
ness. 'The noise is finished, and I doubt

Poor, poor laddies! Look yon!"
He pointed out through the small round
port-glass in the ship's side. The stars
were sweeping past in a line of glittering
splendor.

A knock came at the door, and a rattle of
the handle.
"Take yon fire-ax!" ordered the skipper
fiercely.
Then he crouched beside the door, of
which the key was outside, and yelled in
answer to the knock:
'We ha' an ax! The first man to show

The silence was suddenly intense. It
seemed to Tudgay's strained hearing, as he
stood on his toes with every muscle tensed
to bring down the murderous blade, as if
a sibilant murmur, as of quietest whispering,
ran through that awful quiet of the saloon.
Then the knock was repeated, and a piti-
fully small voice, the voice of a boy, called
quaveringly: _ ^
"It's only me, sir. Let me in."
'Who's wi' ye, boy?" demanded the

The key was outside, and there seemed

'Only me, sir!"
The assurance lost its value by reason of

"They're all here, captain!" the lad

A savage curse accompanied a heavy,

'By -, Tudgay, burst the door!"

The stout oak stood with a quiver.
'Gi' me the ax, then! Oh, the devils!

'Don't, sir!" pleaded the second mate

we were locked in. They'll murder us both

The argument barely reached the furious

"If a man shows his head I'll pit th' ax

talk ta me, ye murderin' scum!"
A savage voice swore, and a head, arm,
and gun were thrust in through the opening
above the door.
"Drop that ax!" the man growled, and
swung the gun upon Tudgay.
"Brain him wi' it!" yelled the skipper,
and with the words leaped like a cat at the

ward.
Tudgay struck with the back of the ax-
head, and the gun clattered to the floor, in-
side the cabin; the man fell back among his

"Cap'n, you'd better submit," came the
mate's silky voice with a suspicion of a
harsher fiber woven in the silk now. "The
key is lost; Tudgay must have a spare one

make terms for you. If you're stubborn
we'll starve you first, then burst through
and handle you."
Captain Kirk sputtered with anger; the
hot retort hovered on his tongue when
Tudgay seized his arm, put a finger to his
lips, and pointed to the side porthole. A
soft tapping sounded on the glass, and the
face of Brooks, the oldest apprentice,
frightened but still plucky, appeared in the
circle. The tapping came from a door-key
in the boy's hand.
With a gasp of startled gratification at the
knowledge that at least one of his lads was
safe, the skipper motioned Tudgay to open
the port, while he himself answered the
mate * through the fanlight. The tone he
used efficiently drowned the small noise of
opening the port.
'I have no key. Tudgay has no key--"
his canny Scotch conscience urged him to
mutter "yet" under his breath--"and if we
had all the keys in the ship I'd make no'
ter-rms wi' a dir-rty mutineer. I ha' a gun
and an ax and a detairmination to see ye
all hanged for gallus-crows, as ye are. Do
yer wair-rst, ye ruddy pirate, and be -
to ye!"
"You'll starve!"
"We can do that--but I doubt we won't."
"The men are desperate; they'll-"
"They may do their-est!"
"We've two more of the boys. We'll
let you listen to them squealing outside
here."
Kirk wavered at this. He cast a poignant
glance at Tudgay. The port was open, fresh
air came in, and the second mate held up
a door-key. The boy, who was hanging
precariously over the ship's side with one
hand to the poop gunwale, shook his head
vigorously and whispered sobbingly:
"I'm the only one nigh, and they ain't
got me yet, and they won't!"
The boy stopped abruptly, clapped his
free hand alongside the other, and wriggled
upward out of sight as if he had caught a
warning sound on deck. Skipper gazed at
second mate, and both saw in the other a
resolve to fight.
"I'll hear one squeal fair-rst," he replied
to the threat.
A deep rumble of voices seemed to fill the
saloon; but Galway made no retort, and
silence fell again, leaving the captives in
a quandary as to its meaning.
"Maybe this is the only gun, sir," sug-
gested Tudgay.
"Likely. But I widna believe any man
fool enough to try to carry a ship o' this
size wi' one weapon. What's yon screech-
ing?"
Both listened; then Tudgay darted to the
window that opened on to the half-deck
recess, which the mutineers had bolted
outside. The screws of the iron cover were
turning. Tudgay shut the port, gave the in-
side butterfly nuts an extra twist, flung the
thick red curtains over the glass and pinned
them, then stood aside, motioning the skip-
per to the other side, and both waited for
the new assault.
"We'll soon know about the guns," mut-
tered Kirk, his eyes aglitter as he watched
the saloon fanlight against surprize from
that direction.
Soon the outer cover was raised and
hooked, and a hearty volley of deep-sea
oaths followed the discovery of the blinding
curtain over the inner glass. A port glass is
a thing of marvelous toughness, and yields
to nothing less than terrific force. So far as
forcing it, unless with gunfire or blows of a
Adventure
maul, the outer iron cover might almost as
well have, been on. A few futile blows with
the port-key followed, then Galway's voice
sounded in peremptory command, the
voices outside receded, and soon the greater
angle of the ship's list told of freshening
wind and work on deck.
"Pairhaps they'll leave us alone a while
now," remarked Kirk.
He was peering in every corner of the
little cabin, and his gaze darkened every
moment, while the little circle of the side
port grew lighter with dawn.
"Ha' ye no outlet--no hatch to yer
room?" he growled.
Tudgay raised the square of faded carpet.
"There was the hatch into the old sail-
locker, sir. But when you built the sail-
room on deck you had the carpenter calk
this up." The removal of the carpet re-
vealed a square hatch, flush with the floor,
and the line of pitch around it was hard and
shiny with age and the chafing of the carpet.
"And what's beneath now?"
"A wing of the store-room, sir. Spuds
and flour mainly, I believe."
"Har-rd stuff to shift wi' such small
scope," mused the Old Man with a shake of
the head. "But man, we must do some-
thing! Gi' me the ax, and do ye get busy wi'
yer knife. Tak' oot the calking. Mak' no
noise, and keep yer eyes peeled at yon fan-
light." They fell to work as a yell echoed
through the ship from the direction of the
foremast.
AS THE horizon silvered with the
first light of day, three dark figures
huddled in the foretop silently
helped a fourth on to the platform beside
them.
"I got the key to them, cook!" the new-
comer, Brooks, said gleefully, panting and
bright-eyed from his perils encountered in
passing the key through Tudgay's port-
hole, his subsequent Indian-like avoidance
of enemies, and his climb aloft.
"Good boy!" muttered the ugly cook,
clapping the lad on the shoulder softly.
The other larger figure resolved itself into
the quiet sailor who had so manfully pro-
claimed the cook's honesty to the skipper
while at the wheel. Besides these, and the
boy just welcomed, another boy crouched
there, wide-eyed with fright, but quiet, and
willing to share whatever might come.
The lightening decks beneath them were
deserted apparently except for a small hud-
dle of men right aft by the wheel; but here
and there, about the galley and forecastle,
dark splotches lay on the clean planks which
looked queerly like sleeping men, yet sug-
gested more than sleep.
The cook laughed bitterly as he scanned
the ship; and his laugh was a thing of horri-
ble mirth, for his head was roughly ban-
daged in bloody canvas, and one powerful
arm still dripped blood from a hastily tied
handkerchief at the bend of the elbow. The
seaman, Tom, was in no better case, for his
blue check shirt was a ghastly plaster of red,
and his hair needed no pomatum to slick it
to his forehead. The smaller of the boys
quivered with the pain of a long, shallow
flesh cut down his face; and of them all only
Brooks appeared unhurt. Still the cook
could laugh.
"Well, lads," he said, cautiously stretch-
ing a cramped foot over the edge of the top.
"something's got to be done right now.
Here's daylight, and they'll see us in a little
while. Then we shall be targets for their
guns whenever we try to move. They'll
shoot us if we go down and starve us if we
stay up here--unless the captain and Mr.
Tudgay bust loose and surprize 'em, which
I don't exactly count on."
"The Old Man and Tudgay'd be mutton
by now if it wasn't for Johnny Brooks here,
as pinched the key out o' the second's door,"
remarked Tom. "I don't understand what
it's all about. They never took me into
their conflabs."
"They did me, though, at first," grinned
the cook. "Looked more like one of them-
selves than you, maybe. Didn't you see
how they waited on me coming out o'
the hold, when I showed up the fake
fire?"
"But what is their notion?" piped Brooks.
He shivered in the cold dawn; and his
companion, a first-voyage boy, cowered
between the men, fearful of what daylight
might bring to add to the horrors of the
night.
"They'll be copped sooner or later," the
boy went on, "and murder's been done.
They'll all stretch rope, won't they?"
"Aye, surely. Meanwhile they're in
charge of a fine ship, well found, full o' grub
apart from the stores, and heading no'th
far away from any shipping track, toward
the littlest known part of the Pacific."
The cook hesitated with a keen sidelong
The Cook of the Yallaroi
glance at the sailor, who met his glance and
held it an instant, then nodded.
"Might as well out wi' it, Joe," he said.
" 'T won't make no difference that I can
see. If we get clear, you've done your bit,
enough to square yourself anyhow; if we
don't-"
The interrupted sentence was more ex-
pressive than many words. The cook
glanced down upon the still silent deck, and
went on:
"Short and sweet, then: Every man-jack
o' this fine ship's crew, from mate and stew-
ard down to me--that's exceptin' Tom and
you lads, and the skipper and^econd, o'
course--is a wanted bushranger and sheep-
thief. Yes, me as well, sonny," he grinned
in answer to a look of incredulity on the
face of the younger boy.
"Only difference is that they all cut and
run and got away, while I got jailed but was
let out by the front door. Never mind why,
now. Galway and the steward was the two
bosses of a gang o' cattle-lifters, and I knew
'em all years ago, but quit 'em when I got
pinched while out on business for the gang.
They'd just reached Dunedin in a stolen
boat when the Old Man found me and
shipped me for cook. Tom already had a
job here, and steered me to him. In five
minutes Galway steps up, asks for a chance
and gets the skipper jumpin' for joy by
offerin' him a full crew, steward and all,
complete.
"Soon as they see me, they thought to
rope, me in along with them, and told me
their scheme. They was to take the ship,
though they didn't say how at first, sail her
nigh to Bounty Islands and shove the skip-
per and boys and second mate ashore there
where they needn't starve because of the
Government stores, and where the visiting
ship would be sure to call in a few months.
Tom, here, they figured on either taking in
along with them after he knew the plan, or
slipping him over the side if he refused.
"Soon as I see that fire, I knew it was the
first trick; and when Galway proposed
standing up for the islands I was certain of
it. This mutiny is the final bid, and blood's
been shed.
"There won't be any landing on well-
stocked islands for the Old Man now.
They'll kill us all, starve us or shoot us,
unless we get top dog pretty quick. They
won't stop for nothing, with the wide sea
before them and a stout ship to carry 'em
to some place where nobody knows 'em and
shipping men ain't overparticular about real
ownership when a fine vessel's offered for
sale at a foolish price."
"You ought to have told the captain at
first!" cried Brooks.
"I tried to," replied the cook simply.
"Didn't ye see how I never moved a peg on
deck wi'out somebody dogging me? Did
ye not see how the steward always brought
or sent the galley stores along for me, so
that I never went aft? Laddie, I was worth
more to you and the rest alive than dead."
"That's no lie, neither!" growled Tom, bal-
ancing his sheath-knife on his palm and
glaring hungrily down upon Galway, who
was just emerging from the saloon com-
panionway.
At the same moment Galway, glancing
aloft in the way all good sailors have on
coming on deck, whether they are good or
bad men or only indifferent, caught sight
of the huddled figures in the top, now, in
growing light, clearly distinguishable from
the bulk of the masthead and the main-
topgallant-staysail tied up there. A ripping
oath escaped him, and he cursed his helms-
man and the men on the poop luridly for
failing to detect and account for the
refugees before. Pointing to them, he or-
dered them brought down.
"Aye! Come get us!" roared Tom, and
his knife flashed in a deadly streak straight
at Galway.
Only the swaying out from the mainmast
of a main-buntline--the mainsail was furled
--deflected the knife and sent it quivering
into the planks two feet wide of its aim.
"Now you've spilled the soup!" growled
the cook angrily.
Two men started forward and climbed on
to the rail at the fore-rigging; but in the
nearer crisis the cook appeared to see some
cheering factor, for he chuckled.
"Tom, blast me if you ain't swapped that
knife to some purpose!" he said. "Now we
know they ain't got any more guns, or
them men wouldn't dare try to get us that
way. Look!"
At the other rail two other men started to
climb, and four seamen together approached
the futtock rigging with knives in their
clenched teeth, while, below, aft, Galway
flogged them on with vicious oaths. The
cook produced his cleaver, suspiciously dark
as to blade, and spat on his hands; but his
face grew stony as he noticed that his was
Adventure
the only weapon. The sight of it, however,
protruded over every edge of the top in
turn, caused the four climbers to be wary
before setting foot on those overhanging
futtock-ratlines.
"Go on!" roared Galway savagely. "He
can only get one o' you!"
"Come up yerself then, an' let him play
wi' you!" yelled back a dubious mutineer.
At the same moment he made a deter-
mined upward dash, grabbed at the top,
then swung downward again as the cleaver
sang and bit deep into the structure of the
top. But the men on the other side had
seized the opening; one darted upward,
reached over, and grabbed one of the boys
by the leg, wringing a cry of terror from the
lad. Like a big ape the cook twisted around,
flung himself full length across the plat-
form, and brought down the cleaver upon
the outstretched arm. Hand and forearm
parted from the rest at the elbow, and the
man fell headlong to the deck below, show-
ering those in the top with spurting drops.
Galway roared, but the man's shriek
drowned his roar. On the other side again
two men made an infuriated rush, and now
the cook saw the hopelessness of it all.
"Up, Tom!" he gritted, darting from side
to side with chopping blows. "Up with
you by the main-t'-gallant-stay! Up, boys,
after him. Can ye climb, sonny?" he asked,
pausing a second to place his hand gently
upon the bowed head of the younger boy.
"Sure ye can, laddie! Up wi' you all now,
and if ye make it we have them!"
One by one the boys swarmed aloft on the
stay, Tom taking last place instead of first,
and immediately under the trembling boy
in case he needed a cheering word or a help-
ing hand. The cook kept the top inviolate
through sheer animal tirelessness and agili-
ty, until the attackers drew back for breath.
No man can hang indefinitely to futtock
rigging and fight with one hand. Glancing
aloft, the cook saw Tom reach the topgallant
masthead and make the boys secure; then,
peering over the edge of the top to be sure
of his distance, he slung his cleaver to his
neck with a rope-yarn stop cut from a coil of
small rigging and swarmed up the stay
after his fellows.
"Now if they follow up the stay I can
chop down a bloomin' army!" panted the
cook, unslinging his fearsome weapon.
But Galway was watching, and as soon
as the first man crossed the foretop and
gripped the stay to swarm to the mainmast,
his voice rose in a savage bellow:
"Come down, you blasted lunatic! All of
you come down, and get after 'em by the
main rigging."
One man remained on deck by the fore
shrouds, to guard against swift descent;
another stood by the main, and Galway
himself watched the mizzen; then every
available mutineer swarmed aloft on the
main, determined to overwhelm that little
bunch of clinging figures high up on the
slender topgallantmast. And a new influ-
ence entered into the game; the parson-like
steward, Skeets, emerged from the cabin
door, glanced over the ship, and spoke in
a sharp tone to Galway, who glared fiercely,
but made no retort.
"Come down, all but two of you!" yelled
the steward, who had apparently assumed
command.
The men climbing, almost under the
main-top, paused. In the breathing-space
the cook, seeing the precariousness of his
position on so frail a hold, slithered down
a backstay and gained the main-top, where
he might still do stout service against his
attackers. The boys were safer farther aloft.
"Come down and work the ship!" cried
the steward. "Leave 'em up there; they'11
come down when they get hungry or
thirsty!"
The men hesitated, some descending,
others seeming to hang upon Galway's
orders. The steward flung his arms about
in rage, and cursed the mate.
"Leave 'em up there, and who's to stop
them spotting a ship and signaling her be-
fore we can?" yelled Galway.
"Shoot 'em down then."
"Aye, I might, if you hadn't sent the Old
Man a present of the gun!" bawled Galway,
thrusting his convulsed face close to the
pallid visage of the steward.
Up aloft the cook and his companions
beg^n to take keen interest in the row; the
hesitating seamen in the rigging began
slowly to follow their descending mates. j
Tom, at the maintopmasthead with the
boys,icalled down softly,land the cook heard--j
"Joe, there's smoke to the s'uth'ard!"
"Up to the truck wi' ye, then, and bend
yer shirt to the royal-pole for a signal o' dis-
tress," returned the cook.
Then, sure that it would be done, he
turned his attention to the little scene on
the poop.
The Cook of the Yallaroi
It swiftly reached a climax when the
steward* having lost completely all vestige
of his godly aspect, brought up his fist in
a lightning-like uppercut to Galway's chin
that knocked him clear off the poop into
the arms of the first hurrying men. In two
jumps the steward was upon his foe again;
but now the men took a hand, some hauling
Galway clear, others rallying around the
cock-a-whoop steward. And with Galway
on his fe,et again, pale with rage, coldly mur-
derous of eye, the fight closed in grim
silence; not three blows had been exchanged
before all hands closed in a milling, savage
melee.
It was one of the boys who first caught
sight of a cautiously protruding head at the
lazaret-hatch abreast of the wheel, the wheel
that swung as the ship plunged along, un-
attended since Galway, who had taken it to
send every available man after the fugi-
tives, had left it in turn to beard the
steward.
"Tom! Joe! There's the Old Man!" the
lad cried, scarcely lowering his voice from
its piercing treble.
Had he shouted the news none of the furi-
ous mob on deck would have heard it; for
blood was flowing now, knives and belaying-
pins hammered and cut, while Galway and
Skeets were locked in a death grapple,
thumbs at eyes or fingers sinking into
throats.
Aloft at the main truck flew a blue check
shirt, bravely proclaiming to all who saw it,
in the ancient language of the wind-driven
navy, that a seaman wished to quit his ship.
Tom slid down, and as he passed the lads
he bade them follow him, for the cook was
calling them softly, and all the while he was
striving to attract the attention of that
peering head aft.
Huddled in the main-top, they saw Cap-
tain Kirk hoist himself swiftly through the
hatch, and turn to give a hand to Tudgay.
When both stood free, plastered from head
to foot with flour like millers, armed with ax
and revolver, one of the boys excitedly cast
to the winds all caution and threw his
leather-vizored cap at them. It pitched fair
at the skipper's feet, and in a moment com-
munication was established by arm sema-
phore.
Sure of the situation now, the skipper
and second mate advanced to the poop rail,
each snatching up an iron pin from the
mizzen rigging as he passed, in case of need,
and stood gazing down upon their foes
battling for them. The brutal fight had
reached a point where no outside interfer-
ence could break the intense application of
the combatants to the business in hand.
The mate and steward swayed and stum-
bled blindly among the others, knees tot-
tering, breath wheezing through red froth
at the lips. Galway's handsomeness had
departed like a Summer cloud under the red
disfigurement of an empty eye-socket; the
steward's lips were drawn tightly back from
grinning teeth, but his pale face had grown
purple.
"Come on, Tom!" gritted the cook.
"Lads, stay here. You can do no good.
The thing's a'most over anyhow. Now,
Tom!"
This time he gripped the cleaver in his
teeth as he swarmed dowfi by a backstay,
closely followed by the seaman. As they
reached the deck, the cook darted into his
galley, and emerged wielding the "tor-
mentors"--a fearful weapon, that huge salt-
meat fork, in capable hands.
"Take the cleaver, Tom," he said, grip-
ping the great two-pronged fork, "and let's
clean this thing up."
They rushed aft, and reached the edge of
the fight without notice. The deck was lit-
tered with groaning ruffians, and stained in
great dark patches. The skipper and Tud-
gay leaped down the ladder to join their
allies as the two chief combatants pitched
headlong and brought down others in their
fall.
"Tap 'em, lads! Gi' 'em a bit wallop ta
quiet 'em," sang out the Old Man, and
suited the action to the words by knocking
all the fight out of a cursing scrapper with
a blow of his iron club.
So far had the fight gone that there was no
call for cleaver or fork, ax or pistol. In less
than half a minute the two belaying-pins
had scattered all the remaining wits of the
mutineers, and then the lads were called
down to fetch rope to bind up the fallen.
"Put the ship on her proper course, Mr.
Tudgay, till we ascertain damages," said
the skipper, coolly turning over the mate
with his foot.
Galway breathed stertorously, his limbs
twitching. The steward breathed too, but
faintly.
"Tom sighted a steamer making t'wards
us, sir," said the cook. "We flew a signal
to her."
Adventure
He pointed aloft where the shirt fluttered
brightly against a clear sky.
"I doubt if any steamer'll want to relieve
us o' such cattle," muttered the Old Man,
shaking his head sorrowfully as he remarked
the state of his ship and thought of round-
ing the Horn with such a crew, even if he
got them in hand again.
"If so be as it's a Government steamer,
sir, as is by any chance looking for us, she'll
be only too glad to take care of 'em," said
the cook simply.
"Why? What do ye know, mon?"
Tom chipped in and told the skipper
briefly the history of the crew, and gradu-
ally Captain Kirk's eyes were opened wide.
He said nothing until he had taken the
binoculars aloft and regarded the distant
steamer intently for several minutes. Then
he too used tRe backstay for speedier
descent, and sent Brooks to take the wheel
while Tudgay looked up the code-book and
deciphered the several signals repeated to
him.
"What d' they say?"
"New Zealand naval steamer, sir, telling
us to heave-to until she looks over our
crew."
"Then ye were r-right, cook!" cried Kirk
with emotion. "I ha' been blind. We'll
ha' ta go back now for a crew, I doubt, un-
less yon steamer can spare us men. Bring
her by the wind, lads. We ha' no men to
heave her to. I'll hoist a signal masel' to
tell him so.
"But, cook, I dinna want ye ta be taken
wi these gallus crows. Ye say ye were wi'
'em once. See, mon, if ye hide awa' below,
I'll tell 'em ye were killed and chucked
owerboard. Awa wi' ye. Yonder comes the
steamer."
"Joe don't have to hide, sir!" Tom blurted
out.
"Let the mon speak f'r hissel'."
"He won't. I'm his brother, and I speak
for him. Joe's done his bit in chokee, but
he ain't wanted. He got his pardon same
time as he got his face all chopped up like it
is, wi' the shovels of mutineerin' convicts as
was trying to murder the warders. Get yer
parchment, Joe, in case 'tis wanted."
The cook, now that the emergency had
passed, resumed his air of unobtrusiveness
that had marked him since joining the ship.
He went to his sea-chest and returned aft,
clutching a folded paper with much the same
expression as a boy wears when presented
with a certificate for good conduct in front
of his mates. The look sat queerly upon
his marred face, but he broke into a quiet
grin as the steamer swept around and
lowered boats, and the dour Scotch skipper
remarked:
"I'll ha' ma eyes owerhauled before I sail
a ship ta sea again. I thought yon steward,
Skeets, looked like a pure-white woolly
lamb, and ye looked to be a shaggy wolf,
cook. I asked the mon ta read a sairr-vice
the fairst Sabbath oot, d'ye mind?
"A-ah, weel! 'Tis the frailty o' us poor
humans, I doubt. Ye're all wool, cook; all
white, fleecy wool, f'r all y'r har-rd mug,
and--" the steamer's boats were alongside,
the officer hailing--"and if oor friends ower
the side tak' us in tow, or lend us hands ta
wor-rk ship, but leave us the dead ta bury,
I'll ask ye ta r'read the sairrvice afore we
dump 'em to their brither shar-rks!"
Our Camp-Fire came into being May 5, 1912, with our June issue, and since then
its fire has never died down. Many have gathered about it and they are of all classes
and degrees, high and low, rich and poor, adventurers and stay-at-homes, and from all
parts of the earth. Some whose voices we used to know have taken the Long Trail
and are heard no more, but they are still memories among us, and new voices are
heard, and welcomed.
We are drawn together by a common liking for the strong, clean things of out-of-
doors, for word from the earth's far places, for man in action instead of caged by cir-
cumstance. The spirit^of adventure lives in all men; the rest is chance.
But something besides a common interest holds us together. Somehow a real com-
radeship has grown up among us. Men can not thus meet and talk together without
growing into friendlier relations; many a time does one of us come to the rest for facts
and guidance; many a close personal friendship has our Camp-Fire built up between
two men who had never met; often has it proved an open sesame between strangers
in a far land.
Perhaps our Camp-Fire is even a little more. Perhaps it is a bit of leaven working
gently among those of different station toward the fuller and more human understand-
ing and sympathy that will some day bring to man the real democracy and brotherhood
he seeks. Few indeed are the agencies that bring together on a friendly footing so many
and such great extremes as here. And we are numbered by the hundred thousand now.
If you are come to our Camp-Fire for the first time and find you like the things we
like, join us and find y.ourself very welcome. There is no obligation except ordinary
manliness, no forms or ceremonies, no dues, no officers, no anything except men and
women gathered for interest and friendliness. Your desire to join makes you a member.
A WORD from J. D. Newsom in connec-
tion with his story in this issue:
New York City.
The custom of allowing captives to live a fairly
free and independent life until their heads are
needed may sound queer, but it is an actual fact.
Such men are allowed to marry into the tribe and
usually go to their deaths quite cheerfully when the
time comes. Their children, however, belong to the
mother's clan, .group or moiety and are allowed to
grow up under the tutelage of their maternal uncle.
It is a rather "quaint" custom.--J. D. Newsom.
TO MY relief and surprize, my explana-
tion to Camp-Fire of our magazine's
use of dashes instead of cusswords was
strongly backed up by nearly all the letters
that came in, and there have been a lot of
these letters. I'm glad. I can't see my
way to any other course in the case of this
particular magazine and, on the other hand,
I don't like to follow any course to which
the majority of you are opposed.
But I forgot to cover one point. Two of
you raise this point vehemently in letters
to me and they are, I think, quite right.
Dashes for cusswords, yes, but when it
comes to dashes for "God," "hell," "devil,"
etc., used, not as cusswords, but in a per-
fectly legitimate way, there's no need of
dashes. Yet our magazine has, on various
occasions, used them in such cases. That
use of the dash is as offensive to me as it is
to any of the rest of you. I'm "agin' " it
and always have been. But there are seven
of us on the staff and, while most of us have
been here for years, there are changes now
and then. As there are a few thousand
other things to watch out for, this distinc-
tion in the use of dashes isn't always fol-
lowed or even clearly seen.
Adventure
For that matter, it's often hard to draw
the line. Those of you who have read proof
know that "style and consistency" are often
hard to maintain. On one side the line
you'll get a series of cases, each case lead-
ing logically on to the next, demanding for
it the same treatment, and all of a sudden
you'll find you've crossed the line--and
done it logically too. Or, stated the other
way, you'll put one case on one side the line,
later put a second case on the other side,
and then find there's no logical distinction
between the two.
We have lots of arguments on the staff
over cussword cases. When is a cussword
a cussword? Sounds easy to answer, but
sometimes we don't find it so. Also, as
stated already, sometimes we just make
mistakes.
Our intention is to use the word itself
whenever it is not plainly a cussword as
used in that particular instance. Some-
times we'll make mistakes, or at least our
judgment will differ from yours. Just be
easy on us and credit us with good inten-
tions.
Another thing. In poetry we'll "let 'em
ride" even as cusswords unless they get too
dog-goned bad. That isn't quite logical
perhaps, but when the word is essential to
the rhyme it is pretty violent stuff to stick
in a dash.
AN INTERESTING report from one of
■ our comrades of the gentler sex regard-
ing Daniel Boone's brother and his family
in general:
The name and fame of Daniel Boone are insepar-
ably connected with the history of Kentucky. The
old pioneer has been honored in many ways, and at
the present time a fine statue of him, clad in hunt-
ing garb, coon-skin cap, rifle in hand, stands in
Cherokee, one of the most beautiful parks about
Louisville.
Y/f ANY of the descendants of Daniel and his broth-
ers still live in the State, the old Boone home-
stead being located at Boone's Landing about thirty
miles below the city on the Ohio River, and not far
distant is the site of an old mill built by the Boones
at a place caEed Booneport. The descendants of
Hiram Boone, a brother of Daniel, live at Boone's
Landing and a member of the family, the late
Grandison Boone, used to relate that when a small
boy he saw Daniel Boone, who stopped there on his
way to Missouri to bid his kinsmen good-by.
Grandison Boone had but a childish recollection of
the old trapper, but his description of him tallies
exactly with that of others who saw him at that time.
Boone had blue or gray eyes and brown hair, and at
the present time many of his lineal descendants have
the same, while the collaterals are brunettes, their
dark hair and eyes probably inherited from Boone's
wife, who was a Bryan.
T HAVE been present at many of the family
gatherings of the Boones, which country-bred
folks would call "dinings." Early in the day the
members of the various families would begin to ar-
rive. Men, women and children, horses, mules and
hound dogs; the squawking of chickens would be
heard; huge baskets of vegetables would be borne in
from the garden, long rows of cakes were outspread
in the Summer kitchen while in the inner kitchen,
where the chefs of the household were on duty, the
most luscious odors would fill the air. City folks
would stand aghast at the generous supplies of food
prepared and its infinite variety.
Meanwhile the men sat under the trees discussing
crops and politics over tall glasses of cold mint
juleps. Some chewed tobacco, some smoked reeky
pipes, while the horses and mules, taken out of the
traces, browsed contentedly close by. The hounds
tumbled in the grass with the youngsters, or loafed
about the kitchen door, slobbering in delicious an-
ticipation of the feast.
When dinner was served all the guests sat about
a long table loaded to the guards with eatables.
Fried chicken, rosy old country-cured ham, chicken
and dumplings, corn pudding, field beans and bacon,
bacon and greens, tomatoes, raw and cooked, butter
beans, spoon com bread, rhubarb, heaps of snowy
mashed potatoes, buttermilk and hot coffee, pie,
cake, preserves of all kinds, pickles, all the riches of
field, garden and orchard were outspread, while the
women of the immediate household waited on the
table and purged their guests to help themselves
bountifully--"Uncle Hiram you must take some
more cake," "Cousin Squire, I want you to sample
my cornbread," and "Aunt Becky, I made this
lemon pie after your own recipe."
'JpHE conversation was Boone from post to finish:
all the happenings in the family, births, mar-
riages and deaths. Old stories were revived, par-
ticularly one to the effect that when the State of
Kentucky brought the remains of Daniel Boone and
his wife back from Missouri the real bodies were
never given up, but weights placed in the caskets
so that the coffins, buried with so much pomp at
Frankfort, hold no honored dust, but as most of the
Kentuckians know no better they are perfectly
satisfied. Another story revived and retold was
that of Daniel's brother, Squire Boone, who, it is
stated by historians, was killed by the Indians.
The family indignantly disclaim this statement and
declare that he settled in Indiana, on the Ohio, near
Boone Township, and there raised his family. There
was a small cave near his home and on the walls of
this cave Squire carved religious and worldly-wise
sentences. One of the former ran, "I sit and sing
my soul's salvation." One of the latter was to the
effect, "Beware of intentions for fear of preven-
tions," possibly intimating that it was foolish to tell
what you intended doing last some one frustrate
your plans.
When old Squire felt his end was near, he got his
coffin, and selected the cave for a place of burial.
He made his three sons promise solemnly to place
his remains there, sit up with them for three days
and nights, then close up the entrance forever.
The Camp-Fire
This they did and for many years the old man re-
mained unmolested in his rocky sepulchre.
QOME time in the 60's--purchased a farm
on the Kentucky side of the river, below Louis-
ville, and it was there that he died on a black storm-
swept night. His son,--, a thoughtless,
rollicking young man spent some time on this farm,
having for his companion a member of one of the
oldest and most aristocratic families in the State.
One day these two, accompanied by a negro servant
and their hunting dogs, crossed the river in a skiff
and went hunting in the Indiana woods. During
the trip they imbibed freely from their hunting-
flasks and, after wandering over a big stretch of
country, finally stumbled on the Boone cave.
I have never heard whether they knew the story
of this cave or not. Anyhow in a spirit of reckless-
ness they broke open the rude entrance, dragged
the skeleton of old Squire from its resting place and
scattered the bones about everywhere. It is whis-
pered to-day that a distinguished member of the
Boone family, now living, has one of the leg-bones
of old Squire, though he can never be persuaded
to admit the fact, even to his own household.
-and his gay companion finally withdrew to
their boat and the negro rowed them back to the
Kentucky shore, fully convinced in his superstitious
mind that the party was damned forever. It is
certainly true that ---- had persistent bad luck
after this escapade, and died a violent death, while
the Boones regarded his taking off in the light of a
retributive justice.
The waters of the Ohio still glide peacefully past
the cave, the forests have disappeared and prosper-
ous settlements sprung up close by, but the memory
of old Squire Boone lives immortal in the traditions
of his descendants and those of his brothers. One
and all they snap their fingers at the historians and
their story that the Squire was killed by Indians,
and declare that he died peacefully in his bed, wear-
ing his scalp to the last.--Elvira Millie Slaugh-
ter.
OLLOWING Camp-Fire custom, Leon-
ard H. Nason rises and introduces
himself on the occasion of his first story in
our magazine:
Chicago.
So now I am come to take a place at the Camp-
Fire, to meet with other read dr s, adventurers and
authors. The first I have ever been, the second
some little time, and the third have but now be-
come, hence this standing up and this bow and this
present writing. For all that I am of tender years,
I have been with the most of those about this Fire,
what time they were in the far places of the world,
upon their different occasions. He that went down
to the sea and reefed topsails in the gale and passed
the weather earing, I have been with him, albeit I
stayed in on the yard, in the bunt, and clung to the
jack-stay with both hands, for which I was beaten
about the ears by the second mate. He that hath
been to the Spanish Main, and on the beach thereof,
I have been with him, and have been cast out of the
American consulate, whither I had gone for food,
on my ear, and gone to the British, and been be-
trayed by my accent, and then sought a missionary,
and been given the grubstake that my own Govern-
ment had denied me. What so cheap in the Central
Americas as the life of a Yankee?
Those among you that know the feel of a squee-
gee, and a marine's boot, and the joy of smuggled
cigarets in the brig, and no tables down for days,
and a tompion lost in a seaway, with the North At-
lantic coming in through the breech-block like a
shower-bath, I have been with you, and have pol-
ished brightwork and seen the world through a port-
hole and strained shellac through bread for the alco-
hol therein like the saltiest shell-back among you.
And last, I was with those who went to war. Hos-
pital, huit chevaux, replacement camp, M.P.'s, ship-
wreck, vin ordinaire, submarines, I knew them all.
From Mezy to Montfaucon I went, I and my com-
rades of the Rock of the Marne, with our battle cry
of "When do we eat?" on our lips. Two bites of the
dust I took, one at Mont St. Pere, and one in the
Argonne, which last was near to being the death of
me. And then at last I was cast away on Fire Island
with the Northern Pacific and beat a watery grave
by a pig's whisper.
So much for the past. I have hung up my sword,
and made my old tin derby into a flower-pot, and
given myself in marriage, and will henceforth live
in peace, and so to my grave, to which I expect to
go in a hearse, and without boots. It is in my mind
that this can not be fulfilled, for it hath been said of
me that I was bom to be hanged.
Now then, greeting to my new comrades of the
Camp-Fire. And to the many gallant gentlemen
and true adventurers that I have met upon the
Road, to whom these words may come, greeting.
May they read my efforts with a kindly and not too
critical an eye. How!--Leonard H. Nason.
COMRADE MARINO forgot to give his
own address, so I couldn't get in touch
with his friend. If the latter sees this, will
he please tell me in just what way this
magazine is printing British propaganda?
Or will any one else who has discovered
British propaganda in our magazine write
me the details? Generalities on the subject
mean nothing except probably some one
with eyes larger than his brains or else some
one who's busily engaged himself in propa-
ganda on the other side. Give me concrete,
detailed facts or don't bother to talk at all.
Also, kindly give me your word that you
yourself are not a propagandist for either
side.
Those who accuse us of anti-British prop-
aganda are given the same invitation. I'm
very eager to find out whether this magazine
is pro or anti in this question. So far I don't
know.
While we're at it, let's everybody send in
detailed charges as to the magazine's being
pro or anti on all the other foreign nations.
Might put it to a general vote and then
we'll know just which nations we're rooting
for or against. The next step after that is
to get the Secret Service to work finding out
Adventure
just how many millions of dollars are being
paid to subsidize us and then make us stop
taking money from both sides.
• Seriously, I'll venture that an appreciable
percentage of these propaganda-hounds on
various subjects are getting real money for
writing these letters of protest. Still seri-
ously, I'll plead guilty without hesitation
to friendliness toward our Canadian neigh-
bors to the north. If our country and the
British Empire ever do go to war, I--and
this magazine if I'm in charge--will do our
little best against them. I hope there
never is such a war--nor a war between us
and any other nation, and meanwhile I can
see no earthly reason for not being friendly
to the Canadians with whom we've lived in
peace for over a hundred years.
Yes, in the magazine I've stood against
attempts to breed ill feeling between Cana-
dians and us. Why not? You who try to
breed trouble are the ones to justify your-
selves. We're at peace with Canada; why
should any one do other than wish to pre-
serve that peace?
As to the British Empire in general, it's
done a lot of splendid things and a lot of
rotten things, has splendid points and rotten
points. So have most other countries, in-
cluding ourselves. I have no brief for or
against it. Let's judge other nations chiefly
by what they do and are from now on.
As to these people with their heads full of
charges of propaganda against our maga-
zine, they make me sick. If they're such
- good Americans they'd better put in
their time doing things for America instead
of talking against other countries. If
they're not good Americans, they are prop-
agandists for some other country and have
no business talking to Americans at all.
If any misguided fanatics do send in
charges, as facetiously urged above, no such
generalities as "such and-such a story is
anti-this or pro-that" will get any consider-
ation. Get down to cold, hard, detailed
facts or don't talk. If this magazine is being
made the unconscious tool of any propa-
ganda Pll be might glad to learn about it.
If it's the conscious tool, I don't know
about it. If I'm a liar, produce the facts.
INCIDENTALLY, since this friend of
comrade Marino's charges us with
British propaganda, he won't object, not
to charges, but to questions, about himself.
He and his father are 100% Americans.
Was his mother 100% American? Was his
father, mother, or any of his four grand-
parents born Irish? Or German? Or
Austrian? Or what? Is he himself an
Irish sympathizer? German sympathizer?
Or sympathizer with any other foreign
nation? Is he employed in or engaged in

Interested in any other kind of propaganda?
Religion? What service rendered to Ameri-
ca? By his father? By any other relation?

Merely asking for facts. In other words,
'what right has any one to slander and libel

Propaganda--this country is rotten with

zine, but--how much propaganda is being

Here's the letter. Be sure I have no irri-

New York City.
I tried to make a friend of mine interested in your
magazine some time ago, and he told me that, while
your stories may be very good, he never became
a subscriber, because your stories for the greater

I told him I would write you about it and he said

The Lay of the Tropical Tramp
We've tramped 'round the earth from twenty north,
To twenty or more degrees south--
We've lived in the gilded lobster halls,
And we've lived from hand to mouth--,
We've struck old London when flush with coin,
And roamed through New York's streets--
But we've always hit the tropical trail,
When we find our bank rolls cease;
We've drunk all drinks, from Pommery Sec
To pulque and White Label--
We have smoked dried grass and poros vile,
Or perfectos fine, when able--
We've borne mosquitoes, chigoes and fleas,
Screw worms have claimed attention--
Malaria, ague and "Yellow Jack,"
And diseases that need no mention;
But even though we parch and bake,
There's joys to balance the scale--■
A pair of dark eyes at every place,
And good men along the trail;
Men with stories wild and strange,
Yarns that beat creation--
Sweet-scented liars from every clime,
Drifts from every nation;
Tropical tramps, tropical bums,
Tropical sour-doughs all--
We hit the pike on the tropical hike,
And expect to, 'til we fall;
Through chapparal, mesquite, bamboo and palm,
'Til the sunset of life doth fade--
We'll tramp till we're lost, 'neath the Southern
Cross,
And get put to bed with a spade.
HEN Talbot Mundy gets into touch
with his library again maybe we can
get some more dope from him on the Ark of
the Covenant and kindred matters. Mean-
time he gives us some more data and tells
where we can get books of reference. Lots
of you have written him and I know that
he has, so far as able, answered every one
of you--no small piece of work and I don't
know how he gets time for it.
I must begin by apologizing for the delay in an-
swering the scores of fellows who have taken such
a surprising interest in the whereabouts of the Ark
of the Covenant and the whole mystery connected
with it.
Even now I'm writing at a disadvantage, being
three thousand miles or so distant from my library,
which is in storage, so I can't even send a friend
very well to write down the titles and authors'
names of the score or so of books that I have on the
subject.
'T'HE names of three books that I can remember
are "The Coronation Stone," "Judah's Sceptre
and Joseph's Birthright," "The Ten Lost Tribes."
The name of the author of the second one is Bishop
Allen, and < f the third is Willis. But there are a
great many more, and they are all kept in stock by
my young friend A. A. Beauchamp, publisher, 603
Boylston Street, Boston, Mass., who has been young
for half a century or so because he dares do what
delights him. He even runs a magazine on the sub-
ject. I guarantee him to be dead white, and I don't
doubt he will send a list of everything on the subject
that he has for sale if requested to do so. What he
knows about it compared to what I know is as in-
finity to a small dog barking. However, I'll set
down as much as I remember without notes, and
trust any of you who know any more about the
subject to correct misstatements.
HPHE English Coronation Stone in Westminster
Abbey is the stone on which Jacob laid his head
at Bethel, when he had that famous dream, which
some thinkers say explains the whole metaphysical
foundation of the universe, and others say was
probably produced by dope. (Myself, like Disraeli,
am on the side of the angels.)
In that stone there are still the iron rings, which
Moses caused to be fixed in it so that the men who
carried the Ark and the other temple paraphernalia
could pass rods through the rings and handle it
easily. It also has a crack in it, which is asserted,
not plausibly I think, to confirm the story of one of
Moses' miracles.
I believe that the Ark of the Covenant is certainly
in Ireland, and that it will one day be found there, at
or near Mount Tara. I know the name of the man
who brought it, along with Jeremiah and the Ark of
the Covenant and the Princess who was Zedekiah's
oldest daughter, to Ireland by way of Egypt from
Jerusalem, after Jerusalem had been destroyed.
HTHESE arc dangerous days in which to say how
much you believe, and why. It's so easy to be
accused of opinions exactly opposite to your real
ones, and anyhow this seems hardly the right place
for a metaphysical discussion. Science and super-
stition seem to be almost as confused as they ever
were. What you kqow, however, is what you can
prove; neither more nor less. No man's opinion
or say-so is really proof of anything. So in answer-
ing the question as to whether the Ark of the Cov-
enant if rediscovered would kill whoever touched it
I must be understood to be stating my own opinion
and nothing more.
I believe that it did kill any unauthorized person
who touched it "in those days." I believe it would
not kill anybody now, although it could be made to
kill instantly if there were any one around who knew
as much as Moses did, for instance, or as much as
the Israelitish priests knew, who inherited the
knowledge of Moses and gradually let it dwindle
Adventure
into superstition until it finally became mere legend.
I suspect that men like Edison and Tesla (hundreds
of others, too, of course) have approached attain-
ment of a Similar knowledge, although they have
gone about it in a different way.
But I am a heretic. No orthodox person agrees
with me. Turning on the light by pressing a button
looks like a miracle to me. So does an oak growing
out of an acorn. I have never ceased thinking
since a Sikh once asked me "If the Creator is omni-
present, where are you? And if He knows every-
thing, how much do you know?" To my mind
everything is miraculous or nothing is. I really
don't care which end of the stick you hold to hit
back. I know high tension wires will kill if touched,
for I've seen it proved, so I'm able to believe that
the Ark of the Covenant would kill, if touched with-
out gloves and if any one had "turned the juice on."
"THERE is a book in two volumes called "The
Great Initiates," written by a very intelligent
Frenchman and ably translated into English, which
is sold by Brentano of Fifth Avenue, New York,
and throws more light on ancient miracles and the
men who "made" them than anything else I have
found. It is rather an expensive book--six or more
dollars, I think--but an awfully good money's
worth. I brought my copies West with me and lent
them to a Pullman porter, who seems to have con-
sidered them worth "adopting" and who is probably
the high priest of a new religion now.
As difficult a task as any I can think of is to keep
to one phase, angle, issue or point of this prodigious
subject, for it's as big as the Bible, as broad as the
universe. Let's try another look at it:
A JEW is an Israelite, but an Israelite is not neces-
sarily a Jew. Abraham was neither Jew nor
Israelite. The Jews are descendants of the tribe of
Judah, who was Jacob's, that is to say, Israel's,
fourth son. The English-speaking nations, together
with the Scandinavian, Saxon, Bavarian and certain
others are descendants of the other, so-called "lost,"
ten tribes, who were carried away into captivity
about 800 B. C. and settled in a country that came
to be known as Scythia.
Those ten tribes never did get along well v:tli the
Jews or Judah-ites, whom they despised and were
often at war with. The ten tribes included the tribe
of Dan. The tribe of Dan had several character-
istics, one of which was that they were sea-farers,
another that they liked to leave their name wher-
ever they went, and a third that they were rather
more prone to piracy and raiding in general than
even any of the other rascals were who mr.de up that
amazing group of mother-nations descended from
Jacob's sons.
"JpHE tribe of Dan had established colonies in the
Isles of the Seas long before the invasion of
Canaan by the Assyrians. The Isles of the Seas
were Great Britain and Ireland. They are repeat-
edly referred to in Old Testament writings. The
tribe of Dan's "long ships" used to sail there regu-
larly. So did the ships of the Philistines, who
established rival colonies, worshiping Baal and
naming such places as Ballyshannon, which is Baal-
Shannon, after their horrible deity.
Heremon is a Hebrew-root word. The Heremon
who became king of Ireland and married Zedekiah's
daughter, thus providing for the continuance of the
royal line of David in accordance with prophecy,
was undoubtedly either an Israelite or descended
from an Israelite who emigrated in one of those long
ships.
When the Assyrians carried off the ten tribes into
captivity they did not find them so easy to keep as
to capture. They refused to stay put. Their route
across Europe was blazed, and has continued blazed,
by that enterprising tribe of Dan, who left their
tribe name all over the place. There are scores of
instances: The rivers Don (Dan), "D(a)niester,
D(a)neever, Danube--Denmark, which is Dan-
mark or the country of the Danes, or Dans---place-
names such as Danebrog. They are easy to find on
the map. Taken in the aggregate and studied in the
light of the Old Testament, they constitute evidence
which nothing much less turgid than pig-headed
scholasticism can obscure.
THE tribes, of course, intermingled, but certain
of their characteristics have continued in
certain countries, together with the most astonish-
ing coincidences: such, for example,'as the fact that
the arms of the United States are exactly those of the
tribe of Manasseh! England is the tribe of Ephraim.
The arm/of the King of England, who is descended
from King David and who therefore actually is by
heritage a Jew, include the Lion of the Tribe of
Judah and the Harp of David. They say the word
Saxon means Isaacson.
Throughout the Old Testament the prophecy is
made repeatedly that the "throne" shall remain in
Judah--that is to say, in the keeping of the Jews.
It was also prophesied that there should never cease
to be a descendant of David on the throne of David.
That leaves those who take the Bible literally in an
awkward predicament unless they accept the
explanation that the stone under the coronation
chair in Westminster Abbey is the same on which
David was anointed king. It is a fact that in every
generation since any sort of history was written
a king has been crowned on it. It also is a fact that
the kings of England are anointed, although doubt-
le s less oil is used nowadays than formerly.
T3UT hang it, I have only touched on the subject.
If you're interested in the fulfilment of prophecy
there are scores of books, including Redding's "The
Three Churches," which is very scarce, and the same
author's "Mysteries Unveiled."
As I said, Beauchamp conducts a magazine
devoted to that subject exclusively. He calls it
The Watchman of Israel, and the subscription price
is only a dollar a year or so. There are authorities
who link up the Great Pyramid with all this and who
claim to interpret the peculiar pyramid marks as
corroborative of the Old Testament and the "inside"
history of the English-speaking people.
TO WRITE the whole story in one volume would
be a task as great as Wells' history, and at that
would leave the job just plowed up ready for the
next man.
I would like nothing better than to handle it as
fiction and construct a story out of it. But where
should a fellow begin? And how go on? And
where's the end of it? Besides, how many are there
who really care enough for adventure in the realm
of fact to stomach the ancient names and all the
Bible references that would be essential?
To me the Old Testament is a library of gorgeous
The Camp-Fire
entertainment. But I would hate to inflict my
views on it on an Adventure audience without per-
mission. And even if I had permission I rather
doubt that I possess the energy and skill required to
make an entertaining tale of that four-thousand-year-
long and ten-nations Odyssey.--Talbot_Mundy.
