to Port Limon, C. R., about 200 miles west of Colon.
It is hard work to arouse our people to appreciate
the necessity of completing the line to Buenos Aires
and«Rio de Janeiro--east of the Andes, at once, or as
soon as possible to do so.
I WAS much interested in reading Mr. Talbot
Mundy's comment concerning the "Anglo-Saxon
people." He says somewhere about 800 B. C. the
Ten Tribes were carried off into captivity by Tig-
lath-Pileser, king of Assyria, from whence they
migrated northward and spread all over Europe.
Usher's chronology gives this date as 721 B. C. and
II Kings XVII, 6th, says "In the ninth year of
Hoshea the king of Assyria took Samaria arid
carried Israel away into Assyria, and placed them in
Halah and in Babor by the river of Gozan, and in
the cities of the Medes." This was in the region
South of the Caspian Sea and east of the Tigris
River, northeast of Babylon, and northwest of the
Persian Gulf in the land of Cuth or Cuthah. They
were replaced in Samaria by men from Babylon,
Hanath, Sepharraim, Avah and Cuthah. These
places are, in some cases, easily found on the ancient
maps.
The Cuthah were the descendants of Ham,
through Cush, the father of Nimrod the mighty
hunter, the beginning of whose kingdom was
Babel (Babylon) Erech, Aecad and Calneh in the
land of Shinar. At a later date they evidently
migrated through southern Arabia to Africa and
settled in Ethiopia (Abyssinia) along the Red Sea,
on the South of the other Hamite colony of Mizraim
in Egypt. In the reign of David they were known
as Cushites, and "The Cush" was one of the mes-
sengers to the king announcing the death of
Absalom. The meaning of "Cush" is "black" or
"blacka-moor," hence by striking off the prefix
"blacka" we may be able to identify them as the
modern Moors in the land of Morocco, hence it is
easy to believe in the existence of an Israelitish
colony, among others, in the British isles--England,
Scotland, Wales and Ireland, with travel and traffic
communications with Phenicia, Egypt, Philistia and
Israel by sea.
AS TO the captivity of the Ten Tribes, one of the
books of Esdras says they left the land of their
captivity, moving through Arzareth or Ararat'--
(Armenia), through the passes of the mountains
into a land where they were free to worship God,
where they remained in large numbers in Russia
and the Caucasus. As Russia is or was known as
"the land of the north" and "the land of the great
prince," both Jeremiah and Zechariah predict they
are to return to the land of their fathers from "the
land of the north." Daniel 12.1 speaks of "Michael
the great prince," who announced himself as the
friend of the Israelites, and predicts their release,
from captivity at the end of the great tribulation
now prevailing in Russia "the land of the north" and
"the land of the great prince." Under the empire
these people were designated as Israelites and all of
them were registered, or as Daniel 12.1 says, "At
that time thy people shall be delivered (from their
oppressions), every one that shall be found written
in the book."
As to the return of the children of Israel, Hosea
says they shall abide many days without a king and
without a prince and without a sacrifice and without
an image and without an aphod and without
teraphim, and in the latter days shall seek the Lord
their God, and David their king. And they shall be
gathered together, and appoint themselves one head
--for great shall be the day of Jezreel in the valley
of Megiddo--modernized as Armageddon.
In the sixth Chapter the prophet states when the
restoration of Israel is to be, thus, "after two days
will He revive us; in the third day He will raise us
up, and we shall live in His sight." Taking the
Biblical day as a thousand years, this period will
cover three thousand years. These years being
Scriptural, with 360 days to the year, and 3,000
years from some notable event in the history of
Israel, we find according to one chronologer that
David became king of Israel and Judah, as one
kingdom, in 1049 B. C. Deducting 1049 years from
3,000 leaves 1951 (Scriptural) years. Reduce this
to our calendar of 365J4 days per year, we have--
11 months and some days, or, say, about Novem-
ber, 1922, A. D., when Israel will begin as an or-
ganized government.
ANOTHER way to interpret this prophecy is to
consider 2% of the 3,000 years as past from
which deduct 721 B. C. the date of Hoshea's sur-
render, leaves 1945 Scriptural years, reduced as
i8o
Adventure
follows: 1945x360 days=700,200 days -f- 36534=
1917 years--when the work of restoration began,
according to the prophecy of our Savior as to
"the end of the times of the Gentiles"--when on
December 10, 1917, Allenby entered Jerusalem and
put an end to the oppressions of the Turks. "The
times of the Gentiles" were symbolized by the Seven
Times Jacob bowed down before Esau (Gen. 33.3)
a time consisting of the prophetic year of 360 years--•
making 360x7=2520 years these times were to
continue with Israel subject to the Gentiles. They
began about 603 B. C. (our time) or about 610 B. C.
Scriptural time, when the king of Egypt dethroned
the king of Judah and carried him captive to
Egypt and Judah lost its independence, making the
term of "the times of the Gentiles" thus 2520--
603=1917, A. D. This is verified by the 1335 days
(Dan. 12) which are 1335 Mohammedan years.
Reduced to our time, the period is 1295 years, a
month and 24 days. The Mohammedan year 1335
expired October 16, 1917, leaving an overplus of
14 days in November and 10 days in December to
complete the period of "1335 days." The Moham-
medan era began in 622 A. D., to which add 1295
years, one month and 24 days and the resulting
date is December, 10, 1917, A. D. These three
prophecies are especially important, as to the restor-
ation of Israel.
J N "BEN HUR" Lew Wallace refers to the Ark
of the Covenant as being shut up in a cave in
Mount Nebo and the entrance closed so none could
find it. In one of the books of the Maccabees
(apocryphal) the story is told at length, with
Jerenuah informed that the Ark is to remain in its
hiding-place until Israel is restored. I am inclined
to believe Mr. Mundy is in error when he speaks of
the extinction of the male line of David by the
murder of the sons of Zedekiah. David had a num-
ber of sons, other than Solomon, among whom was
Nathan, the next oldest brother to Solomon.
Nathan was not of the reigning line. But his
descendants were of more than passing importance
when Zechariah says (12, 11, 12) "the family of the
house of David shall be set apart and the family of
the house of Nathan shall be set apart." As we
turn to the genealogy of our Savior, as given by
Luke, we find He was of the house of Nathan, the
son of David and jointly through Zorobabel the
Son of Salathiel, of the line of Solomon, as written
by Matthew.
AS FOR the rulers of Great Britain descending
through the marriage of the daughter of Zede-
kiah to King Heremon of Ireland, through the
influence of Jeremiah, tradition says Jeremiah died
in Ireland. But history says he was carried to Egypt
by the Jews, after the destruction of Jerusalem,
where he was put to death. As to the British being
the People of the Covenant, there is good ground
for such a belief in the parable of the wicked hus-
bandmen, when our Savior, as he was teaching in
the temple, said to the Pharisees, the chief priests
and the elders of the people, "The Kingdom of God
shall be taken from you and given to a nation bring-
ing forth the fruits thereof."
HPHE mission of Israel was to lead the world. The
kingdom was given to them to place them above
all the nations of the earth. They rejected it. Ulti-
mately it was given to the British Empire, whose
long career in spreading Christianity and civilization
justifies this belief. It shared this honor with the
United States when our great President uttered the
sublime precept: "the world must be made safe for
democracy" which finally made three empires bite
the dust and pass into oblivion as accursed, while
the devils of imperialism, Caesarism and fanaticism
were driven from the earth by the triumphant hosts
of republican 'liberty.
Israel in its blindness rushed to Calvary and was
ruined. But, in "the regeneration" (Math. 19.28)
so near at hand, this blindness will be removed, and
as a nation it will rise again with a king or prince of
the house of David governing his people while the
Son of man sitting in the throne of his glory at
Jerusalem shall rule the world in liberty, peace and
justice.
"For out of Zion shall come forth the laws and the
word of the Lord from Jerusalem!"--E. F. Test.

captured?
Wilson, Oklahoma.
I have a few pieces of kindling for the old, but
good Camp-Fire. About myself, I am from Louisi-
ana, and the shores of the broad Mississippi River.
The only real adventure I've had was in the jungle
of Panama, the Chepo River in and around Agua
Dulce, R. de P. The greatest adventure I ever had
was drowning in the Panama Canal and being pulled
out by a Mr. Spillman of Cheyenne, Wyoming. My
next trip is Russia or China if my plans work right.
The main idea of this butting into Camp-Fire is
to find out of any of its members can tell me Billy
the Kid's pistol number. I saw a .45 Colt single
action, model 1871 or 1872; the owner claimed that
this gun was owned by Billy The Kid when cap-
tured.---.
rT'HE rope trick. A word from one of our
writers' brigade on this interesting
stunt:
San Francisco.
I've justfinished the June 10th Adventure, which
contains Mr. W. E. Besson's inquiry regardingethe
famous "rope trick" of the Indian jugglers. If a bit
of dope drawn from memory and not capable of sub-
stantiation at this time is admissable, I'll unburden
my chest of the account of my own encounter with
this yarn:
COME ten years ago I got hold of a book of travel
--one of Mayne Reid's, I think--in which was
a description of the trick as follows:
A fakir and a boy appeared in the streets of Cal-
cutta (?) carrying a large covered basket. When a
crowd had gathered, the fakir produced from the
basket a rope and a big knife. The rope he coiled
and heaved upward, and one end went out of sight
and stayed, while he held the "bitter end" in his
hand.
The boy, at a signal from his master, climbed the
rope hand-over-hand and disappeared. A few mo-
ments later the fakir called for the boy to come
down, but received no answer. He called several
times and at last, apparently irritated by the boy's
silence, placed the knife between his teeth and him-
self ascended the rope; disappeared. From above
The Camp-Fire 181
came a blood-curdling yell, then in rapid sequence
the severed arms, legs, head of the boy hurtled to
the ground, followed finally by the hacked trunk.
The fakir descended rapidly, his knife dripping
blood. He gathered together the pieces of the body
and placed them in the basket, covering it again.
After a mumbled incantation he opened the basket
and out stepped the boy, unhurtl
"HAT'S the account I read--and wondered over.
But a little later--in the same year--I came
upon a description of the trick in some magazine.
It purported to be an expose of the trick.
An Englishman, who had heard of the feat, who
was a dabbler in mesmerism and hypnotism, waited
for a fakir to appear. One came and the theater
was a street lined with blank walls--so that none
but the immediate assembly, which was to a man
under the fakir's, influence, might see(?)--and the
Englishman, with a camera, found a hole in the wall
behind the fakir. He took picture after picture and,
when the fakir had finished and gone, questioned
as many of the spectators as possible. Without ex-
ception these described the performance much as it
is described above.. But the pictures, covering
every moment of the performance, revealed only
the crowd gaping fixedly upward, while the fakir
and his boy-assistant stood quietly by the basket on
the ground.
Mesmerism of the spectators en masse was the
explanation advanced by the Englishman. He was
not susceptible to mesmeric influence, he stated, and
so was the only person to witness the performance
who "saw just what he saw" and not what the fakir
made him believe he saw.
T WISH I had the names of the book and maga-
zine from which the above are taken. But
there was no reason at time of reading to think of this
point and I made no notes. But I'd be willing to
take oath that I've given here the essence of the two
accounts; they made a marked impression upon me
and my memory, I'm told, is "inconveniently long."
Whether or not the expose of the trick was au-
thentic, I would like to learn. Perhaps both ac-
counts are mere travelers' tales on a par with Herod-
otus' account of the crocodiles' tears. sQuien sabe?
At any rate, I know that some where in the books is
mention of this particular trick and what I saw
surely others of Camp-Fire saw also. Some of the
experts on mesmerism might also be able to say
whether or not such group-mesmerism is possible.--
Eugene Cunningham.
YOU'LL remember I asked you for
opinions as to the "blurbs" following
titles on our contents pages and in "Trail
Ahead" when we began cutting out even
more of the "ballyhoo" than formerly.
Quite a number of you responded and we
went over the "vote" carefully. The
majority favored having the "blurbs" re-
stricted, as now, to a brief suggestion of
the general nature of the story, but. there
were many opinions, all the way from the
majority opinion to a frank liking for para-
graphs of "ballyhoo'' as to what good and
interesting stories they are. The majority,
too, were for a bit of "ballyhoo" in "Trail
Ahead," through against it on the contents
pages. All in all, we believe we've now got
the form for both places that most of you
prefer. Any time you want it otherwise a
majority of opinion will get what you want.
OUR Camp-Fire stations are spreading
steadily over the map, but plenty of
room exists for more. Help make them grow.
A STATION may be in any shop, horrte or
other reputable place. Tne only require-
ments are that a Station shall display the
regular Station sign, provide a box or drawer
for mail to be called for and preserve the
register book.
No responsibility for mai! is assumed by anybody; the
Station merely uses ordinary care. Entries in register to be
confined to name or serial number, route, destination,
permanent address and such other brief notes or remarks as
desired; each Station can impose its own limit on space to
be used. Registers become permanent property of Station;
signs remain property of this magazine, so that if there is
due cause of complaint from members a Station can be
discontinued by withdrawing sign.
A Station bulletin board is strongly to be recommended
as almost necessary. On it travelers can leave tips as to
conditions of trails, etc., resident members can post their
names and addresses, such hospitality as they care to offer,
calls for any travelers who are familiar with countries these
residents once knew, calls for particular men if they happen
that way, etc., notices or tips about lecal facilities and con-
ditions. Letters to resident members can be posted on this
bulletin-board.
Any one who wishes is a member of Camp-Fire and
therefore entitled to the above Station privileges subject to
the Keeper's discretion. Those offering hospitality of any
kind do so on their own responsibility and at their own risk
and can therefore make any discriminations they see fit.
Traveling members will naturally be expected to remember
that they are merely guests and act accordingly.
Keepers answer letters only if they wish. For local
information write "Ask Adventure." _
A Station may offer only the required register and mail
facilities or enlarge its scope to any degree it pleases. Its
possibilities as headquarters for a local club or resident
Camp-Fire members are excellent.
The only connection between a Station and this magazine
is that stated above, and a Keeper is in no other way re-
sponsible to this magazine nor representative of it.

Two-Bladed Knives
A WICKED addition to anybody's arma-
ment, looks like:
Question:--"I note in 'Ask Adventure' that you
kindly offer to give information in regard to antique
edged weapons, and I am presuming to impose
upon your good nature.
I have a double-bladed weapon which was willed
to me by a friend. I did not know that he owned it,
and I have no idea where he got it.
It is 21 inches long. The blades are 1 inch wide
at the broadest place. Both blades are thin, and
sharp on both edges.
Both sides of both blades are covered with in-
scriptions, which are raised above the surface.
Evidently from the appearance of the metal the
background was etched away.
Adventure
The surface of the steel was rusted when the
weapon came to me, and from its appearance I do
not think it was ever highly polished.
The handle, between the two blades, is of a green-
ish-white bone, the like of which I have never seen
before. It is carefully finished, but not highly
polished. On each side of the handle is engraved
a row of circles, with a dot in the center, about one-
fourth of an inch in diameter.
The sheaths are evidently of rawhide of some
sort, covered with what looks like cheetah skin--
tawny yellow, fur with small black spots. This
fur, though evidently very old and much worn,
has never been attacked by moths.
The blades look very old, and are of primitive
workmanship, though the lette~-ng is bold and
free, and drawn by no uncertain hand. If you will
examine the black-lead tracing which I am enclosing
you will see that the inscription is the repetition of
one word, over and over again. I do not know the
language, though it looks something like Turkish,
or possibly Jagatai, or even Persian.
The surfacing of the blades is much like that of
a Turkish boarding-cutlas now in my possession,
which was presented to my father by Gen. Grant.
I would much like tojknow your opinion on the
nationality of this weapon, and the probable limiting
dates of its manufacture. Also the kind of fighting
it was used in, and against what sort of weapon it
was used in defense.
Ancient weapons interest me much if I know
something of their history and method of use in
offense and defense. Collecting them is a fine avoca-
tion in which, I understand, you are an adept.
I have a straight double-edged sword, on one side
of which is engraved in fifteenth-century Spanish,
"Draw me not without cause," and on the other
side, "Sheath me not without honor." Do you
know if the engraving of mottoes was common on
Spanish arms of that period? Have you ever seen
the above mottoes on a sword-blade, and if so, of
what country and period?
Thank you much for any information you can
give on the above matters.
Drop in and see me whenever you have nothing
better to do. My office is near South Station.
Stamped, self-addressed envelop enclosed."--
Allan V. Garratt, Boston, Mass.
Answer, by Mr. Barker:--As to the double-
bladed weapon you speak of, I think it is in all
probability Persian, and its date may be any time,
probably prior to 1800. As to what kind of fighting
it was used in, that is impossible' for me to say with
any certainty.
Demmin does not mention or give an'illustration
of such a weapon, nor do the illustrations of the
Meyrick Collection contain one. One was sold at
auction in New York in 1914 for $5.75, a sketch of
which I enclose. (No. 1.)
It was there described as a "TWO-BLADED
REVERSE CURVED DAGGER, with bone handle
in center, one side engraved with Hebrew characters,
the other with Arabian, blades curved outward in
opposite directions, each 9 inches long, triangular
in shape, scabbards of leather. Length 23 inches."
Blades and scabbards seem to differ from yours.
The engraving of mottoes was common on Span-
ish arms. I have seen a Spanish officer's saber, the
blade being Solingen, made by Schimelbush &
Foest, on which is engraved in Spanish--
"Draw me not without a Reason, nor Sheath me
with Dishonor."
I am enclosing a sketch (No. 2) of a short, heavy
Spanish sword, bearing date of 1818, on the double-
edged blade of which is, in Spanish--
"Draw me not without reason, nor sheath me
with dishonor."

Just Floatin'
WISH I could slough this magazine
job for six months and go along:
Question:--"I want information on the following
points.
,It is understood that the following questions
apply to boats without propelling force other than
oars or sweeps.
Is the middle of September too late to leave
Pittsburgh and float down to New Orleans?
If so, would it be advisable to start from St.
Louis?
What is the approximate time to float from Pitts-
burgh to Cairo, floating days only?
Same from St. Louis to New Orleans?
Is it safe to float nights, with lights but with no
watch?
Will "current boards" keep a floating boat in the
channel?"--Edward French, M. D., Boston,
Mass.
Answer, by Mr. Spears:--You could leave Pitts-
burgh in September and make the Gulf by tripping
the Ohio, but I'd have my doubts about the Ohio
River without a little power--an outboard motor,
say. There are long pools above the Ohio River
dams, and you'd have to lock through about forty
of the dams, which enable steamers to run in low-
water periods. St. Louis would be better, for then
Ask Adventure
you have the river current all the way down, four
to seven miles an hour.
A day's float would be about forty miles. You
would be able to drop down about four days a week,
on the average, working down comfortably. Say
New Orleans in about seven or eight weeks. You
could jam through in less time. I took all Winter--
seven months--to make this trip down, but I just
sauntered along, went over to St. Francis River
for 250 miles, and down Chaffelli.
I shouldn't advise night floating without a watch.
It is done by old river-men on a falling stage of the
river, which keeps the boat in mid-stream, a rising
stage throwing the boat to the bank. You might
meet a fleet of tow barges and be rolled under them,
which happens. I floated nights when the day-
winds prevailed, but kept watch. It's an eery
experience!
Never heard of any one using current boards, or
sea-anchors, except that in winds, shanty-boaters
in a hurry run into the drift and make fast, and are
towed down. This is dangerous if the driftwood is
swirling and the boat is caught in a squeeze.
I'm enclosing a slip that'll help you a little.
Come again, if I'm needed.
If you don't want an answer enough to
enclose full return postage to carry it,
you don't -want it.
Stock-Raising in Australia
piNE opportunities there still:
Question:--"Having seen your address in "Ask
Adventure" columns of Adventure magazine, as one
who answers queries regarding Australia and its
resources, I am taking the privilege of writing you.
I am interested in the stock industry in Australia.
Have had ten years' experience in ranch life in
North Dakota and Montana, U. S. A. I would like
to get in touch with some of the leading stockmen
of your country. Can furnish reference of any kind
regarding character and ability."--John W. Pat-
terson, Fort Mills, Philippine Islands.
Answer, by Mr. Goldie:--Stock-raising land in
Australia is usually divided into first, second, and
third class grades. As in all other new countries, the
richer soil was the first to be occupied and worked to
advantage. In many districts it proved that only
the first class would pay under the then existing cir-
cumstances; but as conditions impuved, second-
class country became as desirable as the first-class
had'originally been. Then the third-class came into
occupation, and in turn proved profitable because it
was secured at low values and had been brought
within easy communication with markets.
In the most closely settled States, such as Victoria
and Tasmania, the greater extent of the land is held
under freehold, and the newcomer who desires to
secure property will find it best to buy an improved
place, or, better still, to purchase some good grazing-
land which is still subject'to considerable improve-
ment. If he has moderate means, the buyer can
make a fair profit on his capital, while he continues
to increase the value of his holding.
Well-fenced and watered sheep or cattle country,
provided with a homestead, may be bought in these
States at from 4 to 8 pounds per acre according to
its carrying capacity; while properties in first-class
order and capable of grazing two sheep to the acre
cost considerably more. Usually these are compara-
tively small, and. a good deal of cultivation is carried
on by the holders. It is on such places as these,
however, that a skilful stock-breeder may make
money and accumulate property.
Like all good things, the best of the grazing-
estates in Tasmania and Victoria must be paid for,
but once established and with the right class 6f
stock in the paddocks, the enterprising breeder from
the old country soon makes good on his purchase.
What can be accomplished on small sheep-
holdings has been demonstrated by the merino
sheep-breeders of midland Tasmania. Here many
of the old families have carried on flocks of the
finest merino for many years. They raise thousands
of stud sheep and send them to the mainland for sale.
The Tasmanian sheep were introduced into hun-
dreds of the largest flocks in the other States, and
sheep-breeding in Australia owes much to the group
of accomplished breeders in the little island. Flocks
of one thousand to two thousand sheep, kept up to
a high standard, have been sufficient to maintain
their owners in the position of small pastoral kings.
In other parts of the island, splendid herds of cattle
have been reared and maintained on small holdings,
and have kept prosperous families on the land.
In Victoria there is still some leased country, and
there are thousands of acres of grazing-land that
offer opportunities to the buyer who has pastoral
instincts, and prefers stock-keeping to the more
arduous agricultural operations.
North from Victoria, on the Murray River, into
the southern pastoral districts of New South Wales,
a great extent of sheep country stretches away west,
and east into the mountains, which stand back from
the coast. Throughout this wonderful stretch of
pasturage there are great productive grazing-
properties which carry from one sheep to an acre to
three sheep to two acres. The newcomer, in his
search for land, will find large estates varying in
value from 4 to 7 pounds per acre.
Provided that he is in a position to finance the
purchase of land and stock, he can not fail with good
management to make any of these properties pay
very handsomely. There are also chances of secur-
ing land on lease from the Government, and others
of acquiring a partly improved portion of a large
run which is being cut up by the owners or subdi-
vided after resumption by the State.
The stock-breeder from older countries finds con-
ditions in Australia almost completely the reverse
of those to which he has been accustomed. All
animals live in the open air in this wonderful climate
the year round. With the exception of certain stock,
such as special studs, working horses, and perhaps
the "house" cows, all the animals feed solely on the
sweet pastures of the country.
The newcomer wonders at what he considers to be
the insufficient steading about the country homes in
Australia. It is soon explained to him that no build-
ings are needed for housing animals in the Winter,
and this mainly accounts for the difference in the
size of a five-stock establishment in Australia and
one in a cold country.
As a matter of course, the working conditions also
differ to a considerable extent. Much less labor is
required to work the same number of cattle or sheep,
and most of the work is in the open paddocks.
A direct consequence of this is that one man can
Adventure
attend'to a large number of animals. There are
yearly operations, such as lamb-marking and shear-
ing, and cattle-mustering and branding, while in
between, the animals are worked from paddock to
paddock according to the condition of the pas-
tures.
"Fats" come on much more irregularly than in
a country where hand feeding is universal, but stock
fatten very quickly on the rapid flushes of grass and
herbage which come in good seasons. The animals
make amazing progress from birth to maturity,
unless they get a very severe check. The system is
thus almost as simple as that on the cattle ranches
of Texas and the Argentine.
Most stock-owners in Australia stock lightly be-
cause of the variations in the seasons. As a rule,
when the pastures are very good, the broad acres
could carry many more animals than are grazed
upon them, but the long-headed stockmen are
satisfied to keep them in good condition, and con-
serve the grass for recurring periods of dry weather.
On his tours of inspection, which are usually
necessary before he can settle down, the land-seeker
acquires a great deal of knowledge of the country
which is essential to his career as a pastoralist. He
soon learns to distinguish sheep from cattle country,
and picks up many wrinkles on the management of
all classes of stock in Australia. Information on the
value of water conservation is impressed upon him.
Except in Western Australia, where, on extensive
pastoral areas, scrub and small timber are necessary
to augment the carrying capacity of the country, he
sees the advantage gained by killing the exhausting
green timber and cleaning up the surface of the land
as the dry timber falls. The experienced Australian
pastoralist will take him in hand on train and
motorcar journeys, and freely impart to him the
tips he has gained in years of pioneering in the
country.
Having at last made his selection and secured his
property, which may be 2,000 or 10,000 acres in
extent according to his means, his ambitions, and
the class of country he prefers, his first year will be
almost solely devoted to making decisions as to the
best means of working his place and of following such
operations as he can compass. If he has purchased
an improved property he will learn how to use the
paddocks, water supply and other improvements on
the best scheme for keeping his stock in condition.
As a general rule, he will discover that to make the
best of his holding he needs to complete the'improve-
ments.
Starting on an improved place; however, the new
owner has a great advantage in being able to work his
stock to immediate profit. He can devote most of
his time and his resources to the actual management
of his sheep or cattle, and the place begins to produce
for him from the jump.
On the other hand, if he begins on partially im-
proved property, the principal improvement is likely
to be the killing of most of the timber and the erec-
tion of part of a ring fence. He may secure a tank
or a well or two; but on the other hand the place
may at first be-waterless. So the new settler must
hustle into fencing, tank or well sinking, and the
erection of a house and some steading. The princi-
pal advantage he has in this country over the man
who takes up virgin acres is that the native grass
and herbage are well established because the timber
has been killed in part, and these respond to a mod-
erate rainfall with a lively growth of healthy feed.
Therefore the place can be stocked up immedi-
ately, and a'lambing and a clip of wool may be
expected in the first year of occupation.
The operations in making a home, in subdividing
the holding, securing a water supply, breaking up
a paddock with a plow, and raising wheat or oats, or
hay and grain for his horses, establishing a small
herd of milkers for the family supply of milk and
butter, will be simple enough to an experienced
stockman coming from the old country. As the
most urgent jobs are completed, a vegetable garden
and a small orchard are added to the supplying
areas. When the new man in Australia reaches this
stage, he is beginning to settle down to the comfort-
able life of a landed proprietor.
Among the leading stock agents of this country
are: Dalgety & Co., Ltd., Sydney; the Cooperative
Wool and Produce Co., Ltd., Sydney; the New
Zealand Loan and Mercantile Agency Co., Ltd.,
with head offices in New Zealand and branches all
over Australia; Chisholm & Co., Sydney; Cramsey
& Lithbridge, Ltd., Sydney; Hill, Clark & Co.,
Sydney; and Winchcombe Carson, Ltd., Sydney.
There are many others, but if you apply to any of
these firms you will no doubt get all the information
you require regarding your chances in this industry
in Australia.
When you get something for nothing,
don't make the other fellow pay the
postage on it.

ALSO some tips about bear-huhting and
A placer mining:
Question:--"A couple of friends recently asked me
to write you for some information on hunting and
placer mining in western Montana.
I spent a few weeks in the old Virginia Creek
diggings, but know nothing of any place that seemed
to suit them. What they want is to find out best
time for bear and also a good bear country--they
figure on using'a car to within fifty miles of hunting-
ground if possible and pack in from car. Can you
give any information as to such a place and de-
scription of country surrounding?
As to the place: They want to know if you know
of any place in western Montana where the country
hasn't been worked over too much. Enough so they
could work without feeling that older hands had
been in and got disgusted and quit. Any informa-
tion you can give on either subject will be appreci-
ated. If this goes to Adventure don't publish name
or address.
P. S.--Both of these men are able to rough it to
the limit."
Answer, by Mr. Davis:--It's a pretty hard propo-
sition to combine a bear-hunt with a placer-mining
proposition. I am afraid the time is past when the
combination that will be productive of results is to
be found in the State.
The region between Flathead Lake and the
Continental Divide is reported to be a first-class bear
country. A good way to reach it is to go to Ovando
in Powell County, outfit there and hit the trail
northeasterly fifty or sixty-five miles.
Bear are now coming out of Winter quarters.*
•This was written April 14, 1922.
Ask Adventure
How do you contemplate hunting them? Some
trappers use bait and then trap them, others use
dogs to find, them and then take a chance with
a rifle. If you are going to use neither dogs nor
bait the chance of bringing home the bear is consid-
erably reduced. The bear may be around, but you
are just as apt not to run on to them.
If you want the names of reliable guides write
C. A. Jakways, State Fish and Game Warden,
Helena, Montana. Horses can be rented at Ovando.
I don't know of any place in western Montana
where the't placer ground has not been worked over.
I do not believe you will find any such place in the
U. S. You write, "Enough so they could work
without feeling that older hands had been in and
got disgusted and quit." The mere fact that older
hands have worked placer ground does not
necessarily indicate that all the gold has been
taken.
Eight years ago a new hotel was constructed in
Helena on Main Street which occupies the site of
Last Chance Gulch, where the placer miners worked
in the sixties and extracted something like $30,000,-
000. The contractor who excavated for the founda-
tion hauled the ground away, washed it in sluice-
boxes and made a tidy sum of money. It happened
that the old-time placer miners didn't work the
ground thoroughly. There are large areas of so
called placer ground in various parts of western
Montana which contain gold and which according
to report might be profitable if dredged on a large
scale.
Years ago there was placer mining on Nevada
Creek, Powell County, a few miles south of Ovando.
Within recent years there have been some dredge
and hydraulic placer mining done on Cedar Creek,
south of Superior, which is in Sanders' County.
There is also some placer mining at the head of the
St. Joe River in Idaho across the range from Super-
ior. There is conisderable placer mining ground
near Libby, Lincoln County. The most recent
placer proposition of vrhich the writer has heard is
in Park County near the Yellowstone Park.
More about the Napo Country
TT'S on the eastern slope of the Andes in
Ecuador. One thing Mr. Young omitted
to mention in his answer, by the way, is
that this territory, or a good big chunk of it,
is in dispute. Ecuador has it now; but
suppose it is awarded to Colombia or Peru;
then will the settlers' titles be any good?
Question:--"I read with interest a letter of yours
in a recent issue of Adventure, which fell into my
hands in Moji, Japan. In fact my interest was so
great that I wrote at once to the Mr. Felton you
speak of at Napo, Oriente, Ecuador, requesting in-
formation.
I at present hold a master's certificate, tonnage
and oceans unlimited, and stand a small chance of
getting command in the near future.
But the sea game has been getting on my nerves
for the past few years, and I have looked for a chance
to settle down and try to make a stake. If the pros-
spects are as good in Ecuador as they appear I
should like to go.
I have sufficient funds to take me south and to
provide a working capital upon arrival.
I have a fair knowledge of the Spanish language
"as it is spoken," picked up on the coast of Chile.
I seem to be understood.
I have some knowledge of farming, a relic of my
youth before the lure of the bounding main, etc.,
snared me.
Now my question is: What are the prospects
as you see them? If I did go what would I be able
to buy South? What should I carry along? To tell
you the truth what I want is a complete little book of
information if you can write it.
Before I close I would say I am writing for inform-
ation. I do not know if I shall leave the sea; I may
but I am not certain; perhaps if things look good
enough--who knows?
If this letter should be published I would request
that my name and address be withheld."
Answer, by Mr. Young:--I have read your letter
with interest. Quite a number of folks were inter-
ested in that Ecuador country, and I have received
letters from all parts of the U. S. and Canada from
men who wish to try it a whirl. Capt. Helms
(former President of the Ajax Tire Co.) has already
gone, and others have either gone or will go. It looks
as if that counrty will soon be opened up unless
something happens.
The reason the chances have been so good is
the fact that there was a small empire over there
which was given over to primitive nature and a few
red men and a couple of white men. These Indians
are as tame as rabbits, although several hundred
miles due south there are some bad Indians (Jiveros)
who are the other extreme. There is some mighty
fine country over there, and after a man once gets
across the mountains and down them a couple of
days he can sit and float for a matter of six hundred
miles in a canoe at the rate of a hundred miles per
day. What stuff that is taken out of the country
usually goes in this manner, and the Indians pole
and paddle back up in about two weeks.
I have heard that there is a launch line or two
running up as far as Napo from Iquitos now. With
one of these light-draft boats that has the propeller
housed up inside of the boat and draws the water up
by a vacuum created by a stand-pipe from which
the air has been pumped, a man could go right on up
above Napo with a good-sized boat. I think the
name of the company making these boats is the
Shallow Draft Boat Corpn. You can get their name
from the Board of Trade of the U. S., at Washington,
D. C. They make a canal-boat that only draws
eight inches of water, and at the Motor Show they
had a small launch running on a half-inch of water.
Two of their boats have been shipped to Brazil for
use on shallow rivers. The Napo and Cururay are
big rivers after you get down them for a day or two,
but are not very large above Napo and a similar
height on the Cururay.
I don't know what effect it will have on the
Indian labor if a number of Americans should go
down there and make the demand more than the
supply. These Indians come in from the forest and
take up with white men and hang around for their
board and a tot of rum once a day. Darned queer
place over there, and darned queer people. Hu-
mility is a part of their custom, and they ask to be
whipped once a year with a switch for some wrong
they have committed. Civilization may spoil them
as it does every one else.
The average planter over there feels as if he isn't
Adventure
doing much unless he has a few score of them around
him. For my part I would be satisfied with a less
number and a few modern machines and a hydro-
electric plant in one of the streams.
There isn't much to tell about the country. You
go to Guayaquil and then to Quito over the G. & Q.
R. R. and ride a mule one day to Papallacta. From
there she is shanks' mare stuff for about fifty-six
miles; but she is a-winder of a trail and will take
you four or five days to make it. The Indians travel
slow and pack about a hundred pounds all the way
for $2.50 and board themselves.
Their women follow them for the first day and
carry their coca (grub) for them.
After you get to the top of the mountain at Bajeza
she's down-hill in a gradual slope for six hundred
miles, and where the Napo enters the Amazon it is
only about nine hundred feet above sea-level.
She's barren at the top, and going down vegetation
gets thicker and thicker until she is typical tropical
jungle plus in the lowlands.
They don't have any Winter, only rain, and I'm
here to tell the world that I prefer a tropical rainy
season to one of these New York Winters with the
temperature changing every day. The worst thing
about trying to go over there during the rainy sea-
son is that the trail is bad and the Indians don't like
to pack over it; but they do pack the mail at all
seasons.
Near Napo there is an American; and down the
river there are a Frenchman and a few white Span-
ish settlers. Up to the present they have had this
vast country to themselves.
'The G. & Q. R. R. is figuring onjjbuilding a railroad
over there from Riobamba, and if Capt. Helms has
his way he will put a trolley line across the mount-
ains for them. I had lunch with him before he left,
and he sure felt the call of the primitive. He had on
a diamond ring with a stone in it the size of a
cherry; but he was longing for overalls and a month's
growth of beard on his face. If you do go down
there and run across him tell him "how" for me.
Fishing: Stocked Ponds
THE more you preserve fish in order to
angle for 'em, the wiser they get.
Brother Thompson has doped out a way to
fool Old Dame Instinct, but my guess is that
the dodge won't work more than a few years
in any one pond;
Question:--"Would like to have your advice on
the best method and kind of baits to use for catching
old stock of bass in small lake or pond. These
ponds were stocked say twelve or fifteen years ago
with bass. For a few seasons they were very easy
to catch; but for the last four or five years they have
been refusing to strike at either live bait or artificial
bait of almost every variety.
These fish can be seen late of an afternoon close
in to the shore but can not be persuaded to strike
at any lure."--, Walton, Ky.
Answer, by Mr. Thompson:--I have had the same
experience as you with stocked ponds, but finally
got bass striking. As fish grow up in a pond I
am sure they feel the vibration from a man's move-
ments on shore; also the small fish that feed in
shoal water scare quickly at the presence of man
and somehow or other transmit this to the other
fish by their actions of getting into deep water.
I have studied this subject a great deal, and finally
began wading. I got to where I wanted to cast,
and after getting in the water never made any
movement whatever for a long time. I am sure
fish do not see you when you are waist deep in water
as they do when you are on shore. I used the light-
est artificial lures with the grooved heads that I
could get. They went deep on fast reeling and
brought out many a big fellow.
When using a fly rod often I had good results
from a bucktail and an 0 spinner, the smallest size.
I used many times with success the little fly-rod
wooden plugs, and one of the best methods is to
attach a dropper fly as usual and carry along the
little plug as trailer. This looks like a minnow
chasing a fly, and very few bass can resist it. Many
ponds like yours are fine for late evening and night
fishing. The best killers are bass bugs with fly
rod, and any surface minnow. With it reel slowly,
and you will have a fine thrill when they strike.

Fancy and Fact in Polynesia
THEY'RE far apart when a man is with-
out capital, especially when he's get-
ting along in years:
Question:--"I am a workingman and filled up and
a little tired (I'm 50 years old) of this eternal work,
work, and slavery, that seems to be the result of
civilization. I want to begin a new life, live every-
thing and go where a man may get a living and does
not have to worry for tomorrow all the time.
South Sea Islands are the subjects of these questions.
Do you believe that there is a chance for a man
that worked from South America to Alaska for his
living, to make it there as a native?
Can a man get land there enough to live on?
I do not want a plantation; it would mean grinding
again.
What group of islands would you advise me to go
to to take a look for that home?
Where can I get maps and literature on the South
Sea Islands?
How much capital would you think is needed to
get a start to live as a native, not as a capitalist?"--
Gus Hamil, Ketchikan, Alaska.
Answer, by Mr. Charles Brown, Jr.:--You are
a workingman, you say. You are fed up with the
year-long grind and anxiety of modem civilization.
Your only escape lies in spreading sail for the warm,
blue waters of Polynesia, you believe.
You see an island valley with a little grass house
hidden away in the green depths of the jungle. All
about it are fruits and vegetables and flowers. And
at the foot of the valley is a lagoon, sparkling
through long hours of sun. Always it will yield you
the choicest sea-foods. Never, never will it fail.
Far up in the cool of the valley run wild chickens
and hogs and goats and cattle--yours, all yours, for
the killing! You have but to call the happy, laughing
islanders,_and they lead you to the hunt. At dusk
Ask Adventure v
you return heavily laden, to partake of the
kill.
Then comes the moonlight, orange-colored and
all-pervading. And with it the laughter and the
singing of pretty, brown island girls, so that you for-
get almost entirely the loneliness and desolation of
the bleak land in which you were a prisoner of cir-
cumstances.
Such is the picture your unhappy mind has
painted. But, oh, my fellow creature, out on the
beaches of Polynesia life can be as cruel as a prohi-
bition officer, especially to the man who, in the
twilight of his years, wants to turn native.
Now mark. When a happy, reckless South Sea
vagabond, holding my own on breadfruit and fish
and sleeping out on the decks of becalmed island
schooners, I met up with all manner of beach-comb-
ers, men that had tired of civilization in much the
same manner as you have done. This legion is
knocking about with but one regret. Ever they
curse the hour they turned their backs on the- home
of their fathers for an uncertain struggle under the
Southern Cross. And always they whispered to me
their one hope, spoke of the day when they would
drift back to the lands so far above the line. Oh,
my friend, the stories I could write of these "breth-
ren of the beach!"'
I do not want you to become one of that legion.
Nor do I want to think of your plunging lower than
a native. You must understand that to a native a
beach-comber or white man that has gone native is
less than the coral over which the island dogs run.
Can you get enough land to five on? Yes, if you
have money--several hundred dollars. For in those
island valleys cash has now become a medium of
exchange, even amongst the "hospitable" natives.
"How much capital would you think is needed
to get a start to live as a native, not as a capitalist?"
Why, when a man "goes native," he does so because
his purse is nothing more than a rag. If he had
"capital," he would never turn to that life. Only
when his resources fail, when he can not again get on
his two feet, does he accept from the natives what-
ever they see fit to throw to him. Indeed, I have
stripped the South Sea of its glamour. I'm cruel,
am I not?
The enclosed form, "Cash Needed by All Guests
on Tahiti Island," tells more about the thing I am
driving at.
Frederick O'Brien has written two very readable
books on French Oceania. "White Shadows in the
South Seas" and "Mystic Isles of the South Seas"
are published by the Century Company, New York
City.
I wish from all my heart I could mail you a differ-
ent sort of a reply. But, you can readily under-
stand, one reason I conduct this section is to
prevent men, especially men who have crossed the
shadow line, from becoming one of that homeless
legion.

Deux Rivieres
JT'S hunting-country:
Question:--"I beg to ask information as to the
country and kind of game found in the locality of
De Riviere. Also give me your opinion of a .35
Remington rifle, pump or automatic, for moose
and red deer. Can this be beaten for above
game?"--Guy U. Blackall, Blyth, Ont., Can.
Answer, by Mr. Moore:--Deux Rivi&res (Two
Rivers), eighteen miles or so east by south of Mat-
towa, on the main line of the C. P. R. and north of
the C. N. R., is a very good locality for red deer and
moose, although from its close proximity to Pem-
broke and countryside it is bound to be pretty well
hunted. However, as this section lies north of
Algonquin Park, and the park serves as a feedei
of game for all the country that surrounds it, the
Deux Rivieres part will always have a fair share of
game.
A better moose country is across the Ottawa
from Deux Rivieres and north to Lake Kippewa.
The country is rough, rocky, hilly, with many Little
swamps, lakes, etc. There is considerable timber in
there, and lumbering has been going for many
years. Other game such as fox, wolves, bear, etc.,
are there but rapidly decreasing in numbers.
As regards the .35 caliber Remington rifle for deer
and moose: I have never used a .35, but I notice
the editor of "Guns and Ammunition" in Rod and
Gun in Canada has this to say about a good moose
rifle: "I would suggest the .303 British, the .30-
1906 Winchester or Remington, the .35 Remington
Automatic, or the .33 model 1886 Winchester for
moose." In the same magazine Adam Moore,
a New Brunswick guide of twenty-five years' stand-
ing, has a word in praise of the .35 caliber for "the
big fellows." Whether the .35 can be beaten or
not, is not for me to say. I know men who have
shot and killed moose with the .22 hi-power, the .303
Ross sporting, and they will swear by their favorites.
As regards a good deer rifle my favorite is a .303
caliber. I've seen great work done with Ross and
Savage.
Hoping I have given you the information you
seek, I will be pleased to hear from you at any time,
and if I can do anything for you, I will only be glad.
Free service (except our assaying and
oil services) but zve don 't pay the postage

Other Waterproofing Recipes
'y'WO of 'em; both simple enough, too:
Question:--"I take your name from Adventure as
being the person to whom to write with reference to
camping, etc. I would appreciate it if you would
send me a good recipe for waterproofing a tent."--
C. Sulling, New York City.
Answer, by Dr. Hathome:--There are various
methods for waterproofing tents. One of the best is
a preparation consisting of sugar of lead and alum,
equal parts, say about a pound of each to a gallon
or more of tepid water. When dissolved put tent in
soak in the solution, and when thoroughly saturated,
hang up and dry. This will make a tent fairly water-
proof, mildew-proof and to a certain extent fireproof.
Another way is to dissolve paraffin in gasoline,
out of doors, then paint the preparation on the can-
vas. This will make a tent waterproof, but is not so
easily applied, and a tent is more likely'to catch fire
from sparks from a camp-fire.

Edgett's Landing, Albert County,

Am sending you an old song which may be called

composed about the time of happening (1791), as
my father learned it in the year 1813, when he went
to New York, a lad of seventeen. He used to sing

Off with your hats, every mother's son of ye, to
the oldest and liveliest member of the Camp-Fire!
Does she belong? Well--I guess yes. Here's the
poem:
The Bold Nor'westmen
Come, all ye bold Nor'westmen who plow the rag-
ing main---
Attend unto this tragedy while I relate the same;
'Tis of the Lady Wellington, at anchor where she lay
Off Queen Charlotte's Island northwest of
Amerikay.
It was in the year one thousand seven hundred and
ninety-one
Great numbers of wild savages on board of our
ship did come,
And for to buy their furs of them our captain did
begin,
But mark what followed after, before long time
had been:
'Twas aft upon our quarter deck two arms-chests
there did stand.
The keys had been left in them by our gunner's
careless hand.
Those savages they seized them and of them made a
prize.
Oh, Lord! We had no other arms for to defend
our lives.
'Twas aft upon our quarter deck our captain he did
stand
With twenty of those wild savages, their naked
knives in hand;
Twenty of those wild savages, their naked knives
they drew:
If he should flinch or budge an inch, ready to run
him through.
Our captain, then perceiving this, he unto them did
say--
"If you give back my keys again, great sums to
you I'll pay."-. 1
Men Have Sung
But the savages, not fearing him, they all drew
forth their knives,
Saying: "The ship, she's ours now! And you
shall lose your lives."
Our captain, then perceiving this--the ship no
longer ours--
He called unto his sailors bold, likewise his
officers:
"Go down into my cabin, boys, some firearms you'll
find there.
See that they are well loaded; mind that they
don't miss fire."
Then down into his cabin we quickly did repair--
But to our sad misfortune no firearms we found
there
Except a brace of pistols, two guns and one broad-
sword--
Then instantly we did agree: "Blow her up," it
was the word.
Then to acquaint our captain we quickly did repair
And instantly he did agree: "Blow her up into
the air."
Our powder was got ready, our gun-rooms opened
wide,
Our souls committed to the Lord, our bodies to
the tide.
Those savages perceiving this, they in our cabins
rushed--
Our captain cried out, "Follow them," and after
them we pushed.
Ninety of these wild savages we killed upon the
floor;
As many more we wounded, and the rest jumped
overboard.
Early on the next morning, just by the break of day,
Our captain called all hands on deck, our anchor
for to weigh.
With our cannon and small arms we on their town
did play,
Till they brought back those keys again which
they had stole away.
Now come, all you bold Nor'westmen who plow the
raging main--
Come listen to my tragedy while I conclude the
same;
Beware of all wild savages, of them you'll find no
end.
And they will strive to take your life when you
have been their friend.
